cons: Stressful, fast paced. Work life balance is decent, but only if you use it. Annual performance cycle has gotten better, but still enforcing some level of forced performance distribution.

pros: For someone just starting out this place offers a lot of good experience in learning to deal with other people and how businesses works. You are also offered great pay and really good benefits!
cons: Many people at the company have been working there  for long time (+15 plus years) and some of them are kind of stuck in the past....At first I thought it was just my team but when asked other people in my departmart that were similar in age they mentioned having the same problem....The company is also really stingy when it comes to spending money on “cost” departments.

review_title: Good work culture; too much reorg
pros: A comfortable place to work. Extremely good work culture, helpful and knowledgeable people. Fame of this company really shines on your CV and helps in grabbing other opportunities. Such a wide portfolio of products creates a lot of different jobs in multiple domains. This can be utilized in exploring the interests
cons: A lot of reorg keeps happening and if you are unlucky enough to be in an afected team then it can put the team in a directionless scenario. Projects keep on getting scraped and you might not be able to get silicon learning. It might feel that all the effort went to trash.

review_title: Great place to work if you love to work hard
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good benefits and work environment. Little perks everywhere. Kids to work day. Lots of learning opportunity
cons: Extremely demanding and you have to be ready to give 150% of your time to keep your job sustainable. Some nepotism  and bias is always in the back ground everywhere.

pros: Exceptionally smart hardworking individuals and teams. Open and direct culture with a desire to execute.  Excellent product development / process to go to market. Exceptional integrity and ethics in business practices.
cons: Growth paths stagnate after 2-4 years in any given role. Requires employees to keep their heads up for next role and position accordingly. Under market pay and time requirements vs. unspoken expectations. Lots of managing up.

pros: great benefits, work life balance is pretty good depending on where you work.  Challenging work environment. can be a place you can work your whole career. rewards top performers with fair compensation
cons: too often there is a buzz word(s) that only stick for about 6 months.   Almost like a word of the day.  bureaucracy, too big. Not very nimble when you need to get work done.  You almost have to go ask 5 people to get something green lit.

job_title: Web Development Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros:
The benefits package is outstanding, job security is pretty good.  Also if you really wanted to, you could work there for years without ever actually having to produce a single thing of worth to the company or your co-workers.

Also, there are some really great communication channels at Intel, although one must wade through quite a bit of bias to get to the real news.  I never saw more corporate Kool-Aid drinkers than at Intel.    At one point I was receiving 20+ "newsletters" per month from various corporate groups, and published two myself.
cons:
Raises aren't great.  Also, upper-level managers can make capriciously stupid decisions.  Sometimes these changes will stick, while other times, they are quietly ignored.  There was never any rhyme or reason to which decisions your manager decided must be enforced, and which ones could be ignored.

I even saw this inconsistency happen at the employee level.  One great example was when my division (which supported construction groups all over the planet) suddenly had telecommuting banned for all employees.  Within a month or two all of the women in my group somehow miraculously got "exceptions" to the telecommuting ban, while the two men in my group (myself included) did not.

Also, Intel is largely run by folks in their mid 50's.  Although the internal groupings of the company seem to be in a constant state of flux, the true corporate management structure changes little, with the same small group of people holding relatively identical positions of power regardless of their changes in job title.  There is no true hope of advancement in one's career for anyone younger than 45.

pros: Unbelievably deep talent pool, some incredible managers at all levels, results orientation.  Compensation is competitive, especially if performance-based compensation is included.  Opprtunity for international assignments.
cons: Company's pretty big.  Upward mobility very limited.  In many groups, significant personal sacrifice part of the job description.   As a senior manager, to survive I spent far too much time polishing presentations (mine or my group's) and too little developing the organization or learning the technology.

pros: Compensation, benefits, and many opportunities to improve your leadership and technical skills through training and mentoring.
cons: Management and bureaucracy. To many levels of management and decisions take to long to be made. Employees tend to move up early in their career to a certain level but then mangement begins to restrict the movement/promotions not sure if it's because they don't want to pay the higher salary associated with the movement or they don't want so many people at a certain grade level.

review_title: Better Than Most, but Don't Expect a Life Outside Work
pros:
Salary and bonuses may be 20-30% lower than comparable companies, but the job stability is unmatched as long as you work on the bread and butter microprocessors.  Most of my friends who've left have lost their higher paying positions at other corporations after a couple of years.  

That said, the work is challenging (at least in my area) and rewarding in a karma sort of way since you realize that many people around the world will use what you work on.  The people are all very bright, and I mostly enjoy working with my team a lot.  Things get DONE at Intel and done on time (mostly), because when they aren't, the world notices.
cons:
Work / life balance depends totally on what group you work in.  Some groups are very liberal (Marketing, etc), but many groups are run by old timers who absolutely do not believe in ever 'working from home', and in some cases even closely track who gets to work at 8am and who doesn't.  Corporate is absolutely WORTHLESS in standardizing this and gives lip service to 'employee work/life balance' that means NOTHING.  In anycase, expect to work 50 hours a week at MINIMUM.

The ranking and rating/focal process is horrific and brutal.  It takes up about 4 months a year when you include normal focal and mid-year focal and the results don't justify it.  It DOES make the place a dog-eat-dog killer of a place to work, where you are never really sure you will not get rated low unless you are doing your best, but the paranoia it inspires and the pain is unneeded and unnecessary.  

Upper management is very, very smart, and I am impressed by their ethics.  However, they are ruthlessly brutal and some of them will not hesitate to blackball you or run you out of the company if you cross them or fail to kowtow.

Biggest downside for the average employee is that Intel, despite being a 'high tech' company gives it's employees absolutely CRAP computers to work on.  4 or 5 year old laptops are the norm unless you are doing silicon design or something that requires something newer.  When my monitor died a year ago I was given a new CRT monitor that I later found on Newegg for $60 and that I wouldn't have bought  even for use at my house, and which of course died after only a few months.  This sort of pennywise, poundfoolish idiocy abounds, except in the silicon fabs, where spending $100M on a new stepper is considered just the cost of doing business (which it is, but come on, so are decent computers for the engineers).

Another downside is that despite being insanely profitable constantly, management constantly looks for more ways to keep this money from the rank and file.  Profit sharing used to be 12.5% of salary when I started, then it went to 8%, now is at 7% and they are clearly positioning it to go even lower.  Health benefits are similarly being reduced.

Last but not least there has been a strong 'diversity' push in the last few years, which would normally be great, but which has resulted in significant bias during focal and hiring AGAINST people who are not 'diverse'.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: Interesting technology.  Access to very high level engineers even as an entry level financial analyst.  Surrounded by some very smart people.  Looks good on your resume.
cons: They tout work life balance, but good luck finding it in your 70hr work week.  As a financial analyst you have very poor support systems and are dependent on volumes of excel spreadsheets to find historical data.  This is a very poor culture for most women.  Intense would be an understatement.  If you enjoy being yelled at for even very trivial things then you might enjoy working here.

review_title: Good place when legends ran it but so so today
Not a great place to be a contractor.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tampa, FL
pros: They are working on cutting edge technology.  There are lots of smart people working hard.  They've got a good cafeteria.
cons: As a contractor, I felt excluded and not part of a team.  You were a different colored badge depending on your status and certain privileges are only for certain kinds of employees.  The group did not treat me like a member of the team, although they were cordial and helpful.  It's a really long commute thru bad traffic with no convenient public transportation option (from SW Portland).  The cubes are tiny.

review_title: Good company aiming to be better.  New emphasis on the people and their families.
job_title: Senior Server Architect in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Compensation among the best in the industry.  Highly innovative company investing in future Research and Development.  Great leadership and moves fast.
cons: Vacation time is lower than industry average, but tries to make up for it with an extended emplyee sabatical every 7 years.  Highly competitive environment, which can lead to information & recognition hoarding by some employees.

review_title: Pay is below market, expectations are high, Managers are painfully susceptible to brown nosing
job_title: Equipment Maintenance Technician in Charlotte, NC
pros: The best reason I can think of to work at Intel is that if you are a technically proficient person, you can grow your skills because of the resources available to you.  You are exposed to cutting edge technologies that you would not see in many other organizations.  If you are lucky enough to find yourself in a good department where teamwork and co-operation are encouraged, then you can thrive.
cons:
Intel always pays below the market average.  Benefits are good.  However, the senior management's inability to stay ahead of the curve in the mobility market has led to a stagnation of the stock price which is a big part of the compensation package.  

Employees are rated on a bell curve system called ranking and rating.  This means someone is always left holding the hot potato.  Instead of motivating employees to do better this has led to a back biting environment where the deceitful employees often are rewarded.  Those employees who can do "do".  Those who can't will lie.  Unfortunately the management structure at Intel requires even 1st level supervisors to be in meetings and to crunch numbers most of the time and this creates a disconnect between the workers and  those who should observing them closely.  The solution is for the workers to submit a "weekly" report of their activities.  This is where the deceit comes in.  Under-achieving workers simply fluff their report or outright lie about their activities.  They are often rewarded simply because they focus most of their efforts on producing weeklys that make them look good.

review_title: Awesome .. Look forward to work again there
pros: IMC is one of the best pay masters in Bangalore with lots of additional benefits/perks. The kind of work that you will get here is much superior than what normally you get in chipset domain with service companies in India. Every single person counts in this company and you would not be treated like computer, chair, etc or I mean to say just as a resource. Overall I would recommend this company strongly.
cons: Some policies are still not so clear as the company was Infineon originally and now after Intel take over, things are in transition mode yet.

pros: Is a great please to work whit Benefits, compensations, careers, Integration and Training. Flexible work schedule, networking with Intel Managers and Executives, and social events organized through the RCGnet community group.
cons: It is well worth the employee with the innovations, ideas, but the company are those who do make money. All that work that is not within the main objective and that in the end it leads to better profits to the company.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
You are working for a winning company.  A company that both is the leader in what it does, and does it well.   They are also a very charitable company, and for the most part (MOST part) treat their employees well.  Salary is good, benefits are VERY good.  Our campus had a nice commissary (though I think they will slowly kill all the employees with the giant portion sizes)  and you rarely wanted to go out to lunch.  

If you are in the right job, it's a GREAT job.  If you have an opportunity to look here, you SHOULD look into it.

I do honestly got the feeling the company actually CARED about us.. well not on an individual basis... that would be ridiculous... but as a collective.   I really cannot say that about many companies, and if it weren't for the downsides of my job, it would have pained me to leave.
cons:
Cons are always wordier:  human nature.

There were many cons for me, and unfortunately they eventually outweighed the pros.  Again, if you are looking for a job at Intel, I wouldn't discourage you from looking.  Just be aware when you get there it has the same kinds of problems ALL big companies have.  One in particular stands out:  Meetings, meetings, meetings and more meetings.  And usually meetings that waste a lot of time; the culture has a greater emphasis on social correctness and five minutes of "chit-chat" than it does work, and I do have an issue with that.  Particularly when you spend a good hour on a meeting that can get done in 20 minutes.  

I also worked some ungodly hours on some issues for customers who decided a month or two later "Oh, you fixed that?  It really wasn't that important."  And unless you are a social butterfly (I'm not) finding a new job isn't that easy.  

I think your job at Intel is going to only be as successful as your team's collective desire and ability to win.  People are generally risk-averse and like job security.  It pained me to watch the young interns sitting next to me love their jobs and do so well on their team, while mine settled for mediocrity and my own mind started to stagnate because it was being stressed without being appropriately challenged.   I worked with good people who were discouraged and felt powerless, and I was turning into one of them. Once I recognized this, I waited for the right opportunity to leave and did so.

Your manager can change in the blink of an eye.  This can be useful, but it's not great for relationship-building/team-building.

Not everyone is always promoted from within.  Managers are more concerned with how they look when promoting someone, as opposed to promoting the people who can do the job.  

But in the end... it's the stress of the job that'll do you in, combined with the ridiculous rating system.   It's too easy to get a "Meets Expectations" regardless of whether you are working your tail off and achieving, or slacking because you've been there too long and are burned out, and need a BETTER challenge.

review_title: Excellent employer, the most professional team and culture
pros: The most professional team with excellent results and customer orientation. The best place to perform and grow - company provides a lot of opportunities and really care about the ees. Vast geographic provides great opportunity to work in different areas in multiculteral envoroment.
cons: Not always possible to build your career path in case you woud like to move into managment space. Although company does a lot but the opportunities are still limited.

review_title: Great company in terms of compensation through the T-COMP program.
job_title: Silicon Validation Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Intel is a bell-weather company, and a stable company to work for. With over 100,000 employees you are guaranteed to be working on cutting edge computer projects ranging from smart-phones to tablets to client processors all the way up to server processors, and you are guaranteed to meet some really smart people along the way making sure you're not going at it alone.

Due to the size of Intel, they are really able to provide stellar benefits, such as a heavily subsidized health insurance program. 401k & Roth 401k options. Profit sharing, 2 types of bonuses.

Career options are plentiful, and many people are able to stay at Intel doing many jobs over their career in different groups while moving horizontally or vertically. There's a technical track as well as a managerial track.

Tuition assistance for getting an advanced engineering degree or MBA.

6 week paid sabbatical after 7 years of tenure.
Great Place To Work program has tickets to a lot of events for free or at a deeply discounted cost. Great for a night out with your friends and family.
Passport Dining discounts.
cons:
The company may be too large for some. I found myself lost in the sheer amount of teams and people. It seemed whenever I wanted to get something done, I would have to talk to at least 2-3 people to get the go-ahead.

The scope of your position will be narrow. I found myself pigeon-holed into the position I was hired for (I love doing it but didn't get to branch out). I tried to step out of my narrow field of work a few times to explore my passions, but found that other's felt that I was stepping on their toes and did not appreciate the help I was providing.

I also found the office politics too much for my liking.

review_title: Great company in terms of compensation through the T-COMP program.
job_title: Silicon Validation Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Intel is a bell-weather company, and a stable company to work for. With over 100,000 employees you are guaranteed to be working on cutting edge computer projects ranging from smart-phones to tablets to client processors all the way up to server processors, and you are guaranteed to meet some really smart people along the way making sure you're not going at it alone.

Due to the size of Intel, they are really able to provide stellar benefits, such as a heavily subsidized health insurance program. 401k & Roth 401k options. Profit sharing, 2 types of bonuses.

Career options are plentiful, and many people are able to stay at Intel doing many jobs over their career in different groups while moving horizontally or vertically. There's a technical track as well as a managerial track.

Tuition assistance for getting an advanced engineering degree or MBA.

6 week paid sabbatical after 7 years of tenure.

Passport Dining discounts.

The company may be too large for some. I found myself lost in the sheer amount of teams and people. It seemed whenever I wanted to get something done, I would have to talk to at least 2-3 people to get the go-ahead.

I tried to step out of my narrow field of work a few times to explore my passions, but found that other's felt that I was stepping on their toes and did not appreciate the help I was providing.

I also found the office politics too much for my liking.

review_title: A tech hobbyist's wet dream, but red tape and top-heaviness weighing on morale.
pros:
- Intel takes care of its employees and has unmatched integrity and ethics in Silicon Valley. Genuine belief in doing the "right thing."
- Work/life balance and flexibility. Not uncommon for folks to dash out midday for an errand, to take care of kids, etc. People work hard, but most managers supportive of choice of when work is done.
- Truly cutting edge technology; company makes a difference in lives around the world with the advancement of Moore's Law (unlike, let's face it, social media companies)
- Excellent health benefits, sabbatical every 7 years
- Smart, humble, and ethical colleagues. They're the #1 reason why I'm still here, as others have said.
cons:
- Salary increases have been modest to immaterial last few years
- Way too many managers doing nothing but sending e-mails and having meetings and getting nothing of substance done vs. actually managing, coaching, and prioritizing work for their employees.
- Decision-making is bogged down by endless reviews and infinite matrices of stakeholders who "need to be aligned"
- Culture of entitlement and laziness from employees from the glory PC years of the 1990's who are fat and happy and not motivated to truly tackle the complexities of the world today
- In finance, way too many employees fighting for too little work, slowing everyone down and creating a culture of territorialism and little fiefdoms

review_title: Reasonable company , Tremendous Dirty politics , Organization lacks vision , US drives everything
pros:
* India Organization policies are reasonable , Offers free transport and standard medical plans
* Work life balance is reasonable
* Salary was better than market and services companies until some time back
cons:
* This is NOT a place for senior technical leaders to grow their career 
* The company as a whole is bleeding money in Mobile and tablet area and is so far unable to make a dent
* The India organization lays off people in hundreds from at regular intervals , however the media does not report it
* Ethics is championed in the media, however senior management does not treat junior leaders ethically
* Severance packages have been reduced lately and are nowhere close to generous
* Everything depends on US management and what they feel and think abut you, Your work rarely counts
* Organizations are  extremely political with mostly dirty politics at senior levels
* Little real work happens at senior management levels in US and India and its all about who is whose good books 
* India management and HR have little to no say in any area. Everything is run from US geo.India HR is virtually non existent and does not protect the org. 
* Technical growth is limited as scope is defined within what the organization wants to do
* Zero to very little onsite openings
* Senior leadership and decision making Roles are created in US geo's ONLY as strategy is to make India in a flat back office like delivery center staffed with junior people
* Person risks unemployability in the market if he remains in this Org for too long as skill erosion happens due to little work and more politics
* Night calls almost everyday with people in PST(California) timezone

review_title: Good benefits but you'll probably worked to the bone for them
pros:
Great vacation compared to most other companies -- for salaried employees: 3 weeks off + 10 paid holidays per year to start, 4 weeks vacation per year after 10 years of service. 

Sabbatical is great and is in addition to regular vacation time: a 4 week vacation every 4 yrs of service or an 8 week vacation every 7 years. (have to be taken all at once)

Good heatlhcare benefits.

Continuous improvement efforts are generally very encouraged; I've never heard "no, we've always done it that way" or "don't rock the boat" in terms of changing business processes.

Managers are generally understanding when it comes to family/personal/medical situations that require a skewed schedule or telecommuting if it's for a brief amount of time.

Some recent changes to the office environment have been good - updated interior design & color pallette.
cons:
Management can be kind of a top-down dictatorship, at least in the manufacturing division.  

Telecommuting for the sake of telecommuting (general work/life balance) is not permitted in TMG. You can only telecommute in cases like a sick child, plumber coming out to the house, brief personal medical situation or illness, etc. Some TMG groups that are more distant from the manufacturing line still allow the old policy of one telecommute day per week (in violation of the policy), so you may have it better if you're in one of those. The current policy is probably better than some other companies, but Intel TMG's ban on telecommute is recent (within the past few years) and it a step backwards compared to other forward-thinking companies that are embracing employee flexibility.

Along with the new office design has come a tops-down mandate in many orgs where people no longer have their own desks. Depends on which division you are in, but you many not have any space to keep personal belongings at work -- no locker, let alone a desk.  

High expectations and high stress for employees who are tied to the manufacturing line (fabs, assembly/test), and groups are always understaffed.  More work to be done than a group could do even if it doubled its headcount. On-call is common, and for some people can be 24/7, 365.

Intel has a large manufacturing presence in the U.S. compared to many other companies that have entirely moved manufacturing overseas. This fact is held over Intel employee's heads, e.g. "you better meet these impossible expectations no matter what cost to your personal health, or else ...remember, we are competing with Asian wages."

Intel completely missed the boat in getting into mobile devices/ iPhones. Company outlook will always be questionable because of that.

There isn't really an "internal transfer" process if you want to move to the same job role in a different state. Any time you change departments, it is an interview process. 

Many managers have just gone up the ladder from engineer to group leader - some managers are good, but for many, technical aptitude does not predict that someone will have aptitude at managing and developing people.

pros: Competitive environment focused on performance metrics:  Generally the high level CSI (Critical Success Indicators) are well chosen and focus on the business outcomes so teams are focused on the "corporate good".  This is critical to keep the large teams (100's to 1000's of employees) targeting their attention on what needs work (yield, cost, cycle time, product development cycles, employee satisfaction, safety).  You know what to focus on to affect your bonus.  The HR policies/standards are generally good and are not influenced by the "flavor of the month" trap that smaller or dysfunctional corporations can fall under.
cons:
Competitive environment focused on performance metrics:  At a lower layer, the mantra of "what get's measured gets done" can lead to excessive measures of tangible micro considerations.  The difficult to measure intangible performance considerations are too frequently ignored.  The combination can create a culture of "turning-red-boxes-green" which actually don't matter to the business.  

Leaders of the valuable cultural attributes can easily become whacked in the review process.  Especially when managers are changed on a frequent basis (I've averaged 1.5 managers/year, not counting two in the box managers of my work).

This can result in team members being rewarded for the wrong behaviors.  Also the individual performance evaluation (focal ranking and rating process with forced distributions) leads to dysfunctional team dynamics (political, back stabbing behaviors).  When your livelihood is on the line, individuals morals become fully revealed overtime.  Over my service I believe I have seen at least 6 head count reduction actions, split pretty evenly between "voluntary" and "involuntary" actions.  Given forced distributions, there is always the chance that a bad review year will combine with a involuntary head count reduction.  Many good folks are being let go this time around and Intel's competitors will benefit from the skilled people being released.  

In this environment Exempt employees can expect to work +60hrs/week minimum.

pros: Best in class process technology. Great product road map with credible cadence, Great employee base with great technical bench strength. Strong and health financial standings. Great management with good vision who are inclined to make changes and adjustments when necessary.
cons: Challenge to grow financial results significantly. Need to find new avenues to grow the company's revenue base and then further growth in profits should follow.

job_title: Process TD Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: (1) Decisions are made based on data but when data is lacking a more conservative approach is taken (2)  Designing new recipes or running experiments (3)  collaborating with hardworking and intelligent people to solve problems (tool errors, defect problems and transistor parametric issues)  (4)  They did hire night shift engineers so we can start getting sleep while on call, but during startup this is not available.  (5) The automation systems we have in place do improve, albeit slowly  (6)  Nice high deductible health plan with health saving account (7)  Very nice gyms with knowledgeable trainers (personal and group) available.  (8)  They do allow comp days after going on call (1 day per on call period)
cons:
(1)  Taking the on call pager, especially during startup.  Getting paged every 45 minutes and being expected to formulate troubleshooting plans at 2am and then be in for work in the fab at 7:40 am. (2) the work can be repetitive, especially with regards to filling out paperwork for tool errors (Q&R system) (3) Passdown is a daily meeting that could be done electronically but they decide to have everyone come into the fab for a ritualistic meeting.  (4)  Too many meetings, though this is probably true of all companies.  (5)  No option for standing desks (though we could by our own commercially available desktop units)  (6) They recently laid off  alot of people based upon the level of stock grant.  However the stock grant was not awarded based upon merit evenly across the company, and so many people are now locked out of the company forever because they were supposedly laid off based upon merit.  Luckily I had managers with the foresight to be generous with stock awards.  (7)  Cubicle farm like most companies.  (8)  If you want to be promoted you have to work on the high profile projects and get noticed.  There are only so many of these to go around so yes talking with people and going to the meetings is worthwhile for career advancement.  (9)  Difficult to move horizontally in the company unless you know people.   

I would not rate this particular job to a friend but maybe other positions involve more interesting work.

pros: Plenty of opportunities to try new things without having to switch companies or relocate
cons:
Not many perks and benefits that most people would use.  General benefits (retirement contributions, bonuses, stock options, etc...) have been on the decline the last decade.  "Competitive with peer companies" is the excuse although they used to be much better and justified lower base salaries because of those higher benefits.  Now the benefits are lower but the salaries remain the same.
Small working environment.  Never had offices.  Started off with gray 72 sq ft cubicles.  Then they "compressed" the cubicles to 48 sq ft.  Then they replaced the 6'-tall gray cubicle walls with 5'-tall tan walls to "facilitate collaboration".  This just made things noisier.  They also shrunk the furniture to make your 48 sq ft veal pen feel roomy.  Now they are compressing these smaller cubes into 36 sq ft.  It feels like some sick and twisted version of Moore's Law applied to office space density.
Company used to emphasis the culture and our six core values.  Not so much anymore.  I think that was an Andy Grove thing.  Last few CEO's appear to have been made from a different mold (although the same mold) -- less emphasis on the employees that made the company great and more emphasis on responding reactively to the bottom line.

pros: Intel is the best place i have ever worked.  I have so much latitude to get the right things done that I can really make a difference.  There are people that think and act there.
cons: Ideas flow faster than work product at times.  Making sure your ideas get actioned by someone can take a lot of energy.  if you get caught behind slow or unimaginative management, you can get stymied fast.

pros: Family oriented. Low stress working environment. Work and life balance with lower pays.
cons: Harder to learn a lot of new technology. You will be assigned to a small area and repeat it forever. Too many people managers. They will never get fired and they start to disconnect on latest technology. Very tiny RSU granted to employees.

pros:
work from home. 
No micro management. 
Shares
cons:
Poor corporate service
Poor hikes in few groups
Too much professionalism that a contractor will not be invited for lunch also.
No on sites at all
Pathetic cafeteria foods
No transparency with hr when joining on the pay. So be careful when joining on the discussion of salary
No team environment. Everyone ll be on their own. 
Few groups try to manage the salary with the brand name alone. So don't get fooled only with Intel brand name. See all ur benefits.

pros: Good break schedule and Intel actually cares about the safety if its workers. Safety is regarded as #1. Pay is great as well as the opportunities for growth. Annual pay raises are a huge plus. The provided benefits are especially amazing for anybody with a family.
cons: Managers tend to offer bigger raises and you have a higher likelyhood of promotion if you're closer to them-- but this is a problem that exists at any company. Starting salary is pretty low, but annual raises more than makes up for it if you stay long term. It's a great place to start AND end a career.

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Decent benefits, many different  businesses you can look at going to. Deep glorious history one can feell proud of.
cons: Times have changed. And the company is still trying to feel where it needs to go to remain relevant. Tried many new things but nothing seems to stick. Part of the problem is lack of commitment and desire to approach things like a startup. The 15, 20 years veteran will talk and assign ARs (action required), only the new comer does the work.

pros:
They were the only ones hiring back during the recession in 2010.  This is a very stable company and the world will always have a place for silicon.

Learn the basics of problem solving...and its OK if you fail as long as you follow the established procedure!

Get experience on real world problems.

The pay is very good even if you are not.  It is difficult to get fired unless you are a random victim of corporate layoffs.

You make state of the art products...not necessarily with state of the art methods.

Did I mention the pay is good? My manager did every time we met and I discussed my dissatisfaction with the status quo. I guess the slightly above average pay is to prevent employees from voicing criticism...
cons:
Have all of your contributions ruined by bureaucracy and politics!  Most everything will have a challenging deadline but most of your projects will not be implemented yay!

Match the development site.  Even suggesting new ideas comes at the risk of disciplinary action from management.  If you get that far the development site will just steal your credit.

This is where creativity goes to die.  I was so excited to go to a company with a reputation of innovation but had my ambition ruined.  I think most longterm AZFSM employees just wallow in that space instead of leaving.  My manager made it sound like a point of pride.

The people here are great at getting you started but this is where careers go to suck up to management...but the pay is good and they don't care if you are technical as long as someone else in your group is, so why work hard when you can suck up....not sure why I need any degree to work here, let alone a PhD or MS.

I spent 50% of my life on call for 2 years.  Now I am at 33% omg yay!  I had no personal life during this time and it still takes a toll.  This was not rewarded sufficiently (I am still at the entry grade level.  I regret missing so much that can never be replaced.

job_title: Senior Product Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel is one of the most technologically advanced companies. There are many rumors about Intel's work culture and brutality. But one I need clarify, if you want to be a leader and stay there for decades you need to be brutal. 

Work life balance: It varies from group to group. If you are in the CMOS manufacturing (which is main area Intel is the leader) then work life balance is bad. If you are more away from the wafer, things are far better. 

Compensation:  I have interviewed with several companies in bay area and wanted to give an idea about this.
Remember this is not software company, so comparison with Google, FB, will not be meaningful.

Base Salary: Average, or below average compared to other hardware companies. Annual increase in fab locations (Oregon, Arizona) is low. But in Santa Clara is higher. However they compensate this low salary by other things (see below)

Bonus: In last few years overall bonus varied from ~14%-19%. If you notice, the minimum bonus is ~14% which quite high for many other companies. So, if you get an offer in other companies keep in mind that Intel regularly pays good bonus (compared to HW companies).  Profit sharing Bonus: Quarterly, Performance Bonus: Annually.

Stock Refresh: This will be variable, for a 6 yr experienced Intel employee, I was getting ~$20k annually (this is stock level 2, where stock level 1 is the best). vest in 4 years with one-fourth yearly

401k: IMPORTANT: even if you DO NOT contribute anything, Intel deposits ~5% of your annual salary in 401k. Means, if your annual salary is $100k, you will get $5000 in your 401k even if you dont contribute anything. Catch is: it does vest immediately, you need to stay for 6 years to get all vested, if you stay for 4 yrs or less only 40% will be vested.
cons: Cant think of anything specific. But I would suggest giving manufacturing employees more compensation.

pros:
Most known silicon manufacture on the planet, shaping the future of compute for generations . 
Good benefits, good people and good work/life balance
cons: Unable to transform and make the needed decisions in order to be successful, tons of organizations and management fat, inefficient processes and decision making. low level of transparency. cannot monitize and develop it's potential.

pros: Generally a supportive corporate culture among assiciates.  Many great benefits.  Overall compensation very good.   Rarely a dull moment with opportunities to work in various groups/roles.
cons: Easy to get lost in 100k+ employee environment.  Some management teams overly abrasive, likely due to highly competitive and demanding environment.    Be ready for regular re-organizations, cube only environment (even the execs), and relentless pursuit to accomplish impossibilities.

pros: Intel is the leader in Semiconductor industry.  You get to work with a lot of talented people.  Depending on which group you work with and who is your manager, your working experience may vary.  But my experience has been very positive.  I found everyone I worked with to be open and fair.  The overall compensation package is very good.
cons: It has the typical downside of a big company.  Sometime decisions cannot be made quickly.  Yearly employee evaluation process is too convoluated and waste too much time.  Sometime career advancement path is not very clear.

review_title: Intel is just Ok.  Not great, but not bad.
job_title: Planning Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Big company exposure...lots of training, lots of resources.  Allow for opportunities to move horizontally in the organization.  Decent benefits, but salary is probably slightly lower than their Internet peers.
cons: Big company bureaucracy...lots of red tape, not enough room for real strategic development.  Stock options are worthless.  Growth is lagging big time.  Not enough opportunity to move up quickly in the organization.  Too many levels between bottom and top.  Need more growth, growth, growth...

review_title: Good company, but you will work a lot for your money.
pros: Great flexibility allowed - work hours and location usually are flexible so long as the job gets done.  The only exception is for management roles were face time is required.
cons:
Overall job demands are very and high with poor work-life balance.
Average compensation - don't expect to get rich at Intel.

review_title: Great tech. company but far too much politics
job_title: Research Scientist in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Exposure to the best technology there is: semiconductor, software
Learn and practice great business practices, ethics. Excellent place to learn management skills
cons: Too much politics to get anything done. Almost like running in Washington to get stuff done across orgs and BUs

review_title: Fast paced work at the cutting edge of technology, very smart people, competitive pay and excellent health benefits
pros: Smart people, excellent products, competitive pay, great health benefits, flat organization, less bureaucracy, detailed and open performance reviews, access to tons of discounts (if that floats your boat), lots of opportunities to contribute socially, reasonable prices in cafe at large sites
cons: Pay scale confusing, some groups better than others, promotions are sometimes unfairly distributed, drab office environment that is sometimes depressing

pros:
Time off from work 
Cleanroom and safe work environments 
Some coorporation among harder workers
Technology based tools
cons:
Too fast paced manufacturing facility leading to stress 
Wrong changes occur to frequently
Poor labor mix and with management playing status quo  
Poor decsion making by senior management  
Severe control bottlenecks work throughput 
Must use agressive tactics to get jobs done

pros:
- Performance based promotion and recognition
- Data driven decisions; relatively low level of politically motivated rational
- Strong support from management for resources
- Incredibly smart engineering teams
- Good leadership from management
cons:
- Large company; bureaucracy is not burdensome, but clearly exists
- Long hours and hard work; work-life balance is not always respected or recognized

pros: Good Employee benefits and perks including free ride back & forth to office , free food on some days in a month, great infrastructure
cons: Management lacks the longer vision to growth the site vis-a-vis with other Intel Sites across the globe. Highly intelligent people are wasted in doing maintenance releases. Managers are busy dealing with improving their ratings (provided anonymously by their team members). In short, managers are quite busy but I am not sure why they are busy ?

review_title: Intel needs to understand that chips are now no more/less than a commodity
pros: Salary and benefits are second to none.   Some of the most incredibly smart people I have ever had the pleasure to work with.
cons: While I suspect this varies from division to division, teamwork is something that is often talked about as a core Intel value, but in actual practice, and particularly between product divisions, just so much was-was.

pros: Intel is much like any other NW tech company, if you're a salaried engineer. Laid back dress (I've seen folks in pajamas come to work) and relaxed "get the job done" hours were a great part of being there.
cons: Extended and off-hour work times. Intel has moved jobs to several international locations, which makes for somebody on conference calls to be awake at 10pm local time to attend meetings. My other huge con was when my last manager did not support me at meetings of any kind. If something minor went wrong, I had to face his boss. Not right.

pros:
good, big company. The organization tries to encourage initiatives and innovation.
You have a chance to work with and on the latest hardware platfrom before they reach the market and since that this is a large organization, opportunities for role change and relocation pop up from time to time.
Intel provide many benefits for the employees. To name few of them: Yeary bonus of between 1-4 monthly salaries (varies according to the company success), private health insurance, competitive car leasing program, shares participation plan, extended vacation each 7 years
cons: As large corporate, the bureaucracy sometime can kill you or the area you are working on

review_title: Good company to work for, but not very driven by Good Software Engineering Practices
pros: Great people, Lots of resources and courses to enhance your knowledge and learn new things.  Has some cool things to work on if you find the right team.
cons: In my organization, Good software practices are spoken about, but the culture still isn't there.  More driven about by the short-term rather than the long term.  No time to research and investigates ways to better the team.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good Health benefits; Paid Sabbatical
cons: No Transparency; Performance review solely based on manager's preference

review_title: Good company to work for, but not very driven by Good Software Engineering Practices
pros: Great people, Lots of resources and courses to enhance your knowledge and learn new things.  Has some cool things to work on if you find the right team.
cons: In my organization, Good software practices are spoken about, but the culture still isn't there.  More driven about by the short-term rather than the long term.  No time to research and investigates ways to better the team.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good Health benefits; Paid Sabbatical
cons: No Transparency; Performance review solely based on manager's preference

pros: The best part of working at Intel was the great salary and benefits. Work-life balance was also good. I was also happy with my management.
cons: Intel is a gigantic corporation that has lots of typical bureaucracy. You can also be impacted by high-level re-organization decisions that affect your department or division, including up to the department or division being removed and getting option of being laid off or "redeployed" regardless of how you have performed.

pros: An overall great company with fantastic technology. Nice benefits package and above average salary. Many different groups with, in principle, possibilities to move around (but beware of small remote sites).
cons:
In small remote sites, it can be very difficult to have a career path or to change job, especially in a technical career.
Some employees heavily play politics. In real engineering teams, it's much better but when moving towards sales and marketing, it can get pretty bad. Something to be wary of.

pros: excellent benefits, competitive salaries, multiple locations of employment available in a number of states.
cons: managerial approaches rooted firmly in the 80's; MBO, 360's, annual reviews.  Designed to give the appearance of actual management guidance but in fact just a system for tracking/justifying  adjustments in grade that keep pace with inflation (averaged over 5 years). Usual management bs about valuing people etc but in reality, no real guidance when career challenges arise. You're on your own.

review_title: Don't Apply if your not an engineer.
pros: Bonuses, Perks, Free Coffee, Events, and Resource Groups.
cons: The over all attitude of all managers is, That an engineer can always do it better".  So, they will always hire or promote any male with an Engineering degree.  They don't care what field of study it is.  cleaning windows an engineer can do it better.  And if you are female, forget it.  They talk a good talk but the attitude is the same...a male engineer can do it better.  You can be at the top of your class,  arrive with registered patents and if you are female you are treated like a little girl.

pros: Very competitive salary, good starting point for a recent graduate's career. Free coffee and fruits in cafeteria. Benefits are good too.
cons:
Very stressful and hostile environment. No teamwork whatsoever, eveybody competes with everybody. Employees are living in fear for upcoming focal review, and for the last couple of years for in fear of imminent layoffs that follow focal.
Some departments have extremely long hours. Often employees have to work 80-100 hours a week. Very stressfull on-call schedule. Quite often several sleepless nights in a row and you're expected to work 16 hrs during the day as well. 
I've heard many engineers were having sleep deprivation diagnosis, exhaustion, sleep problems and had to go to medical leave which only caused them being fired in next year layoffs.

pros: Good work environment with awesome coworkers.  Plenty of experienced staff to mentor the younger new to the industry members.  Middle management has excellent ideas and inspires the troops to do more.  Projects are fun and interesting to work on and provide good learning experiences.  Great benefits three weeks vacation (untracked except by you), unlimited sick time (as long as you don't abuse), quarterly and annual bonuses, stock program at 15% off up to a cap.
cons: Communication within and outside of teams is lacking.  One person will do something without informing all parties that SHOULD be aware of something.

pros: Company encourages people to step up and lead with good ideas and execution.  My group was open to new ideas and work projects if I could show how much it would improve the work-week for my self, team, or others.
cons: Bad communication, little documentation. My management was changing priorities every couple weeks.  Worked long work weeks and handled multiple fire-drills with no rewards.  Work done was pushed away a month latter with new issues to solve.

pros: Good benefits package.  Sabbatical program is still solid.  Medical is at least as good as average for the industry.  Fitness center on-site is a nice perk.
cons: Review program makes it very easy to get screwed out of stock.  Recent restructuring means very little opportunity if you're not a recent college grad, H1-B, or working outside the USA.

job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great place to work - great benefits, great work environment. Opportunities for advancement is real. Safety can never be compromised for any reason. Training is available for qualified technicians. yearly reviews are always on schedule. communications from all level of managements are effective and in time.
cons: not open to receive and understand the 'outside' surrounding community, upper level management values shareholders more than employees.

pros: I love my schedule here: 12 hour shifts, 3 days on 3 days off, 4 days on 4 days off.
cons: My base compensation after 5 years here is less than what our new hires are getting.  How's that for a slap in the face.  Not to mention that neither wage comes close to the construction electricians here on site.

pros: Overall, Intel is a very good company to work for.  They provide excellent compensation and benefits.  The work is always challenging and the software and tools available to work with are generally top notch.  The individual is valued and expected to call out when something isn't right.
cons: Work/life balance is up to the individual to manage, which make sense.  High performers are driven harder than average performers.  The management style is born out of the 60s and 70s white collar working class and that is still pervasive across the company, which translates to high pressure and long hours.

pros: There was a lot of support for flexible work schedules and mobile locations especially for folks working with international teams that had to work early morning or evening hours.
cons: Remote work options were then removed because someone had the bright idea that people had to be in the office to be most productive.  Even if 75% of the team was in a different country in a different time zone.  A lot of good people who weren’t based near one of the main campuses were let go. This is from a technology giant. Seems like they are going backwards.

pros:
Good bonuses 
Subsidised canteen 
Site facilities are good (parking / toilets / office space etc)
cons:
Everything. Relentless pressure from management. Unfulfilling work. Staff made to feel like "resources" that are there to be used up. Us versus them attitude from management. Upper management hold contempt for their employees . Blame culture is very strong,management need "bodies for the bodybags" whenever there is an issue. Performance management is broken,all employees are in direct competition with each other DESPITE all the lip service paid to team work. Toxic atmosphere.Work life balance is very poor. Plenty of weekend / late night meetings and or issues. 

Renumeration is middle of the curve, not bad but not great

pros: Great sense of camaraderie with an emphasis on teamwork and streamlined business policies. Spin up process was smooth, if a little disorganized. Benefits are top of the line and stock opportunities are great. Quarterly Profit Bonuses as well as Yearly Performance Bonuses, with a yearly pay bump (though typically pretty insignificant).
cons: Grade level system that determines salary range. Position in company has no reflection on salary, you must increase your grade level (which takes years per level, and increases in average time with each level) to have any meaningful increase in salary. Not exactly promoting a desire to move up in the company.

review_title: Great technology but low on motivating employees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is poised for changes under Ottellini, there are core groups that are involved with the cutting edge that are far more satisfied with their positions. If you are looking to work for Intel, you want to ensure that you aren't too many layers away from the core technology.
cons: You feel like a cog in the wheel, too entrenched in values inscribed by Grove which are in some ways treated like the US constitution.

pros:
Big company with brand power. 
Bonus and benefits
Financial health
Market dominance
cons:
1) Bureaucracy
: too many layers of managers.  It looks like promotion to manager is abused to lower high voluntary attrition rate and as a result, there are many many managers who manage a tiny # of people
2) Abrasive culture
: People tend to be mean to each other for the sake of being perceived as aggressive 
3) Jungle-like rules of game
: Few people care about new hire or junior engineer.  Very competitive environment

review_title: Not the company everyone portrays it to be, be careful before becoming a cube dweller.
pros: There are a few reasons that it pays to work for Intel.  1) Flexibility- you are able to go about your day as you please as long as your work is completed, most managers are flexible in your work schedule (within reason).  2) Intel is a well know company and can do wonders for your resume.  3)  Work attire, Intel offers a casual environment in which to work, there is not a dress code, one can wear shorts and flip flops if necessary 4) Intel offers good benefits (even though they are eroding).  Hard to beat all the healthcare and retirement benefits that Intel offers its employees.
cons: Intel usually demands long hours.  I work 50+ hrs a week, which erodes into the time I get to spend with family.  The Intel culture is very self centered/focused, from my experience people are out for themselves and its easy to get backstabbed.  I have also experienced first hand how politcal the office environment is.   Promotions and reviews are said to be objective based, but I tend to see it more of a popularity contest.   The most noteable downside of working at Intel is the lack of growth opportunity.  Intel has past its stage as a growth company, jobs have been cut and upleveling your career is becoming harder and harder.

review_title: Financially sound company that could do better to compensate employees during good years.
job_title: Customer Business Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Solid health benefit options and sabbatical every 7 years.
cons: Options and restricted stock units have become more and more worthless.  Employees don't receive enough compensation when company is doing well.  Intel spends their money in R&D and not with the day-to-day tools that non-engineers use.  $40 billion company ran on spreadsheets that leads to multiple inefficiencies.

pros: If you have a competitive drive and strive on challenges and seeing first hand the results of your hard work...Intel is the work place for you.
cons: Some employees get caught up prioritizing their work output and performance while sacrificing their personal time, personal life, and family.  It can be tough to balance this if you don't have a good working relationship with your direct management.

review_title: Enjoyable workplace, and great opportunities for job growth. All dependent on manger.
pros: Culture and Values are top priorities, management typically works with you to work out the best schedule for you work and life balance. There is a ton of opportunity for growth in different fields of engineering.
cons: Salary compensation is low compared to job market. Career is very dependent on the type of manager and upper level manager. Each group varies. Politics can be a factor in job growth and opportunities depending on the group.

job_title: Hardware Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Exciting Work. You can start on small projects but can quickly scale. All depends on what you want to do.  
Challenging work. As a hardware engineer you work on the leading edge process that you wont find elsewhere. 
Lots of smart people that you learn from every day. Results win (though see con about politics). Its a balance that you have to figure out.
cons:
lots of work
big scary company filled with sharks - need to learn how to manage your expectations and others. Cant be politically naive.

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel has been a highly recognized industry leader that compensates its employees well; high salary, 2 bonuses per year, stock options (grant plus RSUs), great medical plan (Cigna) and other great benefits.  The Intel name looks great on your resume and can boost your career.  Intel has many very intelligent and dedicated employees that want the company to succeed.  But...
cons: The best way to currently describe Intel is "High Risk".  The company has struggled with poor leadership and has stopped living the core values that made Intel great.  Since founder Andy Grove retired, an executive power struggle ensued over the past 10 years and many of the best senior managers have left for better opportunities or due to health issues.  Intel has prided itself in driving industry transitions but has absolutely missed the mobile revolution (smartphones and tablets) and is ill positioned to catch up to it's ARM competition (Apple, Qualcomm, Samsung, TI, etc).  There is little work-life balance despite frequent HR programs to improve moral so expect to typically work 60-70 hours per week and in excess of 80 during peek times, including early morning, late evening and weekends.  I traveled up to 60% of the time domestic and international but 20-30% is typical.  Bottom line is your family and you will pay for the pay.  I worked there for over 20 years, loved the first several years and believed that I would finish my career at Intel.  Then things changed and would now not consider returning again.

review_title: Facilities / Construction / Engineering - Experience of U.S.A & international sites
pros: Interesting advanced engineering systems / installations
cons:
Very poor employee morale.
Very poor working environment / atmosphere.
Very poor time management with employees (perhaps due to workloads) resulting in VERY common ('the norm') behaviour such as not to show up to pre-arranged meetings.
Blame culture, particularly applied to Suppliers.
Very common to find unapproachable, 'hot-headed' and unprofessional staff who think that hard nosed / kick-ass attitudes are the only way to get results from Suppliers.

job_title: Senior Network Security Specialist in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: They have more than OK salaries and you can achieve work life balance.
cons: You need to really need to sharp your politic skills in order to get involved in great projects otherwise get ready to work on your resume and work somewhere else cuz you'll get yourself professionally stuck and will loose your technical touch. I have sadly seen awesome talented people leave because of this and know more people are looking for opportunities outside the company. They will also prevent you from moving internally to another org because "it may affect the business".

review_title: They don't treat contractors the same as the permanent employees using petty things, such as free drinks and free fruit.
pros: Well run company, vested in research and development of exciting new technology.  I had one of the best bosses I have ever had and was left to work pretty autonomously.
cons: The cubes are too small and it is difficult to concentrate with all of the noise.  Also, they moved me twice in 6 months which seemed excessive

pros: There are lots of top-notch people to work with.  The pays is very good and employees are provided with free coffee, drinks and fruit.  The health benefits are good but not great.
cons: Work/life balance has significantly deteriorated over the years.  It's hard to do good work as there are too many obstructionists and managers in the good ol' boy network.  There is too much micromanagement and the whole place is meeting-happy, leading to low productivity.  It's a slow moving giant.  Along with the great, smart coworkers, there are just as many people who don't pull their weight.

pros:
-Intel still has an amazing, world class brand
-Decent work-life balance (in the right groups with the right managers)
-What the company actually does is amazing
-Opportunities to learn from truly smart people
cons:
1.  No growth, an execution problem, and a culture crisis

Intel's revenue has been flat/down over the last 3 years, and we have some huge advantages that we've failed to leverage.  There's an execution problem that seems to be an outgrowth of middle management and certain critical product groups really not "getting it", "it" being that Intel faces an existential threat and can't afford to do things the way they've always been done.  Upper management is driving a culture change, but a not insignificant number of folks seem to have missed the memo.


2.  Fundamentally political and bureaucratic environment

One of the firs things you'll hear when you join Intel is that it's exceptional in being a results-oriented meritocracy.  Drink this Kool-Aid at your own peril.  It is very much your usual corporate America environment.   Your success depends entirely on your manager and his/her manager.  Play the game or lose.  And losing in the current environment can mean losing your job.  

Also, in a company with the size and complexity of Intel, the number of stakeholders that need to "buy in" to any decision worth considering is staggering.  It can take forever to affect change and inevitably you will run into at least one person who will need to be dragged kicking and screaming to accept, or even try, something new (see point #1).


3.  Subpar compensation and increasing duplicity from upper management on compensation

Intel's explicit strategy on compensation is to pay better than market in good years, at market during avg. years, and below market during bad years...and there haven't been many good years recently.  "Raises" are essentially inflation buffers, and there have also been a number of changes to bonus calculations (large part of comp and the main lever for pay) and retirement/pension plans that are thinly veiled pay cuts.  Management seems to be resistant to being forthcoming about this.


4.  Recruiting/staffing "strategy" is a mess for everyone involved

The company pays a premium for "top tier" talent, but any effort to differentiate between "top" talent and others seems to be abandoned when candidates are placed.  A significant amount of Masters and PhD hires are paid top dollar only to be tool or design monkeys, and they hate their jobs.  Stars from OK schools are understandably frustrated when they compare notes, and older managers are not immune to jealousy either.  It's a lose lose for everyone involved.  Intel's locations are horrible for attracting younger talent as well.  Phoenix, Portland, and Folsom are less than stellar locales for young professionals.  


5.  "Lifer"/"True Believer" culture becoming more intense in the new, more challenging environment

Intel's taken pride in being a company with a culture that induces people to "commit" to being lifers or jumping ship early.  Middle managers seem to have the directive to weed out people they think aren't in it for the long haul.  The kind of openness you can have about medium or long term goals is limited.  This is something to be conscious of.

review_title: Mort than just a "Great place to work!"
pros: Intel can be an exciting and engaging place to work. They are literally building the future and if you have the right skills and commitment you can too! There are many unseen elements opportunities over their diverse range of careers there. Impeccably ethical, if not to the point of seeking to be uniformly equitable to all.
cons: You really do own your own career there and shouldn't expect much in the way of someone else bringing you along. They are a huge company very much akin to working for a small government in many regards. Management is not iffy on making whole-scale cuts or reorganizations to meet the need of business direction, so no job is completely "safe" from the restructuring ax. They love to work RCG's because they usually have nothing but work to fill their lives. Can make it feel a bit like a meat grinder.

review_title: Intel is an interesting but can be very demanding place to work. Depends on the group
pros: There are a lot of smart people there and the projects can be interesting. The Hillsboro area is very nice to raise a family. There are a lot of things to do, beach is about an hour away and lot of places to go hiking, biking.
cons: This is a fast pace place. Actually, it depends on the group that you get involved with. But most groups are pretty demanding, so working 65 hours a week is not unusual. It is hard to have a balance life when you don't have time.

review_title: Above average industry pay but dull routine work, especially in the high-volume fabs.
job_title: Process TD Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Good pay compared to industry average. 
Process engineer at Intel is an extremely secure job.
cons:
Mind-numbing work (which is why they hire PhDs from any major. What does a Mat. Sci. Phd have in common with a biochem PhD??)
Terrible work-life balance (weekend on-call and about 6 months every year is in a 7 day start up phase). 
Heirarchical management (not welcoming of dissenting dialogue on a problem, even if presented with data)

pros:
Great benefits
Flexible schedule
Work with smart people 
Has a great place to work program that gives tickets to a lot of local events
Feel your work impacts the world
Mostly smart people as coworkers
cons:
Feels like you work at Veridian Dynamics 
Heartless corporation
Constant fear of job loss after medical leave of absence
If you get stuck with a bad boss, you're pretty much on your own

review_title: People are great, Marketing department is in flux
pros:
People were great when I arrived.  They were all let go and replaced with people that were not great.

Work can be rewarding
cons: Lots of turn over.  Marketing department in chaos.  Contact and full time employees roles are blurring and full time staff are devalued. Middle managers suddenly having two assistants who don't do anything, and spending tons of money on contractors that don't have the required skillset.

pros: A good aspect of working for Intel is the cutting edge technology that you have at hand. While most of it is confidential, I will say this. The software they have is a good 5 years ahead of what everyone else has.
cons: Some of the relationships between co-workers can sometime get frustrating and annoying at times. I all depends on the crew leader that you are assigned to.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Great to work in processor design or validation teams as the environment is stable and the engineers are very intelligent and dedicated. Processor teams have effective meetings and management who believe in the company and the growth of their teams. Good benefits and very welcoming to new college graduates.
cons: Work Life Balance is in your hands and work can be very hectic during critical times. Since work culture is different across the various groups, move to a different group if your current one is too demanding or not rewarding. This is easier said than done.

pros: They have an on site doctor's office, so if you're sick you can just go to that doctor. They offer fresh fruit and healthy food options in the cafeteria. Stock options, and every 7 years of employment every employee gets a 2 month paid sabbatical.
cons: They are extremely paranoid about safety. If other people see you doing things, like walking up or down stairs without holding the hand railing they will ask you to hold the railing. Personal safety issues outside of the plant are also considered, i.e. speeding tickets, DWI, car accidents, house fires, etc.

review_title: IT was best of times, it was worst of times
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Smart people, interesting work, great manufacturing and supply chain knowledge.  Excellent money when times were good.  If someone's worked for Intel for any length of time, they probably can hang in most environments
cons: Too many managers near the end - the autonomy of a startup disappeared about 10 years ago.  Inconsistent decision making results in a lot of project stops and starts.If

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- only few teams work on cutting edge products and if you're lucky to join them, you'll gain good experience in product development.
- you get that little extra freedom, as a developer to chose your own way of doing things.
- you get a free fruit during lunch if your're if you reach cafeteria on time :)
cons:
- salary is average
- lot of politics at lower-mid to mid-level management
- you can get stuck in same project for years.
- internal job change chances is very limited to non existent
- if you are good at coding than get ready for loads of work.

review_title: Not so Great Place To Work.
job_title: Soc Design Verification Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Had to think very hard to write Pros. 
1. A few talented people to work with
2. Decent pay 
3. Access to good resources.
cons:
Don't have to think too much.
Based on my experience in the "we used to be the bread and butter of Intel, we are the number one"  team of Intel. 
0. No job security. Be ready to be chopped off before you know it.
1. Chances of having to put up with a bad manager are very high. 8 out of 10 are bad managers. Calculate the probability that one ends up with a bad manager. 
2. Immediate managers micro manage.
3. Immediate managers have lost their touch with technical aspects and are only spreadsheet experts- try explaining to such people technical things and get them to agree.
4. No career growth since the team itself has become stagnant and has lost its reputation with poor performance in the recent projects. Still a lot of churn in the team.
5. Promotions are given to people who are loud mouthed again because immediate managers are not technical. So the loudest seller in the bazaar wins the customer (i.e. promotion).
6. Frequent change in direction/goal for the team. The team is basically trying to survive rather than to grow for the past 3 years.
7. Too many wrappers around industry standard tools that makes it difficult to troubleshoot. The wrappers don't have documentation and sometimes, the so called "experts" also can't understand. 
8. Late in adoption of the latest industry standards - so skills are sort of irrelevant outside Intel.
9. Politics in promoting - wait in queue for your turn to get promoted though we follow meritocracy.
10. Lots of unwritten rules that contradict with Intel's guidelines. 
11. Very little scope to try out a different area as managers tend to not allow it. Only a handful of good managers encourage it.

review_title: Old, clunky, manager heavy, closed to change&risk
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Location was at Portland, cheap city.
cons:
A lot of non-technical managers leading software development
Quite hierarchical 
Arcane build systems, tools, methods 
Close to innovation and changes to the suites
I was fresh out of college and so the rest of my large group. Not diverse in terms of age. 
Managers advise not to rock the boat 
People who call out these are punished during focals, regardless of their skills
It is a hardware company, why work in hw company as software engineer?
Management blocks internal transfers 
Previous CEO missed the iphones, this one missed the cars

pros:
Pay and benefits.  
Compressed work week for techs.
Had a lot of great team mates.  
Successful company.
I had a long run there and it was great though fab life isn't for everyone.
cons: Stress, it can be demanding.  Probably have to start night shift as a tech but not necessarily.  Job security isn't what it used to be.

review_title: Good Bad and Ugly of Intel
pros: The benefits package is the BEST I have ever seen---the company really encourages lateral movement to get new skill sets. I have seen employees go from custodial services to Corporate Real Estate... biz analysts go try out HR.  Love the Intel Values that include the encouragement  informed risk taking... the in-house cafes with free coffee, soda and fruit was nice and so were the gym facilities with classes from Zumba to Boxing. The ability to contact anyone within the company no matter what level in the hierarchy was great.  Can't beat the paid sabbaticals at regular intervals. Also INTEL  encourages employees to get out and volunteer.  Retirement and stock are really above industry standards.
cons: On the downside many mass layoffs with concurrent or mass hiring within just months.No longer reward or value loyalty or longevity of employees.  Some biz groups don't treat the contractors very well. Yearly pay increases are ridiculously low. Don't feel like management can be trusted with their promises of truth and transparency. And if you are a salaried employee it is not uncommon to work 55+ hours a week.

review_title: Careers are what you make of them
pros:
If you are at a core location there are career opportunities available.
Sabbaticals every 4 or 7 years are the best perk.
cons:
Management has forgotten that it needs to keep people around who know the history or products.  They are getting rid of anyone older, and hiring mainly recent college graduates, and H1B visas. 
If you are not at one of the preferred locations your career path is limited. 
The mantra for compensation is "Industry equivalent" instead of being a leader.

review_title: Bad management, decent engineers, bad outlook
job_title: Quality and Reliability Engineer in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Good work life balance, decent perks if not the best, opportunities within
cons:
Very bad and outdated management who lack vision and foresight. This has been proven several times before. They make sure the employees suffer in the long term due to mistakes made by them.

They cannot draw the best of talent to the company due to their conservative mindset in current days fast paced environment.

Not the best company to be in if you want to learn or work on the latest and newest technologies that have potential

review_title: The Beatings will continue until the morale improves
pros: Cutting edge technology, good benefits (health insurance, sabbatical, etc)
cons: Poor direction by management, no clear cut corporate strategy.  Cutbacks for the sake of cutbacks, diversity for the sake of diversity.  Hard to believe how much the culture has worsened over the past few years.  Employee morale is at an all time low.  Constant risk of layoffs or redeployment.

pros: Subsidized cafeteria provides free fruit.
cons:
They are so focused on 'diversity' that they actively discriminate against whites, asians, and indians. Their pledge to have have minorities at all levels combined with their current lack of diversity means that hiring managers of all levels are under extreme pressure to hire only females and minorities, regardless of qualifications. I have first-hand witnessed multiple occasions where whites and asians have been denied jobs or promotions because of their race. The diversity department has also filtered out resumes entirely because of the race/gender of the applicant. It's really bad.
Additionally, once your hired your expected to join groups according to your identity group. Women engineers. Latino/latina groups. African-American groups. Intel even organized a march to protest for women at their site this year. Who were they even protesting?

review_title: Okay job but not the best place for software engineers
pros: Excellent benefits.  Opportunity to work on developing software for cutting edge silicon. Unfortunately the software is often subpar due to the HW focus of the company.
cons:
Pay for software engineers is below market rate for most geographic areas.  The company is not a software company so expect to work with outdated tools and methodologies. 

Usual office politics apply here.... Get promoted by how much you network rather than technical contributions.

job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Strong corporate culture via internal marketing and messaging framework creates sense of community in a dispersed workplace. +100,000 employees and worldwide branding. 'Intel' is immediately recognizable -  a progressive data processing company and chip manufacturer who lives inside almost every computer on the planet.
cons:
I worked in a small satellite campus created after a new acquisition. Intel imported management from the acquired start-up, empowered them to build teams, but failed to train them to lead a professional workforce. HR competently addressed
