the abusive communication habits and is working to change the harmful culture of that satellite before more talented individuals leave.

pros:
Great benefits 
Ability to learn a new career field without leaving company
Tuition reimbursement 
Ability to WFH in some departments (this does not necessarily mean good work/life balance. That will depend on your department and direct manager)
High paying
cons: Management holds to the “do more with less” mantra. High burn out. You really are just a number. Morale is overall low down in the trenches. If you want a great salary and benefits, and can stomach a lot of bureaucracy and being continually told to keep doing more with less, then this is the place for you!

job_title: Former Special Project Manager  in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel is a huge company with a stable future, plenty of growth, and decent leadership towards that growth. The work environment is typically clean, social, and safe, as Intel focuses on security and social interaction for profits. Intel frequently offers small amenities, side benefits like gyms, cafe's, coffee areas, open patios, etc. to their workers to improve the workplace "feel", to build a complete package of benefits to offset their slightly lower than market price in straight salary.  Intel is a very social-conscious workplace, where your status is malleable depending on your network skills, ability to work with others, and innovation.
cons: Huge company, and every Fab, area, and department are different in culture from every other. If you get a good manager, your job is wonderful.  If you have a bad one, there is almost zero recourse to change that, and your career will suffer quickly. AS a large corporation, interdepartment politics plays heavily, and often workers suffer from the bad ideas of one department impacting others, and too often, silly decisions are made with no regard to impact on others.  One example:  In order to save money, the training department fired personnel who used to prepare the classrooms with materials, schedule classes, etc.. THen, every other department had to start printing their own materials for every class, schedule classes without a central booking feature, and suddenly, classes were held without teachers, without students, rooms conflicted because two classes were scheduled together, and every teacher suddenly spent hours more per class in the photocopy room, making booklets for classes than ever before.  This lead to frustration, lost time, and an abandonment of the program by the volunteer teachers, which lead to fewer classes, which lead to fewer trained workers, which forced the training organization to hire new people to straighten out the mess, and we are back at square one, except our experienced class managers are fired, new, inexperienced ones are taking their place, and the teaching pool is reduced from frustration.  And, thousands of man-hours have been wasted on the effort.

review_title: Intel struggles to reward young leaders.
pros: The best reasons to work for Intel Corporation include the many degrees of flexibility bestowed to employees, the ability to work for a leading manufacturing company and the multitude of resources that go along with that, and the location of the company - Portland, Oregon.  Flexibility at Intel Corp means working from home, having no supervision of vacation, skewing shifts, working out at gym which is conveniently located at work, and ability to do daily tasks while at work.  Leading manufacturing company is somewhat intuitive, but the benefits go beyond the ability to put it on a resume.  Learning the aspects that make them successful and applying those to future endeavors.
cons: The downsides of working for Intel corp are as numerous if not more numerous than the upsides.  The most obvious downsides include: Intel is a large, I repeat large company - having over 80,000 employees worldwide, recognition and feeback at Intel corp is nearly non existent, and carreer advancement and ability to move up is extremely inhibited.  In my humble opinion, all of Intel's problems stem from its size (my first point against it) but I will elaborate on the main two deficencies stemming from the shear size.   Feedback at Intel is a once/year process and it is written by the employee him/herself and thus not true feedback, recognition (read reward) is an extremely bearucratric process driven by corporate distributions of how the company should reward on a whole.  Thus if you are in a small strong group, good luck!

review_title: Great Place for Design Engineers to work on leading-edge technologies
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Awesome exposure to leading-edge technologies.
Diverse, sharp workforce, with great team mates.
Company resources and reputation.
Benefits and high quality, clean work environment.
cons:
Bloated upper level management--need to trim
Ranking and Rating system creates anxiety amongst employees and is not accurate
outsourcing of jobs overseas

job_title: Consulting Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Advanced technology
Credibility for going to another company
A few very smart people that you can learn from
Your product is likely to go into volume production
cons:
A large number of mediocre employees
It takes three times the number of people that should be needed to do a given project
10X too many meetings
People in the first few levels of mgmt lack breadth in knowledge, responsibility, and perspective

review_title: Great place, if you're in the right group!
pros:
An egalatarian culture, lot of companies may advertise it, Intel really practices it. Everyone has a cubicle, everyone is required to travel economy class even internationally, and everyone gets a chance to voice their opinion..
A very decent total compensation structure. However, it varies widely between groups.
Some of the top executives are really good. Paul's a great CEO, probably the best since Andy.
cons:
Extremely hard to achieve career growth in Intel. Your growth depends on the general health of your Org unit, and how ambitious your chain of command is, and how aggressive they are at advertising their work. This also has the con that some groups sell an idea very aggressively, make careers for their folks, and fail in the market place. 
It is a testosterone driven company. The one who shouts the loudest in a room is generally presumed to have all the answers.
There are a lot of vested interests and turf wars are very common. Groups work at cross purposes to ensure failure of other groups.
A lot of groups are adrift. There is a general lack of buzz, and my guess is that it has a lot to do with not knowing how they can contribute. Very hard for management to do anything about such teams.
Some groups have bad work/life balance. Poor first/second line planning means that these groups are firefighting all the time.

review_title: Great work balance Bad for personal development
pros:
The company provides great work balance, good working conditions, fair salaries and benefits.
Great place to start a family, buy a house
cons:
Very bureaucratic.
Personal development is slow - great at start ( if you are an RCG ), but get slow after couple of years.
Too many dirty internal politics. 
Due to the focal system - people prefer not to take the risks
There is internal unemployment - hunger and internal competition ( sometimes very dirty ) for good projects. If there is already a good project usually take more people than needed to do it

review_title: Cutting edge products and great place to work
pros: Intel hires the best in class employees and as such you work among a very smart and talented peer group.  The compensation including the bonus is great and rewards employees solely based on merit.
cons: Too many cross functional meetings before any decisions can be made.  Slow to react to issues due to over analyzing with groups of people. Culture is extremely risk averse where every decision needs a buy in from all stake holders or they just end up selecting a safer option.

review_title: Caveat Emptor -- the lowdown from a Senior Application Developer
pros:
-I really don't notice any sexism.
-Most people are fairly profession in terms of conduct.
-Brand Recognition for your next job (which will hopefully pay you what you deserve...see the cons below).
-Free Coffee and fruit..? Uhhh. LOL
-Decent training opportunities (unless your management is blowing it all on booze and girls in developing countries...)
-Good discount, especially on Intel products and things to distract you from how meaningless your work is at Intel.
cons:
-Below average pay for often intense work.  Supporting Moore's law ain't easy!
-Speaking of pay:  just know that fairly soon after they hire you at the lowest price possible, they will offer 10k more to recent college graduates ( "RCGs") even if they are lesser skilled, can't hold a conversation, and are deathly afraid of giving a presentation on the work they just did
-The culture is declining... not what it used to be.  Egalitarianism looks good on paper and most everyone in the offices is in a cubicle... Don't drink the Kool Aid just yet,  Voice a dissenting opinion and get the one lasting aspect of Intel culture "disagree and commit!"
-Other than Moore's law (which will slowly grind to a halt due to heat issues and the fact that as the technology shrinks to near the atomic level, the transistors will no longer work because as dictated by quantum physics (google the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle) the electrons that guide the current may appear on either side of the transistor gate.
-Focal is the yearly review process in which employees who are your so-called friends backstab you and management gives a promotion to the person with the brownest nose (aka kissing a__"

pros: Good salary/benefits; high tech; assets and willing to push tech forward.
cons: Too large; internal politics has always been dominated by the (used to be) high-margin processor segment.  Have never been able to overcome this "every business must meet the ROI bar set by the processor division".  This means their investments in other areas have always been half-assed, since the processor folks were always able to successfully argue that the money would be better spent on them.  Of course, now that that business is in decline, Intel has been caught flat-footed with no back-up plan.

pros: Good salary/benefits; high tech; assets and willing to push tech forward.
cons: Too large; internal politics has always been dominated by the (used to be) high-margin processor segment.  Have never been able to overcome this "every business must meet the ROI bar set by the processor division".  This means their investments in other areas have always been half-assed, since the processor folks were always able to successfully argue that the money would be better spent on them.  Of course, now that that business is in decline, Intel has been caught flat-footed with no back-up plan.

review_title: Great team, smart people, and good place to work
pros: Good smart people driving interesting products. Perfect place to have work life balance, not seen anywhere else. Lot of flexibility to take you career in the direction you would want and the options are limitless. They do value performance and you can expect to work hard and get good recognition.
cons: Too many layers of people in decision making. Have to handle multiple stake holders for the smallest decision. This makes the process slow and cumbersome.

pros: The work-life balance is good but it is entirely up to the employee to enforce, otherwise Intel will take any and all time you have. Good opportunities to learn on the job by covering for those on sabbatical but very hard to get tuition covered these days. Opportunity to work on leading edge technologies and a market leader. Compensation as a whole is good.
cons: New office layouts are a change for the worse, very distracting and no assigned cubes can make it hard to track down your coworkers from day to day. Base pay seems a bit lower than other tech companies.

review_title: Not the best place for mechanical engineers
pros: Salary, Large company benefits (like winning tickets to local events, company network, other young employees to have as friends), pockets of fantastic working environments (you will have to look to find them), can change jobs every year if you want internally
cons: Very unstable for being a "stable" company, re-orgs every few months, fear of "redeployment" during each and every re-org, not the best opportunities for mechanical engineers - you will be the least important engineers at the company, some groups are awful (super tight on budget, not friendly coworkers, work too many hours)

review_title: Great place to work, lovely colleagues
pros:
- Great colleagues; I've found a consistently high level of skill and work ethic.  People are friendly, with a great "how can I help?" attitude.  It's a very positive.
- Interesting work; we are solving some pretty interesting problems, and using very up-to-date tools, languages and processes to do it.
- Low staff turn-over; people like to work here.
- Good salaries and benefits
cons: As a large multi-national, it is spread across many sites.  You may need to work outside business hours and travel a little more than in some otherwise comparable roles.

review_title: Good company, just not if you're young.
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The company is at the forefront of technology in many different areas, allowing access to cutting edge pathfinding and development of new technology. The resources of a large company allow high dollar projects and collaborating across the world. Vacation time is not recorded for salaried employees and is mostly managed by the employee (and maybe his manager). Schedules are often very flexible for engineers (not technicians or FAB employees). Personal growth is encouraged and there are programs to try and help employees expand their skill set. Retirement contribution of ~5% is given annually to a 401K, regardless of the employees own contributions (i.e. not matching). Paid sabbaticals are given every 4 (additional 4 weeks) or 7 years (additional 8 weeks). That is probably the main advantage of working at Intel over similar companies in the area.
cons: Being young at Intel is very difficult. Employees are considered "new" until they've been here 10+ years and given little respect. The raise / promotion system is heavily dated and causes serious problems within groups and among peers (strict quotas for promotions and ranking employees within a group). The benefits across the board have been heavily cut over the past 5-10 years, resulting in a significantly worse overall package than before. No shuttles available at the main headquarters (to SF, San Jose, etc). Vacation is nothing special (3 weeks until 10 years, then 4), vesting for retirement contribution is incredibly long (6 years total, nothing until 2 years - 20%), and vesting for stocks is also long (4 years).

pros: Pay, benefits and compensation is average. Heard they actually pay analyst to review industry pay and target pay structure in the middle. Compared to competitors, they heavily rely on vendors which relieves a lot of equipment work from employees. This make working easy and still receive average salary. Which is a lot of pay for doing so little. Competitors require more out of their employees for this job title. Lunch breaks are extremely long for majority of manufacturing which is against corporate policy, but management allows. Less time in FAB :-) True open door policy without fear of retaliation from manager.
cons: Some people love the 12 hour shifts but not great schedule for a single parent. They promote a work life balance but it does not apply to manufacturing technicians due to non exempt status. Also promote "you own your career" philosophy but again does not apply to non exempts. Career development only applies if you want to stay in manufacturing or if an exempt. This is contrary to  new employee orientation. Focal process is a 'meritocracy' which is a great idea but not true. Focal is based more on perception of work rather than true work and contributions. Decision making process is slow rather than "small and rapid improvements' as preached. Corporate break schedule is not enforced by manufacturing management. This leaves employees abusing breaks which put a burden on the "true" workers. Probably a contributing reason that impact productivity. Especially since there's a dedicated workforce, "remote operations", to processing wafers but don't really do much but monitor screens for faults; then notifies a floor manufacturing technician. Management does not utilize remote operations manufacturing technicians, and floor technicians don't want them too. This probably is more for a sense of job security.

job_title: Capital Commodity Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great people to work with, interesting job and environment, pay is great, Sabbaticals are extra nice.
cons: Work life balance is tilted toward work, you have plenty of things to do and very little time to accomplish

pros: Large company makes for great opportunities to find a variety of job assignments in different areas of focus.  Salary is competitive in most areas.  Industry is fast-paced and exciting.  Smart, motivated people working at Intel
cons: Missed the boat on mobile and catching up.  No work/life balance.  Thick glass ceiling.  Typical Type A personalities trying to undercut each other (not always, depends on the group)

review_title: Not Good for CS people- CS guys don't join
pros:
very ethical company.
Flexible timings
upper management is good.
cons: Not good for CS people from premier institutes. There is not much SW work, CS guys can find plenty of better companies. Most of the teammates are old guys, not ready to share the knowledge. Less growth, highly unstable if you are in to mobile division.. Frequent reorganization. Less dev work in india, most of the teams are doing validation and debug work. Even though they say you can change team, practically very very difficult

job_title: Senior Electricsl Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Great place to work IF you get a good manager. Alot of smart and friendly employees, loved my team. First year was tough ramping up, in a few years its easy to learn and manage work-life balance. 
Alot of diversity, you get to enjoy different cultures. I left for family, will definitely return if my situation changed.
cons:
Alot of re-orgs. Also heard many employees were fired for no good reason.
Job insecurity increases when you go up the ladder, and this applies to both management and technical path

pros:
intel is a world class chip manufacturer enabling amazing "experiences" - respected globally
the leadership team is aware of the challenges related to the PC and are proactively trying various and unique tactics to reinvigorate the Brand in consumer eyes
lots of very smart talent at Intel
cons:
they act pretty old in terms of policy and employee engagement - trying to improve ;-(
very big company with 'big company' pains
highly political in the exec ranks - longevity usually prevails

pros: A known name, good for the resume. Some of the employees are very strong technically.
cons: Group can be divided among several sites, making it hard to know all your peers. Working environment is cold and impersonal (cubicles). People of varied technical levels and experience. A lot of the products are not very interesting. Long development cycles. For the moment, not a strong name in the software field (unlike in the hardware field).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Excellent products and structure to the broader organization; Tons of flexibility depending on the manager (the manager is key here); many opportunities to take positions anywhere around the world
cons: Company is a bit top heavy at the moment; New CEO hasn't done much to improve the situation; the result is that when you have an idea, it might require weeks and reviews by committees to even start to work on it.  There are a bunch of people with similar roles/responsibilities so it is very easy to step on people's toe's which can make it a very political place

job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Good benefits.  Sabbaticals, stock, Quarterly activities and "great place to work" events.
A large company provides opportunities to move around to different positions and locations.
cons: It's a meritocracy so your position is only as secure as your last review.  There is an expectation of continuing to expand your influence.  It is difficult to get a crisp decision.  Decisions are often made by committee although they are working to change that.

job_title: Senior BIOS Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good work environment, great benefits.
cons: POOR planning, they are thrashing now, killing profitable divisions by just not knowing where to go and what to do, in the "buy our way out" mode of big companies going down.

pros: Great benefits and competitive salaries. Nice work culture and people.
cons: A lot of favoritism. If you enjoy working in a high-school environment, this is your place. If you don't hang out at bars with managers you won't move far. Directors will tell you they want you on their team and never give you a feedback later, not even when you reach out to them.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: In any position at Intel, you will work with some pretty amazing people, make life-long friends, and have the opportunity to learn quite a lot. Health benefits are pretty much top-notch, and it seems they are making an effort to keep it that way. The ability to take a sabbatical (eight week paid leave) is a life-changing opportunity, and the new child bonding leave should set an example for all employers to follow.
cons:
From a software engineering specific position: there is no coherent career path for people who want software to be their main focus. Advancing down the technical career path at Intel, strictly speaking from a software perspective, usually means losing a huge amount of relevancy in the outside world - no companies outside of Intel need an expert in the politics and methods required to get things done within Intel. For this reason, I saw many of the most talented software folks leave after several years from fear of resume rot.

Another point to be aware of for just about everyone at Intel, assuming you are ok at your job, your quality of life will depend almost entirely on who your direct manager is - and if you don't have a good one, your life will be miserable. Even if you are exceptional at your job, your career will go nowhere without a decent manager backing you. Spend too long under a not-so-great manager, and your career will be irreparably damaged - this is not a statement of hyperbole or jest. The way the employee ratings and ranking system is arranged requires that your manager play a serious political game, and if they are unable or unwilling, you will end up stalled. "Stall" too long - even being a key contributor to a business critical project- and you will get flushed by HR - also not a joke.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Very Good Benefits.  Great people to work with--very high quality employees.
cons: Terrible environment where they are more excited about how to get rid of you than what you can do for them.  They are constantly trying to replace you with cheaper workers in "lower cost geographies".  Their "focal" process is terribly flawed--anyone can stab you in the back with no recourse on your part.  I had managers that lived very far away from me, sometimes on the other side of the planet, and you are completely dependent on your manager having a favorable opinion of you to survive the yearly review.

review_title: Good work life balance, but no company direction (New Devices Group)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great hands-off management style. Time and work location is very flexible. Salary is decent, bonuses are good. The actual work was interesting. In New Devices Group we were somewhat compartmentalized and could use more reasonable and modern collaboration tools such as confluence.
cons:
The management wants to take risks but just can't seem to commit. "Vision" is lacking and this even pollutes execution. Lower level management and employees seem to be kept in complete darkness. It seems like management will toil away behind closed doors and then pop out and give the engineers some random instructions with no association with what's really going on. We had several roadmap meetings with basically no information and immediately after each of these, the staff immediately agreed that "this is chaos" and lost faith after virtually every roadmap update. 

In all companies there is nepotism, but this group seems to be particularly bad; for example, certain team leads circumvent the normal reporting structure due to deals they made. Moreover, there are conflicting attitudes about knowledge sharing and certain teams get special treatment. This can cause repeat work and resentment between teams. Fast execution is not the organizations strong suit and it needs to be in this industry. Too many programs get started and then cancelled too close to completion and it causes discouragement and "rot" (so to speak) with the employees. Some of the cancelled products would have been great if they had just been turned around and completed quickly, marketed fast, and whether they did well or not, they would have resulted in good lessons learned. I came to the group with the expectation of fast execution and management did not deliver. 

Also, everyone is old and lame. Diversify your hiring and get a good mix in there. 

One more thing; don't force us to use crappy tools such as sharepoint. Let us use slack and confluence wikis etc. Information sharing and collaboration is tremendously enhanced by using modern tools.

review_title: Good work life balance, but no company direction (New Devices Group)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great hands-off management style. Time and work location is very flexible. Salary is decent, bonuses are good. The actual work was interesting. In New Devices Group we were somewhat compartmentalized and could use more reasonable and modern collaboration tools such as confluence.
cons:
The management wants to take risks but just can't seem to commit. "Vision" is lacking and this even pollutes execution. Lower level management and employees seem to be kept in complete darkness. It seems like management will toil away behind closed doors and then pop out and give the engineers some random instructions with no association with what's really going on. We had several roadmap meetings with basically no information and immediately after each of these, the staff immediately agreed that "this is chaos" and lost faith after virtually every roadmap update. 

In all companies there is nepotism, but this group seems to be particularly bad; for example, certain team leads circumvent the normal reporting structure due to deals they made. Moreover, there are conflicting attitudes about knowledge sharing and certain teams get special treatment. This can cause repeat work and resentment between teams. Fast execution is not the organizations strong suit and it needs to be in this industry. Too many programs get started and then cancelled too close to completion and it causes discouragement and "rot" (so to speak) with the employees. Some of the cancelled products would have been great if they had just been turned around and completed quickly, marketed fast, and whether they did well or not, they would have resulted in good lessons learned. I came to the group with the expectation of fast execution and management did not deliver. 

Also, everyone is old and lame. Diversify your hiring and get a good mix in there. 

One more thing; don't force us to use crappy tools such as sharepoint. Let us use slack and confluence wikis etc. Information sharing and collaboration is tremendously enhanced by using modern tools.

review_title: Great Benefits in a Corporate Jungle
pros:
- Benefits are top notch.  Dental, vision, medical + other insurances
- Decent pay
- Flexible hours
- Again, benefits. Stock bonuses everywhere
- Nice work environment (cubes, desks, cafeterias)
cons:
- Annual Focal Performance Review, straight up 'prove you're worthy of not getting laid off'
- Upper management sometimes doesn't know what it's trying to do, the individual contributors suffer.
- Business needs come before the individual, again the individual suffers and your career might take a nosedive in a different direction than intended.  This was a con for me.
- Lots of employee turnover (at least in my organization)
- Corporate politics, gets in the way of progress and creates a toxic work environment
- Mobility within and outside of the company can get skewered by all the different roles and tasks they might have you do turning you into a jack of all trades and master of none
- It can get stressful when they have you perform multiple roles and wear multiple hats to get the job done. 
- Sometimes organizational managers within the company will hire people into an organization under a hidden veil, never fully disclosing what exactly or where exactly someone will end up in the organization.  This can make for a disappointing and undesired 'trial by fire'
- Too many stressed out and irritable people, can make for a negative place to work
- Too many acronyms, we could start another language on all the acronyms we use

review_title: Good salary and benefits; cold culture
pros: It's a feat to include Intel on your resume, and the benefits and compensation (including, at certain levels and above, stock awards) are great.
cons: The culture is cold and people can be harsh with one another. I advise workers to plan to stay a few years while still under age 40, get some good experience and project successes, then move on. This is not a good place to plan to have a long-term career. The older you get, the greater your risk of being booted.

pros: The company is involved in many fields and technologies, there are many opportunities and interesting projects. The COE's vision to make Intel a "data company" is very compelling and it would be great for Intel if the company will be able to deliver.
cons: Tech stack is not updated fast enough in some organizations. Duplication across the company create ego battles and waste. People sometimes have hard time leaving their comfort zone (at least comparing to what you would expect in a tech company that is trying to move fast).

job_title: Systems Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Big brand name on your resume
- $0 high ded. health insurance and 90% paid by plan until deductible is met. 
- 401 k contribution without employee contribution. But vesting starts only after 2nd year of employment.
- Better work-life balance,
- Horizontal movement to other teams is encouraged and is possible if planned well.
- Lay-offs happen, but at least Intel is more compassionate about it and gives 90 days to find a job inside, which many people end up doing and this save their jobs. Also severance packages are great for long term Intel employees.
cons:
- Big democratic company, decision making is extremely slow at almost all levels
- In absence of any timeline pressures this is the best place I have worked for in my career. But  throw in some project deadlines, things just change upside-down and org politics shows its ugly face. Most of the people in these situations try to save the jobs in the next Op-ex rather than helping each other out.
- Information is the king in this company. The more one knows about where to get it and who to get it from matters more than an acquired technical or business skill. So people new to the company often struggle.
- Below par base salary in the industry. It may not be the same case for engineers especially working in the areas Intel has its vision in (Self- driving, AI etc), but for most of the support functions like IT and HR for instance, compensation is not competitive. 
- So many managers! Most of the managers I have seen are pure people managers and do not have in-depth technical or business knowledge to contribute in critical projects.  If that's the only job a manager has, unfortunately many of them don't do it well. I attribute the reason of this to institutionalization. People just get so used to the culture which is not really modern and forward-looking. May be Intel can take a leaf out of new-gen companies like FB or Google in this regard.
- Its hard to get a true feeling of belonging in this company. Its huge and there are so many people who are not co-located but work in the same teams, people just work in emotional/professional silos.
- Blurry visibility on career growth. Like I said it is easier to move horizontally but not vertically. At the most people tend to get grade jumps but even those are not without a lot of political ground-work, infighting and unpredictable.

In short, I would not hesitate to work for Intel, but I would always be on the look out for the grass on the other side and will jump ship at the first decent opportunity without thinking a lot.

review_title: a great company, tons of development, best days ahead
pros:
- strong meritocracy- you get rewarded for delivering impact 
- Ability to go deep and add breadth to your career experiences 
- inclusive culture; willingness to collaborate; almost anyone will give you time for a 1:1
- flexibility and ability to live somewhere other than the bay area 
- great comp and benefits 
- work with smart and talented leaders and employees
- work is challenging and engaging
cons:
- talent isn't consistent throughout the org 
- the workload can be heavy, at times
- some of the cynical employees can get you down

review_title: Great people and technical challenges; poor senior leadership
job_title: Senior Analog Design Engineer in DuPont, WA
pros:
Excellent salary, bonus, RSU, health insurance and other benefits.
Work with some of the smartest people in the world.
Leading edge of technology development.
cons: Senior leadership is poor; no longer have technical capability, only chase after profits.

review_title: Great place to work. Innovation restricted by job secure majority.
job_title: R&D Packaging Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Excellent teamwork on majority of projects. Professional and respectful colleagues. Decent pay compared to the competition.
cons: Many people are just qualified enough to do the job and do not contribute towards growth of the company. Highly skilled leave the company within 2-3 years. What's left over is a company that grows very slowly.

review_title: Great place to start your career and end your career, not so great in the middle
pros:
* Plenty of learning opportunities, especially for starting out in your career.
* Easy to switch groups and try new things.
* Great work culture, especially among engineers. The thing I miss most about my time at Intel was the people I worked with. 
* Some very talented people to learn from.
* Reasonable compensation (not super competitive, but average-ish) depending on location. Avoid the Bay Area location, unless you aren't planning on staying long term.
cons:
* Highly political, especially as you get more seniority in the company. Some groups are worse about this than others. Towards the end of my stint at Intel, most of my week was spent in meetings trying to manage expectations, reporting on workflow efficiencies / inefficiencies to management, and arguing with other teams on behalf of my team.
* Raises and promotion are not truly merit based; your success in the company depends on being on the right projects, in the right groups, and being able to sell yourself to management.
* There are some truly great engineers at Intel. However, in larger organizations at Intel, management tends to try and fill positions as quickly as possible (or risk losing headcount). This results in there being a lot of engineers that don't have the skill set needed to do their jobs well, which can be very frustrating.
* Numerous 'big personality' types at Intel. These are usually very senior and principle engineers that have been in organizations for a while. They are easy to identify; their names will come up in conversations when discussing new ideas, usually in fear that the 'big personality' will come down from their high altar in the mountains and smite anyone that doesn't conform. Often these people bring little value to the organization, but they've managed to hold the organization hostage due to their long term presence and 'wisdom'.

review_title: Intel is truly a rewarding place to work both in the exciting technology employees work with and in compensation.
job_title: Design Engineering Manager in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Intel is a very advanced technology company.  It's very exciting to be working on the latest and greatest technology and on things that you know people all over the world will be using on a daily basis.  Intel is a company filled with very smart engineers and it is refreshing to consistently be working with the best in the industry.  The work is very difficult, but successful engineers thrive in that environment. Intel also has a dominant market share now, and it is rewarding to be working for a company that wins.  Base compensation is market competitive, and the bonus structure makes overall cash compensation better than market in good years.  They have very progressive health benefits that are some of the best in the industry.
cons: Intel is very compartmentalized.  It is difficult to learn from other organizations.  In an 86,000 employee company, this can be frustrating - one knows that other people have probably solved or at least encountered your problems in the past, but it is hard to find those people.  Additionally, the culture at Intel is relatively direct and for certain people this confrontational style can be intimidating.  In certain organizations (notably IT), morale is currently low because they have experienced significant cuts in their headcount.

job_title: Information Technology Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: community of very smart people. It's an environment were highly motivated people will succeed if they can ignore bureaucracy and the occasional bits of incompetence from some seemingly disconnected senior management.
cons: rare bits of incompetence from senior management.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hudson, MA
pros: Intel has a very good reputation. Being No. 1 chipmaker, Intel has a strong strength (money and people) in the R&D section, and thus generates a lot of excellent products, including software products, for example IPP and Intel compiler. Most managers are pretty flexible about the work times as long as you finish your jobs.
cons: You need to work very hard, but sometimes you did not get enough attention (recognition and promotion) if your job was not in high profile area. Also Intel does have the monopoly behaviors in giving the rebate based on percentage instead of volume for customers during the competition with AMD.

review_title: Intel is slowly changing and becoming a 'fun' company to join.  It just depends on the group you join.
job_title: Senior Device Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The top two reasons for working at Intel is, the people and the opportunities.  Intel still houses some of the industry best engineers and it's open door policy allows one to really grow.  Secondly, Intel with it's size offers many opportunities.  It's not difficult to move from group to another.   The caveat is that you have to pick the right group.
cons:
The main downside to working for Intel is the amount of the bureaucracy that is needed to get things done and even worse to get changes implemented.  It is such a challenge to inject new ideas that one is often resigned to accepting what management wants.  At times it's even easier and rewarded to just 'go along' with management.

Further, Intel's total compensation package is no longer on par with the other companies in Silicon Valley.  RSUs and stock options are a significant part of the compensation package but if the stock is not performing to expectations, Intel must revise their compensation and reward system in order to retain their talent as well as reward employees for stick with Intel.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The best reason to work at Intel is for the opportunity to work on truly cutting edge technology.  There are numerous interesting and challenging projects to work on.  Intel also highly encourages employees who are getting burned out or bored at their current job to seek another job within Intel.  This is a benefit from my opinion in that you are able to always stay in a job that is entertaining and challenging.  Another good thing about Intel are the health benefits.  Though like everywhere they have increased in cost over the last few years, they have helped me and my family significantly throughout my years of working there.
cons: I think the biggest downside of Intel would be the lack of recognition for effort and the complete recognition for delivery.  This means that it is extremely important to ensure that you are personally involved in projects that are well funded and have the support of management.  If you end up in a position that does not have that, advancement and recognition will both be difficult.  It also has the potential to reward people who merely happen to be in the right place at the right time versus those produce the best and most complete solutions.  Another downside of Intel is that they tend to pay on the low end of the industry average.  Something else to keep in considersation is that Intel is a silicon manufacturing company.  And as such, they always have their focus on hardware development and manufacturing.  This can result in less importance being attributed to other areas that the company works in (i.e. Software Development).

review_title: Intel: the best and the worst, depending on your priorities
job_title: Senior Process and Equipment Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: If you make good contributions you are usually recognized.  There are opportunities to really test yourself and your capabilities due to the very challenging environment - it's the New York City of places to work: if you can make it at Intel you can make it anywhere.  Pay is very good if you stay long enough; the relatively new switch from stock options to restricted stock options (RSU's) are excellent (for Engineers), like another bonus (on top of the annual big EB and the semi-annual ECBP bonuses.  The bonuses are very good (for Engineers).  Also important is that the large bonuses (and some say low salaries) allow big compensation in good years and job preservation in bad years.  Intel does not lay off engineers - no layoffs during the dot com bubble burst.  Very little politics - people don't have time for it.  Arguments are based on data, not personalities for the most part (though there are always some bad personalities like everywhere).  Intel is also quite serious about business ethics, green philosophy and safety.
cons: Very stressful work if you work in a fab plant.  Very large responsibility, workload and very high expectations.  (But gratifying when you're handling it.  Will build self-pride and confidence.)  Constant incoming work from multiple directions that requires superior time management.  Feels like you're on call 24/7.  Difficult to make good work-life balance.  Some Engineering Group Leaders seem to favor process engineers over equipment engineers.  (My annual performance rating seemed to sometimes be based on who my boss was rather than my performance; the same performance would get OK/Good rating from some GL's and high raves from others.)

review_title: Great place to work if you have a decent manager.
pros:
Assuming you have a good manager it is fairly easy to get time off when needed, and rewards for accomplishments come with the work (though sometimes you have to be blunt and ask).  The pay is reasonable, the benefits are good.  Two of the nicest perks are:
1) profit sharing.  Intel places a percentage of your income into a 401K for you even if you don't contribute.  This is better than matching.  Usually it's between 4 and 9% of your annual income.
2) Sabbatical.  Every 7 years employees get 2 months off, not part of vacation or sick leave.  You have to take it all at once, which is great because you manager has to give it to you all in one lump.
cons:
If you don't have a good manager (sadly my case now) rewards are virtually non existent.
Having had 7 managers in the last 10 years I can say it is really a crap shoot how good your manager is going to be.  Once you transfer groups you are obligated to stay at least a year in that position before you can transfer again.  Hop around till you find a good manager, even if the job isn't 'perfect' then stay with that manager no matter what.
There have been instances of a manager leaving one division and moving to a new division and their entire team following them within the year.
Finally:
There are three castes of employees at Intel.
Green Badge contract employee
Blue badge general full time non exempt
Blue badge exempt (engineers and managers)
transitioning between these castes can be difficult.

pros:
1. Perfect  work life balance
2. ability to grow professionally good
3. Opportunities for learning new technologies
4. Ability to work on cutting edge technologies
5. Awesome benefits
cons:
1. Compensation is on the lower side 
2. If you dont negotiate a good salary when you join Intel dont expect too much growth in compensation especially when you are in a business unit which is more mature
3. very competitive environment, so tough to grow.. too much competition for fewer dollars increase

review_title: Great Place to work but very demanding
pros: You get to work on very exciting products in a fast changing environment that rewards success. You can get lots of responsibility quickly and your career is yours to manage.  The meek or lazy are quickly moved out of the company.
cons: Constant high pressure to perform.  You are only as good as your current performance rating.  You can easily have a long and stellar career but be let go due to a single performance review rating that is largely dictated by your manager.

review_title: I will work for half the salary at any other company
pros: The salary is pretty competitive. Also, the stocks and bonus option is good. It gives a good opportunity to work in a cutting edge technology.
cons:
Intel’s work culture is based on the book written by Andrew S. Grove titled “Only the paranoid survive”. Intel HR policies and management promotes this culture of paranoia in every employee of Intel. Per Wikipedia “Paranoia is a thought process heavily influenced by anxiety or fear, often to the point of irrationality and/or delusion. Paranoid thinking typically includes persecutory beliefs concerning a perceived threat towards oneself. Historically, this characterization was used to describe any delusional state.” 

As far as what I have seen, this kind of practice of making employees paranoia has made many or most Intel employees unhappy. In addition to the three letter abbreviations used at Intel, there are many other phrases used at Intel such as “slap on the face”. Simple things such as someone asking you a question while you are explaining to a group is “Slap on the face” since you did not do your job well enough to explain properly. I totally disagree with this kind of philosophy and it leads to a culture of un-openness. 
Simply asking your manager a question on his/her direction or suggesting some alternative solution which is better could get you labeled as “difficult”. Why? Because first of all, if your manager agrees to your suggestion, it would imply that your manager was wrong or did not think through. As such, your manager would fiercely fight back to any suggestions which are contrary to what your manager thinks. Secondly, your manager suggestions might be based on his/her politics or anger towards someone else which your manager could not explain to you properly. I once found mistake that someone else did which could have cost up couple of days of downtime and when I told my manager, she responded that this is not what I asked you to do and rebuked me. The person who made the mistake actually thanked me for finding that mistake. So, I also think that a lot depends on who your manager is. Some manager wants you to do exactly what you are told without thinking but the problem is when things go wrong, you get all the blame since you did not think it thoroughly. Makes sense, no.. right? Welcome to the world of paranoia… enjoy working at Intel!

review_title: Great place to learn, grow, work.
pros:
At Intel your career is really what you make of it. If you put in the time and energy to learn and succeed, and express your interests in where you want to go to your manager, you will almost always have the support to help get you there. Continuing education is well supported (both through work/life balance and through reimbursement in some cases). Opportunities to do rotations and explore new fields/roles are abundant.

One thing that I like that may be a deterrant for some people is the very direct culture: People will tell you if they think your idea needs work, but the culture is very data driven and you work with some very smart people. As long as you support your position with data and logic you will pretty much always be fine. 

Work/life balance flexibility is great - 1 day work from home per week, other flexible hours options upon manager approval. Can't complain about the flexibility. In terms of work - to be successful you need to take on a lot of work, and it can be stressful at times, but if you like a challenge it can be pretty awesome.
cons:
Compensation is my biggest gripe: I've taken full advantage of the rotation opportunities to learn and grow, but with each new role you need to 'put in your time' - as in longevity, not effort - to get the promo. As such, I don't feel like my compensation reflects my experience, education, level of responsibility, or the value I bring to the company any more.

Pay is allegedly based on merit, but I have not seen much evidence for it. You have to earn your promo several years in a row before you'll get it... If you're also buddy buddy with your manager. 

We like to make things hard on ourselves at times and need to invent a new tool for everything - even when there's a good off-the-shelf or previously created solution that could be easily adapted.

review_title: Excellent benefits, ok base salaries, excellent onsite perks...but work life balance is HIGHLY dependent on your group.
pros: Base salary is ok, health benefits are excellent, and you get 8 weeks paid sabbatical every 7 years (though many people think that is too long to wait).  The onsite perks are fabulous:  onsite spas, salon, fitness centers, banking, dry cleaning, etc.  Communication from upper upper management is excellent.  Intel practices an open door policy of communication which I've found to be consistent across many divisions.  Safety is a high priority, especially if you are working in fab or sort.
cons:
Work life balance depends 100% on your manager and the particular group you work for.  Even within the same fab, how groups are managed vary GREATLY.  If you are lucky, you are in a group whose managers value WL balance so you may only work 50 hrs/wk.  Otherwise, you will work 80-90 hrs/wk for years on end.  And of course this varies greatly from site to site - New Mexico seems to work the least and Oregon by far works the most.  

If you are good at your job, you will receive praise and recognition, but you will be expected to do it forever.  It is very easy to become pigeonholed into a solitary role for many years.  You need to actively seek out new opportunities to widen your skill base because Intel won't do that for you.  In fab/sort the ONLY way to be promoted to a manger is if your DIRECT manager leaves Intel or moves to another group, and you are the senior engineer in the group.  By default, you will be promoted.  There is no annoucement, no call for applicants.  You could be a senior engineer in one group for 10 years and be excellent at what you do...but someone with far fewer years and experience and awards will be promoted to manager simply because their manager left to do something else.  The promotion system is incredibly unfair.

pros:
In context of an engineer working in fabrication:
When you work at Intel, you're working with smart people. You'll be given responsibility fast - so fast that you may feel a little scared being responsible for so many millions - or billions - of dollars of revenue. However, while *you* are responsible, you have a great support system - a lot of people and systems around you to help. I've always found people at Intel very helpful - if you ask someone for help, you will get it.Decisions are all data-driven - the first step is always to gather data -- an if a problem is urgent, to expedite the gathering of the data. Data and model-based problem solving are used extensively. At the engineering level in the fab, there is little "politics" - due to the data-driven decision making. 
Safety is the #1 priority in a fab - and the management sincerely promotes this - and backs it up with dollars to make safety improvement inside the factory and office areas (especially ergonomic equipment).
Skills that will help you in the fab are knowledge of extracting data from databases, statistics, and data analysis with JMP. A little programming knowledge will help you as well.
People at Intel don't like to finish second. Intel likes to win. Intel demands to be the champion. The way Intel achieves victory is by moving faster than anyone else - speed is the key competitive advantage.
cons:
You're likely to feel a little "overloaded" at Intel, at least at first. I feel like I'm always 2X overloaded (but I'm used to it now). You can have a good work-life balance; on the other hand, if you like to work a lot, Intel will take that and put it in its pocket. 
Management is promoted from the engineering ranks. This has is good and bad. On the good side, they understand your job and can help you. On the bad side, the managers can focus too much on the problem of the day and not on longer term things like people development, career coaching, and other "softer" management functions. So plan on taking charge of your own career.
Intel used to shower us with cash - mainly from stock options. Those days are over - the stock has been stagnant for over 10 years. 
You'd think that being at Intel, you'd have access to some of the best computer equipment in the world. You'd be wrong. You'll get a "business class" laptop, which is not good for engineering data analysis. However, with enough push, you can get a high performance desktop system.

review_title: Great company, great people, great products, occasionally a bit too corporate.
pros: Good pay, good benefits, relative autonomy day-to-day (depending on your manager), easy access to management when needed, they take care of you if you plan on staying long-term, and it seems pretty straightforward to move around internally if you want to find a better fit.
cons: Laziness with respect to programming practice and discipline, there doesn't seem to be a sense of professional pride about day-to-day programming tasks, hierarchical structure makes for organizational confusion and feelings of disconnection between teams.

review_title: Plenty of opportunity to make your mark at an industry leader .  Everybody is valued and Intel is looking for leaders.
pros:
I love working at Intel.  Everybody is valued and Intel has a keen understanding that the corporation will benefit when the employees are happy. 

In my time at Intel I was given many opportunities and I learned about different items in every year of my employment.   When I had small children I was able to give my family more time and when I was willing to work harder many opportunities opened up.
cons: Not much for cons from me.

review_title: People & product oriented company, but senior management is losing touch
job_title: Senior Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Culture and value system extremely ethical and disciplined
They treat you with respect.
Flexible work-life balance.
Data/research driven environment
Product & team oriented, not politically oriented
Management encourage you to seek resume-building skills and experience
Your co-workers & management by and large will become your friends.
Job security.
Equity offered across the board, including administrators.
cons:
Needs to think offensively
Quick to kill new ideas that will not immediately generate billions in gross revenue
Intel feels that hardware can influence the platform.  Those days are gone.  Intel needs to adapt and influence higher up in the stack.
Does not act decisively on poor performers
Marginal management gets recycled through the company like a good ol boys club.
Company rank & file is getting older and out of touch with Millenials, not sure if Intel is a cool place to work anymore for recent college grads.
With the exception of a few individual experts, very little industry expertise outside of hardware, PCs, data centers and security.

review_title: Such great potential, resources, and people encumbered by past success.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is light years of the competition in the areas of semiconductor process engineering and manufacturing. And some of the best people I have encountered in the hardware and SOC development areas. For hardware engineering, and software to a lesser degree, offers amazing resources and challenges for a technical contributor. Has interesting and challenging problems to solve. If you get in the right group can really be a great experience. BK and most of the exec staff have a true appreciation of people and creating a good work environment. Good benefits. Physical work environment for me was good (1970s era cubicles with separate lab space), but rapidly converting to mobile work environment which is *horrible* for technical/knowledge workers.
cons:
Big, slow, encumbered by past success, unable to move crisply and decisively to take advantage of opportunities. New experienced execs brought in to build new agile organizations only succeed in building self-serving fiefdoms. 

I came to Intel after having worked at several start-ups (I had also been a Founder in the past). Very, very bureaucratic - one spends 90% of your time justifying your existence and 10% doing actual work. Intel has a disease prevalent at many large aging organizations that are coasting on past success: information hoarding and herds of people spending time guarding their turf. In a start-up environment I spent a lot of time working with colleagues to get things done. At Intel I spent too much time justifying what I was doing, and why working to address other orgs fears that I (and my org) would encroach on their turf. Very depressing.

My first two levels of management (immediate supervisor and Director) were horrible - long time Intel employees who managed me remotely and had no clue about what I should be doing, and what I was doing. THis despite proactive weekly status reports from me. I don't think my immediate manager ever read any status reports I sent. After I left Intel I also found out he also failed to pass along any mgt feedback requests from HR.

review_title: Great company with internal political issues
pros:
There are great benefits to working at Intel.  With the right manager, work is extremely flexible allowing you to maintain an excellent work-life balance.  When I need to handle something at home, my manager and coworkers have no issues stepping in to carry the load while I'm out.  Likewise I'm there to help when my coworkers need it.

There are also a lot of little perks such as raffles from the "Great Place to Work" team where you can win tickets to movies, sporting events, concerts, etc.  There are a number of fun activities planned by individual teams and entire sites to celebrate or just get to know each other better.  One great activity that just completed was a kid's day where we could bring in our kids for fun science and technology events all day.  My son loved it.

Overall, the work environment when you have found the right team is very enjoyable.
cons:
The most difficult thing for me about working here are the politics.  Unfortunately within the leadership and management layers, there are a lot of entrenched folks that seem more interested in promoting their own career than in doing the right thing for the company.  Because of this, I have seen some terrible decisions made that set the entire company back and took many months to recover, but there was no accountability held to the decision maker for this.

It can be very frustrating to be passed up on a promotion only to see someone less deserving but more politically savvy promoted instead.

review_title: Great people.  Great technology and facilities.  Great pay.  Being on-call is horrible.
pros: I love all the people I work with.  They are incredibly intelligent and they challenge me, yet they are really fun to work with.  I like the challenge of learning everyday, and I get to work on some of the best semiconductor technology in the world.  The pay is great.
cons: Being on call was one of the most challenging experiences of my life.  For me, work-life balance is not possible at Intel.

job_title: Maintenance Technicican in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: On-Site Medical Clinic, Bank, Gyms. Great pay and benefits.
cons: Will toss you easily when they don't need you. Regardless of how well you worked. Its a HR decision based nothing on job performance. Favorable criteria is given to those who are hired locally then if you were an out of state hire (Facility must be staff 60% with NM residents).  Not necessarily are the best people kept in a RIF.  The new CEO BK is a burn it to the ground and operate more with less type of personality. Intel will place profit over people!

review_title: Stagnant after 2-3 years if not moving around or got the right managers. Re-org is an everyday thing
pros: Good respect for all employees, good working values, intangible benefits are OK.
cons: Grade level expectation is too much for too little pay. Training and personal growth are very dependant on who your manager is. Changing boss every year is a norm here and expect to affect badly on your performance for the year

review_title: Stagnant after 2-3 years if not moving around or got the right managers. Re-org is an everyday thing
pros: Good respect for all employees, good working values, intangible benefits are OK.
cons: Grade level expectation is too much for too little pay. Training and personal growth are very dependant on who your manager is. Changing boss every year is a norm here and expect to affect badly on your performance for the year

pros:
1. It provides you opportunities to work on challenging designs, cutting edge technologies
2. Lots of employee benefits which I liked
3. Work life balance is good for most part of the year except for aggressive deadlines
cons:
1. Salaries are not upto the market. There could be certainly lot of improvements done
2. Lots of organizational level changes which need to be minimized
3. Lot of time taken for decision making which could be optimized further

pros: I have worked for small employers and large employers. I will say from experience that large employers usually offer more benefits overall and Intel is the best. Great people, great atmosphere, great learning opportunities, great room for advancement, an overall great place to work.
cons: The only con i would give Intel is the annual budget structure for each location is independent of the others. This plays a role and creates an uneven site based bonus structure.

review_title: Great technical challenges and engineers; poor middle-management and corporate bureaucracy
pros: I love the opportunity to contribute to advance computer designs.  Every couple years we are doubling performance and features, which results in a faster Internet and more services to improve society.
cons: Intel is still thinking inside-out with its design practices.  We need to understand our customers better and work from the outside-in.

review_title: Great benefits but limited upward mobility
job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Flexible hours
Work from home
Market comparable compensation
Minimal stress
cons:
You are one of the thousands of employees ... just like any large company
There  are too many people who have been at the company for 20, 25 and 30 years. So your chances of getting into a management role are slim
Promotions etc. depend not just on your performance but also on budget allocation, re-org status, etc. even if company is making billions. So you don't just have to be good, you need to be lucky too

job_title: Technology Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: There are great engineers to work with, the pay is above average and benefits good.  There is also a certain amount of notoriety in the industry for someone working in the technology development part of Intel.
cons: You don't really get to decide where they put you.  If you are unlucky you will get stuck with a group or project that is at a major disadvantage compared to other groups and will consequently be a major burden until the next technology node is reached. There is no work-life balance.  Intel owns you 24/7. Vacations are permitted but not without a penalty before or after you leave.  Management style is very archaic.  Feedback from any employee in manufacturing is disregarded because the "if it isn't broken, don't fix it" philosophy prevails among those in upper management.  They pay you 20% more than average but expect 100% more of your time than other companies (80-120 hrs/week is common).

pros: Competitive salaries, strong healthcare and employee benefit programs, access to leading edge technology projects, Global, excellent employee/career development resources & programs
cons: Many company/group level re-organizations every 1-2 years. Strong Work at Work policy with no regular flexibility for telecommuting. Employee collaboration technologies do not support effective telecommuting or other flexible work arrangements.

review_title: Very bureacratic and control freak company
pros: Technology producing company, a well-known brand "Intel inside". If you have affinity with technology, you will like the products. Product roadmap is well-planned.
cons: Process oriented, no room for creativity or for someone who does not share the established thoughts, shared culture is not intrinsic but more due to freaking controls and "sticks". Working for Intel is like working at George Orwell's dystopia.

job_title: Product Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good technical work, learning opportunities, benefits, RCG compensation, flexible vacation. Tuition reimbursement makes this a great company to start at, and then leave once you have a degree for a higher paying alternative.
cons: Has been reducing benefits, shorts employees' compensation during recessions and never makes up for it, not a meritocracy, changing roles can be extremely difficult, no stock options, RCUs vest over a significant amount of time. Intel does not increase your pay or even encourage new roles if you qualifications change (master's degree, certs, etc).

review_title: great company, some groups have poor work-life balance
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
1. Intel is making industry-leading technology.
2. Good Compensation / benefits package
cons:
- In many groups, work-life balance is not respected. Upper management leads by example and works very hard, this is to be commended. The flip side is - direct reports feel the need to do the same, so whole groups and departments share the "burnt out" feeling.

- too many meetings, and they are too large and too long, this leaves little time for real work.

job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Widely known products. Industry leader in many areas. Your friends and family might recognize the results of your labor.
Wide range of interests. You can probably find what you're interested in being done somewhere within Intel.
There are definitely some extremely talented engineers working at Intel, and the general competency level is good.
cons:
Lots of organizational and corporate overhead. Regular shuffling and reorganization. Training requirements that never seem to add real value. Carousel of workflow and project management systems: Lean, Agile, ...
Corporate strategy sometimes feels disconnected from projects: Staffing and funding doesn't match published priorities.
Always too much to do and not enough time.

pros: Good pay when on shift. Learn a lot about manufacturing. Will work with many different areas and get an good overall understanding of manufacturing process.
cons:
Too much internal politics. The harder you work, the more likely some manager will criticize your performance. 
Huge turnover in staff. Conflicting work duties and priorities from management causes unnecessary disruption to work performance. Work life balance is poor.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Plenty of opportunities for challenging and interesting roles and projects working with some amazingly talented people from all over the world. World class learning culture which drives for excellence in all areas. Decent wages and bonuses.
cons:
No different to any other global hi-tech company....if you can't handle constant stress, change & long hours, don't apply :-) (Work Life Effectiveness is a distant dream)

"C'est la vie": companies exist to make ever increasing profits for their shareholders...your performance, no matter how good and for how many years, does not equate to job security when the lottery of massive layoffs come around every few years...

pros: Stable, Meaningful Work, decent perks, friendly environment. Typical positives of a corporation I would imagine. Less oversight, ability to use a portion of your time to follow other passions.
cons: The caliber of people is not always the highest. Because of less oversight, there are people who slack and leave work to get picked up by other people.

job_title: Transition Change Management Lead in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Salary - Intel Corporation is a giant in the tech environment, so due to its high profit margins, salaries tend to run pretty high.  
Physical work environment - The company has "Googlized" their physical working environments with dynamic, open work spaces, meeting rooms and lounges.   It can be noisy, but I find them supportive and collaborative .    
Health Benefits - Intel also offers a strong benefit package and managing those benefits - from your PC - can be easy as well.     
Diversity - The company has taken a strong stance on encouraging diversity and equal pay for women.
cons:
Work hours - Since Intel has a worldwide presence, many managers (but not all) expect  their employees to work outside 9-5 hours for meetings with other regions.  A few years ago, the company pushed work a more forgiving work/life balance, but those days are gone b/c of the new CEO.
Long hours - Long workdays are expected, and as part of the culture, checking email and performing other work occur in the evenings. 
Crying Poverty - Intel frequently takes spending actions to reduce expenses and enacts layoffs and moving jobs overseas.   It is kind of amazing for a company that makes billions and billions of $, but I called it "Intel constantly cries poverty".  
Raises/Promotions - Significant raises and promotions rarely happen unless the employee takes the initiative to actually apply for a position outside of his/her group.  Big raises and promotions will not happen based on one's own merit of working hard.   My biggest advice is anyone at Intel is don't stay in a job or a group for more than 2-3 years and make every move a new job promotion.   You can be wildly successful at Intel, if you don't get comfortable  at one position.

pros: Excellent Benefits, bonuses, salary, challenging work
cons: PTD management is filled with sociopath's who are not qualified to do their job.  Bob Swan is legit though and I have faith he can do great things.

job_title: Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is a good place to work at if you want to stay on one track, and don't plan on being very ambitious.  Work life balance is decent most of the time.
cons: People in different organizations rarely even try to understand or engage with employees in other teams. As an engineer, I tried to get a low level marketing position, but was told engineers are not creative enough. I think the reason Intel struggles so much is because there are far too many employees that refuse to have growth mindsets, even when given a chance. This attitude is EVERYWHERE.

pros: Very diverse and Global company with lots of opportunities to learn new things and contribute at the same time.  Allows you to take risk in your tasks, while at the same time to improve from the mistakes.  You can easily move from one site to the other given the opportunity and positions open for you.
cons: Very difficult to highlight your contribution in such large organization if you are at the bottom of the hierarchy without having a good network with your direct hierarchy and management.

review_title: Experience as a student hire - 7 mo.
job_title: Manufacturing Engineering Coop in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good pay, challenging environment. Just an all around good, competitive environment. I worked here for 7 months as a student hire, and it was an excellent experience. I would recommend it to any engineer with even a small interest in the industry.
cons: Frequent staff changes, relocations, etc. Many employees become jaded from the constant changes at Intel and the entire industry. It's definitely not like working for the government -- but if you don't like it, I suggest that you don't work in the tech industry.

review_title: Great firm and culture, especially in these hard times
job_title: Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I have a very flexible schedule and top notch colleagues around me to continue learning from.  A company like Intel is a pleasure to work for in these tough times.
cons: The company can be somewhat bureaucratic at times.  Working for a smaller, more flexible start-up would could be a better fit for some, but the gap between the two may be smaller than some would expect.

pros:
Good pay
Good benefits
Excellent work/life balance
Had some great managers
Great development programs
Excellent support while I was working on a master's degree
Some really great people
cons: Too many chiefs, not enough Indians.  There were some efforts to reduce layers of management, but they didn't really stick.  I worked at a small site and a lot of the corporate culture didn't make it to our location.

review_title: Great place to start career, and even continue for a long time afterwards
pros: Lots of engineering opportunities in many product development areas, especially software. high importance given to fresh ideas by a supportive management structure, starting with first level managers. only limit to growing at Intel is individual's drive to network and sense of learning. company contributes yearly profit sharing to employees' 401k.
cons: very large company and hence lot of competition. a yearly performance review based on relative meritocracy and not an individual's sole performance. only top 15% in a review group get ~10% salary hike; the rest get a measely 2-3%.

review_title: They are trying their best but work is boring and one feels small and insignificant
job_title: Senior Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Turns out they are one of the best places as salary and benefits. A stable place Intel still in a very good financial position.
cons: One feels lost between so many thousands of employees. Intel is also a very conservative place when it comes to trying new things. I can understand that, as there is a lot at stake. Not much opportunity to creativity.

review_title: Great Company to Work For, No Extremes, Reliable and Consistent
pros: Great values, history, people and compensation.  They value meritocracy, with an emphasis on data and not politics.  If you don't like your job, they have many others and encourage changing jobs as much as you want.
cons: Can be a little bland and very specific to your group.  Doesn't have the "wow" effect that a Google or Apple may offer, but the core work-life is superb.

review_title: Once great, the company is sliding into irrelevancy.
pros: People are smart and mature and often a pleasure to work with.  Work-life balance is mostly good, though recently a lot of groups went with "no working from home" policy.
cons: The company is so big, it is impossible to make a change.  A lot of time is spent on creating and re-creating slides.

review_title: Great place to work, just need to find the correct group and role
pros: Great people, good benefits and pay.  Must be willing to work hard in order to advance.
cons: currently it is hard to advance due to job cuts, pay rasises have been minimal the last few years for Technicians and starting engineers.  It seems every few years there are job cuts and you have to worry if you will be affected.  Senority does not matter for advancement or for getting released.

review_title: Excellent employee friendly company to start work with.
pros: culture, values, freedom, innovation and work place benefits
cons: don't expect growth beyond certain point, vertical growth especially. All the decision making roles sit at US and more moving towards US.

review_title: Open Culture, Freedom, Respect and Lot to learn. You own your career.
pros: Good Leadership in most areas of technology, as well as respect between peers. High possibility of innovation and freedom at work, cutting edge technology, work-life balance potential. Good and standard policies across the board are things you rarely find in other organizations.
cons: too many meetings(phew), over collaboration, red tapism (large org pitfalls, decision has to go through reviews after review no matter small or big). Long time to turn around in case of issues.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good work life balance, good pay, great benefits, Free items in cafeteria.  Intel tries and has teams to make Intel a great place to work.  It is still a job though.  Some groups are better than others so find a good organization.  The manager helps work your development plan with you.
cons: I didn't get a promotion in 14 years.  Make sure and job change within the company - I think that is where I went wrong.  I would have liked to see more job advancement.

review_title: Intel is inspiring and a place for constant growth
