Total Compensation is very competitive. Intel offers great health benefits with lots of alternatives to choose from.  401k contributions are not matched, but Intel will contribute a certain percentage of your salary to your 401k regardless of your contributions.  Bonuses come regularly. The amount will vary depending on profitability of the company, but you can almost count on them.
cons:
Everyone has a cubicle. Thinks makes your working environment extremely susceptible to noise and other distractions.  The cubes are small (6ft x 8ft for most people) compounding the interruption possibilities. 

Base Pay (what most people look at in compensation) is lower than a lot of other companies out there. If you don't have an "on top of it" manager, you and your entire team will get overlooked for significant raises. 

Some of the best benefits for working for Intel are also part of its downside. Large companies don't always respond well to changes in the marketplace. Besides that, its hard to find a parking spot when your competing with a few thousand other people.

review_title: Intel from a Professional Technicians Perspective
pros: Overall the benefits of health care, vacation and paid time off were very good. Their 401K was excellent for giving freedom to invest in several options.
cons: Intel fails to look at the person as a total package and in many ways refuses to understand how can a person strengthen an organization. My interview process was 2 telephone calls of 20 minutes and I was made a job offer. The Intel plant I worked in was 15 miles from my house. I was told that my experience was above working on the production floor as a manufacturing technician and offered a position of a engineering technician. In my 2.5 years at Intel I neve sat down with a manager and went over my resume, my career goals or how I could advance my career. There was no guidence, no action plan and overall communications was poor. Intel takes a very responsible attitude towards safety but then leadership fails which was evident by a recent issue where employees were given a test on Lock-Out Tag-Out and the failure rate was well above 50%. The belief at Intel is that a computer is all people need for training and then if mistakes are made it is not the companies fault.

review_title: Good place to work, but many improvements needed to make it great
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. Worldwide brand recognition. Almost everyone has heard of Intel and what we do.
2. Some awesome benefits, including an 8 week paid sabbatical after every 7 years and profit sharing that does not require 401k participation. Free fruits/drinks.
3. Great work/life balance. Management is supportive of flexible working hours and telecommuting.
4. Process and technology leadership. Our CPUs are the best, bar none.
5. Tremendous company and employee involvement in the communities that it serves.
cons:
1. Bonus structure needs to be changed for grade 6 and lower employees. Need to emphasize more of an individual's performance rather than a fixed bonus target that is based on a small percentage of an employee's salary.
2. Stagnant stock price. It's such a big issue that even management is trying to address it.
3. Too many reorganizations within the company. Reorganizations seems to happen every year and upper management always claims that it improves some inefficiencies. Better planning and leadership should have been exercised in the first place!
4. Too much bureaucracy and politics and too many meetings. Focus on getting the task done at hand with better cooperation and teamwork among groups, rather than focusing on specific processes and passing the political football.
5. Too many offices in the suburbs and not enough in the bigger cities (e.g. SF, NYC) that is needed to attract a wider talent pool.

review_title: Corporate behemoth, but a surprisingly good place to work
pros: Intel is huge, but don't let that fool you.  The technical people at Intel are generally highly driven and committed to making great technological advancements, and creating products that people really want.  There's really no better place to work if you want to do hard core CPU or chipset architecture, or if you're into process engineering.  As a software engineer there are many interesting projects as well, from working Windows, Linux and Mac internals (not just drivers!) to whole operating systems like MeeGo.  Career advancement is straightfoward: generally if you work hard and garner influence you can achieve a principal engineer position after awhile.  And the pay is very good compared with other companies.
cons: It has the downsides of most big companies: crappy IT infrastructure (e.g. proxied internet access; this would be comical if it weren't so painful) and laptops (you absolutely need a top of the line CPU and SSD to run all the crapware IT installs and still get work done), fluffy corporate communications and poor information sharing between groups.  The work environment is a bit soulless as well; drab cubes as far as the eye can see.  Finally, it can be quite competitive at review time; Intel very much subscribes to the Jack Welch school of management & reviews.  The top performers get the vast majority of the raise budget, and poor performers are culled fairly aggressively.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but needs to lighten up a bit!
pros:
Attracts top performers, hard workers, bright minds
Industry-leading technology and practices
Pay and benefits
cons: This place needs to lighten up a bit - gray cubes, gray environment, gray attitudes ... seriously needs some color. If you are a good technical performer, they promote you .... that's not bad, except that they make you a manager. Now, that's not making the most of what you're good at, is it? As a result, high risk of bad managers (although they may be good technologists/ engineers).

review_title: It tends to be stressful but still room for reasonable work-life balance. Sebbatical vacation is a nice perk too
pros: You will be always moving toward the cutting edge technology or applying those to the exising field, hence there is pretty good chance to learn new things. It is good to make new thing happen, even though it is not rare to get the project canceld in the even later phase. Also Sabbatical time-off is a good to compensate the years of continuous service, and refresh yourself. There are many opportunities that the employee can directly ask to and listen from the senior management, even though the senior managements are generally very skillful to avoid being trapped in hot topics.
cons: As a large company, there are cases where it is more important to have a good relationship/communication with your manager than actually getting the job done, as there are quite some blind spots here and there. Company is very much profitable but not growing fast hence you should not expect better chances for promotion here. Also continuous restructuring makes the employee quite stressful as it is usually out of the employee's reach and yet makes huge impact.

review_title: Good place to start, but don't overstay your welcome
pros:
The good:

- Good name on your resume - You can't beat the name recognition of Intel.

- Very astute Finance Organization - Lots of really bright folks in Finance. Stacy Smith is a good CFO who is not afraid to field tough questions.  

- Tons of high impact work for an entry level employee - Even though I was a fresh college grad, I got to work on a lot of very high importance projects.

- Intellectually challenging and competitive work place - I have worked with some of the smartest people in the world and it was truly an honor.  Lots of incredibly bright folks at Intel.

- Lots of smart folks who are very driven - Intel has a very egalitarian "grinder" mindset.  Lots of folks work very hard for the company.
cons:
The bad:

- Finance HR is awful - I was a promising employee (successful on focal) and I was promised a transfer to another division, then HR and my manager rescinded on the deal.  HR sided with him and the Corporate Finance group was in the dark about the whole thing.  I am no longer working at Intel after that whole fiasco.  

- Extremely lousy middle managers - My boss in Finance was responsible for 12 direct reports and he wouldn't touch a spreadsheet or make himself available at all.  When I tried to talk with  him about business real issues he brushed me off.  Needless to say, he promptly got promoted to a controller level position.

- Corporate mediocrity - Complacency breeds mediocrity.  Intel is a mature company so most of the employees are well paid and lazy.  They do not care about tackling new markets or expanding product offerings... it's all about collecting a paycheck and milking the x86 cash cow.

- Bad Leadership - Since Otellini took over, the stock has been down 30%.  They consistently make bad investments  (WiMax, XScale) and nobody seems to bat an eye.  Intel has an unassailable competitive position but their overall performance has been stagnant.

review_title: A challenging experience with plenty of growth potential and security
job_title: Validation Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible hours, challenging environment, high standards for performance, great benefits, management (usually) pays attention to employee needs, pride of working for an industry leader and innovator.
cons: Bureaucracy can bog down decision-making at the top and middle-levels of management. Even though this has improved compared to several years ago, this is still a problem. Plus the pressure-cooker environment may not suit everyone.

review_title: A typical big corporation at the end of its dominance
pros: Huge cash flows, total job secuirty for high level tech personnel, good pay (a very comprehensive bonus system), time off flexibility
cons:
ineffective upper management with aptly demoinstrated inability to break out into new markets; middle management focused entirely on own career growth; widely spread nepotism; lack of growth opportunities for technical workers; propaganda like communication style between upper management and the rank-and-file

higly recommned reading "Losing Faith: How the (Andy) Grove Survivors Led the Decline of Intel's Corporate Culture" for a great inside look at the company culture

review_title: great place to work for 1 to 3rd yeard of career
pros: Intel is a well managed company. The nature of job is highly technical and detail oriented. Employyees are given basic trainings before expecting to be productive.
cons: The nature of job is highly technical, but at the same time compartimized. Employee is expected to develop strengh in the field of work assignment, but there is rare visibility into adjacent areas or cross functional areas.

review_title: For the most part, I enjoyed my experience working at Intel
pros: I worked on several different projects in my 3 month internship.  My tasks were mostly hands on testing and validation of prototype parts in a lab setting.  Writing some software was necessary.
cons: The management could have been better.  This was apparent because two people decided to leave the group in my short 3 months there.  My manager had a difficult time transitioning me from one project to another.  I took initiative and looked for projects I could possible work on by talking to coworkers.

review_title: Great Place to work if you are with the right team
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. Big Company perks---pay gets better as you go higher up in the ranks, good benefits
2. Decent Hours
3. Good smart People
4. It's a "Great Place to Work" in terms of employee group activities, free stuff, company events etc
cons:
1. Big Company issues, hierarchical
2. Slow if you are looking for growth
3. yearly increments in salary for a Successful rating averages 5%, which is low
4. Political 
5. Manager can make or break your career, always try to be in a group where the manager believes in career growth else you will stagnate

review_title: Good place to learn. Growth is dependent upon your team.Lots of opportunity across various product lines.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-Cutting edge technology
-Best in industry in CPU design
-Top class products with Core,Xeon and Xeon Phi.
-Stability
-Easy to move across teams
-Some really smart folks, especially in Arch, RTL and Circuits
-New CEO is extremely bold, willing to make radical changes to transform the corporation into SoC design and try out new areas and ventures
-Good place for new folks to learn as much as they can
- Well poised to gain mobile traction in the upcoming years
-Open environment, good work-life balance
cons:
-Too big, sometimes you feel like a dot in a painting
-Risk-taking, some groups are slightly averse to this idea, but the new CEO seems better than predecessor at this.
-Lot of old folks, in dire need of some young blood in the company especially in Santa Clara
-Growth opportunities might be limited if you are in a team with too many old-timers
-Pay is not great in Santa Clara, if you start comparing Intel to Apple, sometimes causing the company to struggle to retain top talent but on par with Nvidia and better than Qualcomm
-Politics is prevalent at 2nd level managers and above
-Afraid to fire ppl who are crap
-Raises are lower than rest of industry, but good bonus and decent stock options
-Workplace is rather dull. Grey everywhere.

pros: Good corporate citizenship.  Great company culture.  Lots of different projects going on and easy to move horizontally within your skillset.
cons: Not so easy to move to roles outside your core skillset.  Future of the company is a bit uncertain with the reducing demand for the PC and fierce competition in mobile.  Very interesting time to be involved in the fight for market share though.

review_title: Full of possibilities but tied up in bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Staff Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Lots of cash. With enlightened management could own the semiconductor space
cons: Not a design company -- run by process engineers. Far too many meeting. Many arrogant career managers with no ability but climbing the ladder. No recognition for the brightest and best so they leave.

pros: They pay competitively at the time of hire. The bonuses are real and they are substantial.
cons:
Work/life balance here means don't ever let your life get in the way of work from 7am to 4pm. After those hours, a compelling reason for absence is okay, as long is it happens infrequently and nothing bad happens when you're away. 

In 4.5 years, I never saw anybody get a raise better than the real inflation rate. For the people managers love (which seems to have little to do with performance), they get 3%. Managers there love people that will not speak up when given impossible tasks or when told blatant lies. Managers all manage up, meaning they want you to say you are on top of everything so they can go back to their meetings. When something falls through the cracks, they want to be able to say you didn't ask for help. They do not want you to actually ask for help, and if you do they will burn your time up justifying what you've been doing every minute, but they never take anything off your task list. 

The few Managers I saw that actually spent time trying to help their team get their jobs done were laid off or demoted. Everything new that is rolled out is presented with the punishments for not complying. I never saw a new initiative or process rolled out with rewards or positive encouragement. Every failure, even mechanical breakdowns like welds breaking, are viewed as personal discipline issues because a good engineer knows the condition of all their systems. If you asked to upgrade the system and got turned down, the failure is your fault because you didn't specify when and how it was going to fail, and you didn't re-submit your request with better justification.

I had an alarm that went unattended for 2 hours and caused a problem. One root cause was that they just laid off 2 of the 3 job positions that were supposed to respond to the alarm and hadn't figured out a backfill plan yet (normally 3 job positions are all supposed to make sure the alarms are handled). Two of the three were laid off, the ops tech was busy repairing other broken equipment, and the managers at the incident review rejected those root causes. The only root cause accepted was the ops tech thought the alarm was not critical and took two hours to respond. The solution adopted was to change the alarm message to sound more critical.

I've worked for many companies, and I've never seen a place where deception by omission is the only way to keep your job.

review_title: In the midst of a transformation
pros:
Brilliant co-workers who rise to the challenge.
A deep pool of talents to draw from.
Good IP portfolio to support product development.
cons:
Some projects span the globe which cause meeting times at all hours of the day.
New "open" office configuration brings a lot of visual and audio distractions.
New business realities demand projects to do more with the same or fewer resources.
Resource constraints sometimes at odds with forward progress.

review_title: The best of times, the worst of times...
job_title: Silicon Architecture Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Your colleagues can easily become your best friends. Work/life balance was very good. Health care benefits were fairly good and they have patient advocates who will take up your cause with the insurance provider if necessary which really blew me away the one time I needed them. Opportunities to work from home were superb.
cons:
I worked at Intel for 8 1/2 years. The last couple of years were my most passionate and my greatest frustration. While none of my managers were malicious, their net effect was categorically abusive. I simultaneously had a skillset that was too critical to my server project to allow me to take an offered SoC "Hot Job" (jobs identified as critical for the company's future), but not worthy enough to address the career growth reasons for my dissatisfaction with the project that led me to want to leave, but they still offered me nearly half a years pay to voluntarily separate from the company to make space to hire more engineers for SoC. Let that sink in - I had been offered an SoC-related engineering job and my group blocked my transfer then offered me a large buyout to leave the company because they needed to make room to hire SoC engineers. Again, nobody was being malicious here, but I was in the middle of three different ridiculous circumstances caused by decision of three different levels of management all acting in what, at some level, was the most rational thing for them to do. At no point did anybody stand up to say "the company is paying a good engineer we could use in SoC to leave the company. That doesn't seem right."

Intel will tell you largely and loudly about how much they value the people working there, but they have erected systemic barriers that allow pathological levels of cruelty towards these same people. Intel will shout until they are Intel-blue-in-the-face that they have these wonderful systems for recognizing and rewarding accomplishments, but they're very inconsistent in their use. I worked on my own time for two years creating an architectural firmware debugging GUI tool. After it was announced that I was leaving, architects and engineers from different teams and different projects popped up to make sure that the source code would be available once I was gone. Over 400 hours of my own time creating it, other engineers apparently thinking that preservation of the source for it was of paramount importance, yet it was never deemed enough of an accomplishment for either recognition or reward. I can think of few more stinging ways to wound a departing engineer. When the buyout offer was extended to everyone, 5 acceptees were asked to delay their departure because their skills were needed badly. I was one of those 5 and to this day one of my greatest regrets of my 8 years at Intel was agreeing to it.

I offer this example for illustrative purposes to demonstrate the dysfunctional connection between Intel's intentions, and Intel's actions. That last tool was not the first time I had identified a need, spent my own time providing a solution, had the tool picked up by many other engineers but received no notice from management until I moved on -- it was the third. The problem is systemic with deep roots. It also isn't why I left. I left because my career growth was dependent on the cooperation of a junior engineer who was getting rewarded with annual review bullet points for non-cooperation.

review_title: One bad apple doesn't spoil the whole bunch...
pros: Well deserved reputation... The company has extremely talented executive leadership & front-line technical engineering talent.  Most are deservedly in a class of their own (at the top).  In some way, shape, or form - you WILL have the opportunity to work on THE latest technology, with THE best coworkers, and create-sell-support THE coolest 'things' in the world.
cons:
The difference between Intel & the 'innovation leadership' companies like Google, Apple, etc... is the 'blah' middle management layers.

Most of these people were the ones who helped either make or sustain the 'old day' success... but have now moved up the ladder into positions where they are no longer tops-in-the-field.  Yes - they are still experts in their specific field of knowledge & can be great mentors for budding talent - but they are not good at going 'outside their box'.  

So, while the executive leadership has the right goals & the engineers have the talent to deliver anything... the middle management layers tend to live in a strict world of hierarchy, control, and 'fear' of doing the wrong things.  This effectively kills ground-floor innovative work.

If the idea didn't come from the chartered R&D team & didn't come pre-packaged with approvals, funding, etc... then that idea will never see the light of day. 

Ironic - since 'being innovative' is the #1 task given to these middle layers from their bosses.

review_title: Copy exactly is not for everybody or 5 years at Intel Israel FAB28 as module owner (process engineer).
job_title: Senior Process & Equipment Engineer in Qiryat Gat
pros:
Stability is high, if compared to unstable Israeli's  job market. Very rare lay offs, substantial severance package. 
Engineers that are interested in maintenance/operation will find this place at the edge of excellence in these areas.
One gets to travel and visit other parts of the world (Re locations, Business trips)
cons:
Dull gray work, after you learned the job, your learning curve stops. Technology is developed at RnD site, as an engineer you only COPY the parts of process that was delivered to you. 
Technology transfer is done at RnD site (Oregon US) from local RnD process engineers - the attitude of the place is AWFUL. Israeli engineers that perform the tech transfer are treated as a liability at best.

Engineers lose their original proficiency and expertise in a very narrow area as equipment sustaining engineers (not RnD). Thus they have very scarce ability to find employment outside of Intel (especially after decade of working there).

A lot of functions do not require high profile workers, myself with BSc was responsible for tool set that was more sophisticated than one that had an engineer with PHD.

Low base salary - there are stock plans and bonuses, yet even with them it scratches the mean salary in the market.

Very problematic, army like attitude. If there is a problem with your process section, YOU HAVE NO LIFE as long as the problem exists. Engineers are connected to the production floor 24.7 through phone calls and remote connection.

A lot of large organisation politics, management radiates  tough and intimidating attitude.
A lot of funny organizational propaganda (that is quietly ridiculed by engineers) - might pass as "pros"

Personal carrier development is only managerial, no true technological development, despite "personal development plans".


In the summary - not everything that shines is gold.

review_title: Good company to work for but need to keep your head on a swivel
pros: Training, personal career development (but you OWN this entirely), diverse opportunities, VERY fast paced environment.  Compensation outside of base pay is great.  Many crazy smart people to work with.
cons: Work/life can suffer due to heavy focus on very demanding expectations. Lack of active mentoring for junior employees or those struggling. Base pay is tied to "industry average" instead of meritocracy. Work place competition can border on predatory.

review_title: Good company to work for but need to keep your head on a swivel
pros: Training, personal career development (but you OWN this entirely), diverse opportunities, VERY fast paced environment.  Compensation outside of base pay is great.  Many crazy smart people to work with.
cons: Work/life can suffer due to heavy focus on very demanding expectations. Lack of active mentoring for junior employees or those struggling. Base pay is tied to "industry average" instead of meritocracy. Work place competition can border on predatory.

job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: The work life balance is great compared to other companies. Yes you wont always be working on the latest and greatest things, but being able to take off early on Fridays to hit the slopes was great!
cons: The location I was at (Folsom) wasn't the greatest as someone in their early twenties but there are enough people there to have a good time.

pros:
-Decent benefits
-Plenty of new projects
cons:
-Management sucks. They trick you in your focal  by telling you are successful and give you low# of stocks and then fire you because they gave you low amount of stocks. They find ways to let he older employees go
-Always being threaten to get laid off
-They come and tell you have to move to another city or loose your job
-You will get laid off after you reach 50 and replaced by few cheap heads in India or Malaysia
-You will get laid off if you are close to retirement
-You will get laid off if you take your sabbatical
-You will get laid off if you go on medical leave

review_title: Your experience will vary depending on factors you don't control
pros:
Pay is generally very good, 2 extra bonus programs, especially if you're in higher grade.
You may get to travel to different GEOs - our team had collaborating divisions all over the world (Finland, Israel, Netherlands, S.Korea, Taiwan). Good opportunity to see places. I traveled 2-3 times a year being in an engineering role.
Some good positive aspects of the culture - Intel has a "work-week" (WW) based schedule (simpler to learn and more efficient), it at least declares a lot of good intentions (but in practice you may find a different picture), all kind of training is available to employees (a lot of mandatory programs).
Intel has plenty of relationships in the industry. My team ended up facing customers in "deep technical dive" support programs, I got to work with all big industry names: Samsung, Asus, HP, Dell, Sharp, Sony, to name a few.
cons:
I formed a very low opinion of higher / senior level management. Within the company, they essentially encourage what a good friend of mine called a "clan war". I happen to work in MCG (mobile communication group) that throughout my time (3.5 year) was reorganized 6 times(!). Many times the multi-month work of whole department (not only my team) was thrashed, because some new boss would come and "not favor" your team and whatever result was done to that date. 
Global cross-team coordination effort was very low to non-existent. Teams would "fight" for resources, and have a quite unhealthy competition. Decision would be made with some irrelevant considerations, and forced down to my team. 
As result, the culture actually experienced would not be really engaging. 

The performance review process is essentially botched. Some much higher management essentially issues a quota on number of good performance ratings to your team. Then, you end up in a situation when no matter how much you tried, you'd be stuck at your performance grade, because no good rating can be made available to you (again despite the acknowledgement of high level of contribution and such). Example: our team received only one EE (exceeds expectations) rating, and my manager decided to use it to promote one particular employee (citing his family situation (he had a new child, etc), and his current lower grade). Others were given S (satisfactory) rating

review_title: Work there for a while, but don't stay for too long.
job_title: Electrical Validation Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
As Intel is growing to more market segments, it is also becoming a company that can help you grow your technical scope and learn many new things. You also have a chance to work with different geographies and get experience on how to work with different cultures.

Focusing in Electrical Validation, you take the responsibility of assessing the product performance in terms of its hardware functionality and giving feedback to the design/architecture teams with the objective of guarantee that the final product meets its specifications with a high level of confidence. 

As an Intel employee, you will enjoy many of its benefits which may include: many days of vacation, quarterly bonuses, a savings found, food/purchasing stamps, recognition bonuses... among others.
cons:
Being Electrical Validation one of the last stages of the product life cycle (right before sales, just after the manufacture) the time constrains to do your job can be very aggressive. This leads to a pronounced work-life unbalance, and as Intel increases its product cadence that starts to happen more frequently.

Though they have good options for learning, their career development process is very ambiguous and slow. It is highly dependent on the manager's mood (which can be beneficial or dangerous), there are no clear goals to achieve a promotion. It is also easy to see that the people who has staid in the company for more years have better chance to get one of the available promotions putting everyone else in the queue: so if you are going to enter Intel, you better ask for a salary that makes you happy for a long time.

review_title: Heading down hill - Lack of leadership and Mgmt
job_title: Customer Business Analyst in Folsom, CA
pros: Large corporation where experience and skills may be attained. Some co-workers are very smart and some of them willing to mentor less skilled co-workers.  Access to work across multiple divisions and gain a world of knowledge and experience.  If working is your passion - this is the place for you.
cons:
Intel's long time CEO (Paul Otellini) "jumped ship" and the new CEO (Brian Krzanich) has not performed to expectations. Many top managers have left the company and now BK's right hand (Renee James) is also "jumping ship". One of Brian's strategy is to let go of experienced middle aged employees (35+) and replaced them with low paid interns and recent college graduates in order to cut costs (He recently fired ~4k employees who had been with the company for years and said more layoffs will continue). In one of his speeches to Intel Employees, he said that employees are disposable, all that matters is the survival of the corporation, continuity of Moore's Law and the name of the corporation. He has taken away many of employee perks: Work from home day, work life balance, team builder off-site's, etc... The moral of Intel employees is down and there is no job security - Therefore, employees are not performing at their best.  Management group is very "clicky" - they hire their friends and help them get into Mgmt by giving them top job reviews - but no one dares say anything because even though the feedback says "confidential" they are not - and once you get on the bad side of one manager, you are sunk. If you do a job really well and then want to move to a different position, your direct manager has complete control of your carrier development and may keep you on one role for as long as they want. Focal (yearly job reviews) are a joke... they have to be written by the employee in third person because managers are to lazy to write them and no matter how long you spend or how good you have sold yourself, the manager will still give top reviews to their preferred employees. Standard pay raises are between 0 and 3% per year - as of recent, pay raises average about 1%, since the corporation is going through financial stress - a 1% pay raise does not even cover the increase of cost of living. 
Is it a good place to work? Yes it is - but do not stay on one job for more than a year and be ready to leave after 3 to 5 years. The benefit of working for Intel is mainly to get the experience on your resume - it opens bigger opportunities - better pay - elsewhere.

pros: salary and benefits are good.
cons: open door grievance process - company's way of getting rid of an employee. If employee is getting bullied and they complain to HR, all they get is offered 6 weeks of psychotherapy. HR dont accept that bullying is occuring and try to make out the employee has issues. I once paid a person to type up a professional cv for me after i was forced to quit my job in Intel. She asked why I quit and asked was I bullied there. I said yes. She replied, the reason i asked was I know intel is notorious for bullying.

pros: Great benefits.  Pay is better than average.  Fair treatment of employees.  They have a system for everything....practically no guess work as to how to get an answer or something done.  Extremely safety conscious. Very results-oriented and driven.
cons: Be expected to put work first.  If you're salaried at a mfg site, you will be on-call 24x7.  Promotions don't come easy unless you can take advantage of an unplanned business opportunity.

review_title: Managers and Freshers in bulk | Mediocre performance rewarded
pros: Some brilliant people you could work with.
cons:
"Intel IT is the heart of Intel" is what the Intel management said today in the IT connect event, but somehow IT folks get the least salaries (Maybe not the Managers).
The below cons might not be the case for people in Silicon tech. But is true for Intel IT.

Mediocre performance is encouraged, They simply don't need sharp people from CS background here but someone to "LEAD" / "BOSS AROUND" the outsourced folks.

Managers will tell you, everything is great during the final appraisal meeting but the hike letter says otherwise. Don't join Intel IT and waste your time here, Intel doesn't trust its employee (Only reason RSUs are awarded) when it comes to development projects, They just want to outsource everything and push you to maintaining the project. Later, they'll say that the vendor messed up big time when it comes to design/quality and will impose fixing bugs they created, on you.

Came across "faceintel" website on the day I got my pay letter and could relate to current work environment / HR practices (Misguided Salary structure).

Advice to freshers(RCGs):
You might get big brand/ good training opportunities, but you getting hands-on on a real development project is far from reality at Intel. I would suggest you rather start working in a startup / service industry and join Intel when you have enough technical acumen to simply "BOSS AROUND".

review_title: Technically challenging, but company health is sliding backwards
pros:
Good salary and benefits
Working on the latest technology and really hard problems
Relatively easy for an engineer to move around the company and try different technologies
If you are female, they are very interested in furthering your career to meet CEOs goals (and believe this is the right thing not just a quota)
cons:
If you are working in or support manufacturing, expect long hours just to keep your job. A sweatshop made worse by recent layoffs.  If you are a workaholic with no life balance and a type A personality you will fit right in.  Other areas of the company are not as bad.
Will continue to lay off in my opinion because costs are too high to compete in growth segments.  That means you probably need an exceeds expectations or outstanding rating every three years to be safe under current practices. The Oregonian has good details on this.
The company is still slow to address market trends, slow to make decisions, and slow to execute so it has almost no large dollar growth prospects while spending obscene amounts of money on failed prospects, like $10B on mobile/tablets, and $3B building an empty factory shell in Chandler.  Processes are getting longer with shrinking process margins, making yields challenging (that's why its a sweatshop) and further clouding a demand/order picture the company has never had a good handle on.  The company itself is headed in the wrong direction for growth and opportunity.

pros: A lot of variety given the rotation program.  Get to learn different aspects of finance from PnL, budgeting, capital, as well as strategic investments and product line support.  For the most part business partners are smart and passionate with a good understanding for their segment or area of expertise.
cons: Bureaucracy.  It's a real challenge to drive change or influence significant decisions.  Takes way too long to make decisions.  For finance it's more about looking good and getting "exposure" than actually getting meaningful work done.  Way too much time wasted in the annual review process.

pros: Great place to learn and contribute. Tons of Intel University courses to attend. The company offers advanced education program sponsorship to selected employees.
cons: Internal job rotation opportunity is not that abundant as it claimed to be. But this could be very subjective, and not representative. After all, you own your own employability.

review_title: Intel, not a good place to work
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Free bad coffee, one piece of fruit per day, pockets of descent people, relative good pay for the Portland, OR area.
cons: Company does not have direction.   Exec management is not inspiring nor leading.  I don't think that Intel can reinvent itself to be competitive in the future.  Intel is too internally focused by middle and exec management to address basic business threats.   Intel does NOT have a culture of innovation, but rather it is a culture of butt kissing management and fighting other internal groups who are doing nearly the exact same work.  Intel still has some pretty good fab processing, but it is certainly not leading edge anymore and the product groups are just a joke.  I think that Intel will collapse in on itself and will significantly decrease head count in the next 4-5 years.   The CEO seems to focus on URM's, conflict materials, and any other political based metrics rather than making the business healthy.  His direction and exec/middle management execution has killed all positive thought in all of the groups I know of and people are just putting in their time.

job_title: Senior Finance Analyst in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The best reasons to work at Intel are the compensation and benefits, the high quality of your peers and coworkers in other areas of the company, and the professional challenges that you will be able to take on.  Also, some of the focus areas of the company are new and exciting.  The autonomy that you are often given is a positive, as well as the exposure to sr. management.
cons: The aspects of Intel that tend to be more negative than positive are the acute stress/deadline situations that you find yourself in at times.  Mid-level, to entry level managerial talent is, more often than not (67% of the time), not the type of manager that you would like to have.  Some lack basic people skills; the type of skills that you would think would be common sense for anyone to possess and others lack basic organizational savvy.  Others actually struggle at being forthright and transparent when it is required.  Others could be considered good or great, but again, I have found this to be the case only about 33% of the time over a 10+ year period.

pros:
Good Pay and work life balance. 
Employee Friendly.
Cutting Edge technology.
cons:
No Job security
Need to keep projecting (boasting) about your work and keep arguing with your manager for growth.
Quiet working employees become victims during lay-offs.
First Level Managers project the work done by Engineers and get all the credit.
Since most of the work is very specific to Intel, getting offers outside becomes difficult.

pros: Overall good company to work for. Highly competitive and number of engineering opportunities. Lot to learn and good benefits overall
cons: Work life balance can take a hit sometimes. Your mileage of good work, environment can vary depending on what group you end up in. Can get lost as it is a big company. Sometimes bureaucratic and

pros: Good benefit, flexible, work life balance will depend on group but generally OK. Have lots of opportunity and easy to stitch around at lower job grade. 8 weeks sabbatical is nice after 7 years.
cons: Paid sucks and any RCG is not making that much less than experienced especially when they try to attract young people. Raise sucks too, so you will never catch up with the new hire if you decide to stay here forever. Chance to promote is slim and you will have to be very pro active to push for it.

pros: Intel likes to establish sites at suburbs close to a bigger city.  The pay may not be less when compared to those located in the city but that still out pace of the living cost.  Overall, considering schools, traffic, and you will get a nicer neighborhood, it is a much better trade off than living in the  big name cities.  The sabbatical is a very nice break to work on some longer projects (community, study, travel, or simply home improvement).  After a long and exhausting project, managers (at their discretion) will normally compensate for "compensation time" for a few days off the record.  I have experience where I needed to call off a vacation because of work and the company paid for all air-ticket change fees.  The 401K and other health benefits have various options but the latest trend is to go for HRA to reduce monthly premiums.  In terms of stocks, they have been giving RSU's and that depends on performance.  the number of RSU grants is tied to a certain percentage at lower grade levels and then become a much larger number for staff level and above.  There are also quarterly bonuses tied to company performance (an equation determines the amount).  Since there are lots of sites across the US and around the globe, you can carry-on with your life changes without leaving the company.
cons:
The pension plan has been stopped for current hires and the education subsidy has been much reduced.  That may be inline with other companies.
I have also seen cases where a less experienced external new hire getting a better pay/benefit package than a performing existing employee.  The salary packages of existing employees should be normalized to new hires where possible.

review_title: Welcome to process hell of the 1990s
pros: Pay checks arrive on time at the agreed upon amount
cons:
Intel is process hell and none of it is documented, and if it is documented nothing is maintained.  You spend far too much time navigating illogical processes that have no accurate documentation, if this is for purchasing or using your "benefits".  Corporate policies are years (decades?) behind the norm for high tech employers, if that is health benefits or workplace practices.  

The IT department itself, and any services provided by them is a perfect example of what can go wrong in a large corporate environment.  The IT department is obviously not accountable to making employees successful, they have ancient practices and do little to support users.  The policies they have in place for your personal mobile device or any computer system that you use is beyond draconian...and the policies are entirely illogical.  They force you to change the passcode on your personal phone every 60-90 days, however they don't use a single one-time-password (aka 2 factor authentication) anywhere within your standard IT systems.  If your business unit *allows* you to use a non-windows workstation, good luck on getting it to actually work. Most of the IT policies seem to be to just wish you luck and stop talking to you.  Their policies may work fine if you are in the fabrication facilities, however not if you work in a modern group focused on software as the security policies block many development environments from even working viably without spending 40% of your time playing cat-and-mouse trying to find how to work within the new policy, or the one that intermittently acts differently. 

The work environment is pretty toxic, they reward "lifers" that have been there forever who then immediately dismiss new ideas as not being valid.  They obviously need fresh ideas (innovator's dilemma) however their own practices and structure often drown those ideas before they can even be discussed.  

The CEO tries to claim it is a "growth company" while doing nothing to modernize business practices, empowering employees, or even investing adequately in growth opportunity.  Most of middle management spends their time clambering over each other trying to grow their headcount and budget allocations rather than actually running there business units.  Everyone is building their own fiefdom with duplication of resources and effort, wasting massive allocations of resources in the process...until your team loses and then you get the axe.

review_title: An interesting, ever changing environmente with considerable challenges & questionable ethics.
pros:
- Employee Bonus is calculated against the market success of the business, to incentivize employees to push the business forward.
- Stock Purchase Plan allows employees to invest upto 5% of monthly salary & purchase shares at 15% below market values.
- Annual Bonus provides a much needed fiscal boost.
- Restricted Stock units are awarded for successful annual appraisals.
- Dependant on manager discretion:  Employees are permitted to work from home, take personal time to deal with personal crises & issues.  In the even of familial bereavement some companies allow 2-days paid vacation, I was told "take as much time as you need".
- Training is readily available & encouraged in-house & outsourced (if not available in-house).
- Employees are encouraged to own their own careers & identify knowledge gaps & pursue avenues of interest as this will only ever benefit the business ultimately.
- The business is so vast & sprawling you may move between departments, shifting roles & organisations if your interest is piqued in another area.
cons:
- Compared to other businesses, Intel's salaries are relatively low.  The logic being that the stock purchase programs, bonuses & awarding of Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) makes up for the deficit in salary.
- Stock seldom retains reasonable value.  Many of the old guard (folks having served 15-20yrs) are stuck with no small quantity of shares purchased at nearly twice the current (2017) stock va lue.
- Restricted Stock Units (RSUs):  Sound like a great annual bonus, until you realise the units have to remain owned by Intel and/or the stock management company for YEARS before you're permitted to realise their value.
- Headcount reduction:  Every 5yrs there is a headcount cull.  Every 10years it is a BIG ONE.  Know that your position within Intel is never "safe" or "secure".  Times come & go when EVERYONE is watching their back, morale hits rock bottom (company-wide).  At these times management nor senior management seem to know how to raise morale... This results in any effort to allay fears only really resulting in a further exacerbation of the issue as employees are pushed to continue as usual, as if their livelihood isn't at stake (Needless:  This does nothing to improve the situation).
- Near constant efforts to push automation & reduce head count results in greater & greater expectation from employees who are expected to pick up the slack for the roles which have been removed from your organisation (I.e. Lots of people are fired?  The folks remaining are expected to continue the work & responsibilities of those who have been sacked.
- Cashless payment:  This really opened my eyes to how Intel considers it's employees (resources, not people).  I was tasked with assisting in the installation of a cashless payment system (one which is present on a few Intel sites).  These systems do not adhere to any data protection rulings in the UK or EU.  Repeated ethics complaints were submitted & summarily ignored (to varying degrees - Lawyers were involved, but little was done to rectify the situation).  This has (STILL) left Intel employees more open to identity theft & open to people/s with nefarious intent as the security surrounding the cashless payment is still accessible on the internet (accessible by ANYONE) with approaching ZERO security in place to prevent remote access to the personally identifiable details of hundreds (possibly thousands) of totally unwitting people.

job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Working in Intel makes your life shine in others' eyes. Indeed, it's a good brand with a legendary history.
cons:
Intel won't treat you well in every single aspect. It's a big company, where you are a small screw. No matter how well you perform or how much you sacrifice your time, the company is numb to reward you.

You are not a priority in everything small. There is no free food. It's an old company. It doesn't feel grateful for people who work hard for the company's good. And it doesn't really care if you work here and you love to work here. What kills is that there is no dinner when you work after-hours. Hunger and thirst are your best pals. The canteen which you must pay and tastes like hell is closed. Vending machines will be accompanying you. And it's another place you can't owe money.

You are also not a priority in everything big. Intel is generally reluctant to pay you. Currently, I'm enjoying my low 10th percent salary of the bay area. I have a near-zero stock grant, no year-end bonus or any rewards that can distinguish my effort from others. But two month ago, I finally had an astounding raise in the salary when my manager ranked my last year as successful. And the raise for the successful was 2.1%. I can't thank the company too much for this, because it even didn't reach the US inflation rate! When my manager presented the number to me. I was startled, utterly speechless and faint to argue. The company that I paid homage to with the faith and worked for with the belief treated me in the way I can only describe as shabby and mean. I've trying to quench my anger, frustration and desperation for 2 months. But I found it's much harder than I thought.

Soon after my onboarding day, I found the company is filled with people passionless. Now I understand why, because I've become one of them.

review_title: Going through a mid life crisis and playing the short game while ignoring tanking of morale.
pros: Still a market leader in nanny areas with lots of money to invest and possibly strike gold again.
cons: Leadership is flat footed and focusing on minimal return cost savings to prop up stock price temporarily rather than doubling down on talent to compete with tech leaders.  Morale is in the toilet and Intel doesn't seem to care anymore while execs inch closer toward stock vesting.  Intel playing the short game.

job_title: Senior Consultant in San Jose, CA
pros: Cutting edge technology, great co-workers, strong diversity move, many opportunities to move to other jobs within the company, good overall benefits
cons: Very few people in influential positions that have come from outside, ignoring customer requirements in product development, insular in participating  in global technology activities (unless the drive is from within the company)

pros: Great compensation, good benefits, challenging work on cutting edge products. Intel hires the best people and overall gets a high level of commitment from employees.
cons: Sometimes it feels like upper management does not make decisions based on what is best for everyone. For example, the site closures that happened in 2016 seemed arbitrarily chosen.

pros:
Work life balance.
Sabbatical, generous PTOs and 401k match.
cons:
Frequent reorganization, for me it happened annually management seems clueless of what we were doing. Roll out a promising project then kill it next year. There is no consistency. Eventually team got nothing to do. They paid us to stay there browsing webs. 
Pay grew 1 or 2 percent yearly. Way behind their other Bay Area companies and they have zero intention to make up on that. 
For level 7 and below with successful rating, their stock grant is a joke, next to nothing.

pros: Pay is solid and job is stable if you are a good employee. Good work life balance (Unless you are an engineer in the fab).
cons: Raises and promotions are abhorrently inconsistent. New hires often start at higher salary than people working there for 5+ years. Many employee perks have been taken away in the last few years (great place to work, chip loaner, etc.).

review_title: Great HR reps and benefits, manager quality is a gamble
pros: The HR and benefits department, outsourced to a third party, fight hard to ensure proper health care and worker wellness is maximized.  Very lenient and understanding of needing to address personal emergencies
cons: Managers run hot or cold and reorganization’s happen often and unexpectedly.  Significant quality difference in morale and output of teams with supportive managers vs. jaded near-retirees phoning it in.  Luckily transferring is generally a simple process.

review_title: Great company, flawed in some areas
pros:
There are great benefits, such as medical plan, onsite services for physical therapy and massages, dentist appointments, onsite clinic, wellness center (gym), subsidized cafeteria and bus transportation to several hubs. 

As well, the quality of people is awesome. Of course you can find difficult coworkers or managers, but in general my experience has been great and I've had a lot of fun in the teams where I've worked.

Salaries are not that competitive, but the great benefits and perks compensate a bit for it.
cons:
-Bureaucracy based culture, everyone has to be informed and have an opinion on something before it can happen. And sometimes it doesn't happen because again the project has to go through consultation, pilots, etc. 
-Excessive meetings.
-Performance review system can be unfair or pushy, since you are practically obligated to grow vertically otherwise your chances of staying at the company decrease.
-Micromanagement persists in some areas.
-No clear telecommute policies. It depends on manager discretion and given that commuting is a big issue in Costa Rica, sometimes the flexibility is not the best (not everyone owns a car). In some areas, WFH permissions are very restrictive.
-Work life balance is not constant. Depending on your manager, asking for vacations is like asking for a favor and not a right that you own. In some areas the headcount is not enough and workload has duplicated ( without hiring people to support that additional work), so asking for free days makes you feel a little guilty about leaving all that to your peers.

review_title: Best in class technical experience, Great people, awesome benefits
pros:
1. It's all about the people! great place to work with awesome family and supporting atmosphere.
2. Lots of employee perks and benefits.
3. The sky is the limit regarding what you want to learn and work in.
4. Always being recognized for you work.
5. Healthy competition in the organization. 
6. Clear vision and stability.
7. Great work life balance!
cons:
It's a big company with a lot of levels of hierarchy. In some cases too many managers which can lead to lack of focus.
can be hectic at times in peak periods but that's normal.

review_title: Intel is good - IT is less so
job_title: IT Project/Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Great benefits, great smart people, many opportunities to move around the company (if they don't close all job reqs, which happens at least once/year)

Facilities are excellent (thank you corporate services!)

I do like the Agile changes in the last few years - as long as we stick to the basic concepts & not complicate it with Intelized project management. (Please no more scrummerfall)

Challenging and interesting work most of the time. People are mostly focused on making things better. High quality employees to work with & lower quality ones are more obvious (in a good way) than they were in years past. This really helps morale.
cons:
There are still many low quality managers in IT. Too many processes in IT to count which makes us slow & not able to respond to internal customers. 

Leadership only focuses on escalations and not what isn't on fire at the moment. There are many very complex areas of IT that are held together by long term employees. No these jobs cannot be outsourced without major impact to internal and external customers. Only outsource where it makes COMPLETE sense. 

Too many early and late meetings due to cross site/country teams - APT's should all sit in one country please. 

IT has been measuring their success mostly based on cost and much less on quality. We are there to support our business groups and enable their work, lower quality and slllooooow moving is hindering them. They are laughing at us when we say we are now "world class". I don't blame them.

pros:
Most of the reviews are a reflection of a particular business group,  leadership or manager. I have worked with 5 different managers from 3 different geographies, so I guess I can rate it well:  
- Fantastic work culture, very employee-friendly,  human, sensitive and responsible. 
- An amazing pool of talented people, across the world. International exposure is amazing. 
- If you are a part of a COE (centre of excellence), you would be working on cutting-edge technology. 
- Ample infrastructure, like dev machines, HW, SW, and lab space (of course on a justifiable basis) 
- Most of the managers are encouraged not to micro-manage and connect with people well. 
- Huge office space (In Bangalore at-least), open areas, Gym, multiple cafeterias, good food. 
- If you are a good performer, you will enjoy a good salary and benefits.
- This is far better a place than it feels from outside news and talks about it.
cons:
- Very (very) slow in decision making, due to huge beaurocracy levels. It seems impossible to put everyone on the same page. 
- People on the Technical ladder feel powerless/unheard after a particular level, and its extremely difficult to convey a change to the top levels.
- Business decisions related to a product mostly come from top-bottom, and execution teams have very little say. If you have a moron at the top, as an architect, forget about logical work distribution.
- Slow growth at higher levels, you are expected to please everyone to move up, without being a threat to anyone. 
- Too much duplication of work across the world. Many business groups and product teams do the same, what COE does, maintaining their codebase in several different places and tools, causing an absolute waste of time for everyone. 

Overall, if you have an appetite for aggressive growth, or you want to contribute big in business/product, you might not find this to be an exact match. But if you want a steady and constant growth with very good work-life balance, this is the place for you.

review_title: Could be great if you didn't have to fear for your job all the time
job_title: Machine Learning Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Salary is not great compared to what other companies are willing to pay for AI, but it's acceptable for the location.
Smart folks, nice environment within the AI groups.
cons:
You never know when you get laid off.
Decisions from above often seem to be made prematurely, and misinformed (or maybe even uninformed).
They talk things like transparency.... Well, it's just talk.

review_title: Intel is not a great place to work
job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros: There are plenty of opportunities to work on cutting edge chip projects if you are a hardware engineer. If you are a software person, there are fewer opportunities.
cons: Incompetent and even sometimes unethical management. A seriously bloated management structure. A very poor track record of successful software development.

review_title: Your experience will depend a lot on the group you work in
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Many opportunities to move within the company.
Benefits and stock purchase program are nice perks.
cons:
Review process often gives the same raise to good and bad employees.  Have to be exceptionally good or exceptionally bad to deviate much from the 'standard raise'.
Many uptight employees more concerned with checking off boxes and following process, rather than focus on getting things done quickly and with quality.

review_title: 'Great Place to Work' for the most part.
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel is a highly respected company.  Intel is a stable company for the most part so job security is fairly good.  Intel works on some of the most cutting edge technologies which is exciting.  Intel provides excellent work opportunties as well as promoting extended educaiton opportunities.
cons: Intel is a big company which can make you feel disconnected or 'replaceble' at times.  This can also lead to inefficiencies.

pros: Excellent work life balance. Recently a family emergency arised and I had to work from home for 2 weeks. And this was after taking a long vacation. I worked out a plan with my manager and started working from home.
cons: It is too big a place to have your ideas heard out. You need to be connected..  But I guess it is like that in big Corporations.

review_title: Too much politics for its own good
pros: If you want to design microprocessors, it's one of two employers you can work for. Can't think of any other advantages.
cons: Productive employees are never valued. Yes-men get promoted. Hours are long. Lots of unnecessary meetings, courses, etc. Intel train employees to be followers, not achievers. Can't build any expertise in anything else other than microprocessors. Employees who have been there for a long time are arrogant and ignorant.

review_title: Intel treats its employees well financially , but many employees want to contribute to the company more effectively
pros: Employees are quite well compensated. The company has strong emphasis on ethics. Interactions within the company are very professional in general. The company has deep knowledge on technology, in knowledge archives and within its many talented employees. Intel is a very solid company that can weather the storm.
cons: Decision making is very slow in general, with many levels in the management hierarchy. Quite often, without enough content expertise, the senior management at different levels requires significant amount of education and time to get up to speed to make a decision, which contributes to late "time to market" and unsuccessful penetration in new market segment. Besides the slow decision making process, Intel's hidden culture in its organizations to build a bigger empire and expand ownership and charter continues to hinder collaboration and efficient movement of resources to address opportunities and issues of the company. Quite often, an employee sees that he/she can do more, but it is limited by the system.

review_title: Great stepping stone for entry level positions but longer term potential is a bit cloudy.
pros: Benefits are flat out the best I have seen or heard of from other friends in similar companies (size, workforce etc.)
cons: Grade level promotions are few and far between depending on the organization you are a part of. Sometimes promotions do not get rewarded even if there is reason to give them because of political and bureaucratic reasons.

review_title: Great stepping stone for entry level positions but longer term potential is a bit cloudy.
pros: Benefits are flat out the best I have seen or heard of from other friends in similar companies (size, workforce etc.)
cons: Grade level promotions are few and far between depending on the organization you are a part of. Sometimes promotions do not get rewarded even if there is reason to give them because of political and bureaucratic reasons.

review_title: Stable job, great compensation package, poor work conditions
pros: Good pay, telecommuting options/flexible work schedule, and benefits.  Challenging work with limited resources, utilizing specialized set of skills.
cons: Lateral movement within company is encouraged;  vertical movement is difficult.  Middle managers are good, upper managers are focused on business.  Day to day operations are challenging, and if help is not provided timely, you will suffer the consequences.  Work/life balance is difficult to manage.

review_title: Great place to work; amazing people & lots of opportunities
pros: Career development, opportunities to learn, grow and take risks; great people that you work with; strong benefits programs & flexibility is great.  Results oriented and i love that people are held accountable for what they commit to.  Very disciplined approach, but flexible enough to make changes and really understand the various options.  Fast paced.
cons: Lots of work; need to actively manage your time

review_title: Great company; new leadership is questionable
pros: Excellent company with many benefits including a 2 month sabbatical after 7 years - a really phenomenal benefit.  Many smart people who are focused on helping the company succeed.  Work/Life balances is good and I have found ability to move into a variety of positions attainable.
cons: New CEO and president seem to have lost the mojo and are tilting the scales toward a commoditized business. Business forecast and significant growth is questionable. Not sure it's headed in the right direction.  Political, like most businesses, but results will get you places.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but beware the bell curve force fit with annual evaluations.
pros:
Simply put, this is a real technology company.  You'll have the chance to work with some really smart people.  There is a ton there for you to learn if you take the time to do so.  No other company has the resources to do the things Intel is doing, so you're definitely working on the cutting edge of the silicon industry.

Competitive pay/benefits, probably among the best in the tech sector.
2 month sabbatical every seven years is a big plus.
Retirement contributions by the company are profit based rather than matching, normally this is in your favor
3-4 weeks vacations depending on seniority.
cons:
Lots of talk about work life balance, but that is largely lip service.  This is a manufacturing company at its core, any consideration of balance goes out the window as soon as there is even a hint it will affect production.  This applies to R&D, production and consumption (sales)....the fabs must continue to run at all costs.

Employee evaluations are a game you must play well.  There is a force fit to the bell curve within a group.  The tails of the curve are where things happen, for promotions or getting flagged as an under performer.

It's better to be on a weak team so you can stand out more easily.  If you wind up on a strong team you may be a star performer but if everyone else is too, then you wind up in the middle of the pack when it comes to evaluations, raises & promotions.  Play the game or remain stuck in the middle.

review_title: Good place to work... for QA or Electronic engineers
pros: There are lots to learn, you always have the opportunity to work on top notch technology. Company offers good benefits, it cares about you as a professional and as a person, there is a good work-life balance and it has a very nice and modern campus.
cons: Mexico is just a validation center, there are no software development teams thus, there's not much to offer for software engineers. Besides, Mexico restricts all international transfers, so there are no real professional development opportunities other than validation or management.

pros: Good total compensation package. Great place to work. Very good work life balance. A lot opportunities to try different things. Excellent vacation.
cons: There's a yearly review process that is useless. Pay rises don't keep up with inflation. Growth opportunities are scarce and there's no room to grow technically. Expectations are too high to get even a mediocre rise. Benefits once great are slowly eroding. If you want to grow by staying technical then this is not a company for you.

job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good pay, good benefits, meaningful work.  There is also an attempt (usually successful) to make Intel a Great Place to Work (GPTW).
cons: The IP restrictions can leave you somewhat in the dark about other aspects of the company.  This likely has a small negative impact on Intel's success (though the protection of IP may be worth it), but it can feel stifling.

job_title: Applications Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: If you have the right stuff, the sky is the limit. Intel culture states employees own their career development; my management never drove me hard down any one path.
cons: If you don't get stay current on skills that are transferable to other companies, even if you do your job well, you could have difficulty finding work if you're laid off.

pros: Intel has good benefits, and a great work environment. One gets to work at leading edge technology with some really smart co-workers.
cons: Every company has some good and bad things about them, and Intel is no exception.  Intel is trying to encourage more women to join the tech company, but it needs to put more effort in it.

pros: Intel has good benefits, and a great work environment. One gets to work at leading edge technology with some really smart co-workers.
cons: Every company has some good and bad things about them, and Intel is no exception.  Intel is trying to encourage more women to join the tech company, but it needs to put more effort in it.

pros: Smart people who are willing to help, interesting work, leading company. Lots and lots to learn, likely won't get bored at this job. The location is great with awesome views.
cons: Some long hours required, lots of stuff to learn right away since there are so many products/procedures/etc.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Open lines of communication throughout, good salary, benefits. Intel provide (for the most part) a good infrastructure for new employees to find their feet and get trained. The processes and BKMs are meticulously laid out.
cons: Very bureaucratic, people are more concerned in deflecting responsibilities than solving real issues, people are placed haphazardly interms of projects or 'ownership'- past experience or expertise are not considered,

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Intel benefits are very solid, the work is very stable.   The environment is very professional.   You can expect lots of attention to be paid on things like ergonomics and safety.
cons: Messages seem whitewashed and PC, sometimes I think to the point that the truth behind the message is lost.    Bureaucracy is rampant and stagnating.

pros: Excellent place to work- consistently had good managers and worked with talented and personable people. Performance is well rewarded, and there are opportunities to learn for those who want to push themselves. I only left because I was offered a unique opportunity that closer aligned to my personal interests.
cons: Intel is a large company, and the division of labor is fairly narrow, so you may get locked into a specific set of duties for a long time, as it takes a long time to move up. Such is the case with most big companies, though.

job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Columbia, SC
pros: A great opportunity to work with very intelligent individuals and challenging projects.  Work/life balance depends on the team - can be good or can be very bad.
cons: Very hard to grow career at smaller sites.  Recent downsizing decisions seemed unfair to specific groups - specific age groups and people recently hired to teams seemed to be trimmed immediately from the company.

pros: Great pay and greatgreat benefits,
cons: Long hours, high stress. Review process makes genuine teamwork impossible. Most of the "old" employees  (with more than 10 yrs at Intel) are gone now because of layoffs & restructuring. Good luck figuring out the best way to do things anymore!

job_title: Graphics Validation Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: The code of conduct is well enforced, people are respectful and friendly. There are a lot of amenities for employees and a good environment.
cons: You collaborate with people from other time zones and it sometimes is inconvenient to meet with them. They use a meritocracy based employee rating (focal), but it not always rewards people who work hard or complete a lot of work and it's hard to get promotions in general.

review_title: A really big company - very average
job_title: Senior S/W Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Intel is a marque of technology and a market leader and  the products are the best. Lots of smart people, and opportunities to work on interesting things.  

They pay is good as the benefits. 

Welcoming and diverse environment to under represented groups.

Great for new collage grads (NCG). Every year we get a new influx of NCGs.

Intel is a brand that is recognized around the world. People are impressed when you tell them you work there. 

Pretty decent discounts on some Intel products.

Good energy and a nice campus.
cons:
The IT sucks bad, world class bad. They are constantly updating, then fixing stuff. It's make it difficult to get work done some days.  

They seem to chase a lot of rainbows, as seen on the TV ads. The research is important, but they cut costs on every day expenses and seem to get another pet project. The project will last 6 months and they abandon that one and move to the next hot topic of the week. 

Too many social programs and diversity quotas. I get multiple invites every day talking for this group or inclusion of blah blah.  When did my ethnicity or sexual preference become a topic for work?

If we all just do our work it, shouldn't matter who we are. While everyone should feel comfortable, its just too much feel good stuff.

pros: Great place to work. Best benefits in industry. Medical Insurance is top-tier, best Fidelity 401K plan with select funds, 6% annual income contribution to retirement plan, 8 week paid time off for paternity leave, 3 wks vacation (4 wks after 10yrs) plus holidays; additional 4 week paid time off after 4 yrs or 8 weeks paid time off after 7 yrs; On-site medical and fitness centers at major locations; Excellent separation packages during headcount reductions (as long as you performed well).
cons: Upward mobility is limited in manufacturing division of the company.

review_title: Massive changes over the years and leadership problems driving lack of control and chaos in construction organization
pros: Never a dull moment. Always busy. It is a company making a challenging transformation that some may consider to be epic.
cons: Chaos and lack of experienced leadership driving frustration in the organization.  Struggling to manage through transformation without breaking the spirit of the developing organization

job_title: IT Manager in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Great place to work, great environment for development and career advancement. Great set of benefits, from bonuses to health insurance, Gym, flexible working hours in some cases. IT department is 3rd in size world wide with many different areas to grow to...
cons: Very variable conditions, typical of high tech, fast pace companies, force a continuous re structuring/re evaluation of the working model.

review_title: Biggest technical employee in Gdansk region
pros:
Various projects developed on site, so everyone can find something for him.
No problems with switching teams.
cons:
Formal and complicated way of promotions, also on engineer path.
It is not enough just to show leadership and technical skills - you need to fulfill various non-technical criteria in last few years to be promoted.
As a low-cost-geo site, in most projects you are just treated as "worker", while US teams are filling their "leadership" tables for their promotions.
In Gdańsk site most engineers are grade 6-7, while in US people with same skillset  are 1-2 grade higher.

review_title: Toxic work culture | no value for hard work
pros: good work life balance, good work if you get good team, and good people in that team. but know some people who manage to survive by just being loud mouths and networking, and not doing actual work
cons: No transparency, too much politics, ego driven managers, uncountable reorganizations, no scope for growth, hard work doesn't promote you but impressing the manager/management does and none of the company's value applies to the work culture, just a company filled with bunch of old people, waiting for their retirement, making important decisions

pros: Growth opportunity, verity of projects, ability to move across groups, rotation program, direct and clear communication, leader in the industry, large industrial and academic visibility
cons: inter office politics, lack of personal relationship, dry and dull culture, sloppy dress code, culture of promoting unqualified and those who provide lip services an not those with merits and leadership capabilities.

review_title: Great place to start, not to grow.
job_title: Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-Name on resume
-Good place to get exposure in corp finance, very well regarded in the valley
-pay is competitive
-benefits are good
cons:
-9-5 is rare nowadays, more like 8-6. Still not bad.
-Not a lot of growth opportunities, especially if you're not willing to relocate to other Intel sites.
-Not a lot of vision outside of your silo

pros: The people were most excellent to work with.  This company varies greatly group to group.  I was in a group with a great bunch of people.
cons: Bad apples stick around for a very long time.  Once a persons are in the company will try and keep then around in hopes of reforming bad employees.

review_title: Satisfied, but too much work. No life
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good benefit, Stable jobs and always get compensated
cons:
Work load is crazy, more than 12 hrs a day.
Work hours is out of control, trying to manage 8 hrs or max 10 hrs a day but can't make it. always 12-24 hrs a day
Rate and Ranking Sucks!!!! you've work so hard and when compared to other employees that didn't do much, always get at the bottom of the list. Depends on the MANAGER, if he or she knows how to convince others, then, you will be at the top.
