review_title: Experience varies significantly depending on which business unit you are
job_title: Business Development Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Big brand name recognition and a market leader
- Decent pay and benefits
- Intel has lots of resources at its disposal
- Intel has a very diverse product portfolio and invested in many different industries 
- Lots of opportunities for movement within the company
cons:
- Lots and lots and lots of bureaucracy, red tape and internal politics
- Big corp moves slow
- Individual contributors have little say in strategy

review_title: Amazingly fulfilling... one of the best thing that can happen to your professional life
job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: A very diverse yet professional environment. People at Intel have willingness to help others and strive to excel in their own path, The company's policy to maintain discipline, provide satisfaction and an excellent quality of work to the customers. And Intel breeds risk taking and innovation.
cons: Personal efforts seldom gets overlooked when working in a huge company. Not many opportunities to work on variety of things.

review_title: Amazingly fulfilling... one of the best thing that can happen to your professional life
job_title: Graphics Software Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: A very diverse yet professional environment. People at Intel have willingness to help others and strive to excel in their own path, The company's policy to maintain discipline, provide satisfaction and an excellent quality of work to the customers. And Intel breeds risk taking and innovation.
cons: Personal efforts seldom gets overlooked when working in a huge company. Not many opportunities to work on variety of things.

review_title: Great Benefits, Work with great and very brilliant co-workers
pros: Intel has some of the most brilliant and dedicated employees everywhere. They want to do their best and in return you feel compelled to step up your game. Great benefits and in general salary.
cons: Not clear who actually gets to make the decision. Everyone seems to get a vote. Intel is at an inflection point in it's history and needs to find out where they will be headed.  there is alot of cogs in various areas of the company who really don't have passion for what they do.

review_title: Intel Malaysia - Great Place to work? Maybe not...
job_title: Platform Design Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: Almost everybody in the country knows Intel's benefits are always the top 10 in the country. Employee discounts, monthly subsidy for food, good panel of hospital and clinics, annual comprehensive health check, the RSUs and of course the wonderful Employee Bonus, Cash Bonus and 6th month 1/2 month bonus.
cons:
Let's see what went wrong with Intel Malaysia:

The company used to be what it always evangelise = Great Place To Work. I'm talking about the early 2000s. Everybody treat everybody with respect, knowledge is gained and shared. Employees are treated as humans. An Intel employee was very proud to be working there.

Today, the company is a mess. Projects are getting more and more stressful. Employees focus on taking care of their own interests and the ugly side of office politics rears its head. Now it's only about "Hire and Fire"... it's not uncommon to hear about which department or group got closed down, employees getting retrenched, or moved to jobs that they don't care anything about. It's all about survival in Intel now. Gone are the days of making great technologies that will change the world. Unfortunately, many working there are still delusional, everyday hoping that their INTC stock price would go back up to more than USD100++ like the days of old. Oh well... that's not gonna happen... not with the Intel today.

You might be hired for a certain job, but don't be surprised if your manager transferred you to a totally different job upon joining. Employees are treated as an item in a spreadsheet instead of valuable talent. Sorry, it's true even though you want to disagree.

If you have to chance to go into one of their 'design centres', immediately you'll notice the sombre and depressed mood the employees are in. A certain design centre is famous for its Dungeon Mood which, in my opinion, is counter productive.

Let's not talk too much on the focal system. I can only describe it in two words = Career Killer.

review_title: Great place to work at Intel Barcelona
pros:
You get the opportunity to work at one of the top semiconductor companies in a country where there are not so many companies dedicated at semiconductors. Great place to work, really smart people there.

Even that it is a small Intel site, Barcelona works on pretty important projects for the company. Several of the key decissions of the project are taken by the Barcelona people.
cons: Getting a project cancelled after a lot of months of work is something usual at big companies like Intel. You have to get used to it...

review_title: Intel is a great place to work with many opportunities
pros: Intel is a great place to work - you work with smart people and interesting projects. Business objectives are communicated clearly. There is a shuttle to/from some of the sites. In Folsom, there is a nice new gym.
cons: As with any larger company, sometimes it takes longer for decisions to be made/approved

job_title: Staff Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: There's few other places in the world where you live and breathe latest silicon manufacturing technology. You get to work on interesting products with huge impacts. Development through lateral movement is encouraged. 8-week paid sabbatical every seven years. Cash bonus typically at 20%-40% level. Generous retirement contribution (6%, through profit sharing plan). Meritocracy in general.
cons: Some teams have become more process oriented than result oriented. No bad news on intranet headline.

review_title: Great company, Great people, and brighter future
pros: The quality and variety of the people that you work for and with is top notch,  It will challenge you to be on.  I have had a variety of opportunities in my 20+ years and have very seldom been bored.  New CEO is improving accountability and expectations for the company and leadership.
cons: Stress can be challenging if not managed properly,  also Constructive Confrontational style is not for everyone and can take some getting used to.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
*Opportunities to learn actual engineering work
*Open culture - leadership communicates to employees frequently, co-workers are approachable and willing to mentor
*Great benefits typical of a large, successful company
cons:
*Deadline pressures can affect work-life balance
*If worker not proactive, then they won't be able to influence and shape their careers
*Decision-making is sometimes slow due to layers of red tape typical of large companies

job_title: Analog Validation Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
Great work/life balance
Interesting activities to not keep you bored
They try and make the employees happy, good perks and compensation plan.
It is easy to make lateral moves within the company and explore a whole new field of engineering
cons: Management is a little subjective when it comes to promotions, there's supposedly a system based in merit in place, but it all comes down to politics at the end.

job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Intel is a fast paced and aggressive environment, which provides opportunity for the brightest to excel. There is plenty of opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: Finding work life balance can be difficult, especially for mid-level management and engineers. During ramp activities, expect to work at least 60 hrs a week and be on call for months on end.

pros: Working at Intel enables you to work with fantastic technology, brilliant people, and have daily challenging work.
cons: Suffer from "Big Ship, Undersized Rudder" syndrome.  Agility in decision making is a virtue which is talk about a lot, but in practice it's very difficult existing leaders to move.

pros: They really worked with you on scheduling. I can recall a time I needed to get my daughter early from school and they let me go without a hitch.
cons: They tend to micromanage the employees. The managers like to get the recognition for the work of the employees. There isnt much you can say that is bad.

review_title: NO LONGER A GREAT PLACE TO WORK!
pros:
worked with many talented people with amazing educational backgrounds and wonderful personalities.  

Great benefits for employees.  Decent medical insurance and PTO.
cons:
Performance review process is horrible.  Getting a successful on a review has become the new reason to lay employees off.   In some groups employees are locked into a position in which there is no time to develop your career; employees get stuck doing the job of 3 people and at review process get reprimanded or laid off for not doing anything else.  

Beginning to have very scandalous labor practices on employees.   HR is very deceitful!!!!  Managers are told to give lower stock level shares no matter if employees deserved it or not and little did these managers know HR used it as a criteria lay off thousands of employees.   

Questionable criteria for laying people off.   If an employee is over 40 it is an automatic target for future lay offs.   

For anybody looking to work at Intel keep in mind 75% is fitting in plus self-promoting and 25% work.   Try not to get locked into a position in which you cannot work on your own PR and development because the company will use all the Hardwork you just gave them against you at review time.  

Seeing lots of very good employees being tossed out of the company and told you are never allowed to come back!  Meanwhile,  the employee has just given many years of great service to the company and then being treated like a criminal.   

Loyalty to the company only goes one way!  Don't waste your time being loyal to Intel only be loyal to yourself and work on self-promotion.   

Hard Work is kind of recognized but without the self PR piece is will not be rewarded but later reprimanded.   

For employees affected in this round of layoffs it sincerely was not due to low performance but more so lack of upper management making incompetent decisions.

pros: When working at Intel you get to work with the latest and greatest technologies and products. The people at Intel love technology and the products you help launch power so many great devices.
cons: Products can be slow coming to market and sometimes are not supported with marketing to drive awareness. Often times decision making can be slow and sometimes it's not clear who is the decision maker.

pros: Have worked for 6 years as full time employee.  Great work life Balance. Good perks. Lot of independence to employees.
cons: Have to take path which business needs. Lot of politics. No job security all the years/days they say you are a great performer and they may ask you to leave if company is not doing well by considering you as a low performer.

pros: The technology is great and there is a lot of learning to be had.  It is a chance to work on the latest technologies and gain a lot of good experience.
cons: It is not the company it used to be.  Management has changed from taking care of people to protecting profit.  Although the technical side is cutting edge, the company is no longer forward thinking.  They have missed the boat on a lot of opportunities and so no signs of changing.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros:
- good benefits package
- good work/life balance with the possibility to work from home on some days
- opportunities for growth if you own your personal development
- interesting projects and opportunity to get work with new technologies
- great teams
- good working environment (ergonomic desks and chairs, good private healthcare plan)
- team buildings within teams or on company level
cons:
- a little chaotic at times
- company directions and goals are not so clear to regular engineers
- duplicate work (within different teams in the company)
- fast-paced environment, with projects getting cancelled and focus changing frequently

pros: Good package, Good colleagues, Not much internal politics, Warm up exercises (if applicable) are practical, provides personal annual health check up and also for one family member.
cons: Trying to match timings with US counterpart may end up Indians working for 12 hours or more. Some people say it is easier to get promotions if you are located abroad.

review_title: Amazing Company, Amazing Benefits, Amazing People
pros: Intel's company culture is absolutely amazing. Not only was everyone absolutely friendly, but you can tell that people are genuinely happy to be there. In addition, the benefits are top of the notch.
cons: I think there is always a con to a large corporation environment, but Intel does a good job of trying to create a small team environment within the bigger company.

job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Lots of budget to do very simple things
A lot of possibilities if the marketing organization can get their act together.
Easy KPI and very simple view in modern marketing 
Very exciting technology
cons: The new HQ leader for regional marketing seems to be clueless. This is led by next level of clueless-ness. Only cares about budget spent, no one seems to care about the outcome. A lot of red tapes to get simple thing done. The management setup many committees with a lot of people making comments. Lots of talk, no action. It seems like a lot of people are responsible for very small functions. Everything is about having beautiful PowerPoint slides.

review_title: A lot to learn. You'll love the job if you are interested in physical design.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good team, work culture, easy going. 9-5 job. Decent salary, a lot of company events, perks, decent bonus and increment in salary.
cons: Many teams filled with a lot of managers, few good engineers. Lacks work excitement. A lot of work is repetitive. Managers really need a course in management, conducting meetings. No efficient way for knowledge transfer between senior engineers and college graduates.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Competitive compensation; 20% telecommuting; broad scope of work.
cons: Upper-management seems unaware of the struggles of those in the trenches. It doesn't feel like employees are valued; i.e. we're treated as expenses to be minimized.

review_title: Excellent pay. Lot of mess and pressure
pros:
The monthly paycheck, especially in the months of the bonuses.
Flexibility with work from home
cons:
The senior managers care only if a task was done or not. They don't go into details and it's hard to explain them about unexpected difficulties that cause delays. The direct managers are effected from this attitude and the pressure is reflected to the employees.

we were required to maintain a weekly plan of our work for the following 4-5 months  with estimation of effort for each task. However things were very dynamic and it's hard to know in advance how much time each task will span. Moreover it's hard to have estimation when you don't know the task in details yet.

The Weekly Status Updates should been sent to the whole division (~45 people) although many employees have nothing to do with my work in weekly resolution (and the vice versa- i don't have any interest with getting so much weekly updates). It caused unnecessary tension because some employees "pumped up" their weekly status and made it look like the others achieve much less.

When someone worked from home/ had to leave early / had to come late/ took day off- then it was customary to send notice to the whole division (again, most of the 45 people are not affected with my work)

There are many meetings that just waste time.  For each problem managers set a meeting and expect to hear easy solutions, they don't get responsibility to their decisions that create the problems from the first place.

Personally i worked many hours to get over the mess created by the methodology of work that was decided by the managers. I didn't feel to get respect for it and it  didn't affected managers to accept my suggestions to change this methodology.

No need to mention that the "birthday vacation" and the "7 year sabbatical" are only gimmicks

pros:
Salary is good enough
Documentary database is filled good enough 
You have good medical insurance
GYM on-site - nice thing
cons:
Intel like most huge corporate is just juicing you. Paid you good enough salary but you are feel like squeeze lemon.
Your manager is smiling to you ans do not require but asking to do something but it is not ask - it's must!
Your colleges are smiling to you but it is nothing. They try advance at your expense and before you. They every time say "yes, i'll help you"  but actually not.

pros: Great challenge, experience, and flexibility. You can pick your career at Intel and it is easy to move around.
cons: Intel is a very challenging environment to work in for an IT professional. The average Intel customer is much more technical than most in the industry and the staff level is lower than most shops have. This means you have 30-50% more work that is 50-75% more technical than most IT shops. Right now it seems that Intel is also not a very stable environment that is loyal to their employees.

pros: I liked the team and people I worked with.
cons: The company doesn't care about its employees at all. I left because I couldn't do my job with the tools they gave me. They gave me a computer that didn't work, software that barely worked, most tools were ancient or outdated. This is why Intel is falling behind in technology. Other tech companies are rigorously investing into new tools, infrastructure and technology while Intel keeps spending less and less.

pros: Bonuses structure was the only plus
cons: Lies about job opportunities and responsibilities in interview. Company policy is to treat you an intern no matter your experience yet I was told that they had nothing to teach me technically. Plenty of social engagement if your family member is the reason why you got hired (most of the staff) otherwise very cliquish. Was told by multiple managers that I'd have to work 12-16 hours a day to gain a promotion or the ability to move to another project. Contact from HR about the lies and insults was to deal with it. I don't know who they paid for those reviews very unfriendly worse place I've worked.

job_title: Senior Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Intel provides good pay and benefits, the management is competent and collabarative.  Intel continues to train their employees, job prospects after Intel are bright.  Seperation package is much better than other employeers but unfortunately some people are now having to use the seperation package.
cons: They are closing the Colorado Springs fab, which I believe is a bad decision and a huge hit for the community.  Red tape can be a real headache and a frustration to getting anything done.

review_title: Good place to get technical experience.  Watch out for work-life balance.
pros: As a member of the world biggest semiconductor manufacturer, you will be exposed to cutting edge technical resources which will give you oportunities to build up technical background.  Direct and result oriented culture which can be pros since you don't get much frustration when working with others, and also can be cons when you becomes a bottleneck.
cons: Hard to manage work life balance since everyone is overloaded.

pros: Awesome benefits, decent pay, very stable employer. Opportunity to travel abroad and being part of a global organization. Good management.
cons: In software, Intel is far behind the industry and it's hard to develop technological skills compared to a smaller company. You also feel less meaningful, like a small gear in an enormous mechanism

review_title: Intel is a great place to work for. I left Intel China because I chose to immigrate to Canada
pros: Rewarding of high performer. Constant good player in the market place in terms of revenue and profits. And a solid leader in technology sector.
cons: part of the projects would be cancelled, for example, recent projects in Digital Home Group were not that successful. Also, it's better to have chance working at Intel US site.

review_title: Hard to stand out in a large crowd
pros:
Good pay & benefits
Great work/life balance (though varies depending on how close your job is tied to manufacturing)
Sabbaticals offered to full time employees after every 7 years of employment
cons:
Large company - experiences vary depending on subculture of work group
Little/few promotions given
Managers not skilled at career development of their employees
Changes are slow and often painful within the company
Very conservative company; risk taking is not as valued as company advocates.

pros: 1) has a good training module & facilities..as well as the scholarship grant they have given for improvement of knowledge & skills of their employee 2) always promote their employees as long as they see their capacity, ability & availability regardless of the level of education that has been attained by the employee
cons: none, so far. No comment on this.

review_title: Intel is a solid but slow-growth technology company. Don't come here to advance your career quickly.
pros: Intel is generally a reliable employer with good pay and benefits, especially outside the Bay Area. It's culture is fairly directly and there is some emphasis on meritocracy, within reason.
cons: While Intel is smart financially, it is struggling to grow in the future. Here you can have a stable career but not one with rapid advancement or new opportunities. Intel isn't always looking for innovative business ideas.

pros: We're focused. No distractions. No fluff and no silly campaigns like us savings bonds
cons: Office can have more color. There are a lot of cubicles that look alike. I was at meeting in Santa Clara and for a moment, I thought I was still back at my home campus in Hillsboro. I had to slap myself to remind myself that I was on travel to Santa Clara and not at my home in Hillsboro and my cube was not at pole G5 in RNB, but G5 at JF2.

review_title: Hard to get in, hard to move within, competing agendas, great place to work
pros:
free soda
free fruit
tv rooms
sporting/movie ticket raffles (free)
safety is actually valued (unlikely most companies who just expouse it)
culture
technology leader
so long as metrics/customers (internal or external) are pleased - most managers take hands off approach
cons:
difficult to move within company
competing priorities and flavor of the month
fierce competition within semiconductor space
culture (yes, pro and con)

review_title: Big company, lots of politics but good work-personal life balance
pros: Big company, so it's easier to adjust your strenghts to your responsibilities. Family friendly, but probably this depends more on manager. Many trainings and self development opportunities. Many bonuses.
cons: A lot of politics! Higher management seems more like they were in government. Has internal official recognotion award system, but they don't put enough attention to pick winners approprietly.

pros: This is 1 of the best company! I really enjoyed working in this company, they allow and support their employees to grow... They provided a lot of trainings to ensure that you excel in your job. I got a lot of opportunities and I was able to move from 1 position to another. They have a great benefits as well. I was with Intel for almost 10yrs.
cons: Overall benefits (health card, bonuses, stocks and etc.) are great and they provide flexibility with working hours, but base salary not good compare to others.

review_title: I have been an intern with Intel for one year.
pros:
- Great atmosphere to work, very friendly co-workers
- Extremely good compensation for an intern (PhD-level with MS in EE)
- No pressure or stress
cons:
Not too many cons:
- In such a big company, you don't really feel your work is going to make impact

review_title: Great place of diversity and leadership
pros:
Leadership is capable, and in recent year become more open minded and forward looking. 

Employee base are widely spread around the globe, with good representation of diversity and perspectives. 

Company values are strong and well suited for manufacturing and operations efficiency.
cons: Stakeholder management is a major time sink. Knowing the code of structured dance is sometimes key to get things done.

pros: It is Intel.  Lots of really smart team members and lots of money and resources.  A very unique and strong culture.
cons: It is not what it used to be.  Some folks seem to hold on to the old days and have not changed or adapted.  Over the years it has become way to political and bureaucratic.  There are more dog and pony shows for the internal benefit and have nothing to do with improving processes or products.

job_title: Systems Automation Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule. Benefits are comparable to industry standards. Respect and integrity in the workplace. Great growth potential - people are encouraged to perform in higher roles.
cons: Top down initiatives are pushed on a tight timeline, while grassroots ideas/projects can take some time to gain momentum. Salaries seem to be at the lower end of the spectrum when compared to current industry standards.

review_title: Not open to external recruits! Challenging environment of you are being recruited from other companies
pros: Good employment benefits, salary, RSU, bonus, office perks. Market leader, big spending bucket but challenged by competitors now a days.
cons: Disruptive politics, not welcoming for external recruits, architects are self centred, team culture missing, likely to be abused/exploited in terms of your work assignments, if you are from diversed background. No top down strategy, not a best place for software professionals

pros: Continues to do what is needed in x86 Server compute to maintain the revenue projections.
cons: Marketing department is faltering and way off base with consumers.  Product managers are not innovating features to wow consumers back to PC's.  Tablets and Phones continue to be strong for tech industry (follow the developer momentum and investment) and Intel is still terrible in this category.

pros: great environment. smart coworkers, work life balance, gym, can move around different areas of the company and learn a lot.
cons: too many meetings. can be burocratic and have a lot of red tape. not a good place to just stay in your current job, since the career culture is to move up or move out.  (can be a good thing, depends on what you want)

pros: Good medical, vision, and dental benefits.  Pay compensation was good with good salary, bonus, and stock compensation.  Opportunities for growth inside the company
cons: Work long hours and need to work late in the evening or early in the morning due to the global reach of the corporation.  Work life balance has deteriorated over the last several years due to the demand for more work from the employee.

job_title: Software Manager in Lake Zurich, IL
pros: Talented engineers, who had great ideas. The work was challenging, always had the needed equipment to get the job done. The quarterly bonus & salary were good,
cons: Poor management, could not make deadlines & there were no consequences for consistently missing deadlines. Some managers were more concerned with building up their teams than utilizing existing staff.  Spent money foolishly on travel.

job_title: PTD Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Unlimited funding and resources to create patterning techniques never developed before. Very high pace environment, you learn a lot quickly.
cons: No ability to move up as it takes managers ~10 years for that promotion. You don't earn a PhD to be called at 3am about a software hiccup on a tool. Your salary does not ever increase once you start working and new people will come in with higher salaries than you make and you are much more valuable.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good place to get a couple years on your resume from a well known company and then move on to a better place.
cons:
Company does not invest in employee development or training and instead sees layoffs as the easier solution.
The company's long term future is bleak with no credible plan to fix it, as evidenced by the recent departure of many top executives.
The CEO's integrity is questionable, and views employees as mere numbers and costs rather than as people.

job_title: Senior NPI Program Manager and Product in Cupertino, CA
pros:
Fast pace, technical challenge, good benefits are all positives.
I find Intel to be generally a good company that treats their employee well.  There can be schedule pressure to get product out the door list most other high tech companies.
cons: Schedule and resource pressure sometimes can be very stressful.  The year-end ranking and rating process can cause employee to compete with each other.

job_title: Senior NPI Program Manager and Product in Cupertino, CA
pros:
Fast pace, technical challenge, good benefits are all positives.
I find Intel to be generally a good company that treats their employee well.  There can be schedule pressure to get product out the door list most other high tech companies.
cons: Schedule and resource pressure sometimes can be very stressful.  The year-end ranking and rating process can cause employee to compete with each other.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Munich, Bavaria
pros:
Flexible work ours.You cn take day offs for the extra hours worked.
It is possible to work from home one or two days a week
Good team atmosphere, motivated and engaged engineers
cons:
The company is laying off people. Intel is lettign 12000 empoyees go worldwide
Intel could close the germn sites in the future.
Intel is not picking up on the Mobile bussiness
The acquired technical skills are very narrow, it oculd be difficult to find jobs elsewhere

pros: Intel provides a fast-paced,competitive work environment with excellent benefits. Everyone I worked with was intelligent and hard working. Safety is a very important part of the culture.
cons: The company is currently in transition.  Not all decisions on changes to the work force are not being made at the local level. To be successful at Intel one must always be looking to get to the next level.

pros: Interesting work and great products. Many really great people. Excellent facilities. Good benefits. Most employees are very proud of the work they do at Intel. Open forums between senior leaders and employees.
cons: Support groups within the company such as finance and purchasing that are very difficult to work with which makes your job difficult. Somewhat arbitrary employee review process. Senior management that misses technological inflection points in spite of being warned by lower level employees.

review_title: Decent pay, great benefits, interesting work
pros:
Some projects are very interesting to work on that relate to improving the current process and developing new processes for future technologies. Great environment to work with very technically talented people who have a wide variety of non-work interests (e.g. running club at lunch).
Upper levels of management seem to now have a kick in the pants and are pivoting the company to increased profitability.
cons:
Many layers of bureaucracy in trying to get things done. 
Poor work life balance sometimes.
Grad school mentality of working around the clock is detrimental to long term health

job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great benefits, sabbatical is a very good perk, some really smart people and an abundance of challenges to solve.
cons: Politics, some very bad players in middle management, the focal system is flawed and it's not changing,  data center group not growing as they like it to, aim to pay in the middle of market but expect excellence, and a lot of red tape to get things done, expect to find my people especially in manage ment where you wo for what exactly do they do.

pros: Excellent opportunity to gain knowledge and skill set, great people and very open working culture. You can talk to anyone and engage in technical discussion, even have constructive debate as long as you know its correct. Company always attracts best talents and respects employees who have the right skillsets ans domain knowledge.
cons: Recognition and spot awards needs to be more frequent, this will help keep employees motivated always.

review_title: Can be an excellent place to work
pros: Fast paced cutting edge work.  Depending on the group you are with, it can be a very fulfilling place to work.
cons: Can be difficult to cope with the size of the company and to find your niche.

pros: Flexibility, Company Car, Reasonable Goals Set By Intel, Sabbaticals, Opportunity to cover other people's jobs during their sabbatical, High-Performance Culture, Smart People
cons: Rolling layoffs, centralizing of employees to hub locations (impacts remote and field), low annual raises, engineers are developed to move into various tech and non-technical roles while other professionals are not, performance reviews are too heavily weighted by what your immediate supervisor thinks (opportunity for bias)

review_title: Overall good company. A little outdated corporate culture for a tech company
job_title: Validation Architect in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good technology position in the industry. Cutting edge technology. Stable company finance situation affects employee situation in good way.
cons: Not growing very fast compared to new tech companies in Bay area. Lots of infighting. You need to be tough in addition to be technically savvy to success in this environment.

review_title: Thoughts from an older retired employee
pros: High paying and challenging cutting-edge technical environment
cons: Managers mostly non technical uneducated rookies, highly politically charged and unfair environment (who you know matters more than what you know), highly unfair

review_title: Products that change the world, but bring your "A" game.
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Entreprenurial spirit in the company and in ownership of one's own job.  Awesome products that are changing the world.  Company maintains a growth mentality and has some high growth products, along with stable products and a huge manufacturing capacity.  Lots of flexibility to move among jobs within the company.  Many exempt jobs have multi-country or global exposure.  Sales jobs literally around the world.  Unique opportunity to contribute to a company and employees very genuine about and involved in philanthropy around the world.  Consistent efforts around diversity, employee work/life balance, egalitarianism, and flexibility are differentiators.  Compensation and benefits are competitive and varied.  Recent efforts on morale and respect are sincere reactions to the past few difficult years.  You work with high performing, smart people and there is a low tolerance for bureaucracy and low performers.
cons: Bring your "A" game, it's a competitive environment and comes with some stress, pressure, and some morale issues.  The company is strongly committed to it's business goals and accordingly there are often very aggressive projects and schedules.  Cost cutting has created a sense of less job security at present, though that is moderating.  Restructuring seems to have led to fewer opportunities in management jobs; it's a more horizontal structure.  It's a cubicle work environment as seen on Conan O'Brian; now doing some pilots to change it.  Stock prices hasn't moved much in years so almost every employee who has been at the company longer than 3 or 4 years has underwater stock options.

job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Moscow, Moskva
pros: Great opportunities if you're in the right group and have a good manager. Top-notch technologies, world-wide scope.
cons: Hard to convince senior management, risk taking is usually used without accepting or even gathering 360-degree feedback from peer groups outside business unit

review_title: You get out what you put in
pros: Pay is decent.  Benefits are above average.  Job security is better than most other companies in the semi industry.  There are countless opportunities to move around within the company so you never have to worry about becoming bored or complacent (though you could stay put if you wish)
cons: Depending on your job function and location, the hours can be quite high.  Merit raises aren't great unless you rank & rate really high.

pros: GPTW is one of Intel's core values, and it is very evident within the company.  Intel is way ahead of the game in terms of management of their people and operational excellence.
cons: Reductions in workforce have seriously inhibited ability to advance.  There are inequities in within some of the organizations and monies being spent that seem to produce questionable or non-quantifiable returns.

review_title: Interesting but had to fight with IT in order to get stuff done.
job_title: Graduate Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good benefits package, company stability, lots of opportunities to learn and try different things, multi-cultural environment, good salary, interesting people, smart engineers.
cons: Huge number of employees make it hard to feel as a place you belong to, very hard to find meeting room when you need one, not that great cafeteria, old building not conducive to productivity, terrible coffee

review_title: Very tough place to work, but world-class technology
pros:
world class engineering talent in areas of silicon design & manufacturing
great place to work as a 1st job 
have a process for everything, so you'll learn the "Big Company Way' to do things
lots of very experienced employees, so you can learn a lot from others
cons:
have a process for everything
highly structured, hierarchical organization and culture
impossible to have any influence if you've worked there less than 5 years
not a "nice" place to work - "constructive confrontation" = your boss gets to berate you and you have to sit and listen...

pros:
Amazing breath and diversity of possibilities for a microprocessor company from highly technical to consumer good, to enterprise environments, government influencing, education, etc. 
Ability to conceive, lead and drive your own projects, take initiative, and interpret what is needed and act. 
You can move easily around new jobs, assignments, countries and departments.  
Strong and solid value system with a rich multicultural, multidisciplinary, environment.
cons:
Hard to keep proper work life balance. 
Too many politics particularly on Europe subsidiaries.

review_title: Great company to work if ure not so ambitious
pros: Great Work-Culture in terms of work-life Balance. Lot of employee benefits, events, activities which keep you going at work. Equal opportunity employer and finally a great brand of repute.
cons: Religious approaches being followed and too much specialized people, who ultimately lack in long-term career goals. BU's kind of following easy/customized approaches, thereby being reluctant to new industry standards being followed by Competitor firms.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Excellent work/life balance
Good compensation and benefits
2 month paid sabbatical every 7 years
Flexible work from home policy
Incredibly smart colleagues
Opportunities for international assignments
Easy to switch roles/divisions
Lots of great free classes for career development
cons:
Bureaucracy - lots of red tape, too many meetings, army of middle managers
Inefficient business processes, frequent reorganizations
Some groups/divisions can be very political - difficult to get ahead just on merits/achievements 
No shuttle bus from SF unlike other tech companies in the South Bay

review_title: Great company to work if ure not so ambitious
pros: Great Work-Culture in terms of work-life Balance. Lot of employee benefits, events, activities which keep you going at work. Equal opportunity employer and finally a great brand of repute.
cons: Religious approaches being followed and too much specialized people, who ultimately lack in long-term career goals. BU's kind of following easy/customized approaches, thereby being reluctant to new industry standards being followed by Competitor firms.

pros:

Good compensation and benefits
2 month paid sabbatical every 7 years

Opportunities for international assignments

review_title: Intel is a company that value result from individual employees.
job_title: Senior Commodity Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: The company offer a wide range of opportunities for anyone who wanted to achieve.  As long as you've the will, the company culture will help foster the individual to achieve his/her career best.
cons: Internal politic gets in the way - I wish data driven decision is more heavily weighted instead of just lip service.

review_title: Truly amazing experience. Cutting Edge technologies
pros: Keeping up with the technology, a lot of training, multicultural. Projects are very interesting.
cons: Although it's a very good company, people tend to ruin the spirit. The managers don't care if a valued member of a team wants to leave. It is really hard to increase your position when the manager prefers to hire someone else with no experience on a better position than yours.

review_title: Great employer, great company, absolutely super smart people - need some work on their processes and politics
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good pay and benefits, work/life balance is a focus area and appreciated, interesting projects and good opportunities to work on what you enjoy.
cons: Bit "old school" and conservative, difficult to find approvers or get approvals for things, multiple levels of politics to navigate.

pros:
- Easy company to work for if you want to do the bare min and work 9 - 5. (Until the product comes in house then you work 12 - 14hrs a day for months on end including weekends)
- Company plane can fly you to other locations - easy to do day trips.
cons:
- ALOT OF POLITICS: Your career is not dependent on your performance - It is based on the politics of your upper management
- Many difficult people to work with (too many cultures clashing) 
- No opportunities for growth
- Very difficult to move out of the group
- Underpaid

pros: Met many great people from all over the world. Most people are nice and easy to work with.  On-site recreational facilities.
cons: Management reduces head count, but cannot decide what work can be eliminated and you get no new tools to do the work.  They do not value people who have worked at the company for a long time or are getting older.

pros:
Great work-life balance. 
Amazing rotation and relocation opportunities.
Open door policy. 
Endless training and development opportunities - both internal and external sponsored by Intel.
cons: When business becomes stagnant, there is a clear mood-swing amongst some of the leaders and managers. I was surprised to see how some mid and high level managers turned into selfish characters lacking professional manners and sympathy.

job_title: Lead Infrastructure Engineer/DevOps in Portland, OR
pros: Incredible payment and benefits.  Always an interesting project to jump on.  I really liked the occasional travel to other sites, and the feel of a global team.
cons: About 20% dead weight - people just trading water, not really accomplishing any work.  A lot of resistance to change and inability to learn from outside.

job_title: Lead Platform Architect in Portland, OR
pros:
1. Working with very bright folks
2. Can switch through many technology domains and travel to any campus to network with kindred spirits
3. Good compensation, restricted stock units, and bonuses
cons:
1. Poor performance evaluation process in the sense that feedback sources are anonymous and can therefore be malicious
2. Night meetings with other geos can be exhausting
3. Access to senior management not readily available despite the much touted open door policy

job_title: LC Physical Design Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Work with some the best and brightest talent  in the industry. Excellent  benefits and corporate entitlements.
cons: Actually achieving work/life balance can be impossible, depending on your peers and if you have family.  Plan on specializing in a tiny area of your vast education.

review_title: Process Engineer's have Zero work/life balance
pros: Great pay, stocks, benefits. Hire without prior experience. Project problems are very interesting, but see below.
cons: Managers are generally incompetent, and have no backbone. Project priorities change minute to minute without real cause, expected availability is 24/7. Impossible to promote. Innovation is stifled.

job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in DuPont, WA
pros: Great place to work with very intelligent engineers working on the cutting edge technology.  You will always have challenging work.
cons: Work life balance is sometime skewed.  There are times you will be putting in 50+ a week and there is always ample work to be completed.  It seems like people want the work done now.

pros:
Good perks, work life balance and work culture.
Talented, loyal employees (esp. old timers).
Makes great hardware products and is successful maintaining market dominance in its traditional market domains.
Sense of pride working for a respected company.
cons:
Unsure of the direction the company is heading; projects, priorities change every so often.
Company is finding it hard to enter new business domains.
Hard to move up the ranks.
Unhappy with the way new employees are hired - many mediocre people hired in the last few years.
Diversity hiring given priority over retaining and attracting good employees.

review_title: Great company but struggling with bureaucracy
job_title: Director of Engineering in Portland, OR
pros: Good comp, many opportunities to work in different areas, culture focused on employee development. Great technology in certain areas. Can be outstanding if you can find the right niche.
cons: Lots of incompetence across the company, many people can hide out and do almost nothing of value. Slow decision making. Very political. Lost a lot of extremely knowledgeable people during the recent restructuring -- impacts will likely persist for years.

review_title: Great place for growth and opportunities
pros:
Projects and positions from many fields of study.
Culture of research and innovation highly encouraged by managers.
No micromanaging by superiors.
cons: Not much cons. The company has lots of positives. Might be overwhelming at the beginning if you are not self driven as you are expected to drive your project with little to no supervision.

review_title: Very nice company to work for
pros: Benefits package is just great. nice ethical culture.  I have been impressed on how the finances are well controlled and smartly allocated to projects.  This is a place where you learn and progress a lot technically.
cons: typical issues of giant corporations, work life is polluted by corporate politics.high and  middle management is average. With so many talented employees. company should do much better...

review_title: No Longer a Great Place to Work
pros:
Above Average Compensation
Above Average Benefits (no to low cost medical/dental/vision, sabbatical, SPP, RSU's, etc.)
Good Co-Workers
On Site Amenities (doctor/nurse, cafeteria, massage therapy, fitness center, etc.)
Training classes
cons:
Will burn their employees into the ground (work first, health/family last)
Tolerate bad management practices & fail to address staff performance issues 
Inability to trust senior management, not genuine or sincere
Not focused on the team, only focused on individual or self

job_title: Digital Media and Employer Branding in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Intel is a company that not only allows you to bring your best self to work everyday, but one that genuinely cares about it's employees. The benefits are great.
cons: Some folks may feel that the fast paced environment and constant change is hard to keep up with. The truth of the matter is that change is necessary to keep evolving.

pros: Flexible schedule, free basic healthcare, decent but not great pay.  Good performance is usually recognised and rewarded.  Good opportunities to change jobs within the company.
cons: Projects spread out unnecessarily in too many locations. Benefits have been shrinking over the years.  Recent layoffs were abrupt and almost arbitrary in selection criteria.

pros:
Get real responsibility.
Openness to work on various projects.  
Cool work culture with games room.
If you are in the engineering teams you will get to play with cool tech, build servers, Set up gaming demos, work on the latest Intel platforms.    
I had the opportunity to work on HPC and cloud platforms.
cons: Its really comes down to your mindset, if you want to learn there is a lot of opportunities. However, no one will force you. As an Intern If you want things done, you will need to ask.

pros: This is a place where you can have access to a huge amount of resouces to help you build up your knowlege base
cons: Big organization culture.  Our office manager gives employees an impression that only managers matter in this company, and has done various of things to make the managers happy. Employees are treated with less respects.

review_title: If you divide your salary by your hours worked?
job_title: Media Relations Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: High pay, name company, tech industry
cons: No work/life balance, cold, slow and stodgy

review_title: Intel is turning the ship and is heading to the top again!
pros: Compensation, challenging work.  You work with some of the best and brightest people in the world.
cons: Since Intel is a global company, you will have meetings around the clock.  With today's technology, every employee is connected, but we are only allowed to telecommute once a week.

review_title: Great place to work, highly innovative company, the industry leader.
pros: Highly rewarding, great compensation, opportunity to lead the industry in technology leadership.  Risk taking is rewarded.  Overall compensation is well above industry average, and frequent bonuses are directly tied to performance.
cons: Can be a highly stressful environment.  When you work for a company that is the industry leader, staying in front takes a lot of effort, working with ambiguity is a must.

pros:
Access to technology
Ok salary package
Tele working is supported
In ten years I never had a problem moving hours around in order to support the work, and not much to support personal issues
Great support for leave of absence in support of a big family issue
cons:
Employee review process used as a weapon
more value given to Power point presentations over substance 
long hours required to achive much at all.

review_title: Plenty of challenges and chances to learn new things and advance.
pros:
Chance to change Job roles through out your career.
Working with people accross many countries and cultures and a variety of skills.
Encoraged to take classes and learn new skill constantly,
Opertunities to travel to other sites.
cons: There are times where you work very hard when new products are being launched and new technoligy is being set up. It can be very tiring and stressful. Also there is a lot opf paper work and systems than can be very fustrating

review_title: Challenging and memorable with the great colleagues I had there.
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Cavite, Cavite City
pros:
Open communication like it is okay for subordinates to give feedback to managers
Results-oriented
Great opportunity to learn how to work with different cultures
cons:
Not very flexible with job change.  I wanted to shift to design engineering but management was not supportive since current job of product development engineer since I became very successful in the latter.
Sometimes require working longer hours than 8 hours a day.  I guess this is a curse of Intel being a leading edge company in technology development and production.

pros: Paid time off, the company is cash rich and stable. They are the industry leader and have a good redeployment policy. Amazing talent and great people to work with.
cons: Work life balance is a joke. Ergonomics is not valued company wide. R&R is unfair in some groups. You do not have access to information that will help you with your job.

review_title: Slave driver, employer dont appreciate employees' effort and dont care much about employees' career development.
job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great company benefits such as health care and stock bonuses, and plenty of good company events for employees.
cons:
-Long hours, very traditional environment (depends on group)
-Employer did not show appreciation towards employees, demand long period of OT from salary employees and didnt compensate fairly.
-Company review lack of transparency

pros:
very stable company. 
very organized project. 
lots resource
work life balance
cons:
VERY below industrial average pay. 
very political, 
most even first line leads/managers are more like politician than Engr.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros: Plenty of training and material resources given. You can ask for greater skills development in 1:1 sessions with your manager and it is taken seriously. Variety of tasks are given to even newbies on the job so you get plenty of exposure to the things related in your job scope.
cons: If you want to be one of the best employees, you'd have to sacrifice your work life balance. Can be pressuring and stressful during peak periods.

pros: Strong technology and manufacturing capabilities.  Most of company very data driven and focused on results and doing the right thing.  Not too much politics especially on manufacturing side.
cons: Company still moving too slow despite all the right words and intentions.

review_title: An Environment that keeps you thinking and working - if you want to!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: A predominantly professional environment. You drive your career path and will find leaders to support you. Intel is a company with a rich spectrum of multidisciplinary opportunity. You can also define the right life balance for you, including flexible hours.
cons: Compensation might not be the greatest, tight training and certification budget in some operation groups with loose spending (training, travel, ..  ) on areas that yielded no revenue in years!

review_title: Very good company to work for
job_title: Senior Product Development Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Intel is very value oriented company and always focusing on doing the right thing. There are tons of opportunities and they take risks. Most of the teams are very well organized and fun to work with.
cons: Decision taking process is quite dragging. Even the area that you might be an expert on requires several people's blessings to move forward. I guess that is true for most of the big companies

review_title: Fairly good place to work, as with any big company, really comes down to the team you work with.
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Washington, DC
pros: Lots of options to work on different things without having to leave the company. Many groups are great to work with, and compensation is fair. If working with the right teams, ample opportunity to work on interesting things and grow yourself.
cons: Usual pitfalls of big companies - too much bureaucracy, needing to get buy-in from many people before doing something, slow to change and way too many people who have been there forever and resist change.

pros: Innovative, fast paced, changing the world.  Opportunity to grow, diversity savvy, technical leadership, challenging, sabbatical time off, global presence, industry leader, good bonuses
cons: Culture needing to change, long hours, lots of re-orgs, highly competitive, re-inventing itself, becoming a legacy, administrative overhead sometimes interferes with innovation and its speed.

pros: Lots of cool tools, free fruit, pool table and spa and lots of diversity rooms.
cons: I5 Laptops 4gb Ram, odd when they want consumers to buy I7, regular layoffs keep everyone watching their own situation and the good people leave and are not backfilled so you have large gaps with no one catching the ball.  Lots of wasted time,walking down 3 levels to the cafe for coffee, no garbage cans so again you have to walk.  They treat contractors like subhumans and then are surprised when they have high turnover.

pros:
Intel has the ability to change the world.  The rewards are good (especially if you hang around 4+ years)
You gain trust and responsibility quickly
cons:
Lots of change in 2014/15.  The corp is currently in a constant state of flux and is not clear on it's strategy.  
The appraisal process can be brutal.  (though it's usually fair)

pros: Huge company. Large budget to take on ambitious projects. Opportunity and encouragement of attendance of at least one conference per year.
cons: The experience varies a lot across sites. In big sites you get a better feeling of being part of something big. But if you are in a small office, you feel isolated, plus promotion becomes a matter of flattering the status quo.

pros: Huge company. Large budget to take on ambitious projects. Opportunity and encouragement of attendance of at least one conference per year.
cons: The experience varies a lot across sites. In big sites you get a better feeling of being part of something big. But if you are in a small office, you feel isolated, plus promotion becomes a matter of flattering the status quo.

pros: A career builder and influential engineering direction for both the new college grad and the experienced engineer alike
cons: Sometimes overwrought with politics to the point of suspense. Talk a good talk about top down cooperative goals but often left to own decisions which may end up discordant with management

pros: Intel is the best workplace to make every employee demonstrate their knowledge and skills with professional training and guidance. Intel is the best workplace to make every employee demonstrate their knowledge and skills with professional training and guidance.
cons: Intel should provide more free-work style, such as working at home. Intel should provide more free-work style, such as working at home.

pros:
Health Benefits are Amazing!
Pay is great if your job role is categorized as TECHNICAL. If it is not AVOID.
cons:
Focal Process forces managers to remove 5-10% of their employee base no matter what.
Employees are just a number unless you make friends with Senior management
Zero work/life balance if you deal with any team related to product management or the factory.

review_title: Good benefits, usual big company pros/cons
pros: I have been generally treated well.  The company gives decent perks.  Managers can be good or bad.  Nothing overly dysfunctional.  A largely functional big company.
cons: Upper management often disconnected from the front lines.  Perks are good though not compared to the Bay Area.  Usual large company corporate politics etc.

job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The most successful company on computer chip design and manufacture. It provides you to access the cutting edge technologies available in the world.
cons: Too big to be seen. You have to make yourselves visible.  Similar projects are under developing among varied groups in the company without knowing the same project is underdevelopment.

pros: Good Work Life Balance. Flexibility work schedule. Okay on site perks (free drinks and fruits). Good working atmosphere. Good collaborations between teams. Get to work on the latest technologies.
cons:
It feels like being a second class citizen working at Intel as a Software Developer Engineer.
Most of the work we do are enabling the capabilities of the sensors, we don't get to work on implementing complex algorithms.

job_title: Materials Development Engineering Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Friendly, professional and great place to work company environment.
cons: Due to a very good package that this company offered employees 2016 such as myself, I have to take it. However, working for Intel more than 26 years, stress is the big culprit why employee quit so early in their employment.

review_title: Overall excellent - what you make of it.
job_title: Marketing Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: You are accountable for your success. You are given enough to be successful.
cons: Humans will be humans - you will have strong leaders and weak leaders. Also, as you are accountable for your success, you are accountable for failure.

review_title: Talented people developing stellar products but led by mediocre management
pros:
Challenging product development programs and great compensation
Opportunity to work with the most talented and gifted people you may ever meet
Fantastic chip manufacturing technologies, industry partners and deep resources
cons:
Primarily uses acquisitions for new product line developments, less organic new product innovation (vs. Apple and Google)
Years of firing & hiring has bred management distrust and loss of talented employees.

pros: Excellent reliable benefits, from Health benefits to quarterly and  annual cash bonuses, they are always there and getting better with time.
cons: Lack of energy in the work environment, depending on the organization you end up working, you will find a fairly disengaged workforce

review_title: Great if you're on the right team
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: A lot of really smart people trying to get things done. If you're on the right team, with the right manager, working on a product that you know will be used by millions of people, working at Intel can be highly fulfilling.
cons: Cut-throat performance review periods lead to bad behavior. A mouth-breather of a CEO derailed many lives and careers.

review_title: Decent overall but suffers from size issues
pros:
- Life work balance ok in some departments
- Many good people to work with
- There are challenges to tackle so it is not too boring
cons:
- Pay is stagnant and place suffers from a manufacturing FAB mentality
- High management need to get their act together

review_title: Okay for a good career start
pros: Attractive pay, good benefits, has okay work life balance, for a new grad it provides excellent opportunity to break into the HW industry
cons: Staying for too long greatly diminishes your skillset; as your skills gradually becomes too Intel specific, and are not competitive with rest of industry. Lots of talented and smart engineers leave Intel to FAANG, and UM doesn't backfills the shortage of teammates, so everyone else needs to do 2x amount of work.

review_title: A great place for those that like challenges
pros: Intel continually resets the agenda in the semiconductor industry, and achieves what others deem impossible. The opportunity to work with some of the best and brightest in the industry. Intel values; risk taking, customer orientation, discipline, results orientation, quality, and a great place to work.
cons: The aggressive, results oriented culture is not for everyone. Working for a large company you tend to work a smaller portion of the challenge. Moving laterally across organizations can be challenging.

review_title: Opportunities for professional growth but a heavy price paid in working hours and bureacracy
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Opportunities to work in various disciplines and business units.
cons: Continuous grind of 60+ work hours.  Heavy bureacracy: lengthy decision making processes, requirement to educate a broad constituency, endless meetings.  Flat stock price makes options worthless.

pros: Management is very considerate of the employees especially during these tough times.  Work-life balance is encourage and support for continuing education is exellent.
cons: Due to the size of the company, management response to employees concerns can be slow as it has to come through too many layers.

pros: Interesting co-workers, fast pace, ample opportunities for growth (if you show initiative), and generally good overall compensation package. Skills developed are generally transferrable within Intel and in other job functions. The overall support structure for achieving business goals is strong.
cons: Depending on the business unit, hours and job flexibility can vary substantially (pager coverage is routine in many engineering roles, and the fabs run day and night).

pros: A good benefit package compared to other companies.  Everyone is treated well at the end of the day on my team.
cons: If you are on a "bad team" life can be rough at Intel.  There is alot of backstabbing and inflated egos, especially around 'focal' time.  In most areas there is alot of pressure to perform.  Despite intra-Intel propaganda, informed risk-taking is cause for punishment when it fails, but rarely rewarded when it succeeds.

pros: Benefits and salaries are very competitives for the Hillsboro area market. Diversity is promoted as is respect and understanding of other cultures and religions.
cons: There is a huge discrepancy between working in manufacturing vs office environment. Managers moving from manufacture to office do not follow work-life balance policies, are less respectful of peers and subordinates, and lack communication skills.

pros: A good benefit package compared to other companies.  Everyone is treated well at the end of the day on my team.
cons: If you are on a "bad team" life can be rough at Intel.  There is alot of backstabbing and inflated egos, especially around 'focal' time.  In most areas there is alot of pressure to perform.  Despite intra-Intel propaganda, informed risk-taking is cause for punishment when it fails, but rarely rewarded when it succeeds.

pros: Benefits and salaries are very competitives for the Hillsboro area market. Diversity is promoted as is respect and understanding of other cultures and religions.
cons: There is a huge discrepancy between working in manufacturing vs office environment. Managers moving from manufacture to office do not follow work-life balance policies, are less respectful of peers and subordinates, and lack communication skills.

review_title: Pay plus bonus is pretty good but stock benefits aren't so good
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Urgency - responds quickly to threats
Flexible hours and tele commuting - you could equally well work in Santa Clara, Oregon, or Arizona
Large number of internal positions give you the ability to try different jobs
cons: Beware a bad manager - poor reviews stay on your file and could cost  you in the next layoff cycle. And a manager who can't get you promotions or visibility will leave you unable to move forward.

review_title: Outstanding individuals with some outdated management systems
pros: Education and job support is very important at Intel, which is refreshing.  People are always hard working and willing to support someone who has questions or new ideas.
cons: The employee website and in-house management systems are outdated and could be improved with some strong IT help.

pros: You don't have to work your ass off all the time, easy peaceful life (again this is strictly base on my personal experience, it varies with team to team) lots of perks. The proud feeling whenever the intel adds run on the TV 'ta da da daaa".
cons: salaries bit below market, lot of competition, so difficult to climb up the ladder. Its a huge company, difficult to get yourself heard and work independently if that's the kind of think you are into. They call it a slow moving giant elephant.

review_title: Good company, but needs to learn from the past
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Intel is a good company with great potential, but continues a cycle of laying people off, then when the market goes up, hiring again.  Good pay/benefits and the sabbaticals are hard to beat.
cons: Certain jobs/organizations have been through multiple re-orgs, gets old after a while.  Our most recent re-org went back to the old silo, compartamental structure, not good.  My group just got cut, we're now looking for jobs.

review_title: Great company with slow technologies penetration and bureaucracy
pros: Flexible working hours, job security, exposure to many technologies, personal growth (courses, trainings), many opportunities to change job and switch to another technical area.
cons: There's a feeling that people that are not good technically tend to get management positions. Promotions criteria is unclear and not transparent. There's no connection between mid/high-level management and engineers. There' a lot of "noise" activity that comes to fulfil slogans and objectives defined by management.

job_title: Manufacturing Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Unique culture, great support in all aspects of work/life, benefits are the best.
cons: With automation comes layoffs. If you do not advance into a programmer/engineer role you probably will not be there long.  I was able to use that educational assistance to attain a Bachelors degree, but it was not enough to prevent loosing my job to a robot.

review_title: a great place to work in
pros: A very good salary, positive working environment, stable atmosphere. I really enjoyed the benefits and the supportive attitude. There are lots of training opportunities so it is a great place for personal growth, there are opportunities available. Compensation and perks are excellent, education is also a perk in my book. In general there is a good work atmosphere.
