review_title: Intel is an Unethical Sweatshop with a Negative and Toxic Work Environment
job_title: Analog Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Intel offers fairly decent compensation and benefits, including quarterly bonuses that occur throughout the year.

Admins are generally nice, friendly people that host (somewhat) enjoyable workplace events. These events are good for getting to know other employees, and for being a pleasant distraction from the stress of day-to-day work life.

Intel has an “Open Door Policy” and “No Retaliation Policy” which should work in theory, except for the fact that managers don't really follow these policies. Managers run their own culture within their own teams, ethical or not.

If you're really, really lucky, you MIGHT get to work on a diverse team with friendly people that know how to collaborate in a positive manner.
cons:
Reading all these ridiculous, overwhelmingly positive, one-liner reviews of Intel, a company that conducts itself like a soulless, unsympathetic dictatorial power, makes me sick to my stomach. You can't just look the other way and pretend not to notice the ethical violations of this company, simply because they are handing you a paycheck every two weeks. Get real.

Intel is a company that maintains an unbelievably negative and dysfunctional work environment. Incompetent, lower-level managers consistently foster a negative and toxic environment of finger-pointing and blame. There is literally no teamwork or camaraderie, and you will consistently be blamed for falling short on certain assignments, regardless of whether or not you had the proper resources, documentation, or support to do your job at a high level. You might get paid relatively well, but it won't exactly be a “Great Place to Work,” as Intel’s clownish managers consistently claim that it is.

Let me paraphrase to you some of the Lync messenger interactions I had with my manager on a regular basis:

“Hi <employee>, looking for update here.”

“Hi <employee>, looking for update…”

“Hello <employee>...I'm looking for an update here.”

“Hi <employee>...looking for update here...where is the update…”

“Hi <employee>…when can I expect an update…”

“What is wrong with you? Drop what you’re doing and give me update.”

“Whatever else you are working on…CAN’T THAT WAIT?!”

You get the idea. Seriously, people, I’m not even exaggerating here.

Your manager won't even have the courtesy to ask whether you are stuck or struggling on any part of the project, and whether or not you need help from other designers or engineers. He or she might even “yell” at you through the Lync messenger, which is quite intimidating, isn’t it? Everything is mostly just “Hi, looking for update here...” What a rude and insensitive message to receive from your manager on a regular basis.

What are we now, emotionless robots? Go figure.

In order to get ahead at Intel, you need to utilize the “buddy” system to extreme effect and somehow become “buddy buddy” with your manager. Otherwise, simply producing high-quality work will not be nearly enough to get you a promotion. Extreme politics are in effect at all times with this corporation.

Managers will probably not care at all about work-life balance, and will expect employees to be slaves – even on the weekends. Managers mostly give off a negative and threatening vibe which make employees feel uncomfortable much of the time.

Intel has virtually no quality control over the people they select for managerial positions. Most of its managers have pathetic leadership skills and are completely lacking in basic emotional intelligence. Moreover, managers use fear and intimidation tactics on a consistent basis to manipulate and control employees. Believe me, it's not even remotely fun to be on the receiving end of that type of treatment. When a dictatorial manager treats you as if he or she “owns” you, then you know this isn't a particularly “Great Place to Work.”

“Great Place to Work.” What a joke.

Intel prides itself on diversity – yet, arguably, over 80% of the people at the company are Indian. When you step foot inside the SC12 cafeteria at their Santa Clara location, you literally feel like you are in India. Is this really diversity?

Diversity doesn’t mean having an overwhelming majority of people from one race/ethnicity/nationality that is DIFFERENT from Americans. Diversity means DIVERSITY – having a wide spectrum of people across ALL different races/ethnicities/nationalities. Last time I checked, having over 80% of the people working at your company from India is just like INDIA. Give me a break.

By the way – if you are an electrical engineer and fail to heed my advice by accepting a job offer at this trashy company – please BEWARE of the group MEM-IP (memory IP).

STAY AWAY FROM MEM-IP.

This is a junk group, which totally epitomizes the dysfunctional work environment at Intel. If you are a hardware engineer and enjoy working on memory technology, STAY AWAY FROM THIS GROUP. You will be sorely disappointed if they somehow trick you into joining their terrible team, which they unfortunately did with me. 

MEM-IP maintains a poisonous environment of finger-pointing and blame, and there is virtually no teamwork or camaraderie within this group. It’s an absolutely terrible place to start off as a recent college graduate (RCG) trying to begin a career in hardware engineering. You will learn very little, since the documentation for all circuit designs are extremely poor and haphazardly written. It’s almost as if circuit documents were written by a slacker in high school who doesn’t even know proper English. Internal documentation and resources for this group are absolutely atrocious. 

Mostly, you will be on your own, and will have to bear the brunt of the blame for all issues on your projects, even if management never puts you in a position to succeed. This group operates on a very selfish, “every man for himself” basis. More experienced engineers (when not extremely busy dealing with their own problems) will oftentimes guide you in the wrong direction because they themselves won’t be familiar with a particular design or simulation that you’re working on. And – surprise, surprise – YOU will be blamed by management for going in the wrong direction on that particular project.

Don’t even get me started on meetings – almost every meeting I was a part of in MEM-IP was essentially a forum for finger-pointing, blaming, and chewing out employees that made mistakes in the execution of their projects. In theory, a meeting should be for employees to work together in a friendly and collaborative manner to make progress and resolve issues. The reality is that meetings – whether in-person or online – are very poorly conducted at Intel, and a complete waste of time. Essentially, unethical supervisors or project managers take the reins in meetings and nitpick nonsensical issues, while blowing them completely out of proportion in order to identify so-called “underperforming” members of the group. In meetings, people are regularly treated like crap for making honest mistakes. This is not my idea of a productive or collaborative meeting – this is a joke.

Needless to say, Intel as a business hasn’t been particularly successful in recent years. PC sales are dwindling by the second, and being 10 years late to the mobile industry is an extremely poor reflection on management’s performance in recent years – and we’re not even talking about workplace environment or ethical issues over here. This is pure business.

Intel is a joke.

Intel is so much of a joke that it conducts itself like a university classroom. Do you know how employee performance is rated at Intel? Using a primitive bell-curve system – just like those used in university engineering courses.

Are you kidding me? You rate employees on a bell-curve? What kind of archaic performance evaluation system is this? Are we taking Electromagnetics 101 at UCLA, or something? Give me a freaking break. Intel’s entire performance evaluation system is predicated on constantly weeding out certain members of the workforce who don’t live up to ridiculous and unrealistic expectations.

This means that if you work your butt off 12 hours a day, yet 95% of the other employees in your group are working 14 hours a day, you’re screwed. You WILL be targeted – and ultimately fired. As simple as that. Remember, Intel’s human resources (HR) department needs to maintain its unique quotas – no matter how valuable of an employee you might be. You may have the very best of intentions, but you will be treated like dirt all the way through – especially when they walk you out of that door for the very last time.

Intel uses an archaic and unethical tool called a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) to target, isolate, and alienate those employees that they want to get rid of – regardless of whether they had performance issues or not. This is equivalent to putting a person in “jail” at work – an incredibly insulting, humiliating, dehumanizing, and demoralizing device which, again, targets and alienates certain employees that management doesn’t like. This means that you had better be a goody two-shoes and never complain or speak out against incompetent managers/leaders – otherwise, most likely, you WILL be put on a CAP. Furthermore, managers will blatantly lie and provide false statements on a CAP document, just to make it seem like you had performance issues. You could be put on a CAP even if you were intentionally set up to fail. Are the vindictive managers at Intel really such cruel, cold-hearted people who are completely lacking in even a basic conscience? So much so that they would blatantly lie in order to cover up their own incompetence, and get rid of employees whom they perceive to be a threat to their own power? You’d better believe it.

Intel supposedly has an “Open Door Policy” and a “No Retaliation Policy” which seem to indicate that you can raise any concerns or issues with management, without worrying about retaliation against you. However, these policies are a complete joke and are just a smokescreen created by HR to lure unsuspecting employees into thinking they are safe from any retaliation by their manager. If you raise concerns about workplace issues, you will ABSOLUTELY be targeted and retaliated against. The “Open Door Policy” and “No Retaliation Policy” are complete BS. If they really were legitimate, why do you think the company still utilizes these insane, prehistoric CAPs?

Again, I emphasize, Intel really is a joke – both in the running of its business and its poor workplace environment. If you’re an electrical engineer and you think that getting a job at Intel is somehow a dream scenario – think again. You will be highly disappointed when you go behind the scenes and see exactly how this messy, haphazard company operates. Don’t blindly follow its recent ad campaign with Jim Parsons, star of “The Big Bang Theory,” and somehow get the wrong impression that Intel is some likable corporation. Remember, Jim Parsons doesn’t work AT Intel – he only ACTS for its silly commercials.

Do yourself a favor and take your talents to any one of the other multitude of Silicon Valley companies that are not only on a positive growth trajectory, but also treat their employees with some semblance of decency, respect, and professionalism. Sure, there will always be some unpleasant managers and employees at any company, but these types of people are unfortunately WIDELY prevalent at Intel. And believe me, CEO Brian Krzanich isn’t running down from his office on the 5th floor of the RNB building to tackle any ethical issues at the lower levels. He quite simply doesn’t care – and has more “important” things to worry about, anyways – such as the state of his struggling business.

Sure, you might end up getting lucky and join a good, respectable group at Intel – of which there certainly are a few – but do you really want to take that chance when there are much better companies out there?

In summary – steer clear of Intel. This is an unethical and toxic corporation that runs on nothing but the “buddy” system and extreme workplace politics. Intel is simply not the place to cultivate a lengthy, rewarding, or enjoyable engineering career.

cons: Raises are less than COLI, Corporate Kool-Aid, Managers come and go

review_title: Management making appropriate changes, still too many inconsistent messages though
pros: Company worklife balance, generally supports needs of employees. Have ability to use a variety of technologies. Top management addressing the right cultural changes. Lots of internal rotation opportunities, management always looks for internal candidates prior to going external.
cons: Inconsistent site location policies, prior to Covid-19 teams could be located across 4 or more sites within the US at times. While there are no offices at Intel, seems more and more execs just taking over conference rooms vs truly fostering an open environment.

review_title: Quick pace, stressful, creative, and with potential of significant financial return.
job_title: Marketing Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: There is an openness from people to accept your ideas. Intel is a very mature company so there is processes in place to get just about anything done. Also, the company has a lot resources available to get things done.
cons: There are really high expectations that can be hard to live up to. The pace can be challenging for having and having a good balance between work and life can be difficult.

review_title: Easy to find a job here if you are looking for one.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: A profit making company, if you are looking for job security, this is a place to be.
cons: No real visibility down at the level I am at. My career has been quite screwed up in the inital years as the business groups I worked didnt do any real business, hindsight says I should have left the company but I stayed around as finding jobs as an H1B wasnt easy and I hadnt gained any great expertise.

pros: At intel, you always got oportunities to develop yourself on different position, evenwhen you started as engineer, you might be able to transfer to a positon like finance if you show your capability
cons: Too many peoples and too many meetings at Intel. You will feel it's difficult to initiate or develop a project since the system is too complicated

review_title: A great place to work, especially for Type A folks!
pros:
Challenging work
Great co-workers
Interesting international people to work with
Good use of techology for employees to get their work done
Dynamic work environment/demands so you're never bored
Intel supports GREEN projects
Intel encourages employees to volunteer and provides opportunities
Lots of online classes for employee development
Individual managers can be supportive of work/life balance needs
2 month sabbatical after 7 years service
cons:
Lots of stress
Long hours, especially if a deadline is approaching or for a taskforce
Always connected to work via email, including evenings and weekends

review_title: Big companies, vast opportunities and bureaucratic latency
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Nizhniy Novgorod
pros: Big company, friendly multicultural environment, enormous amount of things to do and you can always find your favorite job. With size you also get stability, which lots consider a plus.
cons: Again, the size. Within a company that big there's also a huge amount of bureaucracy. If you are lucky and your management shields you, you're fine. If not, may the resistance powers be with you. And of course bureaucracy affects overall company performance speed in a bad way.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good Flexibility when it comes to Life Events.  Excellent Health Insurance and Benefits.  Good bonus program and total compensation.  Health Care on site.  Job security appears to be excellent.
cons: High Stress Job.  Highly competitive with few advancement opportunities.  Culturally, Intel is almost completely work focused and not very 'friendly'.  Being in an engineering role, the personal interactions you will see will be very limited.  Don't expect to go to a lot of happy hours with your coworkers.

review_title: All in all, a good place to work.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Very ethical company, and many smart people work there.  Relaxed atmosphere but underlying intensity.  There are many opportunities if  you are willing to relocate.
cons: Entrenched mindsets and slow decision-making make this big company a tough place to be nimble.  Your manager makes or breaks the place, and can make  life very difficult.  Too often there is the "throw bodies at the problem and work weekends and long hours", yet it is not don efficiently.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Range of products is wide. Company does not shy away from investing in interesting ideas. Compensates pretty well. Encourages to take risks. Senior managers appreciate young talent and ideas.
cons: It is bit sluggish due to its size. You will always meet some unwelcoming people in every company. But I think pros win over cons at Intel.

job_title: Process TD Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Challenging problems and a clear mission statement make the work exciting and rewarding. The compensation and benefits are competitive.
cons: A good work-life balance can be challenging to find. The 24-7 demands of the fab are often overwhelming and the culture in the fab is militaristic.

review_title: Good company with a bright future
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel, the brand, the lessons from intel inside - manager are somehow accountable, products are usually kick-ass, global footprint, can move laterally - not up. Flexible hours, wide array of work areas. Salary is fair.
cons: need to improve layoff process, we end up loosing valuable people, and retaining bad apples. Very centralized corporate group. No career advancement.

review_title: 15 years here good job good benefits but my site is closing. Don't want to relocate so I have to leave. huge company
job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Sabbatical, 8 weeks every 7 years. Employee recognition program, free coffee and fruit. Opportunities at other sites, for people that want to stay, stock is finally starting to climb.
cons: Fiefdoms, bureaucracy, cliques. Some ridiculous people as with any company this size. A lot of foolish teams and everything that comes along gets implemented.

pros: It provides great opportunities to recent graduated students. It provides whole pipeline of training processes, good benefits. There're a lot of senior engineers and architects, which new graduates can learn a lot.
cons: It's a big company and some of the projects are not well-defined. what to do and what to achieve is not clear. Lack a good strategy.

review_title: Overall, solid company to work for
pros: Company offers competitive pay with great benefits.  They always try to provide a work life balance when possible.
cons: Over the last few years, raises have been small and the extras are not as good years before.

pros:
Great place to work.
Intersting chalenges.
Good opportunities  if  you want to change your team
cons: Your experience is as goos as your manager. The manager evaluate you, give you opportunities and decide your raise and stock grants. If you get a bad manager you need to leave his/her team or ...

job_title: Senior Process Integration Engineer in Strensham, England
pros:
Empower employees for creative business solutions and recognize their effort.  
Competitive compensation and reward high performance 
Ethical and hold high business standard; make employees proud of their company
Family oriented with good benefits to support employee's families
Stable growth and retain employees 
Worldwide presence with diversified workforce and many opportunities
cons:
Business models are constrained by previous success and difficult to make break through growth 
A component providers with growth hinged upon clients' success

job_title: Global Account Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good pay, benefits and freedom to work from home or office.
cons: there is a tight circle of management that has been there for 30+ years. This encompasses nearly everyone in the top echelon. This style leaves little opportunity to advance or grow at Intel. If you are looking for a "job" to pay the bills and that is all then this is the place.

pros: Great medical benefits. The noght shift differential is pretty good. I believe they raised it as I was leaving from 12% to 16%. There was also the 11% differential for compressed work week.
cons: The benefits were good but the pay raises were slow in coming. They kept the pay as low as possible.

pros: Company offers wide range of career opportunities which is really good.  Also, it follows industry program management process and methodologies so you can learn the latest and greatest.  Good infrastructure to support work issues.
cons: Base pay is a bit low though total compensation might make-up or narrow the gap with industry average.  Company is big so decision making is slow.

pros: Good for resume building.  Free fruit and soft drinks.  On site gym.  I guess the bonuses are ok, probably not compared to other tech companies, however.
cons:
Bureaucratic.  Unimaginative.  Not much creativity or innovation going on here, just a bunch of business as usual and copy exactly, which may not be a bad thing if that's what you're into.  Tons of overhead to prevent anything from getting done.  

Company isn't exactly doing as well as performance indicates; more so financial engineering with lay offs.

pros: The pay is competitive with the market and the benefits are top class. The work environment is casual and the work schedule is flexible.
cons: It's a big company with lots of bureaucracy. You have to be loud and know how to play politics in order to survive. Being good at your job is not good enough. To succeed at Intel mean you have to excel.

pros: At Intel, you're surrounded by really really smart people. They are probably one of the most knowledgeable people within the silicon industry. They were friendly to talk to and very helpful in many ways.
cons: Because the UX field is so foreign and new to the company, it's a bit hard to find a mentor within your own field. Sometimes it can be difficult talking about user experience versus hardware capabilities.

pros: Work life balance, good set of people. Not the smartest but overall a good balance. Good perks.
cons: Upper management issues, too many re-org, no clear company direction or vision, doesn't care about people much

review_title: Be careful - jobs may not last
pros: Lots of smart people, relatively hands off management, lots of opportunities to move around.  Overall have had a great experience working for Intel
cons: The company has changed drastically over the past few months.  Jobs are no longer secure and the foal process will be more cut-throat than ever going forward.  The company may continue to downsize over the next few years or forever.  We could be the next Kodak.

review_title: Can be a grueling, rigid environment, but people make it worthwhile
job_title: Hardware Engineering Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Good core values; some genuinely passionate colleagues and top notch engineering work in areas where it has developed under good management
cons: Lots of rigid hierarchy can sometimes get in the way of the company being more agile; hard to see them reclaiming their glory years without some serious disruption of the politics in play; focal process doesn't explicitly reward team work

pros: medical plans and stock options
cons: little growing opportunities for people

pros: Fantastic opportunity for advancement through periods of growth. Excellent benefits (maternal/paternal leave, adoption, fertility aid, sabbatical, etc.), community involvement. Opportunity for skill development.
cons: MCM and senior leadership can be fickle about seeing through projects to completion. As the wind changes you and the rest of your org can find yourselves suddenly in a redeployment pool regardless of your group having delivered to spec on time or ahead of schedule. Fortunately it's a large organization and normally there plenty of places to land if you find yourself in that position.

pros: Fantastic opportunity for advancement through periods of growth. Excellent benefits (maternal/paternal leave, adoption, fertility aid, sabbatical, etc.), community involvement. Opportunity for skill development.
cons: MCM and senior leadership can be fickle about seeing through projects to completion. As the wind changes you and the rest of your org can find yourselves suddenly in a redeployment pool regardless of your group having delivered to spec on time or ahead of schedule. Fortunately it's a large organization and normally there plenty of places to land if you find yourself in that position.

pros: Interesting tasks, a lot of good people to work with and learn from. Amazing various benefits.
cons:
Very bureaucracy  oriented, a lot of "Scrum" coming lately, usually the trade-off between efficiency of solution and implementation speed is not resolved with respect to the first one.
As a result of work with different timezones you usually have online calls at 12 am and so on
Way of measuring your yearly review according to other employees, not according to the work done.

pros: Less Sales pressure, good exposure to ecosystem, and nothing more to recommend here at Intel after Brian Krzanich took the office from Paul Otellini.
cons: Never ending re-org, employee satisfaction disregarded, development opportunities limited, achievements not recognized, non-objective performance evaluation, unfair salary benchmarking and huge salary differences from country to country even if the cost of living is the same because some Executives do not favor some countries. Wouldn’t recommend to anybody, trying to get out myself.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: Great benefits, smart people, fantastic products  and a real sense of meaning to the work. Its a fantastic brand for your resume and you'll be exposed to a wide ecosystem of partner companies.
cons: Overly process driven - just raising a purchase order can take weeks and there is a distinct lack of trust from compliance and accounting teams.  Can be overly political.

pros: Flexibility, good pay & bonuses
cons: People here are the rudest any experienced hire would probably see. Everyone thinks too highly of themselves & have tons of attitude. Aggressive culture all around & wonder if HR ever sees how people talk & how arrogant conversations around go. I have even heard management say shut up to subordinates. Passive-Aggressive is the new trend in industry & this company is far from it. It kills enthusiasm & motivation to work with so many such people around.

pros:
+Some great engineers to work with and you are given a lot of time to learn.
+Maintain a very good WLB
+Compensation in Oregon is enough to make you live comfortable but you will still consider yourself poor compared to what people are earning in FANG
cons:
+Top heavy and filled with useless managers and Vice Presidents.
+Don't understand the point where engineers who work in an engineering company are disregarded in terms of pay structure and benefits compared to the stupid managers who can't write their own emails.

job_title: Product Design Lead in San Francisco, CA
pros: There were many really excited, enthusiastic people who were passionate about what they did and great at working with other people.
cons: While Intel is a consumer brand, it does not sell consumer products. It has really been banking on Intel Inside for too long and no longer grasps how consumer electronics and computing and ingredient hardware and software affect each other.

review_title: Industry leader, but position has plateaued
job_title: Marketing Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Industry leader. Develop good execution skills and data driven analysis.
cons: Very aggressive, political environment.  Lack of respect in interactions tolerated for employees who can otherwise deliver.  Most people are good team players, but there are a number of a-holes.  The company has not been the same since Andy Grove left the helm.

job_title: Former Manufacturing Technician in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Good opportunity to learn what working for a large corporation is like. I've taken that experience with me to my next job.
cons: Most managers didn't know what we did or how we did it, just that we got good production numbers at the end of the shift.

review_title: Big company has pros and cons.
pros:
Many opportunities to grow and move around with such a large company.  Interesting technology -- some very leading edge stuff going on there.

Nice cafeterias, free drinks, reasonable flexibility in hours.
cons:
Easy to get lost in a big company.  Very competitive and confrontational.  A real line drawn between regular employees and contractors.

Lousy commute from Portland.

Started packing people into tiny, compressed cubes, or in an "open" floor plan where you barey have any space of your own.

review_title: Plenty of Opportunity to Shine, WLB suffers though
pros: Good Company Name, There is plenty of opportunity to take on new roles if you wish, competitive salary, equal opportunity provider, respects the employee,
cons: Global company using a location 12 hours time difference with west cos (india) makes WLB impossible.  The bottom line is king to the detrement of employee meed to consider other locations for good engineering skills, like the US.

job_title: Product Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very structured work environment.  Run like the military.  The copy exact mentality works very well in running a huge corporation.
cons: Felt like a just a number.  Like you didn't matter.  Most things you did seem like just a task and did not see how it made a difference in the big picture

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, loads of really smart people, tons of technical challenges, room for advancement, tremendous diversity, incredible work/life flexibility (depending on what your role is).
cons: Middle management often gets in the way of reasonable progress, too many meetings, too much powerpoint, overly bureaucratic, too risk averse.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: for the most part it is a stable job
cons:
little room for growth, lots of entrenched politicians in the wrong positions. it is as if technology has passed some managers by decades ago.

like most big companies, at some level the managers only care that the work gets done, not who does it or how it gets done.  this can be detrimental if this means only 30% of your team is actually working.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros: Intel emphasizes technology, can work on cut edge technology, and influence industry. encourage open and direct communication.  there are many projects, employees can internal transfer to their interesting projects
cons: in Intel R&D China, it's hard to promote to senior engineer and build reputation in industry. Software projects usually are not successful because didn't find a good way to make it successful yet.

pros: Great atmosphere. Very diverse environment. Great benefits. Competitive pay. Flexible work hours. Holidays, vacation, and sabbaticals. Cafeteria has good food. People are truly professional. Company really cares about their employees.
cons: Too much micro management. Some of the managers that are hired are incompetent. Many are too afraid of the upper brass. Afraid to take risks. Too much corporate beauracracy to deal with.

pros: Very generous vacation time & retirement plan. Decent senior management with emphasis on how to drive products that are important for the company.
cons: Yearly review process promotes mediocrity. Very average salaries that are not competitive. If you are not in chip design engineering, then you can pretty much forget growth. If you can talk endlessly and pointlessly, you will become a manager.

pros: Great place to work is one of the fundamental values at Intel (along with Quality, Discipline, Risk Taking and Customer Orientation). They deliver on these values and are better than many other employers I have worked for over the years.
cons: Can sometimes be a little slow moving and impersonal due to the size of the organisation. Not always fast to raise salaries and bonuses in good times, but rewards are eventually given.

review_title: Great Company! Sometimes may feel overwhelmed
pros:
Good benefits- stock purchase plan, health, dental
Good future/products- good products, intel will likely always be on top in the chips business
Good teams- depending on your team, you will have smart, teammates
Generally smart people
cons:
Legacy constraints- have to deal with legacy code/designs for backward compatibility and evolution
Hard to implement novel ideas- company is too big
Easy to get lost into the system
Company basically is too big
Current/Former employees in the industry that have been there for more than ten years, are not that satisfied if not in management

review_title: Good place to work; experience is very different depending on your manager
pros:
* Quarterly/social/celebration events, free fruit and drinks.
* Decent bonus and 401(k) contribution when the company is performing well.
* Good work/life balance and advancement opportunities (at least in tech track) if you have a good manager.
cons:
Like most other large companies, 
* Different groups will have vastly different work experiences.
* Bad/indifferent managers can make life miserable and are very difficult to get rid of.
* Compensation goes down when corporate profits go down.
* Politics, especially between geos, slows down engineering work.

review_title: Good place to work; experience is very different depending on your manager
pros:
* Quarterly/social/celebration events, free fruit and drinks.
* Decent bonus and 401(k) contribution when the company is performing well.
* Good work/life balance and advancement opportunities (at least in tech track) if you have a good manager.
cons:
Like most other large companies, 
* Different groups will have vastly different work experiences.
* Bad/indifferent managers can make life miserable and are very difficult to get rid of.
* Compensation goes down when corporate profits go down.
* Politics, especially between geos, slows down engineering work.

review_title: An excellent company, doing things the right way for the right reasons
pros: Intel is a great company.  Benefits are great, the people you work with are sharp, talented, and high achievers.  I really appreciate the way they take care of their employees.
cons: All big companies have their challenges.  Intel is a big multi-national company, but they work hard to be respectful and to utilize technology to enhance communication across groups, cultures, and geographies.

review_title: Intel uses contract workers to avoid hiring permanent full time employees
pros: great pay, fun outside events
cons: no bonus for contract workers who are treated like second class citizens, crappy corporate culture, no hope of permanent hire.  Abuse of contract workers to avoid hiring staff positions. Constant reorganization of departments under the guise of accomplishments and goal setting.  Promotion of senior managers at the expense of staff who are expected to do the job of 3.

pros: Useful and challenging work. Exceptional Coworkers.  Good pay.
cons: Extremely poor work life balance as a process engineer.  Poor training.  Undefined expectations.  No sleep. Excessive burnout at one year.  My group was extremely overwhelmed/overstressed/overworked.  However, some other groups had more modest obligations.  Taking a job as a process engineer at Intel is very risky.  If you end up in a horrible group, your life can be miserable.

review_title: Great technical company with counter productive management
pros: Good benefits, great bonus, company pays attention to work-life balance, tries to hire and retain minorities, women.  Lots of interesting technical projects.
cons: Too much politics in certain groups.  Slow to make decisions.  Slow to fire/demote bad managers.  Occasional massive re-orgs that take a long time to complete.

pros: Lots of scope for different roles across many business units, bountiful training opportunities, decent pay, good benefits, great place to work events, flexible schedule, work/life balance and surrounded by smart people with passion and work ethic.
cons: A bad manager can wreck your career irrespective of skill set or accomplishments. Focal process rewards those who embellish their achievements or who can market their brand. Never stay in the same position for more than 2 years.

pros:
Great company. Great people. Great goals.Great culture.
Good incentive structure and benefits.Actually give effort in producing quality products and services. The leadership team is also very fair.
cons:
Due to us selling our house and moving my drive has doubled in time.
From a company perspective, culture, and goals have changed from what it was a few years ago.

review_title: I.T. is not the place to be
pros: Pay is good, Benefits are good (but shrinking), Sabbaticals are great. You get to work with some very smart people. Free drinks and Fruit. Lots of discounts from local companies for Intel employees.
cons: Work life balance (after 50-60 hour work weeks). Lots of early morning and late night meetings. To much middle management that interprets company direction their own way. Most I.T. jobs are being shipped over seas.

pros: Good salary and payment but lots of stress and highly depend on how lucky you are and what group you are joined and how nice is your manager.
cons: Lots of favouritism specialty by Manger and very bad evaluation specially recent lay off w/o fair evaluation at all. Very bad decisions by upper manager and laying off poor guys. How knows, I maybe the next one specially my manager is not happy with no reason after lots of hard working and not a good work/life balance.

review_title: Great Company for people looking for stability
pros:
Great Work Life balance

Good compensation and benefits

Managers and people up in the ladder are supportive and motivate the juniors.
cons:
Average Pay for Software Engineers wrt other employers.

If you are a Computer Science graduate and not that interested in the hardware area then it's better to avoid joining this company. 

Slow growth, which is common to most of the large companies.

pros: Benefits are top notch as are a majority of the people.  The culture is one where problem management rules.
cons: With a 12K headcount reduction and a change in strategic direction recently announced, the company will experience many challenges as it transitions over the next 6-8 months.  Performance management is about to get very serious,

pros: There are lots of opportunities, for talented individuals who are ready to go that extra mile and also have a strong manager and a good team.
cons: Some of the management has not kept up with time, it seems like they people are trying to protect themselves and their cohorts.

pros: Stays current with IT Technology.  Good Benefits Package.  Very Nice Campuses with lots of amenities and activities.  Focused on employee health and ergonomics.  Focused on female talent and career growth (A Pro if you are female).
cons: Company Morale Decline....has become less of a "fun" (Great Place to Work) environment over the past 5 - 10 years.  A large focus on growing headcount in the lower cost geographies and reducing headcount in US (but hardly a surprise for any company of this size).

pros: Great place to work, team oriented with lots of great people.  They have a great benefits package, and higher education is encouraged.
cons: Don't plan on retiring from this place, after you achieve a certain amount of time in service to the company they find ways to get rid of you so they don't have to pay you retirement.

review_title: Nice place to work - for a while
pros: There is a feeling of freedom in the company and an attempt to balance work and life. Employees are well compensated for their work.
cons: There is a lot of in-competition between employees and departments - some of this competition is not the most healthy. This is frustrating.

review_title: Good place to start your career
pros: Great place to work to learn new things from a lot of very smart, innovative people. There are a lot of opportunities to grow into new areas as long as you take the initiative to do so.
cons: Employees are not treated with much respect, essentially being counted as "butts in seats". Wide variation in management styles and growth between teams. Doesn't value experience obtained through years of dedicated service

review_title: Amazing place to build a life long career
pros:
1) Intel is huge and internal opportunites are almost always available
2) They do care about employee's personal and professional growth (in terms of both career as well as mindset). Amount of resources available, is amazing 
3) They have a full fledged technical career path parallel to the managerial ones
cons:
1) A bit of constant reshuffling of people & products in one or the other division lately
2) They expect you to grow/change with the needs of company

review_title: The good and bad of working for Intel
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Very interesting work.  Opportunity to learn and contribute to leading edge technologies. Top pay and benefits. Compensation is merit based.  Stock options too.
cons: Super competitive work culture.  Long hard days.  Intense pressure to produce results.  Little appreciation unless you're one of the fast track, super-star performers.  Steady performers that meet their deliverables without fanfare will not succeed.

pros: Smart, driven colleagues;   Diverse software technologies deployed internally;  Competitive compensation;  Ability to transfer to new groups/cities;  Access to training materials and programs
cons: Counter-productive, internally-focused competition;  Talkers valued over doers;  Politically and socially conservative atmosphere;  Poorly implemented diversity programs;  Ever changing, ever failing product transformation strategies

job_title: Senior Product Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Nice big company, good benefits, possibility to work from home, bonuses, company shuttle running between sites on West US, a lot of amenities on site.
cons: Middle management is lacking competence. A lot of push from upper management, but connection  between upper and lower management breaks somewhere on the road.  Politics, a lot of politics. Sometimes is hard to stay focused in this environment.

pros: Company culture was nice. The quarterly bonuses were good, Health insurance was okay.
cons:
RSUs grants were always small even for exceeds expectations, base salary was too low. High ups would always say during the BUMs that "Intels compensation is good". It sucked being lied to over and over again from these high ups. We're not stupid! I see what my friends at GOOG/QCOM/MSFT/AMZN/NFLX make!

401k Match is pitiful, Employee purchase plan got worse and worse as I continued to work there.

review_title: Intel GDC is good if you like to perform validation
pros: good salary and extras, on average with other IT/tech companies.
cons:
communication is not good, for some reason they use constant meetings to tell more or less the same things.

It takes lot of time to grow in GDC, easy to stay/get level 5 or 6. Beyond that almost not possible.

review_title: A glorious past; a bright future?
pros: A huge impact, access to very competent colleagues (engineer,scientist), and (still) some inpiring and helpful leaders in the mangement.
cons: The leadership, management, and in general the capacity to innovate is in a very bad shape these days.

review_title: Be Aware before you start at Intel
pros: Benefits and pay, clean work environment, located in good areas to live.
cons: Corporate culture in Oregon. Lack or respect shown to employees. Lack of utilization of employees to the level they are capable. Lack of ability to make improvements and change things. Bad management. It's not the high end research place that many are led to believe when starting.

review_title: Good place to start up career but don't stay for long time
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: It would be a good place to start up career development but not for long time, say, more than 2 years.
cons: The working environment and structure make people competing each other rather than cooperating. Promotions do not go by performance and ability but by political and racial skills. Respect for employees is rare. In particular, it is not the place for good technical people.

review_title: Good place for technical career in China
pros: In Intel A&P R&D Ltd, people can become  very senior without being a manager, which is very good for one that is interested in a technical career.
cons: The location is very far from the downtown, and consequently people have to spend a lot of time commuting every day.

pros: You will learn a lot working here. Intel is obsessed with quality and so you will have to jump through lots of red tape to get anything done. Some managers know what they are doing but most do not.
cons: Some managers know what they are doing but most do not. Unreasonable timelines and you can kiss the work/life balance mumbo-jumbo goodbye.

review_title: Too much scope for politics and cronyism
job_title: Research Scientist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: top technology place. Best place to work at if you are interested in silicon technology. Also great now for server ingredient technologies.
cons: Mostly based on meritocracy but lots of scope for mediocre people to get by with BS. Management is too preoccupied keeping themselves in place and looking after themselves than grooming their employees

review_title: Bad Managers , Lots of Bureaucracy & Politics  - India office
pros: Great Work Life Balance and flexibility in work timings
cons:
Low Level Managers are bad.
Apprisal process is not transparent. Managers can do anything they want.
Good people often leave due to politics issues
Definitely not a good company for College freshers. 
Less scope of Learning
Less Salary compared to other Tier 1 companies.
Less Sal Hikes

pros: the brand name i guess, opportunity for travel to Germany if you are in the right team and to gain knowledge and experience in embedded systems.
cons: i work at intel mobile comm, which was infineon earlier, so the legacy continues. mid-level managers need to be more efficient. salary not up to the mark by industry standards.

pros: the brand name i guess, opportunity for travel to Germany if you are in the right team and to gain knowledge and experience in embedded systems.
cons: i work at intel mobile comm, which was infineon earlier, so the legacy continues. mid-level managers need to be more efficient. salary not up to the mark by industry standards.

review_title: Great opportunities across various business groups and functions
pros: Well organized processes for dealing with various tasks. Great technical experts to work with. Opportunities available to change groups or job types and support education to develop employees.
cons: Too big to move quickly. Some org structures and beliefs are still relevant to CPU centric biz in late 90s or early 00s. Because of too many orgs across the world, the work life balance could suffer.

pros:
-	Responsible to track the critical success indicators 
-	Successfully drive new tool qualification vs capacity.
-	Led an excellent team alignment during internal/external meeting
-	Drive the documentation during certification / transfer 
-	Design, document and implement new process to execute our readiness audit
cons: - Is required to follow up in each stakeholders to meet the activity to close

review_title: Great company if you find the right fit for you!
pros: Great place to work. Free soda and fruit. Great pay and benefits. Sabbaticals.  Intel really takes care of you.  It is a great stable company.
cons: My department went through many changes in 2 years.  Too much pressure on their employees and not enough consulting with the people who actually did the work.

review_title: Good company to work for, hard to move up
pros: Stable company with alot of opportunity to move around the company and learn.  The work is interesting and some travel is involved
cons: Red tape, it's very hard to bring your income up to par with fellow employees if you were hired in below average.  There is an incentive that you must come in with an MBA to be paid fairly, even if you rank above people making more than you, you will never be paid the same.

pros: Intel is a great place to work for any newbie. One gets to learn a lot about how an actual chip is designed unlike what is taught in academics.
cons: Compensation is not up to the market standards. As a result the attrition rates are increasing which is what Intel is not known for. This in turn increases pressure on other employees.

review_title: Intel presents unique opportunities found nowhere else
pros: Amazing benefits, high caliber coworkers, and unique products.  This is a one of a kind company with a huge mission and a lot of corporate courage.  Super star employees are the norm.
cons: Engineering culture - this could be good or bad, just know what you are getting in to.  Heavy bureaucracy in IT.  Expectation of an affinity for HW and an EE degree or mathematical bias - other disciplines not really respected.  But it IS a HW company.....

pros: Needless to say, Intel is a tech pioneer and remains on the cutting edge of Process and Microprocessor Fabrication Technology. The company realizes the lost opportunity in the Mobile market and is trying to catch up. The company's efforts to offer its manufacturing prowess to third parties is a bold initiative but will need to be managed VERY carefully.
cons: The current Strategic Planning Process has failed the company. Too many technology inflection points (communications, mobile etc) have been missed or inadequately addressed

job_title: Process Engineer- Etch in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Challenging, stimulating job
Great salary and benefits
Great perks and on-site facilities such as clinic, gym, medical etc.
Great sabbatical plan.
cons:
Depending on the group, work hours can be significantly more than 40 hrs a week, no set schedule and days can very well extend into nights. It's hard to find a work-life balance.
Too many meetings are exhausting and sometimes taking time off is hard without a back-up. Work gets generally monotonous after 1-2 years.

review_title: Overall good, it has changed since I joined in 1994 and not for the better.
pros: Dynamic and ever changing, you'll never get bored; very fast paced.  Pay scale is above the average and benefits are very good.
cons: A LOT of bureaucracy,  it takes several levels of management to make a decision.  In the group I worked in there's a lot of "good old boy" culture and perception rules.

review_title: Good company, familiar benefits, hard to improve position
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
Is a very loyal company in the sense they won't fire you if they have hard financial times
The environment is very good with lots of talented engineers
cons:
Projects can turn boring after a while
Is very hard to have a good visibility to improve your company inside the company

pros: challenge, perks, total compensation, recognition, work-life balance, philanthropy, career options for techs, engineers and managers
cons: empowerment of techs (some engineering positions too) has slipped in last 10 years, tech moves to management for most part eliminated, slow pay increases ( however may be industry-wide due to economic - great recession effect)

review_title: Great company to start your career..Lacks software focus
job_title: Research Scientist in San Jose, CA
pros: Great work environment. Good work life balance. Good pay - at the market rate or slightly lower. Flexibility to move across groups in Intel and learn everything from hardware to software.
cons: Management lacks software focus. As a software engineer, there isn't much to add to your skill sets. Unless you are in a software product team, very difficult to learn new software technologies.

pros: Great benefit, salary, a lot of challenging works,  self motivation,  many bright people to work with and hardworking people
cons: Quality become distant history, upper management (director level) is lacking of direction of cost cutting.  Standardization in this division mean all sizes fit all, and lacking hardware scale able where the SOC and server chip need the same overhead complex hardware.  Which lead to stacking the deck with people to focus on tools and lighten CPU validation.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Flexible time and lots of talented individual contributors. Good work and life balance. Optional four and seven years sabbatical vacation helps a lot.
cons: Lack of both management skills and expertise on the job discourage talented individual contributors. So many talented individual contributors leaves company or their departments due to conflict with managements.

pros: Lack of direction and new management under Brian trying to play catchup game.
cons: Breeds sycophancy. Managers at mid and senior level being unsure of themselves waste their time and energy building their little fiefdoms.  Some are so hollow and act busy or able to glibly talk their way through. If one is glib, yet hollow, and willing to play his/her manager's game possibility of success is there. Rating and review is based on subjectiveness of one's manager  and not based on competence and contribution. Shareholders should question poor management, mismanagement, poor market direction and product roadmap and discriminatory practices with Intel Corp.

review_title: Excellent company to settle your life
pros:
- Working with master brains 
- Best work life balance 
- best culture I have ever seen 
- Give preference/value to the employee words at every stage
- No discrimination at all
cons:
- Wast organisation & too many changes in org chart often
- No onsite, only 1 or 2 week BT's
- No much branches in India apart from Bangalore & Pune for R&D

pros: Globally it is a good company to work for. Smart people. Aggressive culture. But open communication and the possibility to reach everybody is good.
cons: Very bad HR management. During the 2 years I worked there HR contacted me only once to start my exit process. Local management culture is irrelevant of global culture. Local management is managing the company with an iron fist and let's nobody to move without their consent. The local office is managed like a clan and if you are not in the GM's clan, you are out.

pros: Great company to work for.  Work life balance is supported 100%.  Total compensation is great. Where can you get paid for 13+ months and only work for 12.
cons: If you work in one of the development factories, you are expected to be on call 24x7, 365.  Development Eng's don't like to take any feedback from the manufacturing sites on improvements

pros:
Varied array of projects and initiatives
Great people, great benefits
Great existing and new product initiatives... leading edge
cons:
Too many upper-level managers hired from other companies and given overlapping responsibilities... infighting occurs
Has a tendency to try and create new markets before the consumers are ready for them... groups get disbanded and everybody has to start over

pros: Intel is a great company to work for. It provides employees with freedom to move around the company, gives solid leadership and management training and very competitive salaries along with good benefits.
cons: Like any large company, there is bureaucracy in processes and politics that come in the way of getting work done quickly.

pros: Intel is one of the best company to work for, in terms of Career, Work life Balance. Its built on great values and the leaders seem to be taking it forward in the right direction.
cons: Other than PC and Server, not able to get a foot in any other market (eg. mobile, tablets, communications.. ) which has led to various project closures and re-orgs...

job_title: Director, Market Research in Bogotá, Bogota
pros: When you get hired for SMG you'll have a great place to learn, you get total exposure to all business lines, you get involved in high level projects
cons: In SMG difficult to get hired immediately, sometimes getting an offer job is nearly impossible

review_title: Intel - The Former Uncontested Heavyweight Champion of Tech
pros: They still has some good jobs.
cons: Large company that thought it was fueled by innovation; but, was a one trick pony.  Leadership squander its competitive advantages.. Late to the internet party.. neurotic and failed strategy for cell phone and tablets.  It's difficult to imagine how a heavyweight giant like intel could have funked up the long game like it did.

pros: Fast paced ever changing and ahead of the curve. Pay is great with a few perks for day shift or exempt positions. Work with some of the smartest in the world. Usually never find youreslf without something to do.
cons: Very easy to reach your career ceiling. Each job above entry level is highly degree based. No promos to engineering jobs without a B.S. or higher. No emgineering jobs based on experience. Not many perks for night shifters.

pros:
Really talented engineers. Excellent colleagues.
A lot of possibilities to work in different directions staying in same project. Excellent place if you are young and enthusiastic - huge amount of opportunities to work with cutting edge tech.
cons:
Visibility is the first you have to get for promotion. Mostly, real results are not so important as your visibility. 
Big badly controlled company. Actions of different hi-level managers might to be completely opposite. Long reaction on any market changes (starting new market grows possibilities, and up to engineers salaries)

pros: Good work life balance, friendly environment, knowledgeable people, easy to move around within the company.
cons: Pay could be better, not many development opportunities such as courses and conferences. Too big of a push for minorities and you end up with sub par people that fit the profile. Not many perks at work, for being such a big companies they are very cheap. My manager kept most of the teams development  money for himself so he could travel.

review_title: So Far Great People and Good Interview/Onboarding Process
pros:
New Hire Orientation and integration has been good
The people in my group are great - Very personable, welcoming, and supportive
Great benefits and amenities
The pay is good for this role - Awaiting to see what future roles/salaries are like
cons:
Tremendous amount of on boarding that is somewhat disorganized and overlaps (you're required to do training that overlaps with other training)
I can definitely see bureaucracy that will bring about challenges, but I think it's more about learning how to navigate than anything else

review_title: Not culture for young thriving engineer
job_title: Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good salary, average benefit compared to other tech company.
cons:
Managers is defensive and retaliate against employee who report issue instead of acting on the constructive criticism. For example, they would remove engineer who report issue from shift 1 to whichever shift. Training plan sucks. 
HR do nothing much about reporting issue. Basically judging putting the bandage on the issue instead of solving it.

pros:
1. Work life balance is there when you really need it. Got to fetch your kids from school etc
2. Employee benefits (interest on car, medical)
3. Growth: They do hire the better engineers in Malaysia. If you want good peers, you have it.
cons:
1. Crunch time is intense, you might have meetings at 1am with other sites. But that's to be expected in an MNC.
2. Low increments in salary, they don't really pay well until manager level. Cost effectiveness is a value prop of the site

pros:
1. Work life balance is there when you really need it. Got to fetch your kids from school etc
2. Employee benefits (interest on car, medical)
3. Growth: They do hire the better engineers in Malaysia. If you want good peers, you have it.
cons:
1. Crunch time is intense, you might have meetings at 1am with other sites. But that's to be expected in an MNC.
2. Low increments in salary, they don't really pay well until manager level. Cost effectiveness is a value prop of the site

review_title: Not a good start for an Intern
pros: More chances of development within Intel and can move to any stream in this huge company. Support is endless and peer to peer communication works well.
cons: Small part of work is shared between dozens which delays the job to be done by an individual. Senior management focus on juniors is feeble.

review_title: Good place to work for people who desire stability and good benefits and have excellent communication skills.
pros:
* Get to learn lots of new technologies
* Nice divesity. Engineers from all countries.
* Good work/life balance.
cons:
* Politics in growth within a group. Have to show off a lot. Just being smart is not enough.
* Most of the projects end up half way. Not much job satisfaction in lots of software jobs.

review_title: Overall not a great place to work if want some real good work
pros: Compensation, good work culture , good ambience. People are friendly and helpful. Good facilities on campus and good benifits like stock options
cons: Not much scope to grow unless ur a Phd . Work gets monotonous after some time. Unless u get to intearct with the Phd'd the scope for learning is very less

review_title: Nice workplace.. It is hard to say yet, since I just started
pros: It has nice facilities and bee known for high tech. Diverse environment with very skilled people and lots of opportunity to jump higher, but it sounds like working there is little bit monotonous.
cons: It requires lots of hard work. Even during weekends, sometimes you have to get prepared for emergency, especially process development area.

pros: opportunities to move internally but you have to stick in a position for 1 year before you can move. So if you do not like the position you are stuck there for a year whether you like it or not
cons:
less pay
long work hours
Bad management
They micro- manage when it is not needed
Very inefficient
lot of meetings
Direct manager who is not technical

pros: good pay. very competitive work environment though. taught to distrust even peers; need to create a more positive work environment.
cons: tough environment to work in. very competitive. long hours. not very family-oriented. no paid time off when having a baby for example.

pros: The benefits are good and the pay is good. I like how there is a lot of opportunity to grow and move around.
cons: The bottom ten percent of the employees at Intel get put on a corrective action program. This could happen even if all members of a team are top performers. This is done in an attempt to use fear to motivate.

review_title: Great company, very research oriented. Good to work for if you are planning for a retirement plan
pros:
* Manufacturing is a bliss
* Research is the backbone
* Good work culture
* Above average compensation structure
cons:
* Too many veterans creating difficult for decision making
* Very huge political clout results in companies running within the company
* Not so nimble to address the market challenges in computing and post computing
* Career development is very dependant on one's ability to influence

review_title: Stable but depressingly  bureaucratic. Think Boeing or GM vs Google in terms of culture
pros: Relatively recession proof since it dominates world wide CPUs at 85% of DT/MB, 90% servers. Growing like a weed in developing BRIC countries
cons: Missed out on mobile story (cell phone/tablets) and unable to launch new ideas.  Lack of growth in North America results in lack of career mobility and more politics for all.

pros: Deep wallets, can afford to work on multiple projects even if some do not become products.  Usually have bets as incentives to complete projects on tight schedules, which offer rewards to employees meeting milestones.
cons: Work-life balance is very much skewed to work, employees not treated well, company shares a very small portion of it's success with employees.  Upper management not easily accessible to entry level employees.

review_title: Not the job I expected to have
job_title: Process Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Extremely safe environment to work in. The benefits are great, I don't think many companies could compare their health plan to intel's. Lots of opportunities to grow within this company.
cons: Extremely tough work hours if you work the night shift. On call engineers also work 24/7. no compressed work week shift allows you to have your standard weekend. You are constantly off schedule with the rest of your family. No work/life balance

review_title: It has been an experience of a lifetime.
pros: Great job with pretty good pay.  I have enjoyed the many benefits of working for them. I have gained a vast abount of knowledge.
cons: In some cases they ask too much.  After working 60-80 hour workweeks and being on-call for about 5 years has really done me in.  And to see others do nothing while some work so hard is really hard to tolerate.

pros: Managers are willing to listen to junior staffs and mostly will follow up on the concerns employees posted.
cons:
Yet senior management is not listening and only know pushing staff to work his own goal.
Once target is set, senior management also failed to adjusted the target when market situation changed. Besides, they always request employee to spend lots of time on long  term planning but never access the result of long term plan after 2-3years, making the co. Always to use ame method, which not necessary correct.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Pool of strong technical talent. 
You can end up learning a lot if you land in the right team. 
Lot of innovation taking place.
cons:
Lot of organizational politics hurting efficiency. There is redundancy and people look for their own interests at the expense of the company. 
It takes a lot of time to change directions. Basically, very slow moving and resistant to change.

pros: Working in a big organisation give you flexibility and great opportunity heading to the direction or career goal you desire. Here, you enjoy flexi working hour and work live balance.
cons: However, in term of promotion, you would need to wait in a long line before you could become the first three. Influencing is a most important skill you need to gain as there is a lot of meetings but no decision maker. You might need this skill to sail you through all the road blocks and difficult people.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Benefits, Bonuses, challenging projects, cutting edge technology
cons: Outdated management practices and too many organizations and departments want to compete with each other instead of collaborate.  This results in lots of redundant work and duplicate positions throughout the company.

review_title: An amazing career with great opportunities for growth and innovation
pros: Great benefits and compensation including RSUs, quarterly bonus structure and sabbatical after 4-7 years.  Good support of work life balance and flexibility depending on the role.  Innovation fostered at all levels of the organization.  New CEO making a difference in strategy, innovation and hiring top talent.
cons: Typical challenges associated with a large company - bureaucracy, redundancy and slow decision making.   Had become very risk adverse - seeing some good progress in this area lately.

pros:
Coffee and drinks were free.
Cubicles ended up being really nice, having your own space and privacy.
Housing allowance was very generous, but it is based on distance you had to move over anything else (like cost of living).
Lots of opportunities to meet people who were very integral in the electronics industry.
Opportunities for different "careers" inside Intel.
cons:
It took a couple weeks before we could ever get rolling on our project.
I did not have much direction from my boss.
Sometimes it's difficult getting a conference room.

job_title: Operations Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Mobility, excellent opportunities for advancement, growth and learning.  In general, the benefits are very good.  Vacation policy is generous and sabbatical is great.
cons: Health benefits have become worse over the years.  A lot of bureaucracy and duplication of efforts.  Not always easy to get one's ideas implemented.

job_title: Operations Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Mobility, excellent opportunities for advancement, growth and learning.  In general, the benefits are very good.  Vacation policy is generous and sabbatical is great.
cons: Health benefits have become worse over the years.  A lot of bureaucracy and duplication of efforts.  Not always easy to get one's ideas implemented.

job_title: Software Validation Engineer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It is a large company with lots of opportunity if you are willing to move.  Seems to be stable although I have only been here a little over a year
cons: it is a large company and not very nimble.  It takes a long time to get things done.  They are old fashioned and slow in their thinking.  You can find yourself working long hours to keep up.

review_title: Good for some time but not for always
job_title: INTEL SOFTWARE VALIDATION ENGINEER in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Stable company with lots of perks, not so much innovation though and it is hard to push your own ideas
cons: The corporate ladder is really hard to climb, constant arguments with Architects on the implementation details, most products have a very complex architecture that could be simplified if there was some interest in doing so

review_title: Intel - A Great Place to Work
pros: It strives to be the safest place on earth, and I do believe that they are close to achieving that - they certainly are the safest place to work in this area.
cons: they boast a great work-life balance program which is true for the folks that work standard hours, but unfortunately, few of the perks apply to the folks that work within the factory due to the hours worked....so is it truly a con? maybe not.

pros: Work and Life balance. It offers competitive salary or package compared with other companies in this industry.
cons: Hired too many employees w/o proper constraint. Always talking about the revenue first and forget the cost of operation... which resulted in high percentage of unemployment. People always get promoted if they are very good at "Speaking". Many things behind the scene are ugly.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: You will work with the best and brightest people. You will be challenged daily.  You will work for a company that has and will continue to change our world through technology.
cons: This is an general comment that will apply often... You will be left wondering "why and how" decisions are made by management.

pros: Awesome job! I loved every minute of it. Benefits were amazing. I was responsible for ensuring the snack cabinet was fully stocked. Learned lots of new skills and loved working with all the smart people.
cons: Stop firing the mid career level workers. Intel has been replacing their qualified engineers and replacing them with new talent from other countries. Don't have a problem with them hiring foreigners. But stop firing the experienced talent from right here in America.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Good pay, excellent benefit package (company 401k contribution wrt employee contribution, RSU, quartly and yearly bonus, stock purchase program etc), no doubt No.1 in server chip market.
cons: Big elephant hard to make good/right turns, lost mobile market and many other failures in new markets; too much politics inside; too many management people who really do not contribute a lot (proven from all the failure history), from what i observed there is no effective mechanism to chase the management people's strategic decision consequence.

job_title: SQL Server Administrator in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great fun place to work. Looks like most new teams are trying to compose more Recent College graduates.
cons: The company seemed to be going through constant organization change. A lot of people with knowledge were let go recently leaving resources tight.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Decent total compensation (base+bonuses+benefits)
Lots of very smart people working there
Excellent work/life balance...if you want it
cons:
company is struggling to increase profits as demand and ASP drop
A lot of uncertainty about the annual review process has made the environment toxic at times
If you want anything more than just "successful" rating, you need to consistently give 110% - which usually means poor work/life balance

review_title: Great compensation, not very for growing leader
pros: Really lots of goodies (Cafeteria, gym, family activities ...), good work-life balance, great company to work at
cons: Really hard to get promoted from engineering to tech lead, lots of competition, way too much managers don't have inter-communicational skills (but mostly technical), Overlap of the same work/products with other groups / startups Intel buys, less recommended for software developers

review_title: Good place but hard to professionally grow
pros: Generally, it's a good place to work with a good salary and great compensations. You can find experienced people that you can learn from (mainly when you collaborate with the US facilities).
cons: This Guadalajara campus it's seen more like a cheap-workforce place than a good engineer facility. Therefore the possibilities to professionally grow are low and the possibilities to jump to something that actually interests you is really hard (if those work areas are not in the facility/country where you were hired).

pros: Intel has good benefits, usually annual bonus, but depends on the company performance that year. Family friendly place, a lot of employees with kids
cons: Old tools, legacy code, not much of professional development. Salary is average, not a place to grow your career. Promotions are really rare, you have to wait a few years for 10% raise, even if every year you have good review promotions are really rare.

pros: Good salary and benefits. Lots of perks and work with some nice people. Site is very cool and interesting.
cons: Career prospects are low and progress is very slow. Not much technical skills needed for the role. Highly autotmated which gives the technician low visibility of the actual process

review_title: Intel UK is not what it is used to be, stay away
job_title: Customer Business Analyst in Swindon, England
pros: Great name to work for, used to pay big bonuses, good food at the canteen. There are quite a few opportunities for working with the latest in technology and to travel between various offices and clients. Work conditions are very comfortable, diversity is excellent, work hours are 9 to 6.
cons: Too much politics inside the company. English management style is awful, unfair and judgemental

review_title: Intel is a great place to intern.
job_title: Graduate Research Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Based on my three months at Intel Research Santa Clara, they are very flexible with respect to where and how you get your work done. They are open to telecommuting and working from home when necessary. They have good health benefits even for interns.
cons: Intel is a large company, and with it come some of the normal downfalls such as red tape.

review_title: A place where your skills and interests guide your career.
pros: The door is wide open to advancement depending on your skills and interests. You get to work with people at the top of their fields. There is a generous tuition reimbursement and benefits package.
cons: Stock price is rather anemic. The job expects a lot of you but if you're ready to perform, you will do well.

job_title: Product Development Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Work/Life balance is great in terms of balancing out of work issues with the job.  Intel leads the industry in terms of product throughput to the market.
cons: Employees pay the price of working at the giant 'Intel' in terms of salary compensation.  Have had peers leave Intel and go to others within the industry and see an instant 20-30% increase in salary.

pros: Good brand name and chance to work with new and awesome technology. Overall, management does a good job keeping you focused while still giving you room to operate.
cons: Work can become repetitive. Office/cubes look very corporate-like, so after a while you feel like your productivity is drained out. Pay can be a lot better.

pros: Technically oriented, challenging work that can be interesting. Empoyee backgrounds are diverse. Clubs and activities are supported. Free fruit and drinks. Has health programs and exercise room.
cons: Reorganizations happen almost every year. A lot of time is spent in meetings, and people schedule and attend meetings to be visible for promotions. The site is decreasing in size.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Good place to start as a college grad
-extensive use of statistics for data analysis and engineering decision making
-good training provided for recent college graduates
-good place to develop communication skills to drive management decisions
cons:
-Large corporation with layers of red tape
-management makes short term, ad-hoc decisions (layoffs and hiring few months afterwards)

pros: working hours is flexi, sometime work from home due to family needs. Great subsidy like provide fruits everyday, Car loan, broadband subsidy.
cons: Salary is lower. Project get tough and tough, but resources not increase. Long working hours needed.

pros: work life balance, profit sharing, bonus structure, stock participation plan and good health benefits.  In addition, team building activities are a lot of fun.
cons: Sometimes working from home isn't as embraced as it should be.  Promotions tend to be few and far between.  Pay raises are also minimal.

review_title: Senior Software Engineer at Intel India
pros: Excellent work culture, best in industry compensation (India), good growth opportunities for someone who wants to have a career as Technical individual contributor.
cons: High intensity job, employees in core technology groups will have work pressure at all times. Late-night meetings for India employees impacts work life balance. Limited technical opportunities in India for senior individual contributors with 10+ yrs exp. Bit of a big company problem - bureaucracy, etc. Frequent project cancellations / changes are discouraging
