review_title: I don't have words a single word to say
pros: Joining Intel is everyone's dream. but dreams are not true or last only for short duration.
cons: Intel is having the policy of regular reorg. Managers in Intel hire the new employee so that he can be sacrificed next. By this way, manager saves his own job and showing the company that he is good with the reduced headcount.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company is making the right bets and is generally moving in a good direction.  Pay and benefits are awesome.
cons: A lot of the day to day people management is really poor.   Management doesn't really get improved even though they continually talk about improving it.  If you find a good manager, it mitigates the issues quite a bit.

pros: Great Company, lot of innovation in product teams
cons:
Managers at Intel IT can be non-technical, which is a big problem
Most managers don't know what they are doing
Nepotism is big here. 360 reviews , pay raises are all based on nepotism and not merit
Software Engineers take blame of project failures and get re-deployed while managers happily get pay raises seek out other roles if things get too hot.

pros: This was the greatest place I've ever worked in all my 30 year career.  The safety  crew, management,  and the clean room workers. All very educated and always willing to lend a hand. That meaning always willing to talk safety within your area of work.
cons: Intel uses a lot of dangerous cemicals, that being said it is a very safety oriented place to work, if you follow Intel's protocol

pros: I love Intel.  It's been a great place to make my mark and work on creative programs.  the people are great - smart, candid, driven and accountable.
cons: It's having a bit of a mid-life crisis and the constant reorging and leadership changes are having an effect on the company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-good life/work balance
-on paper interesting projects to work on
cons:
-lack of leadership
-a lot of people are around because they're able to sweet talk the right managers, not because they are skilled
-management talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk
-complacency among seniors

review_title: Every problem is not solved by a CPU
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Eau Claire, WI
pros:
Great pay and benefits
A few smart people
cons:
Corporate system geared to create lies
Micro-management = distrust of engineers
Wasting money on the latest leftist political mantra has nothing to do with successful technology
All problems are not solved by a CPU nor the methods used to create CPUs

pros: Great working environment, Work from home,  facilities and commute services, Employee benefits. Overall a great company to work for long term
cons: There are many 20+ employees who have a circle of their own. Difficult to get in and gain acceptance. Need better planning in executing projects. Over all confused wrt to what needs focus - Not all teams. Some teams are just reactive and that causes lot of work life imbalance

pros: Excellent benefits, great diversity, smart, kind colleagues, good pay
cons: A culture of constant work where you never seem to be doing enough

review_title: A solid technology company in a global economy
pros: It is a great technology company with a very solid foundation in the global economy. Life within Intel resembles a college campus in many respects and you are given ownership of your own success within the company.
cons: It can get very political although that might just be the group within which I work. It is generally easy to move within the company to new roles although that is complicated by the economy at the moment.

review_title: Good place to work, but very dependent on your department.
pros: Flexibility, decent pay and benefits.
cons: Your satisfaction will largely depend on which department you are in.  My department was led by the inept people.  Promotions were not based on performance but many other factors with nothing to do with performance.

pros: Intel offers great work life balance and job security. U are always innovating. Communication within the team n among teams is very good.
cons:
Scope of growth is limited (at least to my knowledge).
There is too much dependence on Microsoft technologies. Intel shud start looking at Open source as an option(Some teams are adopting open source technologies and also Agile development methods)

review_title: Good overall company to work for.
pros: Compensation was great. Salary was good with great bonuses, and a good retirement plan. Every 7 years you are entitled to a sabatical, that is a 2 month paid vaction.
cons: Intel puts you in a pressure cooker with high stress. Can interfer with home life when special projects are needed to be completed.

review_title: Intel as a place to work
pros: Creativity rewarded, risk taking rewarded, work with very smart people, lots of opportunities to try new jobs, work with important projects that impact the world
cons: bureaucracy. You compete with your colleagues - bell curve ranking and rating.  Salaries could be higher.  Can be hard to advance pay grades. Silos.

pros: decent pay and the benefits.
cons: meritocracy was supposedly in place but I don't believe it was truely used. in 8 years there were a few detrimental corp. surprises. management weren't as truthful as they could have been.

pros: excellent place to learn. great as a first job. kinda ruins a large number of other employers for the rest of your career.
cons: too rigid and hierarchical, risk averse culture. penny pinching leads Intel to lose out on great opportunities (why was xscale sold off to Marvell? talk about the worst possible timing!)

review_title: A great place to grow industry experience
job_title: Product Marketing Engineer in Columbia, SC
pros: Strong brand. Industry leader. focused on engineering and manufacturing. Mature sales and marketing infrastructure.  Industry leading policies. Internationally diverse customers and facilities.
cons: Extremely process oriented which can limit one's ability to do creative things to accomplish goals.  Since Intel is a money machine, it can breed a highly political climate.

review_title: Great company with lots of talented people
pros: Intel's cutting edge technology will make you always stand in front of the technology trend. Also there are lots of internal opportunities that allows people transfer between groups.
cons: There are also some people doing little things and waiting for the retirement. Not very good project planning within some divisions. Re-org is happening very often.

pros: Lots of smart interesting people.  The people are what really make the company worthwhile.  Its great working there since you get to see early development of technology, as well as process.
cons: Large corporation, easy to get lost. Your project may not make the final cut.  Competitive atmosphere, also more focus on hardware than software.

review_title: not a good place for engineers with lots of experience outside of Intel
pros:
good benefit compare to other companies
bonus is good when business is good
can achieve work/life balance if you have a good boss
cons:
too many re-orgs
too much politics
too many people don't care
need to spend a lot of time to build relationships to get work done, many barriers

pros: Intel is very solid company. Great history and products. Very strong culture and employees who genuinely care. Benefits are very good.
cons: Intel is not for the faint of heart. it is a very demanding work environment. Due to the performance evaluation systems, no one ever seems to not to work for fear of a peer out working them

review_title: Rank and Rated To Death - Process Engineer
pros: Benefits were excellent, Pay was good, Equipment was state of the art.
cons: Some of the management is harassing, not helpful, and it reminds me of what I heard once - it's a dangerous assignment. I hope they learn to treat people better some day.

pros: Reasonable pay. Good benefits. Flexible working environment with the right manager
cons: With PC market decline, the company is desparately trying to gain a foothold in Mobile. Very poor decisions on fairly recent aquisition of a loss making dinasore of mobile chip company in Germany. pouring money into the loss making mobile phone business trying to catch up with Qualcomm.

review_title: Financially stable but too political company.
pros: Intel has strong financial support from the various earning business model, which makes employees financially stable as well.
cons: The company is too slow for so many stake holders with political intentions. It seems so far so good, but not long days after the company might be in trouble some day because of this.

pros: Great company to work for. I really enjoyed working for Intel. The culture is great and the people you work with and interact with are very smart. This company has so many opportunities so you can get on the right career path. Great Benefits.
cons: If you don't challenge yourself you will get board. I saw some underperforms given the pink slip twice in my 2 year career there. So slacking off is not appreciated and underperforming will get you in trouble.

pros: They have a wide variety of projects and necessary skills. They are a very experimental company constantly doing new things so much of the work is like research instead of mill work production.
cons: Be prepared for disappointment if you can't wait to get your work out to the public. Much of what Intel does in the software field never sees the light of day.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: lots of long-time industry experts. stable work environment and work-life balance. decent medical/dental/vision benefit. it is easy for individual contributors to transfer to different positions inside the company to gain comprehensive industry experience.
cons: Intel as a company is moving in slow pace and high level management don't come with good vision to steer the company. there are limited opportunity for new comer to move up inside. salary increases very slowly and as a company Intel couldn't compare favorably with other tech giants.

review_title: Overall great place to work, but things could always be better.
job_title: Graphics Hardware Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros:
Stable Company
Reasonable Pay
Good benefits
Lots of opportunities to try out different groups and teams.
Stock and overall company is moving in the right direction.
cons:
Recovering from a stumbling period
Relies too heavily on process technology to maintain competitive advantage
A little too much focus on how other companies pay employees and their relative headcounts, instead of what is needed to get the job done.

review_title: Great Site - Great people - Activities are boring
pros:
The GDC site is great even if you're a contractor (CW), you can have community spaces or free beverages (GDC ZPN not, only for BB).
Great people to work with - Always helpful
You can learn a lot of corporate things.
cons:
Racism between CWs and BBs
You need to ask "what else can I do?" every time, if not, you'll be bored at work.
Site is too separate of the urban area.

pros:
Sometimes the pay is good--depends upon the group you're in.
Benefits and bonuses are also good.
cons:
Your success--even survival--depend entirely upon the group you're in.  Many of the managers simply aren't good managers, and this is fairly common.
HR is not there for you: HR runs Intel, and what this means is that managers can do no wrong.  A number of my managers had multiple sexual harassment charges or were having affairs with their direct reports or alcohol violations--ad nauseum.  It was astonishing.  But no actions against them were ever taken.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good benefits including sabbatical, 401K and profit sharing
cons: You're always overloaded with work. Senior managers played favoritism.  There is little promotion regardless of how hard you work if you're not a favored team player. Little work and life balance.

job_title: Area Coordinator/Manufacturing Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The salary or rate of pay per hour is above the market average.  You are eligible for a sabbatical once you have been employed for 4 years with the company.
cons: Due to the recent company direction morale at the workplace is below average.  There is too much bureaucracy to release repeat poor performers.

pros: It's interesting work, with some difficult technical challenges.  Work/life balance is good, outside of the final push towards product deadlines.
cons: Your long-term professional success largely boils down to finding good managers.  As the saying goes, "up or out"...you will eventually work your way up to the point where you struggle to be competitive against your peers, then it's only a matter of time before the "focal" (performance management) process chews you up and spits you out.

pros: Good company of you love technologies.  Salaries are industry average.  Perks and comps are great.
cons: New CEO is more worried about pleasing the shareholders than supporting the enployees.  You may have to play politics to advance depending on your group.  Some managers will activity block you from moving to other groups.

pros: Some nice people around. Interviews are usually easy. They generally ask about what you've worked on and some design questions that you would find online.
cons: Intel does not really stand up to what it says. Their hiring events are just a joke. They hardly hire any experienced technical people but rather novice for low salaries. Don't waste your time interviewing with them. In the hiring event they talked about flexibility for its employees to move around the departments but they rejected asic designer saying the designer didn't fit the asic validation role altho the designer had exposure to validation..talk about their honesty to society!

pros: Great set of benefits and perks. Good pay. Very flexible work life balance. Very good 401K. Plenti of job opportunity within the company for folks to try new ideas
cons: Long processes, overheads and slow decision making (as in any large company) will test millenial's impatience (to try do new stuff quickly).

review_title: Good, but not as good as when I joined
pros: Intel definitely provides a lot of great benefits to it's employees, and it is a forward thinking company.  Lots of different jobs to choose from exist there.
cons: Competition has made benefits shrink over time.  Depending on your job, it can be very stressful to work there.  I was there for 20 years in IT, and it seemed like you were never safe.  There is a constant push to reduce costs/budget every year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, San Jose
pros: Excellent benefits package, a company with great reputation at the country level and a place where you can develop your career. If you are into constant evolution, innovation and setting challenging goals every day...Intel is for you
cons: Company culture might not be a good fit for everyone out there. This is a fast-paced company that strives for results. For some people, the constant evolution of the business structures might be hard, so you need to adapt and re-tool yourself quickly.

pros: Ability to rotate ~2yrs across a broad spectrum of business groups and functions.
cons: Very limited ability to drive decisions, poor systems and difficulty getting the right data (much of time spent hunting down data).  Duplication of effort, there's always someone else or another group doing the same thing you are and a lot of time spent getting alignment.

review_title: Not the same company I started with 17 years ago
pros:
-Opportunity to move around
-Depending on the position, flexibility
-Good Benefits
cons:
--Lower base salary compared to other companies in the industry.
- Expectations seem to be doing more and more with less and less people
- 2 layoffs in less than one year
- You can have a "successful" review but depending on the stock level, still be considered a "low" performer. Hypocritical much?

pros: Decent benefits, although they have been going down over the past couple of years. Various jobs throughout the company with room for advancement. Good hours - compressed workweek, 3/days one week, 4/days the next, 12 hr shifts
cons: Toxic management attitude among many of the middle manager class. Upper management doesn't seem to respect workers that actually make the products.

review_title: Great company, needs to work through some issues
job_title: Marketing Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Some of the smartest people I've ever worked with. The culture offers great mobility between teams, departments, and even disciplines.
cons: Middle management is a tough place too be -- too many layers of decision making and limited upward mobility because of the glut of high grade level people.

job_title: Market Development Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good benefits, good salary, many opportunities if you decide a particular job isn't working out.
cons: Becoming a much more challenging environment. Difficult to get  meaningful raise or promotion. Continue to create new ways to reduce the workforce. A very successful company, but missing the smartphone and tablet opportunity leaves them vulnerable. In my opinion, they are not a 100K size company and will continue to reduce the workforce over the next 12-24 months.

review_title: It was an amazing adventure working for Intel. Couldn't have asked for a better employer.
job_title: Corporate Services Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits, pay, and people. The work is chalenging and will keep you interested always. We relocated to FL to be closer to family where Intel does not have a site, or I would still be with them.
cons: Every year or 2, Intel goes through cost cutting. Letting go hundreds of hard working, dedicated employees is always their first answer. Usually the technicians get hit first and the hardest.

review_title: new managment is changing the culture
pros:
good salary an benefits.
there are still some good people left in the company. mostly not in management.
there is still hope that after the fiasco of current management , Intel will get back to itself.
cons:
zero trust in the higher management, from every aspect , including competency and  integrity 
convergence is used as a method to make sure all sites performing as poor as Oregon.

job_title: Process Engineer Process Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Work life balance,total compensation, opportunities for advancement, agressively promotes diversity.
cons: Lots of poor middle managers trying to carve out their own fiefdoms, agressively replacing middle aged workers with cheap labor on H1B visas. The diversity program places many non-qualified individuals in positions they shouldn't be in and they are un-touchable.

review_title: No direction and all propaganda now
job_title: IT Systems Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: Good benefits and pay, used to be a great place to work
cons: Board of directors and executive management making horrible decisions by purchasing other companies and making ridiculous products that will not sell other than their x86 products that are becoming a dinosaur..  Veterans that built the company either retired or laid off killed off corporate culture, innovation and morale.  HR is making it harder to stay at the company for more than a year as their roadmap now either to be promoted or get fired without any leverage within that timeframe.

review_title: Great work life balance but average pay for Silicon Valley
job_title: Commodity Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Intel is serious about work life balance for all employees. My experience includes little to no pressure to work late during unreasonable times and no pressure to take earned leave and/or vacation.
cons: Salary is typically around 20% less than you could earn at other tech firms. It also does not provide regular stock or 401k matching as part of compensation.

review_title: Good company ONLY if you have a good team.
pros: Working on latest technologies. Good work culture overall.
cons:
Bad attitude with team leads, they feel they are superior in terms what they know about the project details. 
No freedom to implement your ideas to write code, even if its better. 
The lead's will impose the one which they feel is correct and will not answer why was it chosen.
They talk rudely if you ask them question on project details, no professionalism. Overall had worst experience here.

review_title: Good company ONLY if you have a good team.
pros: Working on latest technologies. Good work culture overall.
cons:
Bad attitude with team leads, they feel they are superior in terms what they know about the project details. 
No freedom to implement your ideas to write code, even if its better. 
The lead's will impose the one which they feel is correct and will not answer why was it chosen.
They talk rudely if you ask them question on project details, no professionalism. Overall had worst experience here.

review_title: Awesome place for engineering and freedom of thought/learning
pros: Strong business orientation; Loads of resources available for ones self learning and growth; No one constraints you with any thing. HR is very empowering for Employees.
cons: No major cons. Company is big - working through your visiblity can be challenging but can be managed through your strong results orientation and business acumen.

review_title: Careful with which team you end up with.
pros: An elephant, you can work across any division and interact with anyone in the organization. If you have the interest and will to learn, and have the perseverance to do so. Intel is a good place to be in.
cons: Salary is not one of the best in the industry. They expect people to stay because of job security

review_title: Do not work for this company.
job_title: Technology Development Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good competitive salaries and benefits (retirement plan, etc.)
cons: Second level management and up only care about themselves. Working in D1C, D1D, and D1X is the worse places to work due to poor quality of life. You will be penalized if you make a single mistake. They layoff people with 20 years and up only taking a consideration the last two reviews (even if promoted the third year). Very bad company to work for, very bad. Intel lost its race  against Moore's law  Other companies are making millions of dollars with old technologies.

review_title: Discrimination against temporary green badge employees.
pros: Its only good if you are permanent blue badge employee.
cons: Temporary green badge employees have no respect overall. Management is biased when it comes to bad behaviours shown by blue badge employee. Green badge employee will be terminated if he complains against the bad behaviour shown by Intel blue badge employee. This place sucks over all. You can only get hired if you know someone in the upper management.

pros: Surrounded by good people who all started from an equivalent role. Salary and health insurance benefits are very good, not to mention good stock compensation.
cons: Job is very demanding. You are expected to be available nearly 24 hours a day, 7 days a week in order to stand out as a top performing employee.

review_title: Interesting career; don't plan on working till 65
pros: I changed jobs every 2-3 years, so there was lots of variety. The company makes a lot of money, so finding ways to increase profits by 0.1% is a big deal.
cons: The main downside is that management at the highest levels is determined to hound out the last white or Asian male. It seems like this will eventually catch up to the company, as most engineering schools are full of such people.

review_title: Good and stable job if you can stand corporate culture
pros: Stability, good remuneration (if you are able to negotiate one at start),  access to some new technologies (albeit Intel-only, meaning not much usable in a different work environment), many intelligent and knowledgeable people, some ability to change (choose) projects.
cons: Limited career possibilities in a technical path if you're not going to move to US, limited pay rise, feeling a "cog in a machine" where not much really depend on your effectiveness, even your bonus...

pros: Decent work and pay, flexibility to switch between groups
cons: Bad hiring practices which lead to a lot of riff raff getting hired, mediocre talent heading top positions which leads to genuinely talented people getting frustrated and demotivated, too much of politics

job_title: Business Operations in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great Internship program for college graduates.   Good company for aspiring engineers.   Decent compensation and benefits.
cons: Does not do a good job on integrating new acquisition.   The HR partners were  inexperienced, untrained to handle sensitive HR incidents.  Collaboration with other business units present some challenges.  Managers from other business units seem more interested in doing what is needed to advance their political aspiration vs what is truly right for the company.

review_title: Good place to Start your Career, but move on after couple of years!
pros: You learn an extreme amount in a short amount of time. Constant trainings and learnings are a big plus. Ideal situation would be to go to Intel after college, stay there for a couple years and move out to bigger and better things.
cons: Pay is extremely low compared to other companies. I don't understand how Intel retains its talent when they pay 10-15% below market level for their employees.

pros: At its' core, I believe it is a high integrity and ethical company that tries to do the right thing.
cons: It is a demanding environment, but in recent years benefits and now pay have been gradually whittled downwards under the banner of increased competitiveness.

review_title: Not Good, Not Bad - just typical American corporate bureaucracy
job_title: Process Engineering Group Leader in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Average pay & benefits, most jobs outside the factories have work-life balance programs.  Stability in down economy.
cons: Tolerance of mediocrity, risk averse, inane HR policies allows the poor performers to stay, questionable business ethics recently (2009's European Union fine & AMD settlement).

job_title: Design Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: very smart people.  you can find great mentors here. Intel really cares about its employees.  The sky is the limit here.  highly recommended
cons: it can be stressful at times.  you can be working over time.   people can be overly competitive here.  The location is not that great.

review_title: Good place to work  for people willing to own their career development
pros: Good opportunities to rotate to other jobs or groups, good benefits, relatively good job security for high tech industry. Results oriented culture.
cons: The one downside to the results oriented culture is that hours can be long when a deadline needs to be met.

pros:
Industry leading salary
Benefits package best in the sector
Great people to work with, including managers and co-workers
Advancement potential is unlimited
cons:
12 hour days
Work load is sometimes very high
Expectations are high no matter what the workload is at the time

review_title: Squeezes the last drop of blood out of you
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
OK benefits
Does not concentrate on military production
Company is well-known for advanced technology
cons:
Extreme work pressure
Inevitable extensive overtime work
Evel system of performance review
Secrecy does not allow professional growth
No influx of external experienced workers
Lots of brainwashing

job_title: Software Development Manager in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Very interesting projects, very open space in the software division,
you feel that you can really do things. Management overhead is minimal,
and you can focus on what you think brings most value. 
You get free fruits and coffee, and you get challenged to perform :).
cons: Sometimes the corporate processes are very heavy, like filling in expense reports, but most of the time people help you get the stuff done and are not raising barriers.

review_title: Special and diverse culture, fun and challenging to work with
pros: Flexible working hours help in balancing work and life. Get to work with lots of talent from around the world, tackling very advanced engineering issues. Lots of innovation gets done when there is focus.
cons: Large organization can be slow to respond to certain situations. Sometimes changes in business environment forces many unanticipated changes to projects and might because a certain degree of stress.

review_title: Very good company with a lot of internal opportunity to grow career
pros: Work life balance, focus on employee health and career development and a lot of flexibilities
cons: Some corporate politics (which is inevitable) and slow decision making process that hinders the company to flourish.

pros: Good benefits and 8 week paid Sabbatical for every 7 years working.
cons:
Not a lot of exciting opportunities if you just want to be a software developer and write code.
Too many reorganizations for no real good reason - Had 3 different managers within a short time.
Mid-year and Annual performance reviews are bogus, waste of time and not transparent. It's not how well you perform but who you  know in the company.

review_title: Good at processors; poor at most other things
job_title: Senior Director in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great company when it comes to treating employees well. Obviously an excellent company for processor design and process technology (high performance end of the spectrum) design.
cons: Extremely poor at other areas - specifically in having the right kind of management and leadership who understand the markets, prevailing technologies and competition and are then able to derive a competitive product roadmap and execute to it. In fact, it is the company with the least technically sound leadership in my entire career.

pros:
Its a continuously changing company, it offers the opportunity to increase your knowledge at every stage of your process and opens new doors for your career plan and development. It's has the best bosses, maybe the most appropriate word would be leaders. They challenge, encourage and bring out your max potential.
It's a flexible company, as long as you achieve the expected results.
cons:
It demands a lot of work, you might spend some of your weekends working.
There is no recognition for extra hours.

pros: I cannot think of any good pro's . I am serious. Tough deadlines. Lot of backstabbing. Intel used to be a good place to work no more
cons:
Zero growth. If you join intel especially IPG group you will suffer. WIthin 3 years you will be un-hireable outside intel. 
Your skills won;t be valid in outside world.

review_title: A Large Corporation With a Great History on the Cusp of The Next Age
pros: The majority of my time at Intel has been working with great people.   You work hard, but the rewards in personal satisfaction, compensation and benefits make it worthwhile.
cons: Sometimes we knee-jerk to situations.  We are supposed to be driven by data, but there are times when I have seen the "story" override what the data is actually saying.   We need to be careful not to get lost in groupthink, corporate speak and the latest organizational management fads.

job_title: Outsourcing Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Excellent health insurance 
Interesting work
Lots of support
Clear expectations
Good work/life balance
In the suburbs so a good commute for families
cons:
Very flat structure with limited opportunities to move up
After two years in the supply chain organization I have not seen a single new manager
Current climate limits people's willingness to change jobs which means opportunities are stagnant and promotions are limited

review_title: Mix of people willing to work hard, people mailing it in
pros: Worked with some truly world-leaders in engineering, math, and validation, doing things that had never been done before, improving the state of the art every day.  Depending on manager/org, can have a flexible schedule.
cons:
Meetings - So many useless meetings
Also worked with a handful of people who just were not interested in experimenting, or improving themselves or their software.
Was required to work regularly with people in vastly different time zones, without any in-person meetings.  Like we were expected to have strong relationships with people we only talked with over the phone or using video-conferencing rooms.  It just was not conducive to effecient work.

review_title: One of the best engineering companies in Penang
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bayan Lepas
pros:
Let's face the facts... this is a very old and very huge company in Penang. It has gone through a lot but it's still here... and also having the reputation of one of the best companies giving out one of the best compensations, benefits, salary and bonuses.

Working in Intel Malaysia requires one to be resilient as well as willing to step up and do more. If you're one who expects to be continuously paid highly yet doing the same old execution work day in and day out, you'll be managed out as one day your juniors will step up and overtake you. 

The site leaders are united and very aggressive in making sure Intel Malaysia continuous to be the corporate's main offshore sites. 

Medical benefits are awesome.
Dental and optical is about the same.
Salary is above average. Does not make you a super rich person but also does not make you begging for food at the end of the month as well. 
The site facilities are growing old but they're refurbishing it slowly. Hey... it's a huge campus.. give it some time, will ya?

There are many work opportunities. It's a matter of what you want to do, not what you're given to do. Many employees failed to see that.

RSUs.... oh my God... it's amazing.

Profit sharing.... goodness... I can't thank the company enough.

The recognition system .... helps so much in my monthly expenses.

Travel opportunities... I get to go on so many trips to place I never thought I'll step foot on ever in my life. 

Hence, I really do not know what are the rest complains about? You only have yourself to blame. Seriously...
cons: There's a rat hanging around in my cubicle area. I lost a box of wholemeal cookies due to this lil' fella.

review_title: IT Groups not different then other organisation
pros:
1. Work life balance(less work definitely).
2. Collaborating colleagues.
3. Gives ample importance to training technical and soft skills.
4. Open communication (i personally love the concept of no cabins, everybody has the same cubes, be it a director or an intern)
cons:
1. Business travels.
2. Pay and benefits(IT) i heard they down graded the pay scale for IT some 3 years back - speculation/Rumor.
3. Lot of technologies but distributed among groups within IT - no vision of "one - IT", says but not implemented.

review_title: Decent pay, bad culture, many big company problems
pros: Lots of advanced technology, some very intelligent peers, immediate team member's culture can be hit or miss, but mine have been great. You can easily move within the company into different products or disciplines. There is a fairly professional culture vibe (depends on team) that promotes a safe working environment (which is great) but is also very bland (cubes, grey walls, very poor celebrations).
cons:
Focal (the review process) creates a horrible culture by deliberately suppressing employees careers and wages. It creates a artificially limited resource (promotion budget) that encourages people to game the system by doing only what gets them promoted and not what helps their teams, their product, or the company. Promotions and raises are typically not a problem for more junior developers, but there is an extreme plateau for senior developers where advancement is not truly a meritocracy but more luck and opportunity based. I should also note that while the pay is decent for a tech company, it is extremely lacking for a top-tier tech company. Microsoft, Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon, Nvidia and others pay significantly more; and the CEO practically brags about about getting a good deal by short changing the employees (they deliberately aim to be average pay, and have no intent of being above average).

There is also an extreme divide between engineering and non-engineering disciplines with different standards, expectations, and perceived value. Cross discipline skillsets are absolutely not rewarded or recognized despite being desperately needed. This exacerbates the big company problems of management hierarchy, political games, and poor decision making. 


Lastly, the current CEO Brian Krzanich is devastatingly bad for the employees of the company. Between his awful oversight of the layoffs in 2016, blaming first level managers for his own poor decisions and intentionally deceiving the employees in every single corporate meeting (like praising himself for giving back to employees due to the recent major tax savings, while hiding the fact he simultaneously removed bonuses that were worth more than the tax bonus), Intel has been hemorrhaging brain power. Unfortunately his actions have short term stock benefits despite the long term decimation of company culture and morale; it is unlikely he will be removed from his position by the board. 

I've been at the company 10 years, and it has been going strictly downhill for the last ~5-6. I've lost all my trust and allegiance to the company, and the only thing that keeps me there is the personal connection to my team.


Bonus Con: The IT, corporate services, and hiring departments deserve their own special place in hell.

job_title: Corporate Services Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
1) The company is so large that changing careers while staying at Intel isn't all the difficult. It's hard to get bored here but easy to move around if you do.  There are always new challenges to be addressed, some new and some that have been around for years. If you want to excel the opportunities are endless for a self-starter.  

2) Work/life balance has been pretty great for the most part. I've done my share of late nights and weekends, but I've also always had the flexibility to take a last minute day off. Or to leave for a couple hours in the day for an appointment without having to get approval to do so. It's a give/take situation. If you need to be out you're trusted to find coverage and to do what is needed to get your work done. I don't feel like my movements are dictated, and that is super important to me.
cons:
1) Like I said, there are always problems to be fixed - locally and those that are globally impactful. I don't think management does a good enough job identifying those people who have given up on trying to solve the big problems - essentially the dead weight of the company.  I have come across so many people who have told me they can't be bothered to fight for certain improvements, or that they have given up trying. These people have gone into 'coast' mode.  We're supposed to be the best of the best, but management doesn't always manage their people the right way to ensure that is the case. 

2) My relationship with my direct managers has always been a trustworthy and respectful one. But if you go one or two levels up that trust degrades considerably. There is a lot of 'management speak' that doesn't feel genuine, and decisions are made without transparency which causes distress amongst employees. Rumors are not quickly dispelled, and overall it feels upper management just does not have the right connection or 'finger on the pulse' when it comes to their employees/individual contributors. 

3) As an employee I sometimes feel like I don't know where Intel is going as a company.  We get our hands into so many things - new areas and saturated markets. It's hard to keep track of what is most important at any given time.

pros: Everyone is supportive, I learned a lot and I met a lot of wonderful people.
cons: It is really what you make of it. I know some people who only focused on one area in their whole internship and looked back and regretted it. The only other thing is that at least on my team its a 6 month full time minimum so I had to take a quarter of school off.

review_title: Solid good place to work, but not without its faults
job_title: Manufacturing Equipment Technician in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Good pay, stable, and they want you to succeed at your job. Great benefits (401k, health insurance is actually *good* and you have options for cheap vs my last 5 employers).
Safety first and always in actual practice. 
A place where innovation is encouraged and known/calculated risks are taken. The sky is the limit for what we do, and that's recognized in day to day conversations.
There is an effort for more teamwork in small workgroups and people really do try to appreciate different backgrounds.
Going above and beyond is recognized often, and seems to be rewarded.
cons:
It isn't a different planet, and you still get employees in who are more trouble than anything, and slackers. 
People who very obviously need to get fired tend to be there a very long time before they are sent off, even when their problems are gratuitous.
Management is not living and breathing the in-factory environment, and is a little (not a lot) disconnected, but they are responsive.
Hand-tools are a godawful mess. 
The recent reorganization has made things messy, which can be very very frustrating sometimes, but that isn't attributed to your own personal failing.
Hard to get into engineering positions without a Masters or PhD.

review_title: Awesome place to work!  Well Respected company!
pros: Top of the line Company.  Really cares about their employees. It is a challenging occupation. The people I have worked with during my career really care about each other.  That culture permeates through the whole company.
cons:
Can be stressful at times.
Can seem overwhelming, but any job worth doing should be

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Petah Tikva
pros: Huge Company means lots of opportunities. I just completed a move to a different division and will be doing exiting new stuff, which I don't have lots of experience in, and i don't need to compromize on my salary.
cons:
Compensation is good, but not great. My wife works at Facebook and that's a completely different league.
Mediocarity is blooming. Intel doesn't lay off so people quite often which is a good thing, but it leads to mediocarity in some places at Intel.

review_title: There are good jobs if you find the right fit in the company
pros: There is bleeding edge research on microprocessors going on in the company, and potential to be involved in a team that design innovative products. Change to work with many smart people.
cons: A lot of management level. Slow decision making processes sometimes. Sometimes resistance to change the process of doing things. Long meetings that are not nessarily and not entirely helpful to completing projects. reward and compensation system not entirely fair, and it is not that easy to move around and change jobs in the company. Though there are very cool jobs around, that are far and few in between.

review_title: Be carefull what group you work for at Intel
pros: The medical Benefits are decent. The culture tries to push work/life balance, but it is a changing culture.
cons: Chance for moving up thru the pay grade is very limited. In the group i was in, senior management had no idea what to do with Software Engineers, including my direct manager.  We felt like they never understood what we needed to do our job. The chance to move between groups and move up the chain is very limited and hard to do. If you decide to work for Intel, take some time to investigate the group you are going to work for and what the options are to move up the chain.

review_title: Intel, sucks, the life out of its employees.
job_title: IT Security Consultant in Folsom, CA
pros: Intel provides a great opportunity for an individual to travel and see the world in support of their international operations.  Also when the chip business is good the bonuses and stock options can be financially rewarding.
cons: In spite of their stated corporate values, “to be a great place to work’, and other “work life balance” statements, the Intel work culture is very high pressure and demanding.  Yes its nice to get a seven week (paid) sabbatical after seven years employment, but most people I knew had developed health problems as a result of the constant pressure, long work days (ave. 50 – 55 hrs/wk) and stress to perform at very high levels.

review_title: Great resume builder, buracracy can be frustrating
pros: Good resume builder, it's a strong, well respected company. Their manufacturing processes are top notch.
cons: Monolithic, hard to get decisions made, the buracracy of getting things done can be frustrating at times, although it does improve the quality of the products. It's a type "A" place, where people feel free to yell at times...depends on the situation, however if you are thing skinned, or have your feelings easily hurt, this may not be the place for you.

pros: great company with lots of benefits.  lots of opportunities based on your different interest and managers are always helpful and willing to give you feedback and help you advance through your career.  the products you work on are usually really cool things and you get to see your work in completed consumer electronics. company culture is good and laid back depending on which group you are a part of.  great amenities.
cons: compensation is average.  engineers elsewhere can make 30-40% more.  company is huge and sometimes you get stuck in a small role and it takes awhile to get out of it.

pros:
You will never work with a larger collection of brilliant people.
90% of managers are absolutely ethical.  They demand it of employees.
You are in a position to influence the market.
The financial group does a superb job at making sure that your 401k grows.
cons:
The management is stuck on the PC.  They don't see the market evolving.
There is only a moderate tolerance to new ideas.

review_title: How much you work completely depends on your job and your manager
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great compensation-- they benchmark themselves against other peers in the valley. Rotational program gives you a chance to grow a lot of skills. Flexible, work from home options.
cons: If you've got a manager who is a workaholic, they will expect you to be one too. It's a great place as long as you push back on low-value-add activities and you don't let crazy 80 hour a week people peer pressure you into doing the same.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Benefits and close to my location so my commute was nice. Large parking lot and easy to find parking. Cafeteria has good food :) Nice to work for a well known company so it helps open the door.
cons: Large corporate structure and lots of internal politics and back stabbing. Lots of red tape and set procedures i.e., which memo oh... memo 12 on Monday sent at 7:00 PM now I remember.

review_title: It can be a great place to work, but with all big corporations it is extremely slow to respond to change
pros: Good insurance options, decent base salary out of college, good vacation time,  access to big budgets for equipment, decent employee stock purchasing program,
cons: No 401(k) matching, management bureaucracy, Intel pension is a joke, Stock vestment periods are ridiculous, too many meetings, Talentless employees cannot be fired, Intel achievement awards are stupid, Slow to respond to industry change

review_title: Still a great place to learn new/different skills via the opportunity to switch job roles/functions/groups
pros: Work life flexibility (depends very much on your manager), one of the few companies to offer a good 401K matching contribution, Sabbaticals every 7 years
cons: Too much Bureaucracy, lots of NIH (Not Invented Here) syndrome, abhorrence to risk taking, complete lack of accountability and massive yet fragile ego's especially nearer to the top of the management chain

pros: Pay, bonuses if we get them, benefits, work hours.
cons: Too much work and not enough people.  They are trying to run the factory to someone people model.  Too many managers and to many engineers made into managers without any manger experience.  Many of the engineers and managers Intel is the only company they have ever worked for.  With the lean workforce people are being over worked causing ergonomic injuries.

pros: Very flexible work timings. Almost everybody leaves at 5 in the evening (irrespective of when they come :P). Extremely relaxed working atmosphere. Managers are very cordial and friendly.
cons: Pay is good but not awesome. Qualcomm pays more. Samsung give free food. Work is okay at best and that too only if you mange to get into those teams which do some design/architecture related work. Most other jobs, the validation/design automation/layout kinds, are essentially Infosys like outsourced sweat shops, only in house.

job_title: Product Marketing Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel is a great place to work. Intel invests in its employees via training, coaching and opportunities for lateral moves. Open door policy creates great environment. Egalitarian culture: all employees including top bosses have same size cube offices, no reserved parking spots for top bosses etc. Great benefits including a 2 month sabbatical every 7 years. Meritocracy, fair review process.
cons: Being a manufacturing company, it sometimes get too bureaucratic, or mired in procedures for innovative minds. Also, Intel is usually uncomfortable investing time, effort and money outside its core strength (Silicon Manufacturing) and will snap them shut at short notice.

review_title: it was alright but getting worse
job_title: Silicon Architecture Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: great people and flexible work hours. I can organize my work around my most productive time of the day, I can leave early if needed (probably it's only in my department, do not know about others). People are generally open to share their experience and every request for information is generally met.
cons: Intel becomes a management centric company. Managers tell engineers what to do, not consulting with them on best course of action. Management by committee is widely popular. Slow decision making processs and a lot of bureaucracy. Also stagnant wages.

review_title: Interesting work, but you have to find / create & sell it
job_title: Technical Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The company is going through changing pains, so great opportunities for people who want to make that change happen. Pretty good work life balance, if you are in a project that is not spanning across all geos! Encourages temp assignments across company
cons: Large parts of the company are still hard to move to align to the needs of the new environment, or the faster way of working. The project approval processes and controls are very rigid, and need to get more balanced

review_title: it was alright but getting worse
job_title: Silicon Architecture Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: great people and flexible work hours. I can organize my work around my most productive time of the day, I can leave early if needed (probably it's only in my department, do not know about others). People are generally open to share their experience and every request for information is generally met.
cons: Intel becomes a management centric company. Managers tell engineers what to do, not consulting with them on best course of action. Management by committee is widely popular. Slow decision making processs and a lot of bureaucracy. Also stagnant wages.

review_title: Interesting work, but you have to find / create & sell it
job_title: Technical Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: The company is going through changing pains, so great opportunities for people who want to make that change happen. Pretty good work life balance, if you are in a project that is not spanning across all geos! Encourages temp assignments across company
cons: Large parts of the company are still hard to move to align to the needs of the new environment, or the faster way of working. The project approval processes and controls are very rigid, and need to get more balanced

review_title: A good company to work for with challenging projects.
pros: You get to work on leading edge technology products. Fast paced environment that always offers new learning opportunities. You get to be a part of products that really do change our world.
cons: No down time between the rush to get the next new product to market tends to burn people out working long hours all the time. The annual review process promotes a dog eat dog environment as their ranking method will force below expectations reviews on some people that are doing all aspect of there jobs simply because there are others that are doing more.

review_title: Comfortable job with too much politics
pros:
Lots of facilities and very nice work environment.
Given a lot responsibility.
Very interesting job - I've never had the same work day in 5 years.
cons:
End of year review can be very corrupt. 
No work life balance. Due to the 24/7 nature of the company, your day does not end in the evening, or on a fri evening! Its very easy to be bitten by the Intel bug and you end up working 80 hours a week because you choose to! And then its expected of you
Due to the competitive nature, learnings from colleagues does not often flow. If it exists at all.

job_title: Field Sales Representative in Denver, CO
pros: The bennies are top notch and they provide a significant amount of assistance if needed.
cons: You are only a number at the company. 10 year anniversary gift was $75. Starting pay is lower than compared to rest of industry so the extra bennies help make up for some of it. They constantly change focus with the Intel Security Group (former McAfee). I feel like this will be the last hurrah for the security division as they have re-focused yet again.

review_title: An amazing collection of talent. But currently navigating troubled waters.
pros: Competitive compensation. Very good benefits. Sabbatical. Lots of really smart people.
cons: Collaboration is not rewarded in performance reviews, and so is not valued, despite lip service. VERY few true advancement opportunities. Mostly a series of lateral moves. Current massive layoffs are going to tank morale of the survivors even further.

review_title: Summary from a 23 yrs IT PM perspective
pros: Great company with stability for 23 years.  Great benefits!  good bonuses.  Exempts:  11 pd holidays, 3 weeks vacation/4 week after 5 yrs.  8 wk sabbatical every 7 yrs or 4 wks every 4.  Great Place to work and perks.  Casual work environment with some telecommuting available.  Even layoffs are nicely compensated.
cons: There was never enough data to make decisions or resources to get the work done.  Global company so depending on the position you were working around the clock but could work w/ mgmt. for comp time.  Expect to work at least 50 hrs/wk.  Very competitive.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Many options for career advancement and skills training - Intel sponsored classes as well as Lynda.com, among others. Nice bonus options and good benefits.
cons: Not sure about long-term job security post-ACT. I know that restructuring happens, but I think Intel took a hit with the trust that the employees and external folks had with the company.

review_title: We've Got Lots of Jobs But We Only Want Women!
pros: Pay and Benefits are solid.  The free fruit is also nice.
cons: The review title was an actual quote to me from a TA for a prominent GM.   There are big, big bonuses on the line for Sr. Managers to drive a more diverse workforce and you can bet they'll get what they measure and reward.  Great news if you are female or an under-represented minority.  White male?  Get out on your terms!

review_title: Use to be great place to work, not so much anymore
pros: compensation and benefits are good. Lot of great people there. Fast paced.
cons: Less flexibility at work recently, no work from home or remote location, even if the jobs allows it. But not for all just for individual contributors. Work life balance depend on the group you work in. If you work at fab you'll be working 24/7. in some other areas work life balance is better. Growth could be very limited.

review_title: An engineer working for the man
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Intel has a very rigorous manufacturing environment.  There are a lot of opportunities for interesting projects to work on.  Intel is a very stable company that continues to make a profit every quarter.  This adds relative stability to a job at Intel when compared to other companies in the industry.
cons: There are a lot of managers.  Too many chiefs and not enough indians.  A lot of busy work in dealing with the day to day grind.

review_title: Mid level management needs to do a better job of improving the work environment
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: To be associated with the knowledgeable people and gain exposure to the cutting edge technology. The overall infrastructure is excellent. Especially, the netmeeting is cool where you get to meet with dozens of people virtually and share ideas and make presentations.
cons: Your boss is the one who decides about your future. If you have issues with him, try to get out and look out for someone who will be supportive of you.

pros: Great engineering workplace, truly innovative .. hunting ground for phd's. Terrific systems in place, world class manufacturing systems/facilities. The hi-tech stuff can be quite over-whelming at first.. which is why the enginnering staff is full of like-minded phd graduates. Its the market leader by a huge margin and it helps when your closest competitor is struggling. Nice benifits and health care. No official leave requirements.. lots of flexibility and balance for career and life.. really a great place to work at. Nice place to work at if you have family around.
cons: long hours, less opportunity to travel to other offices

review_title: Great company with huge management. Top heavy.
job_title: Analog Design Engineer, Senior in San Diego, CA
pros: Good compensation, a lot of resources. A lot of possible training. A lot of smart people if you go to right group
cons: big, undecisive and complicated management. Too many changes. Management changes decision before the plan get fully executed. This is a big waste of money. They need to think carefully what they want before proceeding.

review_title: Perspective of an Intel Alumni after 9.5 years there
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Learned the basics  of designing and testing high quality CPU's. These skills are invaluable, and believe it or not, not all CPU companies have mastered these basics, and is what I think makes Intel  CPU's dominant in their respective markets.

From 1997 to when I left, had a lot of opportunities make my own mark. Unfortunately, because of the cons, the XScale business was jettisoned and before I left I was absorbed into the x86 part of the business which was different.

I did get promoted twice, and I'm a minority. However, I did work like the dickens for it, and never did make it to the the Staff level, which at the time seems to be the point at which you were taken seriously at Intel.

Back in the 1990's the stock options and bonuses were grea. After 2000, they became worthless.  Intel has sinced switched over to RSU's, which are a surer thing, though with less upside.  I don't see Intel as the rip-roaring growth company so I think this was a good move to keep people satisfied.  Intel put about 12% of your pay into your 401K (SERP). It was reduced to 8% when I left. Still a great benefit

Base salary was below average. During hard times we skipped FOCAL raises. Before I left
cons:
For the first 3-4 years I was there, I worked on average 10 hours a day. For a first generation new product I worked about 13-15 hours a day for 5 months straight, as did about 5 others. The one manager who did that with his underling no longer works for the company. Not only was he smart but was a good leader.  A loss for Intel, IMHO.

Culture is different from one group to the next and changed over time.  Intel's culture is based on Andy Grove's management style.  Confrontational (constructive), and aggressive.  Intel thinks itself egalitarian, but over time has become less so. Now, a  level 3 engineer confronting a staff engineer (level 8) is a very dangerous thing, even if the level 3 engineer is right--which is not an impossibility. Ever hear of a Pyrrhic victory?

The FOCAL process is not uniform, and can be overly harsh. I transfered to a department that wanted to promote me based on my prior FOCAL but couldn't because my former manager refused to recommend me for a promotion--probably sour grapes despite my documented performance but there was nothing that could be done.  I was given an unsatisfactory review (and this after being promoted to level 7) because I reported a staff engineer (level 8) who was upset that I reported him for verbally dressing me down on Microsoft Communicator ( internet chat). Imagine that: he sent me nice little barbs over the 'net and acts surprised that I didn't report him.  My manager was given a bad review, too, when he confronted (constructively) him regarding this issue. This guy must have had major pull (remember my egalitarian statement?)

Intel is known as a great place to work in the Asian community, and I hear Asians really help each other out there and have a much better experience than other groups. This is from first hand knowledge talking with Asian engineers working in the same difficult groups I worked in, and calling them great with lots of support from peers.

Engineers can't get along, and clique up pretty hard. I think some strategic moves made by Intel flamed out partly because of cliques that could not get along, and the unfortunate folks caught in cross fire.

My advice. Get in. Learn the basics. Get a promotion to verify you know the basics. Then find a gig at a smaller company or statup where people are real. Intel is a great place to have worked. I say you should see a promotion in 3 years, else you're doing something wrong, or being put on the list to be CAP'ed out.

review_title: Each group at intel is a different company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. Ability to try different things in engineering (driver to applications) and management.
2. Ability to work from practically any geographic location.
cons: 1. Every group operates as if it is totally independent company. Peripheral groups such as application engineers usually get less raise than core group engineers such as Component design engineers in CPU or validation engineers in CPU.

review_title: Global Innovation in Software and Hardware
pros: The company truly treats the employees with great care.   As a corporate citizen, the company is environmentally conscious and gives back to the community globally.
cons: As a large company it is not very adept at changing directions.   Fast adoption is unheard of and the  principle of innovation seems to override the principle of building from the work of technology communities.

review_title: Great benefits and salary.  Management and job satisfaction so-so
job_title: Senior Manufacturing Technician in Chandler, AZ
pros: Lots of great benefits, quarterly profit sharing, stock purchase plans, restrictive stock units granted in accordance with your review, yearly contribution to retirement fund which averaged around $5-6K. Good health care and dental. The pay was very good, as a technician with a night shift differential, I was making close to $100,000.
cons:
Job was repetitive and boring. As a technician, there was little latitude to actually work on the tools. Most tasks consisted of pressing a button and waiting for the software to finish the test. I worked twelve hour shifts and for the most part worked by myself in isolation in the fab. I didn't feel that there was a team mentality but rather everyone operated as individuals. 
I was amazed at the level of incompetence of some of my fellow technicians. Some have been working there for 20 plus years but have no grasp upon current technology. The only thing that saves them is that the tasks are so amazingly simple. 
Attempting to shift from a technician to an engineer was very difficult. I am a senior in computer science at ASU and because my section didn't require a computer scientist, they were not interested in helping me achieve my degree even though there were hundreds of openings for computer science graduates throughout the company. It is an odd culture that is focused on output and not so much about the quality of its people.
As far as management, I had some really great managers and some really bad managers. I rarely had a manager for more than a year which meant constantly having to adjust to a new management style and new personality. It becomes tedious after awhile. Also there are just too many managers who are terrible people persons. My last manager was just so aggravating and unwilling to work with my degree pursuit that I left Intel after eight years in order to focus on my degree.

review_title: Good experience but now moving on
pros: Intel makes good financial decisions and goes after new business. Compensation is good for senior people.
cons: Frequent management and organizational changes that do not help workers.  Employees often last longer if they change jobs every few years.  Expectations of engineers are often non-specific, unclear and defined after the fact. Doing well often requires long hours to match work of more well positioned peers, may lead to burn out, family issues.

job_title: Systems Validation Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: The best reasons to work at Intel are salary, compensation benefits, activities to volunteer, facilities, and of course, many people who are great at what they do work there. Camaraderie between peers could be the best.
cons: Some of the downsides working at Intel the difficulty trying to change job inside the company, the last period I worked there, there was no Work/Life balance. While I know that Senior Management had to make hard decisions, I think the best approach was a little far from what the values of the company are.

review_title: Success is dependent on your manager
job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Benefits, schedule, flexibility, stability (until recently). 

The people you work with on a day-to-day basis are very smart. You get to work on the cutting edge technology. The processes are well defined, hence the work environment is not very chaotic. Internal transfer system and temporary assignments allow for career development opportunities, which are good for the most part.
cons:
The review system is very screwed up. It is entirely dependent on your manager's perception of your performance. It is very subjective, and there is no clear criteria on how you are graded. It is up to the manager to decide your rank and rating. It is important to do things that are visible to your manager so you are recognized. In most cases these don't contribute to real value. For instance speaking up in meetings even if you have nothing useful to say will get you a lot of recognition from short sighted managers. They also have way too many managers who do not get involved in the day to day work of the employee but still reserve the right to judge their performance independent of peer reviews. 

The culture is also shifting away from the core values under BK. The upper management stealthily tries to remove good people under the garb of performance management. People rated successful are being terminated because they landed on the wrong side of the successful scale (based on a manager's rating, which could be biased). Risk taking and innovation are not being rewarded. The only thing that matters is that you fall in line and impress your manager. 

The overall company direction under BK also does not make sense. There is a lot of marketing fluff  with the diversity hiring. On the one hand they lay-off successful experienced employees and on the other hand they want to lower the bar for entry with diversity only reqs (a $300M fund for diversity hiring). Positions that have diversity hires will be funded by HR for over a year.

pros: Intel consists of multiple different teams. There is possibility to work in hardware, software or work in POC area. There is often big opportunity for growth.
cons:
Unfortunately, management in Polish site in Gdansk is all the time encourages to work longer hours. There is a pressure to prove, that Engineers in Poland are at least twice as good as anywhere else.
Constant meetings spoil a work day. It's hard to focus on task, because all the time, there is "one more meeting"

job_title: Business/Market Development Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good company, with good benefits and good tools to support a better work environment.
cons: Overall strategy needs to be reviewed in a fast pace mode. The cash cow of the company is becoming in a commodity.

pros:
Intel is a 5 star company in terms of work life balance, benefits and leave policies. Very good colleagues and neat ethics. The best for middle aged people to settle down
In engineering terms, good for those who are from Electronics background rather than Computers
cons: Its not a company for freshers, you dont learn a thing here. Plus, already existing code bases are major headaches to get on with. There is no documentation nor training on your current project. It takes at least a year or more to get versed with company processes and projects.

job_title: Test Manager/Tech Support/Integration Test in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Solid and Diverse Engineering Culture
Plenty of Resources to Achieve Goals
Excellent Engineering Infrastructure
cons: Pockets of resistance to excellent diversity and engineering culture principles and training

review_title: You can be a good engineer, but will you be appreciated
pros: Pretty good benefits, decent pay
cons: My experience at intel has been pretty horrible. The job i applied for, and the work promised never came, and I spent the entire time either training subpar contractors, or rewriting tests after a senior engineer. My time was expandable, with no hard limits of when I will not be on some sort of "on call". Compensation is VERY low compared to other companies in the area, 20k+ lower than similar positions in the area. I did not like the competitive feel brought on by the focal process in the company. HR support minimal.

review_title: Intel is definitely a great place to work.
pros:
Stronger Company culture 
Walk the talk 
Great place to work 
Great place to build your career
cons:
Most of Latin America offices don't share the full extent of corporation culture, being the culture, in many cases, accommodated to make room for political arrangements. 
Lack of speed for quick changes, not much different of large corps worldwide. 
Some areas work with people overloaded, mostly the non-sales related.

pros: Great work/life balance, you are encouraged to own your own career and are typically very well supported throughout the process.
cons: The job is cyclical with the economy to a point, I have seen numerous layoffs both voluntarily and involuntarily. I have seen many colleagues and friends get caught in the cyclical web

review_title: Manufacturing Technician: Every Day is like the 'Lord of the Flies'
pros:
- Profit sharing
- Stock purchase plan (discounted)
- 16% night shift differential
- Compressed work week
- Motivated and driven individual contributors
- Fast paced work in a well-respected company (looks great on your resume)
- Worksite has cafe, workout equipment, employee lounge, etc
- Most work groups are committed to work/life balance

Intel is a young person's dream opportunity. Move around as much as you can. Don't be dazzled by the glitz ; staying at Intel too long is a strategy that may hurt your long-term career goals.
cons:
- Work environment has been politicized since the adoption of the "engineering lead" model vs. operations managers
- Cost cutting begins with workforce reduction
- Advancement requirements/opportunities not clearly defined. Prepare to get in the queue to pucker up
- Obvious age discrimination; workers over 50 have a target on their back
- The company has long left the road of its original "core values" / work culture It's no longer about the employees, it's about the bottom line.
- Intel has repeatedly missed fantastic marketplace opportunities. Who is steering the ship, the cook?
- Hourly employees have limited career opportunities
- Technicians beware: In an effort to get equipment running again as soon as possible you may be expected to throw parts at it to quickly get it back up to production. How much did you learn by doing that? You should have learned that it is costing Intel huge every hour that tool is not producing, and whether you get to actually troubleshoot it to find a defective module or circuit card is irrelevant to Intel. This is known in the industry and former Intel techs have had to face this perception (that they can’t really troubleshoot) when job hunting after Intel.

review_title: You shouldn't spend more than 2 or 3 years here
pros: Great opportunities to get experience in project life cycles, engineering work flows, etc.  Ideally if you're an RCG (Recent College Grad) for undergrad or masters.  I don't know what the other employees are smoking that said the work life balance here is bad, that's wrong.  The reason so many people just coast on through working here is because the work life balance is great.  You see the same people coming in, doing their 9 to 5, taking hour + lunches with mutliple breaks for 15 to 20 or 30 minutes, leave early to pick up the kids etc.   If you want to start a family and be around for the kids growing up, come on over!  If you're younger and looking for a competitive work environment, look elsewhere.
cons:
The leadership here is completely lost.  Engineering tools, flows, methodologies are incredibly out dated in many teams and orgs.  Projects are guided by share holders and investors and not innovation.  They say they thrive on innovation, but when you and you're colleagues make suggestions on ways to improve TTM (Time to market) for projects, new methodologies that the rest of industry is using, improved work flows, etc, and they keep saying that we cannot support such things or that we don't have time to make those changes without affecting project timelines, that's a clear indication that they way they work here is not changing anytime soon.  Even when they hired certain VP's by paying 25M+ for them to come in and whip engineerings butt in shape, still nothing has changed.  The VP's talk the talk and say how we are revamping our core of engineering, but in the end, they bend over for the shareholders and will ride this money wave out until they're obligation is up and then bounce out.  At engineering updates they are giving us EPS (Earnings per share) numbers and how project bla is going to make us money.  
The pay is pretty mediocre.   RSU's are grim.  you won't break 10k over 4 for a quite a few years.  Stock purchase is okay, capped at 5% base income.  CEO always says "we pay fair, and in the middle of the range" or something along those lines.  What that translates to is that we hire average to below average talent, meaning potentially myself included.  
The company is in a cycle of hiring and then s/firing/head count reduction/g before quarter close to drive stock price up.   then re-hiring. 
Overall, employee moral is pretty damn low.  A lot of people are interviewing, or looking else-where, myself included.  The coasters of the company are completely happy.

review_title: Business is good and culture is changing
pros: Surrounded by very smart people and a lot to learn and accomplish ... Great support and funding if you are on the right projects..
cons: Last 5 years the culture has been progressively changing and the management been going through headcount reduction acts on a quarterly basis. As a 20 year employee, I have seen the company shift from employee-oriented to just numbers on a power point.

job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel allows the ability to choose career path in a variety of technical/non-technical fields. Many people who have been with the company for 20+ years started out in engineering and then moved to management, marketing or other technical fields. Intel has a high level of integrity ingrained in the corporate culture and also has a culture of innovation. There is an open-door policy at all levels of management. Free coffee/tea/Coke.
cons: Rigid definition of "priority schools" for recruiting purposes; students at non-priority schools have a harder time getting a foot in the door. The gray cubicles are a little depressing, but are slowly being replaced by newer, better-looking cubes.

review_title: World class leader in semiconductor industry, but need to have better efficiency on lower manager lead
pros: Good internal employee website for personal life/work management.  This makes employee better managing on company expense, health benefit, 401k/sock ... etc.  Intel is also a world class leader in Semiconductor industry.  This provide a higher visiblity in resume.  In addition, creates a better net work wo various department in the company
cons: Employee performance should be regonize by manger and yearly performance should be determine more farily.  Management needs to improve.  In addition, work load should be balance and distribute it farily.

pros: It's a respected company. Everyone knows about Intel Corporation. Lately the management has been given employees more of a voice in telling what we think, and that's good. There's not a lot a free perks here, except some manufacturing people get into the chip loaner program where the company "loan" you an engineering sample to build your own computer with. Another reason to work for Intel is that Intel is "winning" right now. That helps with employee morale. You don't want to be working for a loser...
cons: The review process isn't that great. However, it has improved a lot during my time here.

review_title: Lots of interesting technology, can be expectantly corporate.
pros: With good pay, good benefits, you will meet a lot of interesting and highly skilled people at Intel.  Though it may vary by site location and group, there is undoubtedly a lot of interesting projects and technology here.  Good opportunities for continuing career education.  Nice facilities for the most part (excepting the fabs).
cons: Poor work/life balance, performance reviews can be cut throat.  There is a political aspect to the scene, and you may see your first level manager rotate in and out jockying for more coveted positions.  401k takes seven years to vest.

review_title: Great company that's feeling a little too large...
