job_title: Senior Project Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Competitive salary, fortune 500 company, advanced technology, great products.  It's also a way to be able to travel a bit as the company is geographically located all over, that could be good or bad depending on what you want to do.
cons: Endless buerocracy, endless meetings, seems like it's too hard to do the right thing sometimes, no one can make a decision, everything is done by committe.  There are ove 80 thousand employees, and sometimes it feels like you have to talk to evey one of them to get something done.

review_title: If you work at Intel, don't plan on doing anything else.
pros: Intel has very good benefits.
cons:
--If you work there, don't plan on doing anything else. 

--Workloads are not evenly distributed - some don't have to work 40 hours;
   others had to work way more (including myself) (See Below).

--There are complicated tasks that absolutely have to be done,
   but if your manager is not aware of them or how complex they are,
   you can get a bad review.

review_title: Big company, can be awesome if you find the right role in the right group.
pros: Intel innovates technically in the US.  They are industry leaders in certain areas, particularly manufacturing and high end processor design.  They are capable of reinventing themselves when markets deem it necessary.  There are tons of talented people working there.
cons: Too many people.  Everything becomes a battle for territory.  Many jobs are extremely narrowly defined.  Work culture can be downright hostile.  As with any big company you need the right manager, the right position, and the right group to get a good experience.

review_title: Overall my experience with Intel has been positive.
pros: Intel is definitely a great place to work and they take pride in making sure that they take care of their employees.  They understand their impact on the communities that they are located and strive to be exceptional corporate partners.
cons: At times, the politics and bureaucracy can be overwhelming.  New managers need more training to understand the intricacies of dealing with diverse teams and to be better set up for success.

job_title: Staff Analog Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good work life balance. Worked on interesting products. Company acts upon negative feedback regarding managers performance. Reasonable benefits.
cons: No stability for engineers - company always seems to be cutting jobs in one group or another. Engineers have little faith in the upper management. Very slow (if any) career progression for engineers.

pros: Intel has a very egalitarian workplace philosophy, which I found refreshing. There are no offices with doors, reserved parking spaces, or other marks of privilege.  There is also no dress code, and because of the geographic range of the business, I appreciated the ability to telecommute whenever it made sense.
cons: As an attorney supporting groups on the non-core side of the business, I found it difficult to work autonomously.  Almost every action had to be vetted through corporate, which made me less agile and effective in responding to the needs of my business groups.

job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer Grade 7 in Austin, TX
pros: The salary and benefits are good and consistently bench marked against similar technology companies.  In the right group, it can be a great place to work (GPTW).  The work is rewarding and the quality of co-workers.
cons: Recent actions by senior management is disconnected from actual work being done.  In the past Intel would reduce work force by cancelling unsuccessful projects.  They revamped the review process in 2012/3 to target experienced workers.  Now, they are revamping the review process again.

review_title: Not a place for experienced employees
pros: Great technology, some terrific people to work with and, at least in the past, a shiny future
cons: Terrible HR system based upon pitting employees against each other.  The result is team work suffers.  In any situations where staff must leave, experienced, older staff (who are more highly paid) are the first to go.  In addition, the pressure of management to only hire from, "less costly Geos" is strong.

review_title: Great company, but struggling to find new product direction
pros:
Excellent corporate culture ("Intel values"), internal training and personal growth opportunities, corporate social responsibility, code of conduct, etc.
Very diverse product line (SW, HW, FW over a broad range of industries).
cons:
Struggling to find the next cash cow (although CPUs still account for most of their revenue). Failed miserably (and expensively) with mobile. 
Too big and slow to be agile and compete in many new industries.
Too much "blind dependence" on managers' decision-making.

pros: I worked for Intel for >25yrs at multiple locations.  Intel has great Benefits. For the most part Intel has a great culture and good efforts to support work/life balance. Intel allowed me to have a comfortable life and up until the recent years I always felt very secure. I am trying to get rehired at Intel and hope I will be successful.
cons: As in other organizations you have good managers and you have some not so good managers. During the times of bad management it causes stress/communiation and security issues. During times of headcount reductions at certain locations it became very challenging dealing with the unknowns!

review_title: Good Placement Year and learning experience
pros:
1. I was given a lot of responsibilities and was allowed to rotate between several teams to get a rounded working experience. More than I thought i'd get as an intern   
2. Most managers and the people I worked with were really nice and supportive when needed 
3. Good pay, what you'd expect from a placement
cons:
1. Lots of red-tape at times, some processes seem convoluted
2. 'Intel lingo' is used a lot, can be alienating when you start   
3. Swindon where the office is located is not the greatest place

pros: Intel provides the best benefits of a major company in high-tech. This is particularly beneficial when single folks become married folks who start having children. Intel is still progressive when it comes to profit sharing in 401k programs, and also for higher-learning options.
cons: Middle Management has been hollowed out by Intel not having enough high growth, high revenue opportunities. The bench strength of Intel appears to be waning.

review_title: Intel is a great place to work as long as you can manage your own career.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Intel is a pretty stable company in terms of not going bankrupt anytime soon.  

They allow me to work from home 4 days per week, which is awesome.  

The corporate line is that the pay goal is to compensate "above market average", so for most people they pay is quivalent to what they would make elsewhere.  

There are many diversity programs and clubs in which to participate and there is both a stock grant program (RSU) and a stock purchase program (15% discount) for all salaried full time employees.  

Intel is piloting a new program that will replace all of the old gray cubicles with fance new ones and a new layout, so the workplace is not as drab (or will soon not be). 

Intel offers free coffee and soda in the cafeterias.  

The opportunities for advancement are present at intel, but no one is going to advance you for free.  Intel expects that employees own their career and make career and skills choices that would lead to advancement, if that is what they want.
cons:
Because Intel has the policy of generally paying "above market average" this has the effect of retaining employees who are aware that they are overpaid and not attracting the employees who could (and should) be making WAY above market average.  

There have been, over the years, numerous "redeployments" where employees are asked to find another job internally or leave (within 3 months, normally)  this has resulted in the attrition of about 20000 employees over the last few years.  So, naturally, people are worried about their own job security.  Intel has also redeployed groups only to hire their replacements in cheaper geographies.  I have had the opportunity to train my replacement in India - that was fun.  

The benefits have been cut over the last few years.  Intel has cut the amount contributed to 401K programs from 10 to 7 percent and they have also modified, on more than one occasion, the formula by which bonuses are calculated (modified so that the bonuses became smaller, of course).  

Intel does not provide state of the art laptops or desktops for its employees, which is baffling for a technology company.  Typically the hardware given to employees is a generation or two behind the fastest available on the market. 

Oh, and one last thing, the cafeteria food is less than satisfactory.

review_title: Intel is the place to be
pros: Intel is a great place to have a career. As a global company it provides many opportunities to grow and develop, not just in depth of skills but in breadth too. The provide very comprehensive training and professional development opportunities. Our product roadmap is stellar and above all, they walk the talk on leadership integrity and social consciousness.
cons: As a global company working across multiple time zones can be a challenge, having meetings late in the night and early morning is wearing over time. As an engineering company there can be a tendancy to over engineer even the simple things in life.

job_title: Mechanical Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Career growth and no shortage of interesting work to do.
Flexible work hours
Compensation is not bad but not great.
Discount program is very nice.
Pay increases are not good even for outstanding reviews or promotions.
cons:
Bureaucracy and churn in organizational structure. 
No real single owner. The responsibilities are spread out through several organizations.
Politics get in the way of getting things done efficiently.
Ironically, no money at the department level to study issues or  correct them.
No money for operation staff to correct problems before they break.
Sometimes its difficult to see if individual contributions are making an impact to the bottom line.

review_title: 8 years at Intel and 12 bosses later... "if you don't like it now, just wait 6 months"
pros: Working with lots of smart people who care about what they're doing, most at it for long hard hours and with a smile.  When the company does well financially, bonuses can be a welcome boon.
cons: Management struggles with how to grow the business as they remain beholden to their PC OEM business line.  If you're not working in the more stable "core" business groups, this can mean a lot of job volatility.  Having said that, their redeployment program allows for moving around and a varied work experience if you can survive.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Strong financial performance and leadership from top
Job security is good as the company continues to perform and have low volatility in employee turnover
Rotation program provides way to broaden your skillset and experience, and learn different business units at Intel
cons:
Very hierarchical and process oriented (too much bureaucracy)
Hours could be long, although the hours are flexible as long as work is completed on time
Rotattion program adds to ramp time as you start a new in a new role every 1.5 to 2 years; this is both a pro and a con, depending on how you look at it

review_title: A company that does a lot of thinking about the emplyee
pros: The work atmosphere at Intel is great. They invest a lot of effort to think about how to make your life, as an employee better. The work-life balance is very good, and this is one of the core values in Intel.
cons: Promotion to higher ranks takes long time and many good engineers seek opportunities elsewhere. The is a lot of bureaucracy in everything you want to do and moving fast is practically impossible.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Staying power, quite a few employees stay at Intel a while
- Sabbatical every 7 years, lends itself to the first bullet
- Opportunities to move around within the company, depending on your role
cons:
- Large organizations within the company are less agile and are very political
- Difficult to remove a bad people manager as long as they are performing in the short term
- Culture of over promising and apologizing later (within my org).  Lends itself to movement at the top without much consequences.

review_title: Used to be great company, but lost it
pros:
Pays well and on time.
Allow wide opertunities of self development.
Most employees are good and it makes it a good place to work in.
During the years there are many opertunities to take good courses and get knoladge.
cons:
Management went from people orientaion to revenue machine.
Sterss have became way of life, work and home balance is no longer parameter, people submit thier life into work and being throun away as "old" part that need to be replaced by new and less expensive one.

review_title: Overall good, but, some managers need to be trained about being open
pros: Big company. Lots of positions or job roles. Vibrant work environment. Easy to change jobs between groups. Good work life balance.
cons: Review process is not so transparent. It depends on managers though. Manager may write all the nice words in the review document and tell you all the nice words. But, still may give you some stock allocation, which can be treated as low performer.

pros:
- Some of the best minds work here. Its a challenging environment but if you are up for that the satisfaction of working with these people is worth much more than anything. 
- Very helpful people. I worked in three different teams but found it the same everywhere. People genuinely try to help out. 
-Great benefits. The base might be lower but the rest of the benefits make up for it.
cons: None at all. Well okay, maybe the number of meetings need to be reduced.

pros: Intel is a great place to work. I really enjoyed my management and the projects I was tasked with. The company really does value its employees and show it through random parties, great benefits, and nice salaries.
cons: Intel is still a silicone company. There's a lot of learning and process implementation that needs to happen before they can excel and be recognized in the software and cloud markets.

pros:
- Some of the best minds work here. Its a challenging environment but if you are up for that the satisfaction of working with these people is worth much more than anything. 
- Very helpful people. I worked in three different teams but found it the same everywhere. People genuinely try to help out. 
-Great benefits. The base might be lower but the rest of the benefits make up for it.
cons: None at all. Well okay, maybe the number of meetings need to be reduced.

pros: Intel is a great place to work. I really enjoyed my management and the projects I was tasked with. The company really does value its employees and show it through random parties, great benefits, and nice salaries.
cons: Intel is still a silicone company. There's a lot of learning and process implementation that needs to happen before they can excel and be recognized in the software and cloud markets.

review_title: A company that cares about it's people
pros: I have a strong feeling that the company really cares about developing its employees and making them better developers / engineers / sales / and managers. The office doesn't have any sense of "politics" that I feel might happen in other places. The people are all intelligent yet compassionate to fellow coworkers and brand new team members. My manager is amazing and really supportive and with recent restructuring the different teams really care about looking out for each other and other teams to make sure everyone is doing well.
cons: The company is in major transition which makes the atmosphere mildly tense but nothing too terrible.

pros:
Opportunity to work with lot of good and smart coworkers.
Good benefits
Good work life balance.
There are many activities to unwind in the larger sites, including good gym facilities
cons:
Culture may vary from team to team depending on your manager.
There are a few process oriented managers, who add inefficiencies to the system
A lot of what you can do at the company depends on yourself and you manager, always gauge your immediate reporting manager when interviewing for a role.
Leadership is losing its edge and trust with employees

pros: Intel is a cutting edge technology company with a proven track record. It has a yearly cadence of introducing new product to market. As a Technical Marketing Engineer/ Project Manager in Intel working on the latest and greatest processor allows you to experience the products potential prior to the product hitting the market. Guiding customers in their design process allows you to shape the future of the end product before it hits the market.
cons: Large Corporation, hence it is middle heavy and slow to react to new and emerging trends.

pros: You get to do technically challenging work right away and you get to work with very talented people.  The company culture is good and people enjoy working together.
cons:
There is a lot of stress to get your work done with high quality.  
Its a big company and it gets harder to get promoted as you get higher up.
There have been some layoffs and it feels like they are hostile to older employees.

review_title: Great team and exciting to work on cutting edge technology
pros: Fun and exciting to work on upcoming Intel products. Great team and very nice people overall. Good gender balance on team.
cons: Management seems more concerned with internal politics and can be disconnected from engineering. Lack of consistent project priority means constant context switching, which is frustrating and inefficient. Some outdated technologies.

review_title: Intel: The Ideal Place for an Internship
pros:
As an intern, the pay at Intel simply can't be beat.  In fact, it is very nearly what a newly-hired full-time engineer would be paid.  There are also several non-wage benefits, including relocation reimbursement, cash bonuses, stock options, and medical and dental insurance.  All of these great benefits are even available to interns!  Also, there were several paid days of Intern Outings, where all of the interns would go out to get ice cream and hang out at a park, or something like that.

Besides the pay, the culture at Intel is great.  People are friendly, knowledgeable, and willing to help.
The small working groups really help to make a large corporation like Intel still maintain the intimate feel of a small company.  Small groups are able to get things done more easily, with less interruption from the chain of command.
Although the working groups have the feel of a small company, it is great to be able to leverage the resources of a large company like Intel.  With a strong focus on ergonomics and safety in and out of the office, Intel leads by example in providing its employees with the safest and most comfortable working environment possible.
With a great variety of special interest groups, Intel is a great place to keep up-to-date with new technologies, or just refresh your memory of things you once knew.
cons:
Working in Hudson, MA, I was somewhat disconnected with the corporate offices on the west coast.  I have heard it said that the closer one gets to the corporate offices, the harder it is to get useful work done without interruption.

For interns on short work terms, like three-month rotations, the employee cash bonus program does not work well, since the amount paid is based on the number of work weeks since the most recent hire date.  This nullifies any weeks in the previous work term that were not already paid a bonus, since there was a termination in between.

In the Hudson location, there is some growing pain in the area of converging on a common tool chain.  I imagine that this is an artifact of the several acquisitions that have taken place over the years at this facility.

review_title: Intel, get a clue, listen to the people you have, they know how to make you successful once again.
pros: Great people. Great technology. Good opportunities to work globally. Flexibility for work.
cons: Risk taking is dead. HR is a disaster. Managers are more interested in saving their butts and covering up than doing doing the right thing.

pros: Compensation and benefits are very good. LOA is easy and fair. Work hard and if you have a good manager you will be happy and well compensated. There are a lot of good people that truly care that work here. They will try to help you if you need to switch shifts or need to work around outside commitments and college.
cons: Totally output driven. The "little guy" is rarely heard. Managers have no accountability. I've had extremely bad managers here and it took forever for Intel to get rid of them. They preach safety but output is what mostly counts.

pros: I like working for Intel - the work is interesting, compensation is good and work-life balance is great. To be true, there is a lot of work but flexibility allows to combine it with family life. One of the official corporate goals is result orientation - the work is judged based on what's accomplished not the time you spend doing it. I love it.
cons: It is a big mature corporation. There are processes, rules, meetings. You have to accept the culture and work within it.

review_title: It is hard work, but I love the pride I feel because of the cutting edge technology
pros: It is a leader in its field, and is constantly innovating; it values the environment and has vast community outreach programs; I derive pride from the fact that we are 2- 4 years ahead of our competitors in process technology because of the hard work that we do.
cons: Very small office cubicles, dull office environment that projects a feeling of miserliness on the part of the company

review_title: Good place for Electrical Engineer if you dont mind the politics
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Great place for a electrical engineer. But you need to be very competitive and able to handle politics.  Took me a while getting good at the latter.
cons: If you walk in with experience, you will land a good salary . If you start as a rcg or intern, you will earn much less. The company prefers to pay more in stocks and less annual salary. Growth to next level is very very slow. Awesome work/life balance.

pros:
-Great people,  and strong benefits across the board.  
-Opportunities to influence and define new processes.  
-For a large organization, it's flat so there is opportunity for visibility from senior management (depending on the job function
-Flexibility in work/life balance.
-Management is knowledgeable and reinforces passdown and relevance of work to overall strategic objectives by Intel.
-Plenty of learning opportunities, and skill developments offered.
cons:
1) Switching  jjob functions is challenging unless you have a strong network in 100K+ people company.  

2) IT infrastructure, especially sourcing tools and MRP could use improvement.

pros: Decent 401K Investments, good bonuses if you are higher up... I am not. Very good education benefits.
cons: Pay structure is heavily vested towards bonuses and stocks rather than salary, work life balance is talked about but not followed through, poor commitment to software development, the company is full of ladder climbers, management is constantly throwing their teams under the bus, everyone is playing politics.

review_title: Great environment to learn and grow as an engineer
job_title: Quality and Reliability Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: You are surrounded by very smart and data driven engineers who take pride in getting things done. Culture and dress code is very relaxed but can fell like being in school sometime
cons: Work can be stressing at times especially during the launch of the product. Depending on the group and sometime you are stuck in the area you work in if you are not self motivated. Company is too big it is hard to climb up and be noticed.

review_title: Intel is a Great Place to Work
pros: Intel has an excellent stock program. You are able to invest in Intel by buying Intel stock at a discounted price. This company also offer great health benefits compared to other large companies along with a sabbatical (8 weeks off with pay every 7 years of service).  Intel also offers a nice 401k and work-life balance.
cons: Your education and experience far out weighs what's required for the position they hire you at. Promotion is not as swift as it should.

pros: Intel's commitment to Safety is, in my opinion, second to none.  Safety First is more than a motto - it is a way of life, encouraged at every level in the company.
cons: At one time Intel had a strong reputation for promoting from within. Now the institutionalized roadblocks make it nearly impossible for a technician to grow into an engineering position.  Silo mentalities dominate many areas in the company.

review_title: Used to be okay... now -> terrible
pros: You can work with on future technologies with realy smart guys. Office culture is fine. Just fine. Used to have team events.
cons:
No money for anything. No trainings, no conferences. If you want to buy a book for 10 USD you need to ask at least 3 managers for an approval and even then you will probably not get those 10 USD. You always hear how Intel is making money but really they just cut cost everywhere.You have to pay for all the trainings and books from you own pocket.  

I was employed for a position that never worked out. I never did anything that they told me on the interview. NEVER AGAIN.

review_title: My experience at Intel has been good and rewarding
pros: Intel is full of smart and energetic people.  Intel's engineers are resourceful and full of passion on what they do. In the R&D department, They are technical experts on what they do.  The company values individual contributions.  Personal growth is great, a lot of resources to strengthen your knowledge and advance your experience.
cons: Challenges are common as on any other places.  Work-life balance can be challenging depending on the organization.  However, Intel can be quite flexible in accommodating those aspects.

review_title: My experience at Intel has been good and rewarding
pros: Intel is full of smart and energetic people.  Intel's engineers are resourceful and full of passion on what they do. In the R&D department, They are technical experts on what they do.  The company values individual contributions.  Personal growth is great, a lot of resources to strengthen your knowledge and advance your experience.
cons: Challenges are common as on any other places.  Work-life balance can be challenging depending on the organization.  However, Intel can be quite flexible in accommodating those aspects.

pros: Great Benefits, Salary and Working Environment.  In manufacturing the compressed workweek schedule is great for having extended weekends.  Overall a good company to work for.
cons: The culture can be too engineering centric - demanding expectations and lack of work life balance can be draining in the long run.  Limited room for advancement and constant threat of looming layoffs make for a stressful environment.

review_title: Good company but you can definitely get lost.
pros: Everyone works very hard and seems to enjoy their job.  Great benefits.  Pay is very strong.  Employees get to manage their projects, which is great.
cons: You can easily get lost, as the company is huge.  Some people have been there for a long time and very stuck in their ways.  Extremely difficult to find out where to go for some of the basic needs such as  benefits.  The job description can be very different from what you will actually be doing.

review_title: Startup culture has matured to a large corporation
job_title: Research Scientist in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Recognition for technical contributions, leadership in hardware (if you do silicon you should work for Intel at one point in your career.) Deep pockets. Culture of personal responsibility. Wide latitude in locations and ability to work remotely with your group.
cons: Focus on individual contributions rather than team value. Hard to integrate for mid-career entry employees.  There is an established career advancement path that you should move along in terms of promotion if you want to enjoy a long career.

review_title: No work life balance-But great Benefits
pros: Great Health Benefits (like a doctors office right in the building), Excellent facilities, Many discounts and promotion, Brilliant People, Cutting Edge technology.They regularly heir new college graduations with no experience (many semiconductors rarely do not that) so its a great opportunity for them. This company is like having an IV league school on your resume in the semiconductor industry. Once you specialize in something finding a job can be done within weeks just because Intel was on the resume.
cons: Raises are rare and usually very small. To get a promotion you essentially cannot have any life out side of Intel. I was specifically told by my manager that to be successful (not even Exceeds or Outstanding) Intel culture needs to be your life (which is why they like to hire new college graduates they feel that experienced engineers have cultural baggage from previous employers). Some times it is difficult for the management know what their employees are doing on a regular basis because they are pulled in many directions. This requires the employee to focus on perception rather than the actually job. I felt like I was simply a number rather than a valued contributor to the company even though I have made significant contributions and  have saved the company hundreds of thousands of dollars (not much for intel as a whole but justified my salary over 5-6 times over. Having one "Needs Improvement"  or "Successful with no stocks" rating during the annually review can result in a layoff 3-4 years down the road even though you have worked extremely hard to improve and become very successful and valuable member of the team. This does not layoff is not about saving money for Intel but the new CEO will regularly remove "low performers" to please stock holders. Extremely stressful because goals are always changing (but this is in the same in all semiconductor companies). The new CEO is very very focused on metrics on every level and ways that seem ridiculous to others from the outside. I was reprimanded for not meeting the quota for documenting minor safety caches i.e. I saw a person walk down the stairs without holding the hand rail and didn't document it. This is the level of detail of how Intel values metrics.

job_title: Process TD Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Work is challenging, never get bored. Working on the greatest transistor process technology gives you satisfaction. A place where your passion can be satisfied and working alongside some of the brightest minds.
cons: Pathetic work culture. Great work life imbalance, infact no life. Shots called from top down and there is constant fear that trickles down from the top. Meetings held late night like 12, 1, 2 or 3am and expected back to work again by 7:30am. Work 80+ hrs/wk every single.

review_title: A giant kid with niche toys
job_title: Technical Product Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Great company and bonus options
Good benefits
Great work culture and vacation policies
cons:
Management chain is sometimes like a kid that wants to play with expensive toys, and throw them away after playing with them for a few months

They try to get their foot in the software and services market, but eventually decide against it and think that their priority is only HArdware,, which makes sense but also shows that they cant multitask in a sense. For example, getting online within offices and getting stuff done on the internet is a huge pain, which in todays world just doesnt cut it

pros: Highly energized and focused engineers  Good (if not great) benefits,  compensation. Great place to work. (For majority of the prior 10 years).
cons: IMO the trend of building and establishing other geo locations continues to accelerate to the detriment of U.S. engineers.   New era?  Who knows.  The most recent 2 years definitely stood in stark contrast to the preceding 8.  My exit was as unforeseen as the previous CEO's  step-down.

pros:
1. Great work-life balance.
2. Health benefits
3. Unlimited free drinks and fruits.
cons:
1. Too many meetings.
2. IT only supports Windows OS. If you are using Linux and OS X IT support is limited.
3. Hiring poorly skilled candidates because of "diversity initiative". Managers specially looking for diversity candidates (women in tech and other minorities) to fill head count at the cost of skilled candidates.

job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Very nice people to work with.
Strong mentor ship program.
Interesting and challenging projects.
Very willing to teach skills related to the specific field on the job.
cons:
Worked on a project that was a long term research, so I didn't have any concrete examples of products I worked on when I finished.
Many people coming in and out of the group.
Manager was out of the office/abroad during my time there so I had very little communication with him

review_title: Big company trying to adjust course
pros: Pay and benefits are competitive with a “Geo Differential” adder for employees in Santa Clara to help offset the higher cost of living.  They are dealing with the changing market shift from PCs and laptops to tablets which Intel has not been successful in penetrating.  Intel has made draconian changes in the past that worked out in the long run.
cons: Very little training and even less development for first and second level managers.  Content experts are promoted with hit and miss results with regards to leadership and coaching skills.

review_title: Horrible company and very political environment full of lies
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Pays well above market rate by %30 (This is probably why it's attracted A LOT of gold diggers.)
cons:
Skills learnt here will not be transferable to any other company. This is not a good thing when there are so many lay offs.
Engineering culture has been reduced to an exhausting game of politics. It's like working in a 3rd world country environment. %98 hardly speak English even when an English speaking person is present.
Information is hidden from people who do not belong to the pack. Career growth is based on who you know.

job_title: Senior Applications Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: you are encouraged to learn and improve, you are given resources to do so if you want and have the ability and drive.  Depending on group its a nice place to work but you have to have the grapes for it. In other words, when you are young and can spend the time.
cons:
Plan on annual layoffs, make sure your work can be applied elsewhere at any time. Layoffs likely will increase as the ship takes on water. 
Annual focal process that takes a lot of time and is a waste since magic spreadsheets and Bell curve statistics will be the judge anyways.

review_title: A good large company with bad executives
pros: It _was_ a great place to work...until it wasn't.
cons:
Since it's a large company focused on chips (ie. Chipzilla) with often fat profit margins, it's easy to get complacent, thinking the PC is going to be the cash cow forever.   Intel failed to execute many potentially good products in the past, but the biggest missed opportunity was the smart phone revolution.  

The ranking and rating system for employees basically encourages backstabbing and undermining team members, promoting the ones that are the best at doing that.

pros:
Decent Pay
Incredibly smart and hard working engineering organization
Global opportunities
cons:
Company not growing as quickly as it needs to maintain steady opportunities for progression
It is "old guard" of tech, which means the thinking can be a bit constrained in some of its traditional cpu businesses (note Intel has MANY businesses)

job_title: Technical Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Decent pay and benefits for region, though not exceptional and less than a number of peer companies.
- Better respect for work-life-balance than many peer companies.
- Many nice, supportive, and helpful co-workers.
- Can be a good company at which to start a career.
- Sabbaticals are a nice benefit.
- Good maternity and bonding leave benefits compared to most U.S. companies.
- Intel has a general expectation that its employees are responsible professionals, so office employees are rarely micro-managed.
cons:
- The accountants are running things (literally). 
- The company is more profitable than it has ever been, yet still finds ways to reduce benefits nearly every year.
- Doing a good job and earning a raise appears to increase an employee's chance of being fired since that raise has now made the employee more expensive than lower-performing peers.
- The company earns billions, yet still manages to structure layoff criteria in ways that "coincidentally" disproportionately target older workers.
- Executives seem to see employees as little more than an expense line in a ledger that should be slashed whenever a boost to profit margins is desired, rather than as people who are committed to the success of the company and who have families and lives that may be irreparably harmed.

review_title: Great Place To Work..Not So Much Anymore
pros: Love the industry, the field of work, benefits.
cons: Focused on promoting diversity even though they don't know how to do their jobs. Management is poor. Upper management don't care. No career development opportunities within the system even though they talk about it. One would want to focus on specific roles/skill sets but come yearly focal, you have to sign off on something completely different. Its all to make management look good on paper. Zero work life balance due to business needs.

review_title: solid employment at a great company
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Boston, MA
pros: steady employment and very project oriented. Something I enjoy. There is a high morale for those in the engineering teams. Those folks add a lot to the bottom line of hte company and they have a lot of freedom to make decisions and work the way they want. Management doesn't maintain a tight hold on anyone.
cons: Too big. I feel like a number and that I dont make much of a difference. Each person is in a small group that doesn't contribute much on its own. You really have to have an imagination to feel like you are adding to the bottom line come quarterly results.

job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Chandler Heights, Optional[AZ]
pros:
Compared to other tech companies Intel is relatively stable and the chances of getting laid of are smaller. 
Intel is fairly flexible about work hours and working from home, however this depends a lot on your manager as there is no corporate guideline. 
Benefits are ok. In general if  you work hard, you will be rewarded.
cons:
Stock is doing terrible as everyone knows, so chance of getting rich by working at Intel are almost zero. 
A lot of engineers move to management way too quickly. As a result there are too many managers and not enough competent engineers. 
Not enough smart engineers.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
You get to learn best practices and processes at a top company
You work with very intellegent and passionate people
You get to "rotate" to other areas of the business so that you gain experience in multiple types of businesses
Training (Intel University)
The stock participation plan (SPP)
cons: Salary was not always competitive with the marketplace. In some senses they discount your salary because you are working for a top named company like Intel. The review process called "focal" does tend to be a bit unfair and you only get good reviews IF your manager is willing to defend you.

review_title:
Challenging work environment.
Very talented group of engineers to work with.
Good salary and benefits.
pros: Still works in a  mode. Always trying to satisfy the next customer. Not much long term vision and time spend to achieve the vision. Due to recent , lot of politics between every team.
cons: The pay is good, the work can occasionally be interesting, and the company makes the right products at the right time. Management is pretty flexible about your schedule as long as the work gets done

review_title: Challenging and up tempo place to work, the only limits are the ones you set.
pros: Most of the work is challenging and enjoyable, the only limits are set by yourself. Many opportunities to travel and grow within the company, I have been to Europe, Asia and all over the west coast. Worked with people from all over the world. I've been with Intel over 10+ years and have enjoyed many experiences in and out of work.
cons: Work can be hard and long, when projects and deadlines need to be met. Wages are slow to grow for long term employees, new hires get competitive wages, usually higher than current employees.

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Sabbatical - Hands down!  Intel gives 8 week paid time off every 7 years to live your dream.  Now they allow an option of 4 weeks paid time off every 4 years!  This is above and beyond your vacation days.  The company is very large so you can change jobs and even careers without moving to another company.  The company air shuttles they have from Arizona, Oregon, California allow easy hassle free travel to company sites.
cons: Unimaginative cubicles led to unimaginative people or maybe its the other way around.

pros:
-- Intel tries to make it a "Great Place To Work" 
    - They have free movies/events and free fruit.  If you are non-exempt (non-salary) this is a great.  If you are exempt (salaried), it depends on your specific job if it is really a benefit, since work still piles up.  

-- They have a full doctors office on site, so getting healthcare is very easy.

-- They have a nice gym / fitness program & many fitness classes.

-- They have a shuttle to public transit for those who wish to go green and they offer a pre-tax benefit so that you can save money on public transit.
cons:
-- There is a divide between the treatment of exempt (salaried) employees and non-exempt employees, Technical and non-technical employees & levels of stress based on how close you are to the Fab.
            - If you are salaried, in a highly technical area that is in TMG (The Manufacturing Group), you will often be expected to work your nights and weekends with no added compensation.

            - Ironically, the higher your degree level (PhD being the worst) you will be less appreciated than others because others will expect you to meet unrealistic deadlines that force you to work 60-80 hour weeks.

-- Deadlines are often set on weekends or right after holidays so that you are forced to work on your "off -time"

-- The fast pace/high demands are not offset by freedom.  You are no longer allowed to work from home unless you have a good reason and you are expected to be physically present at least standard work hours.

-- There is a lot of hypocrisy here. There are "Great Place to Work" events that appear to be geared towards the employees that are not worked as hard.
            - Upper management throws around the term "great place to work", but the extra events / team builders / dinners seem forced and just to save face.  They are for all employees (technicians and less technical staff also) not just for those that they are likely designed for to offset the long hours.  There is nothing extra for those that work crazy hours.  

            - The "Great Place to Work" events come with a cost. If there is a deadline coming up or the Fab is waiting on you, your work still needs to get done, so you may get free food or a free movie, but will have to work late because your work is still there.

review_title: Great potential, great base DNA - so why try so hard to change it?
pros: Flexible work hours; lots of positions to move to in case you are stuck with a bad manager...
cons: Near-constant state of re-org for some groups; Intel has been trying to change its DNA for at least 20 years... not content with the 60+% margins, they are relentlessly trying to break their mold and explode  their growth for the major stockholders.

pros:
Large company with many different opportunities
Pretty good cafeteria with free soft drinks/coffee (Santa clara location)
cons:
Bonus pay determined by hire date and not time spent working. Many people who started 2+ weeks after me received quarterly bonus while I did not.

Not much attention paid to interns
Project was described as very important and actually did seem like a great thing to have automated. Not much of a push from manager/mentor to actually get approval to run the necessary scripts on a server.

job_title: Component Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Decent compensation package, ability to upskill and change positions in the company, (usually)interesting work.
cons: Atrocious hours, active layoffs, benefits are being whittled down over time, employees are expected to pick up the work their laid off peers left rather than getting replacement staff.

pros:
•	Responsible employee that will consistently deliver good quality results, which includes a high level of data integrity, outstanding sample prep techniques and professional reports. 
•	Independent and efficient. Able to understand job pass down clearly, and always deliver on time, with minimum follow up/ supervision. Capable of clearly understanding specific requirements, and delivering the desired outcome to peers or managers as needed.
cons: be happy and more active and Capable of clearly understanding specific requirements, and delivering the desired outcome to peers or managers as needed.

review_title: Manufacturing department treats engineers like slaves
pros: you will get a paycheck
cons: you work 60+ hours per week with no overtime, always on call, always working weekends, no 401k matching, no comp days, bonuses are <1/2 the amount promised upon hire, only 15 days vacation/yr, you are not allowed to use the tuition reimbursement benefit, there is no opportunity for vertical career growth, your yearly review and raise amount is based on departmental budget, not your performance, manufacturing is severely understaffed, you are required to start work ~7am every day even though you work late and are up all night on call.

review_title: Dirty politics is destroying the work culture.
job_title: Senior Reliability Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good Salary and excellent benefits.  Bonding leave and sabbatical are awesome!
cons:
People work for themselves, then for their teams, and then for the company. 
Dirty politics, which used to be limited to upper management, is now affecting engineers at working level. 
First level managers lack training, second level managers lacks vision or are unable to translate BK's direction into what it means for their group.

review_title: Dirty politics is destroying the work culture.
job_title: Senior Reliability Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Good Salary and excellent benefits.  Bonding leave and sabbatical are awesome!
cons:
People work for themselves, then for their teams, and then for the company. 
Dirty politics, which used to be limited to upper management, is now affecting engineers at working level. 
First level managers lack training, second level managers lacks vision or are unable to translate BK's direction into what it means for their group.

pros: Dominant position in CPU's.  Relatively agile for such a large company.
cons: Rising competition in CPU's.   Company culture and employees are a bit insular and therefore can be naive about the markets in which they participate.   This causes Intel's leadership to be late on certain technology trends and industry trends.

review_title: Intel why have you gone downhill
pros:
When I started at Intel, things were a little rough as I worked with a tough lead and worked many hours 60+, but I learned the ropes quickly as I got acquainted with many people will to help.   I felt we were more as a team as we were able to interact with other teams better working on the same project.

Starting pay, RSUs and raises were once good like 5%, but ever since moving grade levels, noticed the raises were not as good. I got higher pay increases when I started off at a lower level than higher unless promoted.
cons:
I am ranking these as I see fit.  

1. Under BK as our CEO things have gone really bad like our benefits. We are making record revenues and profits every year, but somehow our money is not going back to the employees.  Our raises keep on getting worst every year and for RSUs, it keeps on getting worst value wise. I remember getting promoted from grade 5 to 6, 5 years ago and I got SSL2 stock worth $11K value.  When I got from grade 6 to grade 7 promotion my manager was only able to give me SSL3 stock worth only 7.5K.    Then, our 401K for retirement has not been reinstated back to 6%.  Our quarterlies funding drops as well, as we do not have anymore winter parties and are replaced with snag a snack day.  

Management always talks about cost cutting, but they seem to make some big acquisitions and spend a lot of money  on external executive hires and a lot of diversity propaganda.  Unfortunately, there are a lot of senior leaders that left the company that would have made a fine CEO in the future.  

2. Go through many managers, (1 manager per 1 year) 

3. Working with other cross sites in way different time zones. Europe and Asia, always trying to find the right time to fit into our schedules. Sometimes we need to have meetings either late or early.

4. Lots of reorgs, we go through once a year now.  I do not see the point why other than it creates a new position for someone wanting to be promoted

5. Working on projects, we tend to work within our own team instead all different teams working together to solve problems.  

6.  Lots of meetings that are sometimes pointless, find out which ones are important to attend. I tend to skip some because they are not relevant to me.

7. Lots of Intel senior management that stayed within Intel for many years have left or "retired" during BK tenure and most of the upper staff tend to be folks we paid a great deal of money to hire on the outside.  They tend always want to focus on cost cutting instead of improving morale and culture.

pros:
- If you drop the initiative, you can do steady progress with reasonable resources.
- Resourcing is high compared to other research groups across industry
- while known to few people, it is very highly regarded in the academia.
cons:
RETENTION: CR has a big retention problem. CR leaders must form a coherent way to retain employees. High performers are leaving in significant numbers. Many of them express sadness that CR did not make an effort to retain them. This makes others want to leave (well that is how people work these days). 

If you do not value them while they are here, they will not stay. The message we hear often is that we can replace you. I think it is up to the leaders to introspect if they are indeed replacing the talent that went away (or planning to leave).

Several engineers complained that the messages they hear from leaders is confusing. If you fail to retain the key contributors , we will face a gradual decline in the ideas and quality of work. We will also have hard time to recruit (since the engineers will not refer someone knowing the state of affairs).

Be proactive in retaining talent. If the engineers who push the ideas leave , we will have a serious issue. Decades ago, one could treat the retention with a power play, there is serious competition for talent today.

ABUSIVE POWER PLAY: Some of the leaders operate by power play, blocking access/stopping support/questioning essential expenditures/approval for literature to exert control over the engineers. This is abusive to say the least. The practice of punishing/abusive the engineers who have a difference in opinion  or plan, idea or ambition is hurtful. 

We are surprised that in the world of #metoo, why Intel does not train the leaders to stop using their power play tactics. It may mean the difference between a retained employee and one that leaves. Use knowledge and logic instead of power play culture. 

I am ashamed to even share this with my colleagues at other companies how CR/TMG treats their employees.

review_title: Competitive pay, fun assignments, but too much sheilding of incompetent co-workers.
job_title: Soc Design Engineer in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Open and casual. Good pay and benefits. Many nice perks. Global company with a good outlook. Many smart coworkers with 20 years experience in the industry. Fun and interesting assignments.
cons: Intel is too loose with hiring. Many competent engineers are forced to pick up the slack for a small number of very very incompetent people. These people should never have been hired in the first place.  As a young person I watched my peers reject Intel for the likes of Google,Amazon,Etc. I believe Intel no longer attracts top talent like it used to.

pros: Great co-workers, flexible work schedule, exciting and interesting work.  you get the ability to truly work on great projects
cons:
Mgmt has truly lost its way.  cheap cheap cheap is the only way.  outsourcing & off loading work to low wage regions!!!!  this company has become desperate with it's decision making
If you work for Intel Mgmt will not value you at all! you are an expendable commodity.  
IT has become a terrible place.  everyone is looking to jump ship

review_title: A great place to work if you have a manager with a clue.
pros: Benefits and a great addition to your resume.
cons: There is no work/life balance as a process engineer. Middle management is horrible and the annual review for promotions is an archaic and unfair system. How well you do at Intel depends on your manager, unfortunately most managers here are clueless. I feel very undervalued and unappreciated, and the majority of my co-workers feel the same way.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: It feels great to work for the leading semiconductor manufacturer in the world. Depending on the group,  you may have the opportunity to travel to one of Intel's many sites around the world. You also get to work with some of the smartest people in the world. This provides an experience in which you are learning something new every single day. The benefits package is great and provides great medical care and extra bonuses during the year. The free drinks in the cafeteria are also a plus!
cons: There is a lot of bureacracy and politics at work here.

review_title: Life is good for a loyal Intel employee, assuming you have a life outside Intel
job_title: Graduate Technical Intern in Santa Clara, CA
pros: The pay is good, the work is challenging, and AMD sucks.
cons: You feel like a tiny cog in a giant machine.  The Santa Clara campus has a dozen buildings connected by sky bridge.  Each building has a sea of tiny battleship gray cubicles laid out on a grid.  Locations are denoted by building number, floor number, and pole number.  The pole notation makes the office seem like an enormous  game of battleship.  As such it is both easy to get lost, and easy to find your way.

review_title: Software engineer that is happy with their job.
pros: I enjoy Intel's flex schedule. If I want to sleep in I can just come in a little later and just leave later. If I want to get off work early I can come in earlier and then leave early. I also enjoy the many benefits that Intel offers and the chance to work on the latest and greatest technology.
cons: Promotions are not solely based on performance, but more based on whose turn it is. They talk about meritocracy but that is only part of the story.

review_title: If you pay peanuts you get monkeys.
pros:
Working for CBO is a lot of fun if you like pubbing and clubbing with a fun young crowd. 
After a while you will develop very good Excel-based reporting and email management skills.
Excellent soft skills training classes are available to any employee.
Intel has always been a very good reference to have on your CV/Resume.
cons:
No chance for a career advance unless you are a brown nosing the management.
Style of management is awful, too many managers stick around just because they have a mortgage to pay in Swindon.

pros: Overall great tech company and a good place to work.  Given the economy, Intels very well positioned even though times are tough.  Good pay and benefits, good healthcare options, but few frills (ie no free lunch)
cons: Lots of pressure, lots of competition, but this comes with any opportunity.  Managers are expected or feel they are expected to contribute in ways outside of the management role...

review_title: Some great experience and peers but some incompetent managers.
job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Cutting edge technology, benefits, good people, pays well, cool office area, did I say great coworkers, nice laptops, travel to Ireland & Israel
cons: advancement blocked, incompetent managers, ineffective human resource dept, performance reviews based on manager's personal opinion, triple documentation, short handed, small or no raises, New hires make more than people who have worked there 10 years.

review_title: Good people, good management, challenging work
pros:
I work with highly professional people, which I learned a lot from.
The project I'm working on has a real impact on the world, and is full of technical challenges.
In general, I'm isolated from whatever office politics that may or may not exist, which is a good thing.
Good and fun people and workplace.
cons:
Work can be stressful, esp. for people doing things related to the business core (which is not the case for me)
Being in a large organization means having difficulties reaching out to people and creating collaborations.

review_title: Dream Job, cutting edge technology, Great Place To Work
pros:
It is the Best semicondutor company in the world.
Obviously cutting edge technolgy
People listen to you, however young you are / however inexperienced you are. (lot of diversity too)
Large corporation; so lot of oppurtunity to cross pollinate and move laterally if needed.
Well rewarded (well rounded compensation, rather than just pay).
cons:
Large company, so difficult to respond to quick changes in market. but catching up.
May feel getting lost doing somethign so small, not able t see the big picture unless you have a good manager, group or mentor.
Some departments work can be very demanding.

pros: Surrounded by extremely talented and motivated people.  Has competitive pay, interesting work, and lots of technical depth.  Plenty of projects to move around to.  Company has a fair redeployment program if a job function gets obsoleted.
cons: Still is an inside-out company.  Too many organizations touching a product.  Encumbered by legacy products and legacy thinkers.  Though it has ambitions to be more system oriented, the company still focuses and values silicon & CPU innovations the most.

pros: The company is impressive to work for in terms of the scope of its operations.  There are a lot of opportunities to move about the company and the world.
cons: This job is very hard on someone who wants to spend time with the family.  I always get the feeling from management that 'hey we pay you well, we can ask for whatever we want'.  Additionally, I was very disappointed that the terms of my employment (time off) were not the same as discussed at my interview.

review_title: Great company but pretty slow an too adult
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: In most of the cases work/life balance is ok, but not in my personal case. The organization cares about ethics, social responsibility and sure creates a lot of high end technology
cons: The company is very slow, is the opposite than Facebook; most of the management staff is pretty old, too optimistic, risk adverse and very mind closed. Intel is a great company for an industrial or electrical engineer; but from a software engineer perspective it sucks (and a lot)!!!

review_title: After 15 years, still a great company to work for
pros: The company has great core values that are deeply embedded in the culture (customer orientation, discipline, results orientation, risk taking, great place to work, quality).  This in addition to the focus on meritocracy, makes Intel a great company to work for. Also of note, Intel is one of the few companies that has a sabbatical program (8 paid weeks off every 7 years ... in addition to a pretty standard vacation allowance).
cons: As I would imagine is true with most large companies, it can be harder than getting things done than one might think is really necessary.

pros:
Industry leader with good benefits
Excellent facilities, work-life balance and good peers to work with
Continue to grow by having a protocol to "copy exactly" when machining
cons:
They need new people to also be an exact copy of the group leader - and don't usually know it
Have problems when acquiring companies and expert personnel and then Intel-izing them. which often does not work

pros:
Industry leader with good benefits
Excellent facilities, work-life balance and good peers to work with
Continue to grow by having a protocol to "copy exactly" when machining
cons:
They need new people to also be an exact copy of the group leader - and don't usually know it
Have problems when acquiring companies and expert personnel and then Intel-izing them. which often does not work

pros: Lots of people to talk to and projects to talk about. Good programs and classes for career development, project/people management, public speaking, etc... Convenient air shuttle to fly you from place to place. Friendly workers, and anyone in the company is easily reachable. Employee circuit pages are very helpful to get the inside scoop on the company.
cons: I don't like the gray cubicles -- the color seems to drain my creativity away. New Employee Orientation may seem boring and unnecessary after a certain point in the day. Food can be expensive at times.

review_title: Great team, nice benefits but questionable future
job_title: Digital Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Work-life balance determined by the employee, managers are easy-going as long as you deliver your work.
Good benefits, great Oregon countryside and lots of places to see/hike. Great place to settle down.
Good sabbatical benefits.
cons:
Promotions/raises tend to be allocated according to seniority (i.e. years spent at work) rather than individual success which can kill your ambition/competitiveness.
High level management especially in the architecture/design area can be unsteady, I have witnessed many nice projects getting cancelled after months of work.
Too much focus getting to develop the process technology and not enough budget spent on researching and developing new products/architectures.

review_title: Great company to work for with a very unique culture.
pros:
Continuous training and development of employees. Provides resources and tools to be able to do your job well!
Hard charging, open communication, not very formal, fair to employees, encourages employees to openly give feedback, speak their minds and challenge their managers.
Very process and systems oriented but espouses continuous improvement.
gives you a global perspective. 
Culture and values is really very unique and strong.  The values are practiced in all countries. 
Committed to safety.
cons:
as a global organization,working with different timezones can be tiring.
sometimes inflexible(because of established processes) and can become bureaucratic because it's a large organization.

pros: Fantastic work/life balance, minimal interference from management in dtd operations, good compensation and excellent benefits, consistently changing technology keeps the job interesting.
cons: Only one real drawback, it is tough to break out of the technician title if that is where you start.  Working on my graduate degree now and still no light at the end of the tunnel.

job_title: Senior Automation Linux Administrator & Architect Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Structured company to keep the business running. Nice HR and consideration with employees.
Multiple opportunities to develop or keep a career, multi functional and fun.
Most of the employees are easy going and nice place to work.
cons:
Some of the acquisitions bring their own customs and sometimes bad habits. The process to integrate, educate and get into the environment is not efficient causing unconformable situations. 
Lacking of automation processes and well organized library of technical documentation.

pros:
Been there 12 years, 2nd company after college, its awesome and I love working for them.
The challenges are insane, the work hours ridiculous, but the rewards are awesome.
I love working for the Israeli's, working with the mexicans, the Indians, etc.
Nowhere else is like Intel.
If you don't like your manager, you move, simple as that - you make your own career.
I've been given so many opportunities, it's ridiculous. Got nothing bad to say about Intel except I wish my relocation was longer :)
cons: My wife complains I work too much, but I love it!

pros: Many job opportunities, interesting project and plenty of courses and trainings available for the employees. Company culture is set on values and ethics, which is great. Intel provides access to many on-site facilities and has a good benefits plan.
cons: Some decisions are made without proper transparency, preparation or consultation - which sometimes has a negative impact on business and employees. Also, too many meetings that could be an e-mail - this can be really frustrating when you have lots of work to do but must attend 3 meetings in a row.

review_title: Quickly dropping. Layoffs of the experience and knowledge.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros: Still have competitive compensation package, there were interesting projects and good conditions. During previous years it was a place, where you can do your job and avoid "office politics", now it is going to change.
cons: After new management team is raised, strange processes are going her. Layoffs of the experienced employees, closing of the best projects. Future of the firms is going to be unknown, conditions going worst, politics become the most important on a work place.
Performance management is not consistent across the board, with especially non- or low-performing managers being given multiple opportunities (years) to recover.

review_title: good pay, not for team players
job_title: Silicon Test Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Pay and benefits are good, you work with some really smart people
cons: You also work with some less than smart people.  The worst part of intel is the yearly review, promotions are all based on bell curves and are applied at the second level manager level, who often can't do a good job of determining the skilled from the good salespeople.

review_title: Big company.  Solid products.  Good to employees
pros: Intel has many solid perks, bonuses, stock purchasing, decent wages, and does a very good job keeping a careful watch on the health of its employees.  They are big enough with 100k employees to be a world unto its own.  Most groups inside Intel have very reasonable hours and a solid life away from work
cons: Not the highest wages around.  No matching 401k.  Intel missed the 4g phone market and blew a lot of money.  They are a big big company... so that means they don't move particularly fast and it has cost them.

pros: Working with cross enterprise group of people with deep knowledge in the security domain. This group crosses many areas from development of silicon to driving the requirements into the drivers and software all the way to drivers and managements of these services.
cons: Challenge to drive enterprise wide security standards driving alignment with external standards. Large group cross all of these areas, silicon development, drivers, software and aligning to the set of external standards.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Intelligent technical colleagues -- 95+% of your peers there will be great.   The work is challenging and intellectually stimulating.
cons: Poor middle and upper management, horrible CEO, inability/unwillingness to differentiate between good workers and do-nothing BS-ers, an unfortunate hesitance to terminate managers who are consistently rated poorly.

review_title: One of the best company in Penang
pros:
Good work-life balance
A lot of training provided to grow employee
Challenging work
Opportunity to work with diverse co-workers around the world
Very flexible working hour
Systematic and organized
Having a manager rating system by their employees which is a good feedback tool to the management
cons:
Decision making is slow due to too many hierarchies 
Very frequent re-organization
Job scope is very specialized 
Job security is low because of frequent lay-offs
Increment is low (depends on teams, groups, and department)

review_title: Management understand it is time for a change !
pros: It is a huge corporate America company that accepts the fact the times are changing !. Sometimes there is no other choice but to let the "old" people go and hire new college graduates that were born into the new technologies. Innovation is encouraged by management.
cons: Like in all corporate, you need to be very careful not to get stuck in a position that is very specific to the company and can not truly contribute to your skills set.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Good stable company, less politics
Good new focus on diversity hires. Almost half of the new hires will be diversity hires which includes any female, African American male, LGBT, Veteran, etc.
cons:
Low salary
Stock has been stale for 15 years now with no sign of EPS growth for the company
Low growth oppor for employees esp female employees. Most Managers are men.
Paid too much $25 Million to Murthy to hire him from Qualcomm

review_title: Amazed by the accuracy of "the layoff" intel page
pros: Work life balance is the only thing Intel is good at. The real intel defined at thelayoffDOTcomSLASHintel . One has to go through it before joining Intel.
cons:
Managers listen from one ear and its out the other that very moment.
At Intel, You have absolute freedom to do whatever your Manager tells you to.

review_title: Used to be a fun place to work
pros:
I liked my co-workers
I loved the dog policy and bringing my dog to work
I loved having my own enclosed office with shades and locked door.
cons:
No room for growth.
Low pay and overworked 
Too many processes
Low moral
Too many layoffs and wondering if and when it's going to be you next.

review_title: Being a $60B company is not easy
pros: Stable, classic and is made of multiple startups. Career options at Intel allow one to move from one group to another after successfully completing  12 months in a role.
cons: Stability comes with a price, it is not easy to make the elephant move towards new trends. While it is good in some cases, it has also hurt the bottom line.

review_title: Good work culture; too much reorg
pros: A comfortable place to work. Extremely good work culture, helpful and knowledgeable people. Fame of this company really shines on your CV and helps in grabbing other opportunities. Such a wide portfolio of products creates a lot of different jobs in multiple domains. This can be utilized in exploring the interests
cons: A lot of reorg keeps happening and if you are unlucky enough to be in an afected team then it can put the team in a directionless scenario. Projects keep on getting scraped and you might not be able to get silicon learning. It might feel that all the effort went to trash.

review_title: Great place to work if you love to work hard
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Good benefits and work environment. Little perks everywhere. Kids to work day. Lots of learning opportunity
cons: Extremely demanding and you have to be ready to give 150% of your time to keep your job sustainable. Some nepotism  and bias is always in the back ground everywhere.

pros: Exceptionally smart hardworking individuals and teams. Open and direct culture with a desire to execute.  Excellent product development / process to go to market. Exceptional integrity and ethics in business practices.
cons: Growth paths stagnate after 2-4 years in any given role. Requires employees to keep their heads up for next role and position accordingly. Under market pay and time requirements vs. unspoken expectations. Lots of managing up.

pros: great benefits, work life balance is pretty good depending on where you work.  Challenging work environment. can be a place you can work your whole career. rewards top performers with fair compensation
cons: too often there is a buzz word(s) that only stick for about 6 months.   Almost like a word of the day.  bureaucracy, too big. Not very nimble when you need to get work done.  You almost have to go ask 5 people to get something green lit.

job_title: Web Development Analyst in Chandler, AZ
pros:
The benefits package is outstanding, job security is pretty good.  Also if you really wanted to, you could work there for years without ever actually having to produce a single thing of worth to the company or your co-workers.

Also, there are some really great communication channels at Intel, although one must wade through quite a bit of bias to get to the real news.  I never saw more corporate Kool-Aid drinkers than at Intel.    At one point I was receiving 20+ "newsletters" per month from various corporate groups, and published two myself.
cons:
Raises aren't great.  Also, upper-level managers can make capriciously stupid decisions.  Sometimes these changes will stick, while other times, they are quietly ignored.  There was never any rhyme or reason to which decisions your manager decided must be enforced, and which ones could be ignored.

I even saw this inconsistency happen at the employee level.  One great example was when my division (which supported construction groups all over the planet) suddenly had telecommuting banned for all employees.  Within a month or two all of the women in my group somehow miraculously got "exceptions" to the telecommuting ban, while the two men in my group (myself included) did not.

Also, Intel is largely run by folks in their mid 50's.  Although the internal groupings of the company seem to be in a constant state of flux, the true corporate management structure changes little, with the same small group of people holding relatively identical positions of power regardless of their changes in job title.  There is no true hope of advancement in one's career for anyone younger than 45.

pros: Unbelievably deep talent pool, some incredible managers at all levels, results orientation.  Compensation is competitive, especially if performance-based compensation is included.  Opprtunity for international assignments.
cons: Company's pretty big.  Upward mobility very limited.  In many groups, significant personal sacrifice part of the job description.   As a senior manager, to survive I spent far too much time polishing presentations (mine or my group's) and too little developing the organization or learning the technology.

pros: Compensation, benefits, and many opportunities to improve your leadership and technical skills through training and mentoring.
cons: Management and bureaucracy. To many levels of management and decisions take to long to be made. Employees tend to move up early in their career to a certain level but then mangement begins to restrict the movement/promotions not sure if it's because they don't want to pay the higher salary associated with the movement or they don't want so many people at a certain grade level.

review_title: Better Than Most, but Don't Expect a Life Outside Work
pros:
Salary and bonuses may be 20-30% lower than comparable companies, but the job stability is unmatched as long as you work on the bread and butter microprocessors.  Most of my friends who've left have lost their higher paying positions at other corporations after a couple of years.  

That said, the work is challenging (at least in my area) and rewarding in a karma sort of way since you realize that many people around the world will use what you work on.  The people are all very bright, and I mostly enjoy working with my team a lot.  Things get DONE at Intel and done on time (mostly), because when they aren't, the world notices.
cons:
Work / life balance depends totally on what group you work in.  Some groups are very liberal (Marketing, etc), but many groups are run by old timers who absolutely do not believe in ever 'working from home', and in some cases even closely track who gets to work at 8am and who doesn't.  Corporate is absolutely WORTHLESS in standardizing this and gives lip service to 'employee work/life balance' that means NOTHING.  In anycase, expect to work 50 hours a week at MINIMUM.

The ranking and rating/focal process is horrific and brutal.  It takes up about 4 months a year when you include normal focal and mid-year focal and the results don't justify it.  It DOES make the place a dog-eat-dog killer of a place to work, where you are never really sure you will not get rated low unless you are doing your best, but the paranoia it inspires and the pain is unneeded and unnecessary.  

Upper management is very, very smart, and I am impressed by their ethics.  However, they are ruthlessly brutal and some of them will not hesitate to blackball you or run you out of the company if you cross them or fail to kowtow.

Biggest downside for the average employee is that Intel, despite being a 'high tech' company gives it's employees absolutely CRAP computers to work on.  4 or 5 year old laptops are the norm unless you are doing silicon design or something that requires something newer.  When my monitor died a year ago I was given a new CRT monitor that I later found on Newegg for $60 and that I wouldn't have bought  even for use at my house, and which of course died after only a few months.  This sort of pennywise, poundfoolish idiocy abounds, except in the silicon fabs, where spending $100M on a new stepper is considered just the cost of doing business (which it is, but come on, so are decent computers for the engineers).

Another downside is that despite being insanely profitable constantly, management constantly looks for more ways to keep this money from the rank and file.  Profit sharing used to be 12.5% of salary when I started, then it went to 8%, now is at 7% and they are clearly positioning it to go even lower.  Health benefits are similarly being reduced.

Last but not least there has been a strong 'diversity' push in the last few years, which would normally be great, but which has resulted in significant bias during focal and hiring AGAINST people who are not 'diverse'.
