*Flexibility will vary from group to group and manager to manager, but in general flexibility is a huge plus. If you need to be absent during normal working hours, or work from home, it is never a problem as long as the job gets done and quality is not impacted.
*Intel is a meritocracy and is data driven; if you bring tangible results to the table, you will be recognized (and vice versa).
cons:
*Bureaucracy, and resistance to change. Management knows this is a problem and has attempted to resolve it, but there is still a long way to go.
*Health benefits are ok, but not as good as compared to other tech companies
*The work pace is fast here, and it can be quite stressful at times trying to meet unreasonable deadlines. Although management understands the need for 'work/life balance', you really need to be able to set your own limits and say 'no', or else the workload will never stop growing.

review_title: My small group is good but gotta EARN back that trust at a corporate level
job_title: Design Engineering Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Compensation and benefits are about the best in the area.  But as someone else pointed out there are not a lot to compare against in the Portland Oregon area.  

For my group there is good work/life balance.  But from what I've heard from contacts in other groups around the company my group is in the minority.
cons: There remains distrust of managment and the company.  I think some of this lingers from all the redeployments/layoffs/firings - folks have not forgotten.  Even though most of this appears to be over management has insisted that it will consistenly look to "improve effeciency".  Even though this is standard fare for any good organization the way this is communicated leaves the employee feel uncertain about thier future.  Also, like someone else mentions, there is flux and uncertainty in terms of what will stay in the US and what work will move overseas.  It's true that phrases like "5 engineers for the price of 1" were often heard a few years ago.  All this coupled with stagnant stock price has meant low moral for some folks.

review_title: Good employer, but expect to work hard and be flexible
job_title: Operations Manager in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Good opportunities to increase your formal and "on the job" education. Most managers are open to flexibility to achieve work/life balance. There are good personal benefits such as employee discount programs, well maintained gyms, bike to work facilities, good team building events.
cons: Often demands quite a lot of flexibility outside of normal scheduled work hours, very competitive workplace between peers, somewhat flawed annual review process.

review_title: Great place to work but not if you care about career advancement and career growth.
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
First, Intel provides a great place to work with effort made by the senior management to constantly adapt and tune the company culture to reflect the "in" thing in the valley. For example, as a result of Conan O'Brien's parody of the company's gray walled cubicle farm's a pilot project to convert an entire floor in a Santa Clara building was launched and received tremendous approval from employees. Starbucks coffee shop style bays adorn the four corners of the floor with giant flat screen TVs, bookshelves, and bar stools etc. Also, hot beverages and cold fountain drinks have been made available free to all employees. 

Second, technology runs through the company's veins. So anything technology related is valued and great many resources are thrown at employee ideas that sound worthy of further pursuit.

Third, the management culture is cut throat. Hence it is a great place to spend a few years to sharpen your sword and get out and fight the war outside.
cons:
First, It is a creaky ship and it is leaking from all sides. It is an old tech company with very little attrition. The main reason for this is the dot come bubble. Those who joined at least a few years prior to the bubble received stock options in spades and worth some money. Those who joined during or after the bubble really suffered and as a result have been leaving in droves.

Second, there is too much bureaucracy when it comes to career development and promotion opportunities. Those who suck up to their manager stand a better chance at getting promoted. Managers lie on a continual basis to employees. They promise the world before a project is about start and when the project is successfully delivered, they conveniently forget all the reassurances made earlier. They are self-serving assh*les who'd rather satisfy their own managers than their employees. Managers routinely make ass saving decisions rather than what's right for the project or the company. Employees usually suffer the consequences.
Third, promotions are based on a rotation system although it is clearly stated that the company is a meritocracy. It is a socialistic meritocracy not an absolute meritocracy. As a result you'd have high performers routinely passed over for higher grade promotions in favor of lower grade promotions for someone else within a rank group. This unwritten policy is very shortsighted and ends up sucking talent away from groups.

review_title: Great place to work but not if you care about career advancement and career growth.

review_title: Just another face in the croud
job_title: Graduate Intern Technical in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Intel is a very large company with quite a large number of projects going on simultaneously. There are quite a few areas available within the corporation, so a person does not need to feel like they need to look outside the company to find a new area to work. The company also has extensive classroom courses available for further developing skills. Intel has a strong influence on the local area, and has a lot of people willing to donate time and money for local community service projects. They seem to want to take care of their employees, with on-site gyms, and a number of cafeterias.
cons: The biggest problem is also stemming from the large number of employees. Its very easy to get lost in the shuffle. The Jones Farm campus looks like a farm of cubicles, as far as the eye can see. There is very little that makes a lower level engineer stand out. For the most part, I felt like I was a name-less face-less person with regard to the corporation. I had no interaction with any management beyond my personal supervisor. I did not feel like I made much of a difference in the corporation during my time there. Any number of other name-less face-less automatons employed there could have done my job. I also felt that I was kept in the dark about what I was working on. I had a very narrow idea of what I was working on, but had no idea where it fit in, in the grand scheme of the company.

pros: Many different roles within the company, many different customers of different sizes and strategic significance, Intel is an influential company which opens doors, strong exposure to big business, freedom to travel as needed, exciting new technologies.
cons: Being a relatively flat organisation it is hard to get positional promotions. Intel is a true manufacturing company and as such many of its internal practices are very mechanical, including things like the annual pay review. In Europe it seems that Intel pays less for the same positions in other companies.

job_title: Grad Intern Technical in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I enjoyed the corporate culture. During my time there, I did not experience any bureaucracy or unreasonable policies. I had all the tools I needed and a supportive team to help with issues.
cons: Some people can't handle the cube farm, but I had no problems with it. Projects in emerging markets don't always last long if not initially successful and aren't always approached from the best perspective or with the right expertise.

pros: Lots of flexibility, openness to new ideas - even a culture that at least encourages new ideas. Resources to implement globally. I sometimes felt like I had the best job in the world.
cons: Some lazy people - but what do you expect. A lot of meetings - many unnecessary. I quit, but I had friends who were layed off earlier - and it was pretty arbitrary.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The pay is pretty good, There is a prestige factor (your friends and family have heard of Intel and know what they do).
cons: It can be intense, Management is very focus on what is wrong and spends 10 minutes every 2 years reviewing what we did right. The hours are long and require frequent off shift work.

job_title: Undergraduate Intern Technical in DuPont, WA
pros: Fun work environment. The mangement was very accisible for interns.  There was a lot of options to meet with different people accross the company to find out where your interest were.
cons: Lack of ownership of projects.  The company is no longer growing like they use too.  Limited ability for career advancement.  Lack of dedication to road maps.

pros:
o Very good base compensation.
o Very good basic benefit package.
o Excellent bonus program.
o Company legitimately tries to be ethical.
o Pockets of true engineering brilliance and passion.  There are true technical rock stars here - engineers who have shaped entire industries.
o Deep understanding of hardware design and production.
o Company understands it needs to diversify for growth, and it is doing all the right things there.  
o Intel values education highly.  They will subsidize your education.
o Exposure to a wide array of interesting technology.
o Product focused teams tend to be well run and well managed.
cons:
o Technology focused teams tend to be poorly badly managed.
o Low stock option/rsu's.
o Depressing, grey, "cube farm" mentality.   The fix is to push everyone into significantly smaller, but significantly more colorful cubes.
o Huge, mega-projects, involving 100's-1000's developers spanning multiple geographies.
o While Intel understands how important software is to their business, there is very little actual understanding of how to develop software.  
o Director level management (and up) are, more often than not - either corrupt, self-serving, or incompetent.  
o Armies of people appearing to be frantically busy, but actually developing/doing very little.  It is the appearance of progress which is valued.
o Like any large organization, there is a rather huge bureaucracy fueling it.
o Lots of meetings, lots of anonymous people demanding things from you, lots egos telling you how you must do something.
o Ship dates are routinely set from above.  Engineering estimates rarely used.
o Almost all attempts Intel has made to diversify beyond its core desktop CPU business, have failed on a massive scale (e.g., Larabee).  These project failures impact peoples' lives on a large scale.
o Questionable upper management decision making.  Recent acquisitions, such as Mcafee, are a case in point.
o Matrixed organizations with no one at the helm.
o Competitive, not a teamwork, oriented environment.  In general, you have to push to get someone to help you.

pros: Good place to work with a lot of other smart people. Management was good and does fun stuff to get people to network.
cons: My wages was cut alot and I mean alot (almost 10) when they consolidated the group.  Did not have any benefits when I was getting paid well also. I heard how valuable I was to the group but they still did not offer me anything else.

review_title: Excellent pay and benefits. Company treats employees very well indeed.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redmond, WA
pros: Fantastic pay, flexible time off, smart and passionate people. Opportunity to live anywhere and work remotely for some employees.
cons: Dispersed workforce can impact team dynamics - many people prefer face-to-face interactions with co-workers, but at Intel most interactions are over email/IM or by phone.

pros:
Sabbaticals... Every seven years you are eligible for 8 week paid leave on top of vacation.  If your manager is nice, you may be able to combine it with your vacation time for a 12 week span.

Pay/bonus... When the company is doing well, you will get a nice bonus.

Free drinks/fruit for blue badge employees....

Quarterlies/team building ... I've been on some fun team building events which I wouldn't have done outside of work.

Some departments offer challenging work.  You may learn alot depending on who you work with.
There are some very gifted engineers that I worked with.

Telecommuting - I worked from home when I had personal business to take care of.  You can just send an email saying you are working from home when you need to.
cons:
Its not a 9-5 job.  You are expected to work long hours during project milestones.  That's the double edge sword with telecommuting, since you're always connected.   Also, they will buy you free dinner to work late at the office.  That's cheaper then paying you overtime.  As a salaried employee though, I didn't get overtime anyway. 

Watch out for the buddy network.  There are alliances which are built up and can cause you problems if you are not well liked by a powerful manager.

Focal process.  This is based on 'perceived' contributions... like a popularity contest.  As you rise up the ranks, you need to boast how great you are and get involved with a lot of things (even if you don't really know what you are doing) to show how much influence you have on the project.

Management is not always honest to regular employees.  They offer alot of lip service when you voice a concern.  They have their own agenda, which may not be the best for their employees.

review_title: Performance is based of manager and not on performance
pros: Workspace, pay, benefits, sabbatical, bonuses, truly diversified in acceptance of lifestyle
cons: Politics, favoritism, ignorant management, review system,

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
If you search out the projects you may get to work on some interesting software technologies, unfortunately none ever see light of day (i.e. customer use).
In general, the pay is above average, 
For those employees who contribute nothing to company income or morale, the pay is extremely generous
cons: Innovation is frowned upon. I have seen incredibly poorly designed and written code praised just because done by senior developer, and obstinate hurdles put in the way of trying to fix it. There is a nonsense competition to appear to be productive.

pros: Looks great on the resume.  Lots of opportunities (if you are willing to move to the right location).  Pay and compensation is fair over the long term.  Lots of smart people.
cons: Depending on your group, you can get a new manager every year.  There are pretty big re-orgs and pendulum swings every few years.  Hire hire hire, freeze freeze freeze.  Big on phone meetings.  You can spend your whole day i them.  If you don't want this, ask who you'll be working with.   IT is very very siloed.

review_title: Great benefits, but you have to have very thick skin, skilled at bullying, and 12 hour work day habit to REALLY succeed.
pros: They take care of the employees, and are always looking to improve.  A LOT of cool stuff going on inside, and there is always something new to learn.  Hands down, some of the smartest people I have ever worked with.
cons:
The further up in pay grade you go, the more they demand of you to be a "thought leader" or "influencer."  That's double-speak for bully.  If you can learn to yell and scream at peers and colleagues in one breath to get your point accepted with a power point, then act like nothing happened the next minute, you will go very far.  Doesn't matter if you are right or wrong, just matters if you can torture the data enough to confess agreement with your point.

The people I have seen who do well (i.e. get promoted quickly and rewarded handsomely) at Intel do one of three things:
1. Invent the next iPhone.
2. Succeed at solving very complex, intricate problems, saving the company (literally) millions.
3. Use every moment at work to promote VISIBILITY for themselves, whether it is useful/needed or not.  

 They struggle mightily  with customer orientation and sometimes just don't understand why their ideas are not what others really want or need.  They do this basically because they are on a continual death march to not be considered a "commodity."  They fear that once the point of "it's just a processor" is reached, their empire will crumble.

And one more thing... as far as "career opportunities", yes, total agreement with others that their are many opportunities, HOWEVER the physical location of where you are at is directly related to said "number" of opportunity.  If you work at a plant that is outside of Hillsboro, Santa Clara, (maybe) Folsom, your "opportunity" starts to fall off VERY quickly.  So, choose your site carefully if you decide to join Intel.

pros:
Intel provides finance employees with the opportunity to rotate through various functions (capital, strategy, reporting, cost….) on an 18 to 24 moth cycle.  It's a great place to learn your craft.  Spend some time there and you can go work anywhere.

Plenty of opportunities to relocate as well, including opportunities to go ex-pat.
cons: Compensation is adequate…that's all.  A big part of T-comp is, or at least was, tied to share price which has remained stagnant for years and there's little that the typical employee can do about it.

pros: Lot's of job security, great benefits (life insurance, 401k, stock purchase program), and a lot of opportunities to do different things all within Intel, really smart people.
cons: Lots of red tape to get anything done, lots of 'good ole boys' relationships that can limit your growth, Intel tends to ignore work experience outside of Intel (once you're hired), low-to-mid range salary wise.

review_title: A quicksand of tradition and stability...
pros:
Benefits
Free peaches during the fall
Work-life balance
Global community
cons:
Over two years working in one of Intel's product strategy units [not engineering and I think that's important to discern], I met some awesome people but overall, I found little challenge, inspiration, or vision in the company and its culture. I often felt like the company as a whole was on auto-drive, sticking to management styles, roadmaps, lifestyles that were familiar and comfortable to them, rather than taking risks and seeking true, sustainable positive changes. I witnessed an idea rejected because it wasn't on a years-old roadmap and thus deemed impossible to execute; Apple came out with devices that implemented the idea 6 months later. I sat in many meetings where the audience typed furiously on their laptops or snored loudly over the conference call during the presentation, giving 0 cares, or they pigeon-holed on a completely unrelated topic that delayed crucial decision-making. Everything at Intel felt like it moved slowly, bogged down by tradition and its resulting band-aid fixes/decisions.

I also encountered serious issue with the company's management selection scheme. Managers seemed to be chosen based on how long they've been at Intel or what's on their outdated resume, rather than their demonstrated merits and character. When respected colleagues approached my manager requesting to change projects due to consistent sexist and demeaning comments made by the project manager, they were immediately told to quit whining or start looking for new jobs. When I approached my manager with concern that I felt unchallenged, was not experiencing growth, and reaching my potential, he told me that I shouldn't worry since learning the organization chart and how the different business units interacted with each other was still a major achievement.... UH, NO.... not after I've been there for about 2 years and I regularly expressed to him my goal to build my technical expertise.

In summary, based on my experience, Intel has some great people but if you're looking for serious growth and inspiration as a non-engineering designer, this is not the place you will find it.

job_title: Mechanical Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits and compensation, and depending on what business unit you work in, lots of freedom and autonomy.
cons: As an ME, your are often treated as a second class citizen, e.g. not much in the way of career path programs, little appreciation from upper management. The company is still very much an older generation mindset place to work, as much as they say differently.  If you want hip, forward thinking work practices, e.g. google, look elsewhere.

pros: Sports and other activity tickets for free, cash awards and bonuses. Flexible work schedule with short sabbatical every 4 years and long sabbatical every 7 years. Excellent work/life balance
cons: Difficult to advance, a lot of lifers that makes it difficult to break into culture. Can have long hours and have to work weekends with no adjustment in schedule. Difficult to shut off

job_title: Mechanical Design Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Great benefits and compensation, and depending on what business unit you work in, lots of freedom and autonomy.
cons: As an ME, your are often treated as a second class citizen, e.g. not much in the way of career path programs, little appreciation from upper management. The company is still very much an older generation mindset place to work, as much as they say differently.  If you want hip, forward thinking work practices, e.g. google, look elsewhere.

pros: Sports and other activity tickets for free, cash awards and bonuses. Flexible work schedule with short sabbatical every 4 years and long sabbatical every 7 years. Excellent work/life balance
cons: Difficult to advance, a lot of lifers that makes it difficult to break into culture. Can have long hours and have to work weekends with no adjustment in schedule. Difficult to shut off

pros: Great benefits, great promotion opportunities, lost of opportunities to grow your skill sets. CEO has great vision for the company, and is determined to not miss the IOT trend as we did in mobile. Meritocracy is great for those who work hard, and thrive in that sort of environment.
cons: Very engineering-minded company, and that approach is applied to what seems like every layer of the business. Seems to be an underlying resistance to evolve in some areas of the business, particularly on the software side which seems to be treated as a cost center to the hardware business.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Being able to see what CPU technology is coming in the future is pretty neat.
cons:
Most people that I've run in to at Intel doing Software Engineering really aren't Software Engineers and don't really know anything about proper software design principles. They throw a lot of people who are really Hardware Engineers into software positions, even software architecture positions, and the result is poorly-designed software with poor quality. The focus is more on getting things out the door to meet a deadline rather than quality.

There's also a strange reverence for the people who started Intel more than 40 years ago and trying to do things like they did back then. The problem is that it isn't 40 years ago and Intel should focus on the present and the future rather than people from 40 years ago and how they would do things.

If you are a Software Engineer looking to advance your career at Intel, don't. Software Engineers aren't valued there and you'll be frustrated by the lack of rigor in their software processes.

job_title: Senior Manager in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Lots of Intel lifers.  A high percentage of people love what they do and have been there for 20, 30 years.  It's more the norm than exception.  That is a good thing I suppose.
cons: Lots of Intel lifers.  New hires will find it extremely difficult to fit in.  Lifers tend to be exclusive and not ready for change.  It makes it very difficult to bring in fresh ideas and work in a collaborative way.

review_title: Work life balance depends upon your direct report.
job_title: Architect/Project Lead/Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: The benefits package is very difficult to match.  With a decent direct management chain it is a great company to work for.  Managers are given many liberties that allow them to make it a great place to work, if they choose to do so, they can allow for great work/life balance and the freedom to innovate and create within the realm of job scope.
cons:
Under some managers, resources were limited, scope fixed, deadlines dictated, overtime mandated, and there was very little by way of creative and innovative freedom.  

Intel's annual focal process demands a full bell curve making it such that not everyone can be declared successful, even if all were.  Therefore it is common practice for managers to hire and keep a 'fall guy' around just so that they can meet statistical expectations.  Absolute preference is given to the minority classes when it comes to hiring practices, refferal bonuses, and promotions. 

After loosing a few key employees, my last manager started playing games with the focal process in order to retain employees he would dumb down job titles, suddenly you were a "Software Engineer" when previously you were a "Senior Software Engineer" and writing a minimal 1 page focal review for you, allowing for very little input, and minimizing statements of accomplishments.  This made it more difficult for us to transfer within the company, he knew that other internal managers would consider these reviews when you submitted yourself for a new job so the more worthless he made you appear the less likely you were to be able to move on.  When confronted on the topic, he assured me that all of Intel was now doing it this way now to save time because it was really just a way to facilitate a conversation of expectations between manager and employee.  I did some checking around with friends elsewhere in the company and found this to be an absolute lie.  Any and all attempts to raise these and other issues up the management chain just resulted in direct retribution from my manager, who managed to make my life even more miserable.  

I once submitted an 'anonymous' ethical complaint about the very questionable practices of a colleague within the company, within 24 hours I personally heard from that individual who was herself investigating the complaint.  I learned the hard way that NOTHING is anonymous within this company and every complaint counts against you regardless of how valid it may be.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: Good benefits, sabbatical.. typical corporate culture... It's a good role for starting up career but not sustainable as you get burnt out...
cons:
Good old buddy system.. politics in AZFSM management... promo's given to buddies...
many of the L1/L2 managers dont even have simple BS degree and proper experience, where they make decision in highly technical environment and pretending that they know... really??

review_title: The pay and benefits Make it Worthwhile
pros:
-Great pay, especially once you take into account shift differential and OT.
-Benefits and discounts on products
cons:
-It's a huge corporation, at the ned of the day you're still a number.
-HR makes it sound like they are there to help you but I never received the needed help from managers or HR.

review_title: Was awesome at first, but is getting worst
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I worked with excellent managers and team mates.  Pay is okay, health insurance is awesome and dental is free.
cons:
Reduction in benefits over the years 6% is now 5%
Bonuses are a lot less, but paid in quarters now.  Paul Otellini was generous towards the employees 
RSU's are less due to the stock price going up
Layoffs are occurring more frequently during BK's tenure and it sucks
Spending 300 million on diversity hiring, but yet we are laying off 11% of the workforce.

review_title: Great company but challenging times ahead.
pros: Think of Intel of a collection of fiefdoms battling for fun and profit.  If you get into the right fiefdom, then you have a rewarding experience and a great chance to learn new things that you never would have before.  In my 20 years at Intel, I have been grateful for the opportunity to do many interesting things.  Especially my last four years, has been an amazing experience with a great team - Open Source Technology Center.
cons:
Because it is a collection of fiefdoms, your experience in various places might be mixed.  If you work in software or a product team, it can be very stressful.  Also things change rapidly, you'll be working on something and then off after 8 months.  Everything indicates that this will continue.

With the recent actions, there is an incredible amount of stress as people adjust to the new operating parameters.  Right now it is unknown what is a good employee and there are some who have decided to leave than to deal with an unknown system. It would be wise to wait till things have settled down and things are more clear on how compensation is going to work.

Intel is still a good place to work, but work conditions are very tough right now and it could be alleviated by hiring more people, but that can't happen till clear expectations on compensation and what it means to be successful is more clear.

review_title: Big company that will not really own up to its promises to individuals
pros: Good pay, probably the best in Oregon.  Benefits are great.  The work is challenging.  If you have a good manager, your life will be good.  If you are under a good management chain, then your work may pay off and actually contribute to real products and you may have opportunities.
cons: There are many poor managers at Intel.  It's a fact.  People who seem assertive get promoted to management, but these are not necessarily good people-managers.  I would say, in general, Intel does not discriminate in this regard.  Personality match is not much of a consideration regarding decisions at Intel.  Senior management at Intel is often full of hubris, but lacking in judgement.  Additionally, they may listen to the wrong people and bad decisions that affect your life will issue forth and you'll feel like a little boat in a giant ocean with big, big waves.  As you probably find in most places, people are often interested in making their mark (notoriety) instead of doing the right thing and sometimes as bad as just wanting to hear their voice talk over others in meetings.  Sad to say it is true.  If you join Intel, stay with good people and when you see genuinely good opportunities, take them.  But be aware that times can get dark and you'll wonder if your career is in jeopardy for various reasons:  economy, poor management, and getting trampled on by people just looking out for themselves.

review_title: Good work, too difficult to career advance
job_title: Senior Security Researcher in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
It is a very good as rewarding job.
Intel culture is nice.
Good place to work.
cons:
In Mexico, the politics is always a step down over the culture.
As always there is too much work to do, and little time to get it done, however, management understands it so, it doesn't mean work more or past hours.

pros: Variety of roles and countries to work in.  Strong culture which tries to respect all diversities.  Established company that will not go out of business.
cons: Erratic senior management with ever changing and chaotic strategy.  Re-structuring every few months causes discontent and fear.  Benefits package has eroded over the years and behind others despite assurance of market rates.

pros: Good projects that challenge you technically
cons:
Extremely poor management. Most of the managers in STTD are technically inept. People have won Achievement awards for technology that doesnt even work, hundreds of milions of dollars have been spent on it.
           One manager in particular is extremely loud and obnoxious and has the worst employee retention rate. If you are buddies with the senior management then you are ok. I have seen employees that actually invented and implemented some really good technology being laid off because a few managers target them in the yearly review. If you are a new engineer try to avoid this group. Senior managers use your work to gain recognition and you dont get much in return.

pros: Local Teams are very focused and team spirit is very high. Good friendship and cooperation between team members.
cons: Division and corporate level management is bad. Too much focus on short-term quarter to quarter progress and no long term focus. The result is completely missing key market changes and the company keeps playing catch-up game.

review_title: There are groups where creative, innovative approach is appreciated with a blend of reasonable work life balance.
pros:
Easy to switch between business units/products lines based on self interest to experience new design challenges. Company is open for that, managers obviously might not :)
Get to interact with wise people of industry and grasp from their experiences. Good culture. (not in all groups) 
Good work life balance.
cons: Changing culture due to competitive market. Some groups have less focus on excellence rather more on project delivery. Sometimes, good work gets restricted to some and others are considered execution brigade.

review_title: A delusional and old fashioned company
pros:
Flexibility (To be discuss more in depth)
Team activities (To be discuss more in depth as well)
Work space readily available (To be discussed......)
cons:
Flexibility (wait, what?), yes, flexibility is not always a good thing, since some managers expect you to execute a task even late at night (like 3am, 4am?) without OT claim. Much flexibility, so wow. This is sometimes not avoidable, because you are expected to adjust yours, and no one else's timetable to work with US/Bangalore counterparts. Yeah sure you can wake up late the next day, but with everyone else working in the morning, expect to get sounding/judging from the others.

Team activities, due to the overall culture in Intel (in my ex team in particular), team activities are usually forced or down right a waste of time. Watching movie (everyone watching different movie if I might add) in the cinema? How is that going to help with the team's morale? Outdoor activities are not any better, with managers not joining to managers joining, but not taking initiatives to lead the activities. You get the picture.

Workspace is a joke. Newcomers and only newcomers will be pushed to Kulim no matter what. It's "part of their expansion program", or so they claimed. Call me stupid, but aren't newcomers need more guidance than old timers? Or is it more convenient for the old timers to not make a change?

To sum it all up, there are much better working cultures out there with much better people and much better environment. Mediocre pay, mediocre benefits and mediocre facilities. The only thing Intel has, is its fame from decades ago being the dominated brand that we all came across while growing up, that's what it is, a company stuck in the past.


P.S. Google about Intel and see what came up, and with that you can basically tell what kind of culture you will be having to be working in Intel. Decision is yours to make.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Good work/life balance if you work for the right manager.  Opportunity for advancement and a long career if you want it.  The company seems to care about their impact, conflict free supply chain, and others.  They strongly encourage employees to give time to the community and back it with $ donations to the cause.
cons: They very much a hardware company and don't understand software development in most groups.  Every project I've ever been on has been understaffed and we're pushed to do more in less time.

pros: Never been paid so much to do so little in my life.
cons: Intel has laid off thousands of people in the last couple years. By the way laid off means you intend to bring those people back. Not only did Intel fire (layoff) thousands of people there are not rehireable ever. Intel has on a hiring Street and many people that lost their jobs are still unemployed. Talk about adding insult to injury. Just goes to show how out of touch three senior leadership is. They waste millions of $ training new people . Maybe they don't understand what's going on , I mean their pretty busy worrying about security flaws, no 5G ,AMD and so on.

review_title: It is a great job as a whole.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I like that Intel is very environmentally conscious corporation. I also like that everyone in the company is treated equally. The products we distribute affect the world globally. I like the team I work with, and they are very respectful to me.
cons: Working at intel is a lot of hard work. One thing that I think is a con is that part of our compensation is with stock rather than salary.

review_title: Great Company, Great Technology, Great People
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Three reasons I enjoy working at Intel - great technology, great people, great company. This place is filled with bright and energetic people who create really cool stuff. The ideas, innovation, drive and creativity of Intel employees is astounding. It's invigorating to work here. Intel's innovation has literally changed the world. The combination of the company's financial track record, corporate social responsibility and environmental practices are unparalleled. Sure there are things in the work environment that need to be improved and updated. The good news is that senior leaders know this and are working on it thanks to open channels of communication and a very in-touch human resources function.  To sum up my experience of Intel as an employer in one word I'd say: integrity.
cons: A perpetual challenge at this large multinational company with employees in over 60 countries is building and developing relationships with co-workers on virtual teams. Another downside of working at Intel is watching the company miss opportunities that were within its grasp. For instance, because of Intel's position as a component supplier to the PC industry Intel has sometimes failed to benefit from its innovation. As an example, years ago Intel came out with an Intel branded MP3 player - this was years before the debut of iPod players.  Undoubtedly company strategists had the right idea and were ahead of the market, but they pulled back seemingly for fear of alienating downstream partners.  That was painful. On the bright side, the company learns from its mistakes.

review_title: Can a large corporation continue to grow and innovate? You bet!
job_title: Chipset Validation Engineer in Irvine, CA
pros: For a large corporation that has seemingly seen its best days with regard to stock price, Intel Corp. is still a very great company to work for. Employees are well-respected for the most part, and they are encouraged to provide constant feedback to their immediate managers as well as senior management. The work environment is still very egalitarian; everyone gets cubicles, even managers. I can imagine that would not suit some, but for me it's perfect. Work hours are very flexible, and Intel tries to accomodate different employees needs. Finally, there is the pride of working in a company that even now continues to be at the forefront of technology and innovation, and Intel does a great job avoiding the curse of stagnation that has hit other high-tech firms like HP or IBM.
cons: Intel is still a company that is often run top-down. Although individual employee contributions and creativity are recognized, there is still a sense of process and bureaucracy within which every individual contributor has to function. This is also true for the rating and review process, which is necessary but seems somewhat rigid in its evaluation mechanisms. Change is occurring for the most part, but change seems to be slow which I guess is unavoidable in a company this size.

pros:
A good place for getting a work experience as intern. 
Actually, there are a lot opportunities to try different positions during internship. But if you want to get a real responsibility and real career growth, you need to be outstanding person (a genius). Sometimes it's better to get work experience as intern at Intel, and after that to get a real job with real payment, with good strings in your CV.
cons: Although it's a good place for getting experience, internship programs can lengthen up to 4 years in Russia. Not everybody would endure such a long internship for small payment.

review_title: It's a job with great influence and responsibilities, takes a lot of work and patience, but makes me happy in the end.
pros: Intel can sometimes be a huge and slow company, but the amount of thought and vetting they put into their products, and the way their products teams interact, is commendable.  Intel is very demanding, and very detailed, when it comes to getting out the right product, with the right features, and the best cost structure.  Intel is probably more focused on cost now than at any time before, and that's a good thing in this current environment.  You need to come prepared to defend any feature that you want to implement, and with product horizons that are sometimes 5 years out, that can be difficult.  Still, this level of structure has produced some of the best products in the industry.
cons: It's easy to get frustrated sometimes when you see people making poorly informed decisions, and half of my job is to educate and make sure that planners from other teams know at least as much as I do.  The products I plan for often need features to be available in other products, and it can be very disheartening if those features get ZBB'ed due to cost reasons, when the ROI from my perspective is huge, and the other product planners don't feel the same way.  I've seen great opportunities for innovation fritter away because the usefulness of these features was misunderstood.  Even so, it's very rewarding when you can make a business case for a technology, and get it through the justification process.

review_title: Good place to work, but they lose documents.
pros:
Great compenstion package and benefits
Good work environment
Travel opportunities depending on position.
cons:
Frequent layoffs
Documentation on product that is barely one or two years old is frequently lost or difficult to locate even for employees.

pros: Challenging work, opportunity to move around, great peers, and scope for learning. Intel has taken being a great place to work at heart, and have been doing various things to help with improving the morale of the employees. Also, to go with the changing times, we moved from Options to RSUs, giving more value to the employees
cons: The company is too big, so sometimes I feel like a small cog. Also, sometimes the decision making is slow and laborious.

review_title: working with the best people, on the most advanced technology, it is a very exciting place to be.
pros: Intel has tremendous resources and the smartest people I've ever worked with.  It has more focus and discipline than other tech companies I've seen and worked at.  Intel makes sure to give teams the resources they need to get the job done.
cons: Intel has more focus and discipline than other tech companies I've worked at.  While that is great for cranking out great products on time, it is not a laid-back work environment.

review_title: Innovation is not only make hardware faster
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Munich, Bavaria
pros: Make modern system possible, Intel deliver the basic technologie to bring gread ideas to the customer. Working on the basic staff. A lot of interessting thinks happen in the company.
cons: The company runs fast, but nobody knows in which direction. A lot of interestings thinks happen in the company, but do not tell any one about this, he can use it for this own ideas.

pros: Intel has a pretty good work - life balance program, offers reasonable benefits, and there can be a lot of opportunity to move around within the company, if you wish
cons: Intel has a reputation of being slow to get things done, simple decisions require multiple layers of approval, pay is probably below  industry average, despite numerous efforts to convince you it's above average.  Also, bonuses and stock based compensation are strategically awarded/vested every few months to keep people to stick around for that next payout, rather than jump ship sooner.

pros:
1) Places very high premium on ethical behavior. 
2) Work flexibility - ability to work from home and customizable work schedule
3) Opportunity to try different roles through rotations and temporary coverage programs. Lot of options and support programs to advance career.
4) Intel brand is very strong
cons:
1) Depending on role, expect to have early morning or late night meetings on a regular basis due to interactions with sites across multiple time zones
2) Too many meetings - that is seen as a good thing in some cases.....
3) Overlap on charter between multiple groups. You will need to build your turf....

review_title: Don't let the size of it scare you off
pros:
Personally I've been able to weather a number of general economic downturns at Intel by virtue of its size and stability.  What it lacks in dynamism it makes up for with a deep well of resources that can see it through hard times.  Also, because Intel is a big place, you can change jobs every couple of years internally without having to brave the waters of the open market.  If you want to have a long career here, you can.

If you work in an office role vs. a factory role you have wonderful work flexibility.  The ability to work from home on a discretionary basis is literally game-changing for me.  I would hesitate to work anywhere else that did not offer a similar policy.

Sabbatical is a wonderful benefit (8 weeks paid time off every 7 years or 4 weeks paid every 4).
cons:
All of the downsides associated with working at a big company -- the inefficiencies, excess management layers, the diffusion of purpose -- are present at Intel but are common "big company" issues and not special "Intel" issues.  As long as you can tolerate this sort of big organization sclerosis you'll do fine at Intel.

Intel is top-heavy from a management perspective, which limits your options for growth via promotion.  You'll have to be content making lots of lateral moves.

job_title: Quality and Reliability Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: As I mentioned in the title, Intel is a great place to work with a lot of oportunities to growth professionally. Besides the compensation benefits are very good like bonus, stocks, medical insurance, gym, etc
cons: Burocracy is the highlighted con that you will face at Intel. So you must get used to and have some patience when you want to implement a project or idea

review_title: Basically scored low on every metric you use for measuring satisfaction from a career.
pros:
- Onsite gym
- Free coffee and fruit
- parking
- mobile phone and plan
- health insurance
- good cafe
cons:
- no salary/career progression
- long hours
- poor salary considering hours worked
- overly political resulting in the technical and engineering skills suffering
- negative moral among employees due to workload and manager expectations

job_title: Technical Marketing Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Massive amounts of Internet of Things technologies, great benefits, a lot going on. As with any big company Intel has a lot of different products, projects and events happening to tap into. My particular role grants me a lot of freedom and creativity within my team and tremendous opportunities for growth. Someone sitting a few rows down from me may have an opposite experience based on their manager. This review is based on my own satisfaction level which is probably unusually high...I have a great boss and a great time.
cons: There are more than a few "lifers" who dwell in Intel's remote locations and rarely see the light of day. Unfortunately the net effect is that major trends take a long time to percolate to these people. Much of what is happening in the industry passes them by and they don't really have plans to go anywhere anytime soon. Interspersed with lifers there are some very talented and motivated people as well. Once I built my network it was easier to avoid the lifers and get things done by focusing on the talented folks. On the whole, Intel is not great at software. The office designs and layouts are often stuck in the 1985 office-space realm though they are taking steps to refurnish. Different groups have different "lifer quotients."

review_title: Great place to work, great people, and a wealth of knowledge surrounding you.
pros:
I worked in two groups during my seven years at Intel and they were both fantastic. The people were great, the work was challenging, and I felt I was evaluated fairly. It can be a tough place to work as aggressive timelines are set, with high expectations, but my management was always very supportive and did a great job removing road blocks and helping me do my job - always asking if there was anything they could do to help.

I enjoyed the culture of the groups I worked in as well. They enjoyed solving really tough engineering problems, but also liked to joke around and have a good time. My groups both presented very positive work environments and I felt fortunate for that. It made it fun to go to work.

My immediate management was very good as well. No complaints. They let me do my job without interfering and trusted my suggestions and input. Felt like like they actually listened to me. Harder to speak about upper management - I didn't have much direct contact with them.

I felt compensation was very good as well. They have great onsite cafes, a bonus structure, stock opportunities, good salaries...Again - work hard, play hard.

Overall, it's a huge company that works on a lot of different products, so there are a lot of different opportunities for challenging, fun work (Even for Mechanical Engineers - lots of thermal/mechanical problems to solve!)
cons:
You've got to remember that Intel is a huge company... so it will take all the time you want to give it. It's easy to get into the habit of working 10 hour days without thinking much about it as there is always more to get done. The pressure can feel pretty high sometimes as well. There are definitely ebbs and flows. 

As with any large company, the culture can change from group to group, as well as the management style.

pros: Intel is an awesome company that truly takes care of their employees. Everyone working there is super friendly and helpful if you have any questions. They have an open door policy so you can talk to anyone in the company, which I believe helps innovation and keep an upbeat work environment.
cons: Intel is a huge company. Some groups are better than others. I was fortunate to work in an awesome group, but I have seen people in other groups working 60+ hour weeks consistently. It all just depends on what group you are working in.

pros: a talented workforce, a unique culture, and a drive for excellence. there are opportunities to work around the globe. competitive pay and benefits.
cons: sometimes that unique culture can come across as too rigid, too task/result oriented and not focused on the well-being of the people. it's a hard balance. in the manufacturing world, it's 24x7x365 and *somebody* has to cover the work at all times...

job_title: Program Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Fantastic benefits, Intel Code of conduct that employees strive to follow.  Quarterly  team building events. Good working conditions. Challenging problems to solve.
cons: Workforce reductions due to changing markets.  Currently downsizing, laying off 12,000 employees. Every year employees see less employee loyalty.   Need to re-vamp yearly review, very old school and dated.

review_title: Started out great, now struggling to survive
job_title: Senior Facilities Operations LSS/FMS/I&C Technician in Los Lunas, NM
pros: Great benefits and perks.  Pay is excellent but hours can be long.  Company is flush with cash.  Long standing position as leader in the tech industry.
cons: Competition and senior management has not a single clue about how to move forward.  The original fire and brilliance died with Andy Grove.  The ship is now rudder-less.

review_title: Not such a "great place to work" anymore
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Pay and benefits are really among the best.  Co-workers are among the best and brightest.  Lots of parking now
cons: Lack of clear direction where the company is going.  Great mistrust for senior manufacturing management.  Unjust and ill informed headcount reduction tactics, loosing many good people unnecessarily/

review_title: Not such a "great place to work" anymore
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: Pay and benefits are really among the best.  Co-workers are among the best and brightest.  Lots of parking now
cons: Lack of clear direction where the company is going.  Great mistrust for senior manufacturing management.  Unjust and ill informed headcount reduction tactics, loosing many good people unnecessarily/

job_title: Failure Analysis Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Leading edge technology and labs
cons:
Big Intel of old is gone.  Culture is overly focused on political correctness and hyper diversity efforts. Being first to market is a problem, now. Review process is unethical and the Andy Grove management technique of fostering internal conflict as a motivator is also unethical.
Managers openly say they wouldn't recommend Intel to friends.

review_title: Fantastic company as long as you keep your nose clean.
pros: Good salaries, good work ethic for the most part.  There is room to learn a lot and grow professionally, if you take advantage of it.
cons: They have had quite a few lay offs in recent years.  Unfortunately, even the smallest mark on your work record means you are at the top of the lay off list.

review_title: Low or no growth until you're super agressive
job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Portland, OR
pros:
Work with super smart people
Long term roadmaps provide opportunity for growth
cons:
Individual growth can be stifled by a single bad manager.
Managers do not encourage cross group movement, or do so 'on paper' only. 
Every few years management pays lip service to Work Life Balance but usually you're expected to suck it up and fall in line. Evening meetings all the time and no compensatory time off. 
Aggressive schedules, burnt out employees.

pros: Awesome- very relaxed life specially for professionals in the retiring stage of their career. Can join and have a rewarding sign-off. Good work like balance tough for every level of engineers.
cons: Slow and non innovative management which makes sure that it stays way behind the competition where companies likes Nvidia etc who are posting record quarterly growths. If only the management used their resources to their full potential maybe such a behemoth in innovation in silicon industry wouldn't have sunken with the setting sun.

review_title: Smart people, secure employment until recently
job_title: Senior Finance Manager in Santa Clara, CA
pros: You get to work with some of the best people and as a finance professional, you get some of the best career development platform in the valley.
cons: Big company, lots of bureaucracy. It can be hard to stand out and they don't much value experience from outside.

review_title: A tiny cog in a big wheel
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: free beverages, free fruit, wear whatever the heck you want, flex time to work-from-home some days and come in late and leave late, or come in early and leave early, etc...
cons: Raises suck and are infrequent

pros: Opportunity to grow and assume new roles, constant opportunity to learn. Good structure and measurement
cons: Too staid and fixed in their ways - org structure and managers not incented to drive innovation in commercial areas - very weak management despite valiant attempts to reinvent themselves

job_title: Senior Software Development Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: World class organization with open culture in work and personnel practices. Very ethical work place with very clear escalation path for harassment and discrimination.
cons: Like any technology organization, reward is a little skewed to  few top performers. With there is little difference between team members in terms of performance, this can be frustrating some times to both managers and team members.

job_title: Senior Software Engineering Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros:
Some of the best people I've worked with are at this company.
It is large enough that you can find a career that interests you almost anywhere.
cons:
Not a place to go if you want to grow or innovate.  
If you want to occupy a chair for 30 years and then retire, this could by your dream job.
Employees are largely forbidden from using industry standard solutions (even if they are better than homegrown ones).
Working at Intel is now considered a "black mark" on resumes (especially for software people).

pros: A lot of opportunity to grow as a professional and to learn
cons:
Work life balance has room to improve.
Silos.
One Biz Model.
Impatient.
Engineering, in addition to marketing/planning, teams not often enough held accountable when product/offerings "miss the mark".  This can foster creation of various Silos as well as amplify ramifications of "local" optimizations that may not serve best the entirety of the corporate body.

review_title: Good for young career minded individuals
pros:
Intel is a very well paid and easy place to work.  If you want to be successful, you need to be able to put in those extra hours that all American corporate companies expect ( note you probably won't get paid for them).  
The upper management creates a stable environment which has been able to shrug off countless down terms in the markets in recent years. I have seen many people come and go over the years. But they have kept much of the core team intact and improved it. 
They are great benefits. healthcare.  It is the safest company I have ever worked at. The conditions are excellent. there are lots of onsite areas such as gym, clubs, even hair salons, multiple restaurants at each site. 90% of the people who work there are good honest, hardworking and focused people. In every company, there are a few bad eggs. The work is challenging but fun if you are prepared to work hard and possibly willing to travel you will be OK.  For me I enjoyed 25 years, I traveled and lived in foreign countries, was able to take my family with me on occasion. You need to make a choice if corporate America is for you.
cons:
If you are stuck working with an immediate superior who is abusive of his power or just weak minded they will float and could be in the position for a number of years.  I have found that middle management is reluctant to take action against a BAD boss, particularly in the EU regions. 
That situation in itself has caused more misery for not only me but many, many of my colleagues over the years.  
They tried management feedback and when bad scores came back. the group leader called in HR and told us we just didn't understand the questions! This lead to a worse situation particularly for those who spoke out. So, in the end, everyone just gave OK feedback or didn't bother.

job_title: Software Program Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great benefits, higher than industry standard salaries, Work Life Balance is great dependent on the business org and job duties, good  opportunities for skills improvement.
cons: Too much of the "That's not how we do it at Intel" mentality.  Outside experience is not valued. Roadmaps and Business Groups are constantly changing, which results in the company slow to react and execute.

review_title: Senior system engineer at Intel IT
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Smart outstanding peers. Good benefits, avg salary, sabaticals, company wants you to grow your career.  Take advantage of advanced degree reimbursement program and stock participation program.  Don't stay in the same job for more then 4 years.
cons: Lots of red tape, low morale due to constant layoffs, management afraid to take risks, stale technical leadership. Stock hasn't moved much in past 15 years.

review_title: A semi-old tech company with great culture, clear vision, and lots potential
pros:
- very inclusive and open office culture; you are free to debate with a senior exec.
- paid well and far better than most non-tech(but not as good as the top NEW tech companies)
- very organized with established processes and desires to perfection in operations
cons:
- not as shiny as NEW tech companies (e.g., FAANG); slower growth, less corp perks...etc
- sometimes too slow or too organized for my liking

review_title: Work for Intel for a few years, then go get a real career at a good company.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros:
The pay is decent.

There are some very challenging problems to be solved. Working on projects to solve them can provide very valuable experience.

The in-house training is good.
cons:
Middle management became overstretched and (in the organization that I left) was not able to devote enough time to resolve issues with respect to project resources and staffing.

The current move to reduce the work force through attrition makes job security non-existent. There is an rule that 10% of the people in each department get a negative performance review each year. Since Intel has started reducing its workforce, these negative reviews are getting handed out arbitrarily.

Many project teams are dispersed with team members in India, Asia and the Americas, which leads to meetings during family hours.

The company does not provide adequate tools to do a proper job. The compressed cubicles are not large enough to work effectively in. When I left Intel in 2007, I had a 4-year old laptop, a 10 MBit network connection. It took about 15 minutes each day to boot it up and connect to Intel's network.

review_title: Do not invest in Intel if you work for the company.
pros: Very good reputation, and well respected by those outside the company.  Having a few years experience at Intel helps a resume.  Intel does have excellent in-house training: management training, time management, planning, etc. Intel does encourage challenging yourself and moving into different professions; and offers educational reimbursement for employees.
cons: Very bureaucratic, advancements are political and not done fairly across the board as preached. The same management team that oversaw the decline of Intel's stock price and image in the early 2000's are STILL in place. If I had done as poorly as those execs in my time at Intel, I would have been fired following the annual review (Focal) years ago.  Instead, those guys get promoted up!

review_title: Intel *could* be a great place to work, given the right circumstances and depending on your point of view.
pros:
Intel Corp. is a well known global company. Just mentioning that you work for Intel will automatically earn you respect. Intel's large capital reserves as well as duration in the market gives a good feeling of stability. Quarterly updates from senior management will help you spot trends in sales of products and help give you an idea about where the company is headed.

Total Compensation is very competitive. Intel offers great health benefits with lots of alternatives to choose from.  401k contributions are not matched, but Intel will contribute a certain percentage of your salary to your 401k regardless of your contributions.  Bonuses come regularly. The amount will vary depending on profitability of the company, but you can almost count on them.
cons:
Everyone has a cubicle. Thinks makes your working environment extremely susceptible to noise and other distractions.  The cubes are small (6ft x 8ft for most people) compounding the interruption possibilities. 

Base Pay (what most people look at in compensation) is lower than a lot of other companies out there. If you don't have an "on top of it" manager, you and your entire team will get overlooked for significant raises. 

Some of the best benefits for working for Intel are also part of its downside. Large companies don't always respond well to changes in the marketplace. Besides that, its hard to find a parking spot when your competing with a few thousand other people.

review_title: Great place to work, but be prepared for low- to mid- industry average pay.
pros: I on my fourth year here at Intel and I am pleasantly surprised with the company.  In general, the corporate culture follows the Intel Values of Customer Orientation, Discipline, Quality, Risk Taking, Great Place to Work, and Results Orientation.  Although not stated blatantly during meetings or interactions with fellow employees, most people I have encountered espouse these traits.  Very data driven--people encourage you to express your professional opinions and expect you to back it up with data.  It is very exciting to be working on technologies two to five years out before they hit the store shelves.  It is also very satisfying to know that Intel highly encourages community involvement whether we participate in group sponsored activities, or spend our own free time volunteering in the community--and the company will match our hours with grants.  Intel donated $2000 last year for one of our community projects.  Overall, Intel employees volunteered over 1M hours last year and will more than likely exceed that tally for 2009.
cons: We are in a mature industry, so opportunities for growth can be limited.  Plenty to learn though to keep things interesting.  Management encourages development plans, but the current economy has reduced discretionary spending for education.  This more than likely will improve in 2010-2011--luck willing!  Intel is cheap--coach class, limited  offsite quarterly budgets, and below average pay scales.  Our stock price is much lower than when we entered, so most of our options are under water.  It's a world wide company and people will work around the clock.  It's up the individual employee to determine whether or not to put in the extra hours.

review_title: Intel from a Professional Technicians Perspective
pros: Overall the benefits of health care, vacation and paid time off were very good. Their 401K was excellent for giving freedom to invest in several options.
cons: Intel fails to look at the person as a total package and in many ways refuses to understand how can a person strengthen an organization. My interview process was 2 telephone calls of 20 minutes and I was made a job offer. The Intel plant I worked in was 15 miles from my house. I was told that my experience was above working on the production floor as a manufacturing technician and offered a position of a engineering technician. In my 2.5 years at Intel I neve sat down with a manager and went over my resume, my career goals or how I could advance my career. There was no guidence, no action plan and overall communications was poor. Intel takes a very responsible attitude towards safety but then leadership fails which was evident by a recent issue where employees were given a test on Lock-Out Tag-Out and the failure rate was well above 50%. The belief at Intel is that a computer is all people need for training and then if mistakes are made it is not the companies fault.

review_title: Good place to work, but many improvements needed to make it great
job_title: Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. Worldwide brand recognition. Almost everyone has heard of Intel and what we do.
2. Some awesome benefits, including an 8 week paid sabbatical after every 7 years and profit sharing that does not require 401k participation. Free fruits/drinks.
3. Great work/life balance. Management is supportive of flexible working hours and telecommuting.
4. Process and technology leadership. Our CPUs are the best, bar none.
5. Tremendous company and employee involvement in the communities that it serves.
cons:
1. Bonus structure needs to be changed for grade 6 and lower employees. Need to emphasize more of an individual's performance rather than a fixed bonus target that is based on a small percentage of an employee's salary.
2. Stagnant stock price. It's such a big issue that even management is trying to address it.
3. Too many reorganizations within the company. Reorganizations seems to happen every year and upper management always claims that it improves some inefficiencies. Better planning and leadership should have been exercised in the first place!
4. Too much bureaucracy and politics and too many meetings. Focus on getting the task done at hand with better cooperation and teamwork among groups, rather than focusing on specific processes and passing the political football.
5. Too many offices in the suburbs and not enough in the bigger cities (e.g. SF, NYC) that is needed to attract a wider talent pool.

review_title: Corporate behemoth, but a surprisingly good place to work
pros: Intel is huge, but don't let that fool you.  The technical people at Intel are generally highly driven and committed to making great technological advancements, and creating products that people really want.  There's really no better place to work if you want to do hard core CPU or chipset architecture, or if you're into process engineering.  As a software engineer there are many interesting projects as well, from working Windows, Linux and Mac internals (not just drivers!) to whole operating systems like MeeGo.  Career advancement is straightfoward: generally if you work hard and garner influence you can achieve a principal engineer position after awhile.  And the pay is very good compared with other companies.
cons: It has the downsides of most big companies: crappy IT infrastructure (e.g. proxied internet access; this would be comical if it weren't so painful) and laptops (you absolutely need a top of the line CPU and SSD to run all the crapware IT installs and still get work done), fluffy corporate communications and poor information sharing between groups.  The work environment is a bit soulless as well; drab cubes as far as the eye can see.  Finally, it can be quite competitive at review time; Intel very much subscribes to the Jack Welch school of management & reviews.  The top performers get the vast majority of the raise budget, and poor performers are culled fairly aggressively.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but needs to lighten up a bit!
pros:
Attracts top performers, hard workers, bright minds
Industry-leading technology and practices
Pay and benefits
cons: This place needs to lighten up a bit - gray cubes, gray environment, gray attitudes ... seriously needs some color. If you are a good technical performer, they promote you .... that's not bad, except that they make you a manager. Now, that's not making the most of what you're good at, is it? As a result, high risk of bad managers (although they may be good technologists/ engineers).

review_title: It tends to be stressful but still room for reasonable work-life balance. Sebbatical vacation is a nice perk too
pros: You will be always moving toward the cutting edge technology or applying those to the exising field, hence there is pretty good chance to learn new things. It is good to make new thing happen, even though it is not rare to get the project canceld in the even later phase. Also Sabbatical time-off is a good to compensate the years of continuous service, and refresh yourself. There are many opportunities that the employee can directly ask to and listen from the senior management, even though the senior managements are generally very skillful to avoid being trapped in hot topics.
cons: As a large company, there are cases where it is more important to have a good relationship/communication with your manager than actually getting the job done, as there are quite some blind spots here and there. Company is very much profitable but not growing fast hence you should not expect better chances for promotion here. Also continuous restructuring makes the employee quite stressful as it is usually out of the employee's reach and yet makes huge impact.

review_title: Good place to start, but don't overstay your welcome
pros:
The good:

- Good name on your resume - You can't beat the name recognition of Intel.

- Very astute Finance Organization - Lots of really bright folks in Finance. Stacy Smith is a good CFO who is not afraid to field tough questions.  

- Tons of high impact work for an entry level employee - Even though I was a fresh college grad, I got to work on a lot of very high importance projects.

- Intellectually challenging and competitive work place - I have worked with some of the smartest people in the world and it was truly an honor.  Lots of incredibly bright folks at Intel.

- Lots of smart folks who are very driven - Intel has a very egalitarian "grinder" mindset.  Lots of folks work very hard for the company.
cons:
The bad:

- Finance HR is awful - I was a promising employee (successful on focal) and I was promised a transfer to another division, then HR and my manager rescinded on the deal.  HR sided with him and the Corporate Finance group was in the dark about the whole thing.  I am no longer working at Intel after that whole fiasco.  

- Extremely lousy middle managers - My boss in Finance was responsible for 12 direct reports and he wouldn't touch a spreadsheet or make himself available at all.  When I tried to talk with  him about business real issues he brushed me off.  Needless to say, he promptly got promoted to a controller level position.

- Corporate mediocrity - Complacency breeds mediocrity.  Intel is a mature company so most of the employees are well paid and lazy.  They do not care about tackling new markets or expanding product offerings... it's all about collecting a paycheck and milking the x86 cash cow.

- Bad Leadership - Since Otellini took over, the stock has been down 30%.  They consistently make bad investments  (WiMax, XScale) and nobody seems to bat an eye.  Intel has an unassailable competitive position but their overall performance has been stagnant.

review_title: A challenging experience with plenty of growth potential and security
job_title: Validation Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Flexible hours, challenging environment, high standards for performance, great benefits, management (usually) pays attention to employee needs, pride of working for an industry leader and innovator.
cons: Bureaucracy can bog down decision-making at the top and middle-levels of management. Even though this has improved compared to several years ago, this is still a problem. Plus the pressure-cooker environment may not suit everyone.

review_title: A typical big corporation at the end of its dominance
pros: Huge cash flows, total job secuirty for high level tech personnel, good pay (a very comprehensive bonus system), time off flexibility
cons:
ineffective upper management with aptly demoinstrated inability to break out into new markets; middle management focused entirely on own career growth; widely spread nepotism; lack of growth opportunities for technical workers; propaganda like communication style between upper management and the rank-and-file

higly recommned reading "Losing Faith: How the (Andy) Grove Survivors Led the Decline of Intel's Corporate Culture" for a great inside look at the company culture

review_title: great place to work for 1 to 3rd yeard of career
pros: Intel is a well managed company. The nature of job is highly technical and detail oriented. Employyees are given basic trainings before expecting to be productive.
cons: The nature of job is highly technical, but at the same time compartimized. Employee is expected to develop strengh in the field of work assignment, but there is rare visibility into adjacent areas or cross functional areas.

review_title: Great Place to work if you are with the right team
job_title: Senior Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
1. Big Company perks---pay gets better as you go higher up in the ranks, good benefits
2. Decent Hours
3. Good smart People
4. It's a "Great Place to Work" in terms of employee group activities, free stuff, company events etc
cons:
1. Big Company issues, hierarchical
2. Slow if you are looking for growth
3. yearly increments in salary for a Successful rating averages 5%, which is low
4. Political 
5. Manager can make or break your career, always try to be in a group where the manager believes in career growth else you will stagnate

review_title: Good place to learn. Growth is dependent upon your team.Lots of opportunity across various product lines.
job_title: Component Design Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
-Cutting edge technology
-Best in industry in CPU design
-Top class products with Core,Xeon and Xeon Phi.
-Stability
-Easy to move across teams
-Some really smart folks, especially in Arch, RTL and Circuits
-New CEO is extremely bold, willing to make radical changes to transform the corporation into SoC design and try out new areas and ventures
-Good place for new folks to learn as much as they can
- Well poised to gain mobile traction in the upcoming years
-Open environment, good work-life balance
cons:
-Too big, sometimes you feel like a dot in a painting
-Risk-taking, some groups are slightly averse to this idea, but the new CEO seems better than predecessor at this.
-Lot of old folks, in dire need of some young blood in the company especially in Santa Clara
-Growth opportunities might be limited if you are in a team with too many old-timers
-Pay is not great in Santa Clara, if you start comparing Intel to Apple, sometimes causing the company to struggle to retain top talent but on par with Nvidia and better than Qualcomm
-Politics is prevalent at 2nd level managers and above
-Afraid to fire ppl who are crap
-Raises are lower than rest of industry, but good bonus and decent stock options
-Workplace is rather dull. Grey everywhere.

pros: Good corporate citizenship.  Great company culture.  Lots of different projects going on and easy to move horizontally within your skillset.
cons: Not so easy to move to roles outside your core skillset.  Future of the company is a bit uncertain with the reducing demand for the PC and fierce competition in mobile.  Very interesting time to be involved in the fight for market share though.

review_title: Full of possibilities but tied up in bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Staff Design Engineer in Chandler, AZ
pros: Lots of cash. With enlightened management could own the semiconductor space
cons: Not a design company -- run by process engineers. Far too many meeting. Many arrogant career managers with no ability but climbing the ladder. No recognition for the brightest and best so they leave.

pros: They pay competitively at the time of hire. The bonuses are real and they are substantial.
cons:
