pros: Yes. Intel has hard-working and intelligent staffs, who are working on cutting-the-edge technologies. Technically, intel is a giant and has a master role in sever and PC market. Intel has huge legacy in the two major market and good reputation.
cons: Intel is actually losing competitions due to her "big company disease". Management are disengaging people with office politics, spending money on silly things, slowing down innovations. The company has been lost in market focus and slow in response.

job_title: Product Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: large company (obviously), so there are opportunities to move around within the company.  This is encouraged by most managers even though it might cause short term productivity loss.
cons: The way Intel Corporation does their annual ranking and rating does not support the team work the company pontificates.  Individual team members are compared against each other resulting in people needing to keep accomplishments for themselves

pros: Great benefits for employees, including on-site fitness centers, free fruit and drinks, etc.  Great co-workers.
cons: Employee culture has gone downhill over the last 5 years and employees no longer seem to be a priority.   Intel is now scrambling to figure out how to replace the PC business and not miss out again on technology .  CEO has come across as arrogant, especially with the inappropriate layoffs in July 2015.   Employee development is varied - depends on the group and manager.

job_title: EMEA Financial Analyst in Santa Clara, CA
pros: International experience is good but it is so complicated to get since competition is high. Education opportunities are good but management is not allowing all the time just because to become negative to you.
cons: High level of pressure. Very low wages. Non appreciation of work. They do not even care you got married or have a kid. They put a lot of pressure on you. They sent morally harmful e-mails immediately after your return to job from holiday. INTEL Swindon is so bad to work.

pros: Most co-workers are honest hard-working people that just want to make Intel great again.  Unfortunately that is impossible based on the very hostile internal environment and the executive mandate to fire 11% of the workforce (currently underway).
cons: Hostile work environment; lacks teamwork & real innovation and too short-sighted.  The company is fighting to survive but the leaders we have now are politicians that are accustomed to easy times and 65% gross margins.  The leaders do not have the strategy, intelligence or business acumen to revive Intel.  I expect the company to be cut to the bone < 70,000 employees, stripped into parts and sold.

pros: Intel is a great place to work at if you like to be challenged and awarded for your accomplishments.   Management is understanding and flexible.
cons: Not enough focus on improving inter departmental communications.    This would greatly improve meeting the project deadlines and success of Intel in general.

review_title: One of the best companies for which I have worked
pros: Extensive benefit package, fantastic opportunities.    The work is very interesting and in many cases cutting edge.  Take advantage of all the learning opportunities you can.
cons: A company this big has so many pieces, sometimes the smaller parts get lost or ignored.

review_title: Great place to work if you have right manager
pros: All Pro's of a top tier company. Good work life balance.
cons: Intel is a big company with great policies and principles. However it is dependent on the manager who you report to since Intel hands lot of power in a manager's hand.  if you don't get carried  away with what is on the card( intel values ) you should be fine.

review_title: The best decision I ever made
pros:
Where do I start? Managers care about the employees. the teamwork is very clear. With the organization not as tiered, it is easy to approach managers at multiple levels. Those within your BU seem to know the employees fairly well.
- WFH is an awesome benefit.
- Vacation time is nice
cons: Where I will agree is the fact that salaries are a little lower compared to the rest of the industry.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Incredibly smart and talented co-workers
Great work-life balance most of the time (there are always exceptions)
Consistent and fair compensation
Great benefits
cons:
Incredibly difficult to navigate
Very silo'd organizations that make it hard to break through for collaboration
Process, process, process --almost to a fault; sometimes you just want to get things done!

pros: I enjoyed working at Intel, working as part of a team in hardware validation. It has its challenges, but has been a good place to work. I miss working with my team.
cons: Better direction from upper management and better support for moving forward on that direction. The mobile world has passed us by which I find regrettable.

review_title: It was a great experience, they have a very good benefits programs for all the employees including interns.
pros: Becouse your are going to work with the teams that are building the ultimated innovations in Technologies.
cons: The company is now going through a huge organizational transformation and that can bring to the employees a feeling of uncertanty about their on job possitions.

job_title: Senior Finance Specialist in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Flexibility to work from home when needed
- Work life balance
- Benefits are great
cons:
- Process heavy
- New CFO looking to improve EPS through all means necessary
- Slow paced, decisions are dragged on or never made
- Bureaucracy
- No upward mobility at the analyst level
- Evaluation process is political at best

pros: Challenging work, ability to integrate and touch a lot of people. using state of the art facilities and good benefits. A lot of career opportunities and willing to preserve employees
cons: Very bad training. takes a long time to get in. as big as it is it is very clumsy to work in. obsolete software and databases in a lot of ways.

job_title: Job Pre-Si Valid/Verif Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: Tech job in the suburbs. Folsom is a great town near so much, and Intel, for all its faults, is not a bad place to work overall.
cons: There's thrash, especially at the project and upper management level, but day-to-day is usually down to earth and interaction with other employees and managers is either good, or you can find a place where it is (easy to transfer)

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: You can learn a lot in a wide variety of areas and be exposed to cutting edge technology. Anyone who likes playing with the latest technology would have a blast in the labs there.
cons: Middle management seems clueless and unable to properly plan or lead. There are a lot of employees who were hired in a rush before a hiring freeze and are not suitable for the job, but it's impossible to let them go now.

pros: good place to start a career. talent colleagues will help you grow. complicated system let you know how a big company like Intel workds.
cons: bad place to continue your career. Not much room for promotion. some managers are really stunk. staying there for long time doesn't mean you are that smart.

review_title: It's a great place to work, with lots of opportunity to grow your career and try new things.
pros: Corporate culture is very direct and the compensation, benefits and retirement package is solid.  Taking on different roles and growing your career is encouraged, so there's little chance of getting bored.  Work life balance is encouraged, and programs exist to assist employees in this area.
cons: The work culture is intense, which can result in working long hours and having work life balance fall out of kilter.

review_title: Nice place to work, but wish I had a more interesting job.
pros:
Rotation programs.
Good benefits and perks.
Most policies and processes make sense, unlike at other large companies.
Management is fairly open with information.
cons:
Middle management doesn't do a good job.
Excessive amounts of workplace politics - lot of business is conducted through "hallway conversations".

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: The job was a very good place to learn about manufacturing, however the environment was not very  flexible with regards to your personal life
cons: Terrible work life balance.  I often worked all weekend and typically throughout the night.  Intel may be better outside of a manufacturing environment

pros: Compressed work week, competitive pay, good benefits, good management, friendly coworkers, lots of advancement opportunities and fast paced work. MT's get great work / life ratio but the same can't be said for engineers, but that's why they make the $$$
cons: you won't last long if you can't multitask. Can be stressful if you let stressed out engineers get to you.

review_title: My internship was immensely helpful at enhancing my technical skill-set and thereby expanding my repertoire.
pros: As an intern you will get a chance to work with good projects and also see what may interest you. In addition to a good pay package, internships are mainly converted to full-times.
cons: It is too big a company so it is easy to get lost and hence it is important to keep focus and try to secure a chance to work for projects that interest you.

review_title: A great place to start your career, but pick your manager well!
pros:
Being a large company spanning across continents, there is a large pool of resources to improve your skills and networking. 
Intel-ers work hard and play hard too.
cons:
Constantly high stress level (at least in my department). 
Lack of cooperation amongst departments force you into a particular field with few chances to learn outside of your area.

pros: stability is one of the good things at Intel, good salary in addition to having good place to work, Intel is world leader at semi-conductor that I'm glad to work at
cons: the main things disturbing at Intel is lack of vision and not doing pure competitive analysis and not listen to what the user needs so its stuck with the x86 architecture while other companies are  growing much

review_title: A great place to start your career, but pick your manager well!
pros:
Being a large company spanning across continents, there is a large pool of resources to improve your skills and networking. 
Intel-ers work hard and play hard too.
cons:
Constantly high stress level (at least in my department). 
Lack of cooperation amongst departments force you into a particular field with few chances to learn outside of your area.

pros: stability is one of the good things at Intel, good salary in addition to having good place to work, Intel is world leader at semi-conductor that I'm glad to work at
cons: the main things disturbing at Intel is lack of vision and not doing pure competitive analysis and not listen to what the user needs so its stuck with the x86 architecture while other companies are  growing much

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Munich, Bavaria
pros: Depends on position, there are lot of interesting jobs. Mostly fast processes, nice working atmosphere, competent people (on the technical level). Huge amounts of learning material for the interested engineer.
cons: Too much management overhead. Endless discussions where everybody feels important. Office politics and fights between managers,

review_title: Good place to start your career
pros: The salary is extremely competitive for new hires, and is a great starting point. The benefits are great and there is lots of room to learn for those who are motivated.
cons: not a lot of room for growth as a technician. Not informed of the big picture and very repetitive work. Easy to get stagnant in the job role.

review_title: Happy to have a job, but unhappy at my job.
job_title: Mask Manufacturing Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Its the number one company for processors. Intel is a stable company and layoffs rarely happen. The main departments in the company are very professional and good career growth.
cons: The career growth in certain departments is non-existent and its not about the most qualified candidate, but about who they know or who likes them. Its shocking that some departments in Intel run like this.

pros:
-Work Life Balance
-Managers stands for their employees. At least my manager did.
-You get to learn a lot from intelligent peers. Interaction between teams is inevitable and is a great learning experience
cons:
- Engineers are often made to juggle between tasks
-Communication from the top level management does not reach everyone and if it reaches, it's always late

review_title: Time will tell...Intel is in the fight of its life
pros:
Great People who are responsible and get things done.
Great resources.
Great benefits - Sabbatical is amazing.
Intel treats it's employees well
cons: Too many old-timers who aren't willing to explore new possibilities.  No fire in the belly of senior management.  Too reactive.  Too many meetings.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: It was great to work with incredibly intelligent and talented people.  It is a large company so you have the ability to change jobs internally and continue to grow professionally. The benefits package is great, including an 8 week sabbatical every 7 years (US).
cons: It can be a very intense and demanding environment.  Intel will take out of you as much as you are willing to give. This can lead to burn out if you don't manage your personal boundaries.

review_title: Current employee, Worked as a student two years, Full time for one almost one year.
pros:
As a student I got a chance to work on lot of cool stuff.
my manager always understood my needs as a students, For example I could take a vacation for one month when I had university exams.
As a full time employee I get a chance to do stuff that affect millions of people.
cons: It`s a huge company so sometime it`s really difficult to find the person that can answer your question.

review_title: Has to be one of the best large technology companies to work for
pros: world class company with world class employees, great work-life balance, strategically significant, solid and consistent experience throughout my career, excellent core values, ability to interface with counterparts in other countries and work with customers all over the globe, informed risk-taking is encouraged
cons: Sheer size can be an issue for newcomers, need to network a lot to become successful, would like to see more US work sites beyond those concentrated on the west coast

pros: Lots of great teammates and stimulating intellectual environment. On site fitness facilities and nursing/healthcare consulting available. Sabbatical is a great perk.
cons: Work/life balance can become a bad joke. Conditions very dependent on management. One of my best jobs and one of the very worst. Training in tribal knowledge insufficient resulting in failure.

job_title: Software Development Manager in Chandler, AZ
pros: There were lots of opportunities.  I moved up to middle management and was able to make a lot of decisions.  We were not micro managed.  Being able to make and drive decisions made if feel like I had an opportunity to help the company move forward
cons: Over the years I was there the company grew.  It did dilute a bit but the core values were still there.

review_title: Great company to start a professional career with many growth opportunities, nice working environment and benefits
job_title: Product Engineer in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
You can manage your time since is a goal oriented company
Many growth opportunities in both management or technical areas 
Many other benefits like food subsidies, travels, trainings
cons: Is a very specialized company, so many of the knowledge acquired can't be used in other companies. This apply specially to technical positions like engineers.

pros: Amazing Opportunities to grow and learn. Extremely streamlines processes set up in the company
cons: Middle management tends to form groups, leading to office politics and gossip...and wrong/one side information about employees reach the decision making authority, which stagnates growth when there is no Manager FOR the subordinate, but the Manager behaves like he has to bear with a bad hire.

pros: it's one of the best companies in the world, one of the biggest , and working there gives you a chance to know more about modern technologies and the chance to meet brilliant people ad develop youself.
cons: the company is big enough to make you feel lost in it, you will feel that your value is not really estimated,

review_title: Keep moving from job to job or be targeted
pros:
Good benefits
Good environment working with peers
Good culture
Good Work life balance
cons:
- Very competitive
- You get targeted as stagnant if you stay in a pay grade for too long (even if you enjoy your job and achieve successful reviews every year)
- Some jobs provide no future growth 
- They constantly bring in college grads even when they are laying off
* stagnant means they will target you for voluntary separation when they have a lay-off

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: This company takes care of its employees like none other. Job training was top of the line. You did not have a supervisor, you had a facilitator .Former employees of Intel of Guadalajara consider themselves as one big family. We had such fun doing our jobs making for excellent quality products. Everyone had a sense of pride and responsibility that was greatly compensated with gifts to include extra cash bonuses. Great, great company.
cons: Growing in such big company is always a challenge.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Smart,  collaborative, hard-working people who want to produce the best work possible.
cons: Despite great talent and opportunities, the overall culture is oddly frustrating and at times toxic, partially attributable to an Emperors New Clothes approach to managing up.

pros: You get paid, free parking, free tea and coffee
cons: Blame culture, training is a joke, shifts are crippling if you have a life dont even apply. You own your own trianing, a cop out for 'we aint getting involved so dont blame us'. Dog eat dog atmosphere, people blame everybody else, apart from themselves, 75% of intake promptly leave, pay is mediocre for the time you spend there. If you are married 'good luck', you might see each other some time. You work either a Saturday or a Sunday every week. Dont think of the gym or dentist on site to use, you wont have the time to go. They are constantly recruiting - why?????

pros:
Relatively better work culture will flexibility in working hours.
Scope to contribute in lot of areas.
Innovations & Ideas are welcome.
Largely very minimal micro management.
cons:
.In some divisions its almost more than 300 days working (wfh over holidays n weekends) specially if team size is small. Difficult to plan vacation.
.No remunerations for working on weekends/holidays. Comp off is solely on Manager n in most cases it will be difficult to avail.
.Compensation could be slightly better.

review_title: Great run, but is the writing on the wall?
pros: Great health benefits, intelligent and engaged workforce.  Dedicated to a diverse work place.  Awesome having on site medical facilities.  Work life balance is stressed, but can be job/group specific in practice.
cons: Executive turnover and misguided leadership continues to be late entrant into emerging markets.  Metric driven culture seems to not recognize company capabilities

pros: Great Benefits - good place to learn a lot of technical acumen.
cons:
Re-orgs creating alot of instability, and paranoia about job security- and impact too much on commissionable targets.

Annual appraisals - "Focals" - You can have the best year of your life- but it doesnt always get recognize for political reason.

review_title: Great place to grow; may or may not be a home
pros: Good pay, great peers. Projects and pace can be fantastic challenges.
cons: Entrenched engineering mindset equals engineering biases and blindspots. Be selective regarding group or manager--they are your lifeline to the company.

job_title: Computer Systems Analyst/IT Consultant in Folsom, CA
pros: There are some great IT managers who allow their employees freedom to perform to their abilities.
cons: Some in management still hold to the darker side of culture and over-promise for every single project, so work/life balance can be hard to maintain. Sometimes upper management doesn't hold lower management responsible for the bad performance of a few, and then all employees get penalized (such as in telecommuting policies). Except for some of these kinds of issues, the rest of the culture is pretty great.

pros: Quick response and help from hiring manager, interview was moderate but they touched almost all the topics on my resume, this team was really on their toes when it came to setting up telephonic interview, feedback, on-site interview was setup after telephonic interview and scheduled within a week, prompt replies from team lead and hiring manager, really amazing and helpful team.
cons: Frequent reorganizational work within Intel which causes delay in hiring process and sometimes even offers get rescinded due to that.

pros: Compressed work week. Learn something new every day. Intel invests heavily in their employees with training/educating. Safety culture. Strong leadership. Recognition system. Stock purchase program. Bonuses have been great. Good benefits.
cons: Huge organizations. Sometimes it feels like your contributions go unnoticed or unappreciated. Focal system tends to feel like you're competing for crumbs.

review_title: A pretty good place to work
job_title: Quality and Reliability Engineer in Portland, OR
pros:
Challenging work that teaches you a lot about dealing with people
Opportunities to take on a lot of different projects
cons:
Pay not as good as other tech companies
The work is not at technical as you would think (especially, coming of out grad school)
Experience you have can vary a lot based on the group

job_title: Software Development Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
- Fast Paced Development
- Freedom over how you develop and what to develop
- Flexible time off and Work from Home
- Small close circle team working over many different technologies
* Reviews are specific to the team I was working on. Other teams may vary
cons:
- Unspecified agenda and responsibilities makes everything hazy. 
- Development is sometimes not completed, rather than focusing on solid development, its mostly focused on "just works" type completion
- Wrong Scrumming and so called agile process, demos and weekend/night work makes it difficult

review_title: Overall, it's a good company to work for.
pros: Great Benefits, Competitive Pay, Bonuses, Great Diversity,
cons: the culture varies widely from site to site. Some are more inclusive and caring while others are not. Intel lacks the ability to forecast the present/coming business headcont needs accurately and as a result frequently hires and lays off (redeploys) employees.

review_title: An old company gradually dying of mediocre management
pros: Name recognition.  Every decision has impact across the industry.  Good line on your resume.
cons: The external image does not match the internal reality.  Intel is an old company slowly dying of the cronyism, patronage, mediocre abilities of those who were promoted during the too-rapid growth of the 90's.

pros: Job security in Oregon is GREAT!!! The pay is good and the work is easy. The breaks are very generous and you get a sabbatical every 7 years
cons: Management and training is very very poor and it takes a LONG time to get a promo, often they are awarded on networking rather than merit

review_title: Good place to work, but not great
pros: Get to work on cutting edge technology. Good compensation and benefits. Some very smart people around whom you can learn a lot from
cons:
Some very incompetent people have managed to work the way up the management
Too big a company, and the company believes in giving you a very small slice of the whole problem

job_title: Compoenent Design Engineer in Folsom, CA
pros: good company to work rigt out of college. Cutting edge CAD tools and advande design challanges. Fairly good learning curve for the first few years.
cons: Lot os politics and favorable treatment for handfull few. After 5+ years in the company the advancement possibilities are limited. More like state/government job, show 9-5 for a pay check.

pros: No micro management. It's result oriented. You will need to show your work during every checkpoint, may it be every week or every month. Work is flexible, no pressure, you manage your time.
cons: Sometimes, collaborative work takes place in different sites meaning in different time zones. So when that happens you may need to work at odd hours.

pros: Great pay.  Looks great on resume.  Worked on interesting product.  Loved the location.  Co-workers were cooperative and fun to work with.
cons: I work in software and Intel is not good (yet) in software engineering.  They do not have good practices in place.  Requirements are vague and untestable.

review_title: My time here has been great.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Hillsboro, OR
pros: You can learn as much as you want and are surrounded by some exceptional individuals.  You can branch out and cross disciplines, it is all up to you.  If you have the right data that backs up your position, high probability of success.
cons: As with a big corporation, it seems that there are too many layers before a decision gets done.  Sometimes frustrating to always need "alignment" with others.

review_title: Hard work with good pay out but worried about eventual balance or burn out
pros: Pay, opportunity, stability, cutting edge, enjoy working with products consumers are interested in, Good people, compensation, benefits,  upper management seems to care about employees.
cons: Commute can be horrible. I have a long term concern for work live balance. Can be a highly competitive work environment,

review_title: a great place to develop but too much bureaucracy
pros:
wide range of expertise to choose from 
think of what you want to do  - then just start doing it. when the time comes, the title will simply be handed over to you. 
challenging work, but lots of tools around to help you do your job 
helpful colleagues
sane working hours
cons: tons of meetings, documents, forms to fill, standard procedures, presentations. way too much bureaucracy overhead.

pros: Pay, benefits and growth in expertise (to a certain point).
cons: The first 5 years the growth in technical knowledge is fast if you own your own training and push back on barriers.  Getting off of nights or moving into Engineering without a degree is next to impossible.

review_title: From Design Engineer to Strat Planner
pros: Intel is so large that it provides the opportunity to grow your career and try new things without changing companies.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy.  Decisions take forever and there is no clear path to the decision makers.  Silos within the company prevent great innovation

review_title: stuck in the past, byzantine bureacracy
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: often interesting work when dealing with the latest technology. There is more than enough resources to afford any required tools.
cons:
archaic bureaucracy, idiotic rating process called 'focals' that undermine any sense of team. management offers self justifying platitudes rather than taking any real action.
company seems in constant churn
groups are swapped around like checkers

review_title: Judge yourself - I term the experience sweet and unsettling both
pros:
1. Competitive salary
2. Bi quarterly Bonus sharing
3. > average increments wrt market
4. Continuous tracking of objectives -- with managers
5. Campus services (food/bus/juice)
6. Flexible timings (including WFH)
7. work-life effectiveness
cons:
1. No sabbatical
2. Increments are not too high considering its a big firm
3. Flexible times sometimes may mean you have to work from home ;)
4. Aggressive update management in the hierarchy
5. AC is shut off after 6pm

review_title: Learned more than I ever thought possible.  And stretched myself to my own limits, and beyond.  It was fantastic."
pros: "Own your own Career" is the motto.  It's true.  You do it, and they set the table for you to do just that.
cons: The execs have been there FAR too long.  The rotation of the industry means the leadership rotation needs to happen as well.  Rotation OUT.

pros: Summary: Intel Labs offers the flexible working schedule, competitive salaries and mostly interesting projects. And hence, Intel Labs' employees are very qualified engineers and researchers. The Intel Labs community supports any experience exchange and learning development.
cons: Unfortunately, the recent actions of management are likely to be out of Intel values scope. I really dislike my current project. Fails in management ruins by work/life balance. Also my current project roles are in opposite of my expectations.

pros: With the right manager or mentor,  it's possible to enjoy a challenging and growth oriented career in various business groups. Sabbatical every 7 years. Intelligent and driven coworkers.
cons: Difficult to leave "work" at the office at the end of a work day. There is no such thing as a 40 hour work week ... more like 60 hrs as standard.

review_title: Intel - A truly great place to work
pros: Intel India had some seriously dedicated engineers under its employment. Some folks are really knowledgeable in their fields. Its a great place to start off once career in Hardware.
cons: In Intel India the teams are not very supportive towards innovation although the management does support it. This creates a conflict for guys who like working and thinking out of the box.

pros: Intel is a very comfortable workplace, it is kept in order, and has clear guidelines. no shortcuts or bending of the conduct rules. you know what is expected of you. other benefits such as health plan, ex-studies, bonuses.
cons: Little consideration of work life balance, not formally expect you to have full availability to work at all times of day and week.

review_title: Not such a Great Place to Work
pros:
- working with advanced process
- Good colleagues
- Stable with job security.
cons:
- Very low compensation. 
- very slow advancement both professionally and salary wise
- unprofessional management decisions, bad process of decision making.
- too much emphasis on redundant bureaucracy, interfere with innovation and actual work trueput.
- works with "private" methodologies and design tools(intel made), irrelevant experience for future career outside of Intel

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Overall Intel is a great company with a long history of having created technology that changed the world.  They are continuing that tradition today in a variety of different areas.
cons: Intel is a very large company and it is sometimes easy to get lost in all the structure.  While this is common at any large company it is especially true at Intel

pros: Reasonable about remote work in many divisions.  Great benefits.  Company giving a lot of lip service to diversity - some may actually resonate for positive change.  Co-workers generally easy to work with
cons: Constantly downsizing means constant pressure to defend your and your group's reason for existence.  Male dominated - look at the executive ranks for proof.

review_title: Great Place to work... if you are under 40.
pros: Good Salary and benefits.  Smart people working there.  Opportunity to grow your career without having to change companies.
cons: In the middle of a transition away from PC business.  Many loyal employees with 10+ years of experience are being pushed out of the company to make way for more diverse and lower paid workers under the guise of corporate restructuring.

job_title: Process Technology Development Engineer in Portland, OR
pros: Good salary for the area, reasonable PTO, good health insurance coverage
cons: Breakneck pace, lack of manpower, churn rate less than 2 years (Average most senior engineer in most groups has been at the job for 2 years, besides managers), overloads PhD's with low level operational tasks. Resistance to hiring automation/programmer specialists in some groups. Precious time wasted in constant meetings. Bad work-life balance

pros: Good technical expertise. Good learning opportunities about processor and hardware level details. Some absolutely brilliant engineers work here, and it has good opportunities for mentorship.
cons: Shrinking market share, traditional management, the work environment can get stilting and boring over time. Not a lot of appetite for risk taking in the folks working here in general.

review_title: Great company, but a large ship takes great effort to steer
pros:
Talented work force, great environment, amenities commensurate with a large corporate atmosphere.
Technically-minded peers, open door policy, teamwork frame of mind for the most part.
cons:
Competitive environment can be a put-off for some.
Individual contributors who are dependable and produce good quality work are seen as less valuable than shooting stars that climb the corporate ladder.

job_title: Software Engineer Intern in Shanghai, Shanghai
pros: 9:00 to 5:00 , no work at weekend, good facility, people are very nice, free fruit, nice dinning hall an d bus.
cons: there are not so many activities, not easy to get the return offer, the tax is high, and do not have living bonus and other bonus.

job_title: Technical Program Manager in Folsom, CA
pros: Good benefits,okay pay. Get to work with a very diverse team and learn from others. Ability to change roles and try new things.
cons: Long hours for the pay. Different groups have different dynamics so you cannot judge the company by 1 group that is flux.

pros: Really smart employees.  Employees are empowered to make decisions.  Global company.  Arguably the best hardware company on the planet.
cons: Hardware company.  Software is used to help sell hardware products - not necessarily a bad thing, but if you are a software person you have to be ok with being a hardware enabler.

pros:
Good teamwork among peers
Good career opportunity
Good employee benefit/ discounts
Good GPTW from time to time
cons:
Tedious, sometime boring job scope
Expectation never aligned between top to bottom, what is above expectation means anyway?
Ineffective meetings
Uncertain future/ Unclear direction from the management?
Focal sometime not robust for evaluation on employee innovation but their job scope required them to stay stable and consistent (ex product performance), typical local maxima problem.

review_title: I don't have words a single word to say
pros: Joining Intel is everyone's dream. but dreams are not true or last only for short duration.
cons: Intel is having the policy of regular reorg. Managers in Intel hire the new employee so that he can be sacrificed next. By this way, manager saves his own job and showing the company that he is good with the reduced headcount.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company is making the right bets and is generally moving in a good direction.  Pay and benefits are awesome.
cons: A lot of the day to day people management is really poor.   Management doesn't really get improved even though they continually talk about improving it.  If you find a good manager, it mitigates the issues quite a bit.
